especially in this afternoon's debate - that the man who has the main responsibility for war, outrages, murders and the expulsion of their homes of innocent people, still governs in Serbia, the rest of Yugoslavia.The man who is accused of genocide and who should be tried in the Hague Court is still free.I'm talking about Milosevic.While Milosevic continues to rule Serbia and it does not choose a democratic path, that country will continue to be a constant threat to peace throughout the Balkan region and, also, in Macedonia.Mr. President, the agreement promoted will constitute the first application of the Stability Pact in Southeast Europe.Undoubtedly, its terms, accepted by the Swoboda report, do not pursue peace, but a greater political and economic subordination in the country, the control of its natural wealth, the overexploitation of its workforce, and an even greater use of the country as a basis for attack against the countries and peoples of the region that resist the new order.And all this in exchange for the promise of a future adhesion to the European Union.The report accepts both this orientation and, more in general, the whole policy of the European Union for Southeast Europe.

In the new agreement, both sides commit a responsible state leadership that is considered a fundamental and positive element of the partnership, and a regular dialogue will take place in an area that the community actively promotes.Second, a new procedure was created to treat violations of human rights, democratic principles and the rule of law.Compared to the current approach, the responsibility of the state in question is given a stronger weighting in the new procedure, and the consultation process is more flexible in order to be able to lead an effective dialogue about the measures to improve the situation.In particularly urgent cases in which there is a serious violation of one of these essential elements, measures are immediately initiated, about which the other party is informed.Third, the EU and the AKP have agreed on a new, special procedure for serious corruption cases.This is a real innovation, both in the context of the EU/AKP agreements and generally in international relationships.This procedure is not only used in corruption cases that deal with EEF money, but also in a further framework in all countries in which the EU provides financial support, and in which corruption hinders development.The procedure is therefore not limited to EU activities.This is an extremely important aspect in which the funding of public finances is taken into account.By accepting such a provision in the partnership agreement, the EU and the AKP countries jointly set a clear and positive signal, which will certainly be recognized by the European taxpayers and hopefully also by European investors.Another new area in the agreement between the AKP countries and the EU is immigration.We have concluded a balanced agreement on cooperation in this area.This new dimension of the partnership agreement reflects the guidelines for which the EU advocates the contract of Amsterdam and the conclusions of the European Council in Finnish Tampere in October 1999.The European Union undertakes to develop and implement an immigration and asylum policy based on the principle of partnership with the countries of origin and regions.The agreement concluded with the AKP countries prepares the way for new initiatives, especially with regard to the rights of nationals of third countries within the EU, and for measures to facilitate integration.We have agreed on regulations related to illegal immigration.The EU and the AKP countries will be determined within a framework that is to be negotiated with each individual AKP state, the possibilities and instruments for the return of illegal immigrants to the relevant countries.This also includes people from third countries and stateless people.With these extremely innovative approaches, the manner of the government can be improved.The agreement also creates a good framework for stabilizing the mutual reinforcing effects of trade cooperation and development aid.We have agreed to include negotiations on new trade agreements to liberalize trade between the parties and to develop regulations on the regulation of trade issues.With regard to the temporal framework for the trade negotiations, we have taken into account the wishes of the AKP countries.Negotiations are started in 2002 at the latest.This two-year preparation phase is to be used to strengthen the regional integration processes and the ability of the AKP countries to manage trade negotiations.

Stenzel Report (A5-0034/2000) Mr. President, I would like to make a very short declaration of vote on behalf of the group of the European People's Party on the Equal report.We followed a voting procedure exactly corresponding to the agreements previously taken with the socialist group.The socialist group, however, has changed the relationship, making it less clear than it could have been.This fact led us to abstain from the vote.We want the report on the Equal initiative to be approved, also because it is very important both for refugees and the elderly, and for the disabled and women.It is a pity that, due to the procedure followed, very little attention has been paid to the report in this plenary session.I am convinced that the nationality of the rapporteur has had its influence - a type of influence completely out of place in this assembly, since it is in contrast with the European values ​​and certainly with the parliamentary values ​​to which our Parliament recalls so often.These are the considerations that have prompted us to refrain from the vote on the relationship.We want the Equal initiative to go on;We share the great part of this, but we deplore the procedure that has been followed as well as the unworthy way in which it was exploited by some groups of Parliament.Mr. President, also as representative of the Pensioners Party to the European Parliament, I refrained on the vote regarding the Equal initiative because, while introducing to a greater extent than the past the support for projects aimed at fighting discrimination based on age, it was not quite incisive and concrete in this direction.I also abstained for another reason: I believe that the time has come for the institutions of the European Union to cease the experimentation and the search for good practices regarding what we have to do and begin to give concrete indications to European citizens on what Europe wants Europe.We must take concrete measures and go from theory to practice..We voted in favor of the Commission's communication report that establishes the guidelines relating to Community initiative programs (PIC).We are basically contrary to this type of programs and structural funds, but since the vote concerns only the how - and not the measure in which - these resources must be used, we followed this.We believe that the guarantee of equal opportunities for the groups mentioned in the report is important.We did not vote against the relationship as we believe that some right general principles, such as the need to combat racism in the workplace and reduce the inequalities based on sex on the labor market.However, we have not voted even in favor because these intentions remain very vague, if not even at the unrealistic level.In the chapter relating to the help and training projects in favor of refugees, the report instead takes a step back compared to the initial text, since it takes care to clarify that refugees are no longer interested as such, but the "refugees only in accordance with the Geneva Convention".Such restriction is inadmissible at a time when in all of Europe numerous refugees are found in a dramatic situation, without protection, forced to work in clandestinity and to hide, while the governments and the police forces of states that are said to be democratic give them hunting.

It simply authorizes the commission to do so if it wishes.As has already been said, the council decision proposal is divided into two parts.The first concerns the financing of Member States to apply community programs.The second part is to authorize the Commission itself to finance studies and pilot projects.There are a few minor amendments: Amendment 2 aims to guarantee that the financial contribution in favor of the Member States can cover not only the data collection costs but also the costs of management, compilation, aggregation, etc.Amendments 3 and 6 are intended to soften the calendar since the Member States will have to wait for the implementation of the application regulations to find out what programs really involve; they also aim to align the calendar with dates and regulations.Amendments 4 and 5 aim to ensure that financial information is regularly transmitted to the budgetary authorities.More significantly, the Fisheries Commission, within the framework of amendment 1, accepts the recommendation of the budget commission according to which the financing should be entered in post 1 (b) rather than at post 3 of the financial prospects.Although in its preliminary draft budget, the Commission has registered credits in post 3 "internal policies", the Parliament has created a new B1-500 budget line to finance the measures during discussion.This provides security, to ensure that the necessary resources continue to be available.Mr. President, I think we all have to agree with the assertion of Ms. Attwooll at the start of her excellent report according to which these two proposals from the Commission, aimed at better understanding the scientific and socio-economic situation in the fishing sector, arrive at a critical moment.The exhaustive collection of the data that is proposed and their appropriate processing will be essential elements to discuss with more rigor the revision of the common fishing policy.This - obviously - if the data is ultimately obtained.Because, as our rapporteur also rightly points out, the Commission's proposal has no compulsory nature for the Member States.The sending or not of the data is completely voluntary, and their non -presentation would only mean the loss of a certain economic compensation, which, moreover, is not very high either.Given our experience in terms of data presentation in the fishing sector - and I get back to reports on the implementation of pop - I think that instead of having a complete table of the situation in this sector, we will end up with a confused panorama, in which Member States will provide, for example, scientific data, but not those relating to employment, while others will communicate those on employment, but not to -get them and transmit them.And, of course, I am afraid that some prefer to give up financing, if it allows them to continue to hide their mismanagement, to which we have already attended in cases where the sending of said data was compulsory, as in the case of pop.

Regarding the calendar and objectives, the Council provides that the objective of achieving a good state of surface waters be carried out no later than 16 years after the entry into force of the Directive, the Environmental, Public Health and Consumer Protection Commission wishes that this period is reduced to 10 years.The Commission also asks for any discharge or loss of hazardous substances by 2020. The final objective must consist of reaching close values ​​of zero by 2020. The Council hopes to reach a good state of groundwater after a period of 16 years, but the commission intends to put an end to the deterioration of the qualitative chemical state of groundwater to reach the level of good state of groundwater within 10 years.All standards and all objectives related to protected areas must be carried out before 10 years and not within 16 years.I must say that I am in favor of these reductions in deadlines, with greater reason when repealed ones have been foreseen.Regarding the costs, I approve the proposal that here to 2010, Member States will have to ensure that water pricing policies encourage a more reasonable use of water resources.In the same sense, I hope that the European Commission will make a clear statement with which it undertakes to present a proposal to ensure that the prices of water use reflect environmental costs and costs in terms of resources for 2012. I will end up citing one of the amendments of the Environmental, Public Health and Consumer Protection Commission that does not need any comments: "Water is not a commercial good like the others, but a heritage that belongs to the people.European and to protect, defend and treat as such. ".(En) I want to officially record my concern about the Lienemann report and also the reasons for my vote.We have all agreed on the need to establish adequate controls for the protection of our water supply and also for water users.Much of what the rapporteur says about the water problem is worthy of praise.However, the issue of rights or taxes for water use is an issue that, by virtue of subsidiarity norms, are the member states that have to decide.In my opinion it is not appropriate to use a medium as rough as the imposition of a common European burden on this issue.In Ireland all the main water users, who are trade, industry and agriculture, already pay water use.This is a decision of the national and local government, and at that level it is where all future decisions must be being.Those are the main reasons for my vote..(En) The European Union is currently in the process of adopting a new water legislation in the European Union with a view to updating and establishing a long -term strategy to achieve a clean drinking water supply and the protection of current water resources, rivers and coastal waters included.I support the objectives of this community action in the field of water policy, but I do not support the proposal that domestic waters have to pay rights for the water used.

As I had the opportunity to say, the Commission is aware of its share of responsibility.In this context, it brings a final touch to a first draft proposal for an evaluation panel, a scoreboard, so that all the institutions and the other parties concerned can evaluate the progress made in the implementation of the necessary measures and in compliance with the deadlines set by the Amsterdam Treaty, the Vienna Action Plan and the conclusions of the Tampere European Council.This evaluation panel will not be a simple legislative programming instrument, but also and above all an instrument for strengthening transparency and responsibility for all European institutions to citizens.Because it is for citizens that we set up the space of freedom, security and justice.The progress recorded will be due not to the Commission, the Council or even to the European Parliament, but rather to the Association of European institutions and to the Member States themselves, insofar as, as has been said here, determined tasks of the scoreboard will be entrusted to the Member States under the principle of subsidiarity.In the coming weeks, I will carry out a tour of the capitals in order to probe the opinion of the Ministers of Justice and Interior Affairs.I intend to debate this scoreboard project with the European Parliament and civil society.We intend to present the final version to the "Justice and Internal Affairs" council, under the Portuguese presidency, after the consultations that I have just mentioned.My intention is to make this scoreboard a political and strategic orientation instrument for all institutions, but also an examination of examination on the part of public opinion.I therefore recognize - and this is a challenge to which we are all faced with - the need to develop a communication strategy that allows the general public to perceive what is the effective added value of the Union in everyday life, in these areas so essential to citizenship, respect for legality and, basically, of democracy itself.Beyond the scoreboard, I would like to say that the Commission intends to present the following initiatives, during the year 2000, and I would like to emphasize here that I welcome that the Portuguese presidency considers the development of this space as one of the priorities of its work program.I hope it will be possible, with the Portuguese presidency, to work clearly in a spirit of interinstitutional cooperation, which also constitutes the political message of Tampere, and that this spirit of interinstitutional cooperation will be followed by the subsequent presidencies.With regard to immigration and the right of asylum, the Commission intends to present proposals for the development of a community instrument on the temporary protection of refugees;Start the analysis of the criteria and conditions for improving the implementation of the Dublin Convention and the possible amendment of its legal basis, in accordance with the Amsterdam Treaty;Continue the debate from the communication already carried out on the rules leading to a process of asylum common to the whole Union;And present proposals for the development of legislation providing for the granting of residence permits for victims of the trafficking in human beings who cooperate with justice against trafficking networks.

to vote- Lienemann report (A5-0014/2000) I salute the quality and the ambition of this report relating to Life.I will briefly remind you that Life is a financial instrument at the service of environmental policies within the European Union as in third countries, that it acts from neighboring Mediterranean countries, the Baltic Sea countries or countries candidates for membership.The We have submitted a communication on joint asylum procedures and a decision -making recommendation authorizing the Commission to negotiate with Iceland and Norway an agreement intended to extend to these two countries the rules applied to the Member States of the European Union under the Dublin Convention.The Commission actively contributed to the work of the high -level group on immigration and the right of asylum.Finally, in December, the Commission presented a proposal for the creation of the European Refugees Fund.In the field of judicial cooperation, the Commission presented proposals for settlement with a view to the communitarization of certain agreements: one on judicial cooperation and the execution of decisions in civil and commercial matters, (Brussels I);Another relating to the competence, recognition and execution of decisions in matrimonial matters (Brussels II) and yet another concerning the summons and notification of judicial and extrajudicial acts in civil and commercial matters.We presented, still in 1999, a communication on the victims of crime in the Union, by starting a reflection born of Tampere and by demanding the development of minimum standards on the protection of victims of crime, especially on their access to justice and their rights to the compensation for the prejudices suffered, including legal costs.I will also mention the presentation of the decision -making project on the fight against fraud and falsification of means of payment other than species.In the field of the Union's legislative framework, with regard to the fight against financial crime, the Commission presented a project to revise the money laundering directive.In 1999, we attended the entry into office of Europol.After what was asserted here by the Portuguese presidency, with the new cycle in the fields of justice and internal affairs, the start of the reflection relating to the implementation of the new skills attributed to Europol by the Treaty of Amsterdam, we sincerely hope that it will be possible to discuss in the same way with the Commission with regard to the question of democratic control and the articulation between Europol and the relevant judicial instances.In 1999, the Commission presented its contribution to a European action plan in the fight against drugs, which is the basis of the strategy adopted by the Helsinki European Council.This list of non -exhaustive actions allows me to reaffirm today before the presidency of the Council and the deputies, with great conviction, that if 1999 was the year of the consolidation of the action of the Union in this fundamental field, it will also have been the beginning of a new phase of acceleration of the creation of a space of freedom, security and justice.The year 2000 will undoubtedly be the year of truth for the European institutions and the way in which they will be able to meet the requirements of citizens in terms of guarantee of freedom of movement, in compliance with rights and the guarantee of security and stability, thanks to adequate judicial protection.This amounts to saying that the year 2000 will be for the Council, the Parliament and the Commission, a test year of the political will to take Amsterdam seriously and to contribute to the foundations of an extended political union for the next decade.

The packaging continues to represent a huge mess in Europe and entail a load for the environment.A sector of the Socialists, headed by Bernd Lange, affirms that yes, that the principle is good, but that we should not introduce it until 2010 or 2012, as reflected in the amendment 45. The common position establishes the year 2006. This is, in the opinion of the Green Group, more than enough time for the automobile industry to prepare for the change.Therefore, I ask my colleagues not to support the amendment 38 of the democraticristians and nor the amendment 45 of a group of socialist deputies.When vehicle manufacturers must run themselves with the costs of recycling vehicles then they will design them so that it is easier and cheaper to reuse them.For example, problematic plastics, the PVC, will disappear from cars and will be replaced by biological plastics manufactured from plants.They will ultimately be cheaper, also for consumers.20 years ago, most of Parliament tried to get the European environment more ecological.Today, this environmental position is in danger, subject to the pressure, above all, of the French and German car industry.Therefore, deputies, let's vote against amendments 38 and 45. As a group of greens, we roughly support the common position.Mr. President, the remains of vehicles at the end of their useful life constitute one of the great environmental problems, both for the amount of spills and scrap and for substances harmful to the environment.For this reason, the GUE/NGL group advocates the implementation of norms, as broad and consistent as possible.This directive allows us to move forward, but provided that Parliament does not destroy or weaken the position of the Council.If they were approved, many of the amendments presented would considerably weaken this directive.I especially refer to the amendments of the PPE group, but, unfortunately, also to some amendments of Mr. Lange, according to my understanding.It is not difficult to imagine that the automobile industry of some countries, for example the German, has worked intensely, through pressure groups, about the approval of this directive.For us, it is decisive that the following points are considered: the one that contaminates, pays.This implies that the producer must assume his responsibility, even in economic terms, for the recycling of vehicles.You also have to have rules for cars that already exist.In this matter, we cannot accept that the position of the Council is weakened on the date of entry into force.The percentages and demands of recycling in certain years should not be worse.It is also important to limit the use of hazardous elements such as lead.We will vote against all amendments that oppose this.It would be very negative, not only from the environmental point of view but also for the credibility of the European Parliament in environmental issues, which the amendments that considerably weaken the directive are approved.

Mr President, Ladies and Members, at the end of this debate, which I have followed with great attention and a lot of interest, I would like to give some considerations that add to what I have had in recent weeks in the presence of President Prodi before you.Your two rapporteurs, the Messrs of Dimitrakopoulos and Linen, recommend that the Parliament be accepted a formal statement in accordance with Article 48 in their very thorough and carefully developed report, so that the government conference can actually start work on February 14, as the Portuguese presidency proposed.On our part, after we have submitted the statement to be drawn up by the Commission on the basis of the Article 48 of the Treaty, we are pleased that this conference can begin - otherwise thought earlier than originally thought.We know that the weeks obtained will be very useful.After reading the design of the statement and after the explanations of the speakers of the individual factions, I would like to add a few comments.First of all, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission has an understanding of the concerns expressed several times about the scope of the agenda of the conference.I understand these fears, these concerns that the agenda is too scarce;And yet I believe that, as I did after the Helsinki summit, you can work for constitutional questions in front of the committee, based on Helsinki's mandate.And in this spirit and within the framework of this mandate, the Commission has developed its own statement, whereby it fully exhausted the mandate and also read between the lines.We have not limited ourselves to what is incorrectly referred to as the three "remnants".Like Richard Corbett, I don't like the expression "remnant", which gives the impression that these are three insignificant or incidental topics.However, there are three extremely serious, important and difficult topics - so difficult that in Amsterdam the common political courage was not sufficient to treat them exhaustively.As for us - here I answer Mr. Seguro, who was concerned beforehand - we did not satisfy ourselves with these three topics, even if I think that they have priority and have to be treated now.They are the first, but not the only topics of which the conference must take on, Mr.We have also dealt with other topics, and we have shown our idea that because of the difficult situation before the expansion, other topics at the conference would have to be addressed - if the Portuguese and then later the French presidency are ready.We are ready - whether it is now the Charter of Fundamental Rights, the elaboration of which has started, the GASP and the effects of negotiations on a defense policy on the institutions or the very difficult topic of revising the contracts where we will continue to work.There were many comments on the commission's statement;All of these topics were addressed and often treated in detail, some based on exact suggestions for new articles.But nobody mentioned that we were outside of Helsinki's mandate.

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen the commissioners, when this assembly is called to reflect on the theme of human rights, it runs a great risk which in a way was also emphasized by the climate in which we are called to debate this theme so important.The absence of the Council and almost all the deputies makes us aware of the abyss which still separates the noble deep and useful declarations on the formal level of the concrete application, in the field of daily policy, of human rights.I think that this Parliament, starting with the contribution that Europe will bring to the meeting of Geneva, must climb this chasm and act, not only in terms of principles, but also on that of truth and even loyalty.Human rights should not be the subject of an interpretation that is only linked to denunciation or punishment.We must, as Parliament, look at the subject of human rights especially in the sense of prevention.We must therefore be able to export a culture of legality, a culture of law, compliance of law.I believe that the long season of accumulation of treaties and signatures of treaties has definitively ended.Today we have many, perhaps too many, treated that intervene in terms of human rights: if these treaties remain only a simple utterance, they will only constitute unnecessary collections of reflection.We must go today to the next phase, that of the daily and coercive application of what is written in our treaties, even if we must not forget that certain fundamental treaties must still be accepted.I am thinking here of the Rome conference and of the fact that fourteen of the Fifteen States of the Union have not yet ratified the Treaty on the International Criminal Tribunal.I think we must verify and modify certain political instruments that serve us to measure the quality of human rights in the world.We have often used instruments which, formally, can be practical but which, on a political level, prove to be completely useless.I am thinking of the use, or even abuse, of embargo in recent years and of the too cautious application of the suspension clause of agreements between the European Union and third countries in case these do not respect human rights.I believe that we are mainly invited to update the horizon of the protection of fundamental rights.Globalization is likely to be interpreted as essentially repressive.In many countries, the principle of human rights are for the moment calls into question;It is believed that these rights and the right to life, denied by the death penalty, are dependent variables, while globalization, often taken in a punitive sense, risks being the only unifying tissue of the rights, actions and policies of all the countries of the world.

Therefore, I think it is necessary to act in two directions.On the one hand, we should ask the Commission to grant special measures as part of the aid sector intended for the fishing sector in order to relieve the effects of this catastrophe on the productive sector of the affected areas, and also ask them to demand strict control of the ships driving under cheap flags.In this regard, the current negotiating process on Malta's joining the European Union must serve to demand from this country that it is rigorously checking the oil tankers driving under its flag.On the other hand, it is necessary to prevent.Portugal is a country that has given its sensitivity to the topics associated with the sea.I would like to ask the Portuguese presidency to examine the possibility of starting a comprehensive strategy for contraception of marine pollution at European level and to concentrate all means - technological, structural and socio -economic nature - from which we already have to prevent a disaster like this in the future.Finally, I would like to highlight the work done by the volunteers and the local authorities, which reminded me of old times when I experienced similar situations at the time.One has to thank them who, given the defenselessness and missing funds, courageous against the serious effects of this catastrophe for the coastal regions, for the ecosystem of the sea and the fishing resources of Europe.Mr President, as chairman of the committee for regional policy, transport and tourism, I would like to congratulate the Commission, especially Commissioner Loyola de Palacio, as to this incident, which was deeply shaken by all of Europe.In the traffic committee, we are ready to debate questions about marine safety and later, of course, about the conclusions that result from the conclusions that arise at the legal level.Allow me a few more remarks: First, the Commission has really focused on what guilt the Italian classification company Rina affects, because it must be checked whether the joint law has been applied.Here we have to start with our efforts.Secondly, in such cases, we should examine whether the charterers, for example the oil companies, are responsible in addition to the shipping companies, since they are complicit on environmental disasters like this and consequently must also pay for the removal of the damage.Apart from that, the reactions to the ecological disaster are justified in every respect.However, this must not tempt us to pillorate the entire merchant shipping, this sector that is so important for the economy, which covers around a third of the transport volume.So we have to react moderately, strict, but also sensibly.I am not at all against the fact that it is considered about the tightening of community law, but we, as other colleagues, must have emphasized from the implementation, because - and we must not forget that - there is already a legal framework at the level of the European Union.This frame is developed enough, at least if you compare the different regulations worldwide.As a result, the Member States, even under the supervision of the Commission, must finally begin to apply community law.

I have the great pleasure of immediately giving in the word to Prime Minister António Guterres.I thank the President in office for the Council, António Guterres, and I immediately pass the word to the president of the Commission, Romano Prodi..Lady president, first of all I would like to make my hottest congratulations to Prime Minister Guterres for the initiative that was taken for the Lisbon summit, and congratulate me for the quality of the preparatory works.We fully share his analysis that we have heard and that has been so highly applauded, and we support his initiative.I think together we can make Lisbon a successful summit.In this intervention of mine I will limit myself to presenting the contribution of the Commission for Lisbon: our long -term strategy and our vision for this summit.In Lisbon we have to decide on something extremely simple, namely if Europe will be able to regain its leadership position, for a long time lost, within the economy and technology.This depends on us, on the economic growth that we will be able to impose on the European system, on the degree of employment that we will be able to create, from the level of education of our citizens, from the formation of our working class.These are not new themes, as has been said by Prime Minister Guterres.We do not do, in fact, another exercise like Luxembourg, like Cardiff, type colony, but we want to deal with these themes, which we have already addressed, with a completely new approach: not one topic at a time but all together, to finally build a system of interventions.We do it now because it is the moment when all this may be successful.In fact, we have a unique opportunity in front of us, an opportunity that has been built on the success of a wise policy implemented in the recent past: we have low inflation, a balance of globally healthy payments, public accounts in order, and we finally have the unanimous forecasts of very strong economic growth, forecast, as the Portuguese Prime Minister pointed out, which do not mean certain of economic growth.Never as now, in the last generation, there has been unanimity by all scholars in Europe on providing for a possible long period of high growth.Not even with the increase in the price of oil there was an interruption in this growth or a recovery of inflation, as could be feared.However, there are some worrying signs, but they do not prevent us from continuing a development policy as we had thought and planned.The challenges of Lisbon are therefore very simple: to the technological challenge we must respond by recovering the lost ground in the field of knowledge, knowledge, technologies, especially of reforming technologies.We can thus return to a head position;For this reason we took the E-European initiative, thanks to which the Commission decided, in its administrative reform, to give a concrete example.We are committed - and it is a commitment that I confirm in front of you - to create a commission, we could better say an e -commission, in the sense that any relationship of supplies, research, etc. with this institution will no longer have to take place by paper but by direct electronic way.

Large public investments have been made at federal, state and local scale.They have been huge and have been investments in the new infrastructure.Be careful, here our direct effort, I repeat, direct at public level and at different levels is to build telematic highways, that is, the roads through these new vehicles circulating.The market, individuals, companies will build vehicles to circulate, but it is we who have the obligation to build the new highways.Therefore, what Prime Minister Mr. Guterres about computers in all schools, about the network that must include all peripheral regions, is not an obligation that can be imposed exclusively to the market, since the market does not do so and, on the other hand, without it we do not reach those new development and productivity objectives that are necessary.Therefore, our problem is to avoid the crisis of peripheral economies, which does not imply a centralization or centralized programming, but it means to provide peripheral economies with the same opportunities that we provide to centralized economies.This is why the program must be directed to schools, so we must take a whole kind of age and insist, get that in that class there is no longer anyone who is outside the new literacy.Lisbon, therefore, has a very precise strategy.In Lisbon, in my opinion, the real problem is to inject a new value for employment, for growth knowing that we can do it and, therefore, we must go to this model that is based on safe balances.To summarize today's debate, I want to remember a phrase used by one of his honor, if I remember I Mr. Commissioner, we are facing a reform that there are no qualifiers that are exaggerated to say how important it is.It transcends competition, transcends the cohesion of the internal market, I think it deeply affects what is the sense of European integration, the sense of the legitimacy of European integration.Therefore, we count, Mr. Commissioner, with that inter -institutional dialogue to profile a reform that we all expect and to which we consider that we will bring to fruition with its piloting and our cooperation.Mr. President, Lordship, I thank the Commission for Economic and Monetary Affairs and the entire European Parliament for the great interest shown by the issues of the competition.Mr. President, in my opinion, this joint debate is the most living and valuable testimony of it.We have heard very deep considerations that, at the same time, are of philosophy of economic policy and analysis of the institutional structure.Our common attempt is to modernize and strengthen the policy of competition, pillar of the social economy of market and European construction.The conductive thread of all these aspects of reform of the competence policy, which we are going to deal with jointly, is a conductive thread oriented to guarantee a more effective protection of the competition, to reduce the bureaucratic weight that taxes on companies and to bring the processes of decisions to citizens closer.I want to thank you personally and deeply to Mr. Von Wogau the effort with which the white dossier and the quality of his report have examined.I would like to group the considerations that have been made throughout the debate on the Von Wogou report in four points that I do not consider as criticism of the Commission, but fundamental contributions, since there are concerns that it is fair to have and that we want to overcome together: the question of efficacy, the question of the risk of renationalization, the question of coherence in the application, the question of legal certainty.I will examine them one by one very quickly.Effectiveness: I am convinced that this reform allows reinforcing and not weakening the protection of competition in the scope of the single market.Avilies, the current notification system no longer allows this objective to be achieved, because it does not guarantee the information of the Commission on the most serious restrictions - a agreement that only nine prohibition decisions have been adopted after a notification and in the absence of denunciation - it does not guarantee transparency and does not provide a true legal certainty to the companies that, in most cases, receive a simple administrative letter of file.The proposed system will improve the protection of competition, first of all because it will allow the commission to concentrate its action on the most serious restrictions and, therefore, because it will imply a greater extent to national authorities and competition in the repression of violations and, finally, because it will allow the victims of infractions to go directly to national judges, whose mission is to protect subjective rights.The issue of renationalization: first of all, although it is superfluous, I would like to remember and underline, if possible three times, that the white paper does not affect the most concentrations and state aids - we are not thinking of a return in these matters - but, as regards regulation No. 17, there is a risk of renationalization.

The commission's delays must be reflected in the proposed calendar, so the date of 2003 must necessarily be reviewed.At the same time that defines a sector reserved for postal public operators, based on weight and price limits, the directive on postal services would allow liberalization of stages and controlled.The brutal reduction of these limits calls into question the balance between public service obligation and economic viability for postal services.In a context of globalization, where the logic of profitability and benefit is increasingly opposed to the interest of balance of territories and social cohesion, it is urgent to remember here our adhesion to the European public service well ties today to the postal sector, tomorrow to the railway or the day after the health sector tomorrow.Mr. President, I take the floor as well as other Scottish members of this assembly, representatives of Scotland, to protest against anything that gives rise to a decrease in the quality of rural life in remote areas.The service and post offices are an essential element of the life of rural communities throughout Europe, not to mention Scotland.It would be a disaster that, intentionally or even without knowing it, measures will be taken whose effect was harming them.I don't think it's anyone's intention to do something like that.Nor do I believe that the commission has proposed to declare war on the islands of Scotland or Greece.But they could accidentally cause great damage.The question is to determine at what speed and with what methods the gradual liberalization of postal services would have to be carried out.If a limit too low was set to continue the right of monopoly of the postal service, it would be antieconomic to maintain the universality of the service in remote areas with a price that remained affordable.The crucial issue is to find a balance between universality and affordable price.The message that is transmitted today very clearly from all parts of the Assembly to the Commission is that it must walk with lead feet.I should not, for example, take a leap from 350 grams to, as someone has suggested, 50 grams.On the contrary, I should be careful.I imagine that anything less than 150 grams would be extremely reckless in these circumstances.The solidarity and cohesion of the peoples throughout Europe depends on thinking that a letter can be sent anywhere and that will deliver anywhere else, all with a reasonable price seal.Let's defend universality and affordable price!Mr. President, to guarantee a quality postal service of quality, it is essential that its public character be maintained.The Universal Service, which entails an offer of quality postal services at affordable prices and provided in all points of the territory, constitutes the basis of the entire operation of the postal system and must promote a uniform rate throughout the national territory.Now, so that it is, it is essential that it be maintained as a public service.Only in this way is it possible to guarantee that the network, from collection to distribution, is a comprehensive network that cannot be fragmented or used only in part according to the conveniences of postal service operators.

However, unfortunately the fear that this leads to the creation of a European institution that restricts subsidiarity remains too great.In any case, I am going to contribute to the part that corresponds to me to swell the support in favor of Mrs. Theato's report.Mr. President, we are basically in favor of the resolution that has been presented to us, although we think that it can only be an invitation from Parliament to the Council so that, through a modification of the treaties, an effective criminal protection of the financial interests of the Union is guaranteed.The institution of a European prosecutor and the establishment of criminal figures common to all the states of the Union is, without a doubt, a good idea, however, I consider impossible to think of putting it into practice without first having created a court order of the Union.We are talking, in effect, a criminal law, a field in which the resistance of national states to community is and will always be strong.In fact, it is unthinkable that substantive and procedural legal norms can be established for a single area such as the protection of financial interests, without having previously created a European court order.It is enough to read the precise and exhaustive motivations of the Theato report to realize how many and what are the problems still pending solution.However, this idea must be promoted and there is no doubt that in this attempt to protect financial interests we will realize the need to have a community juris corpus that must be incorporated into the treaties.On behalf of my group and in mine, I also express the desire that the financial soul of the Union serves as a guide for the establishment of a European court order respectful of the rights and guarantees of citizens, that is, of a court order that increases the guarantees that, unfortunately, in many states there are no acceptable levels.Consequently, on behalf of my group, I express a favorable judgment on the Theato report;However, I consider that, in the substantial aspect, it is an issue that must be included in the agenda of the Intergovernmental Conference.Mr. President, the report of Mrs. Theato on the protection of the financial interests of the European Union proposes, in particular, in a first phase, centralize the criminal proceedings through the creation of a European prosecutor.This proposal is radically against the spirit of the current system, in which criminal law and criminal procedure, which constitute the core of national legal systems, must depend on the sovereignty of each people and be the exclusive competence of each State.Now, the idea of ​​a European prosecutor, on the contrary, aims to relegate the states to a subordinate role in these issues.In addition, this proposal would trigger a succession of absolutely unpredictable reforms.According to the Theato Report, the European prosecutor would be necessary, in particular, to better frame the investigations of the Office to Fight Fraud, the Olaf.But in parallel we find out, in the Van Hulten report that is debated today, that the European prosecutor would also be monitored by a European Union court.

I therefore delighted that the responsibility is attributed to individuals without the commission relieving its responsibility.In practice, experiences - only 9 files have been refused, 94 % of the cases that the Commission had to deal with were not formally settled but via unpublished administrative letters, legally non -binding, or simply by expiration of the time -clever period clearly that at the age of globalization and the enlargement of the EU, the work of the Commission is limited by temporal, personal and financial constraints.To conclude, I would like to say what I expect from this reform: fair competition and the same conditions of competition for all, legal security for all businesses, a uniform application of competition policy, a simplification of procedures in accordance with the principle of the one -stop shop, the coordination of the national authorities that I believe I should be independent, close cooperation of the authorities and national courses with the Commission as well as a clear distribution of skills andnationals in the application of European competition law and agreements.From the Commission, I expect that it focuses on the essentials by accomplishing its main guardians of European competition policies.I look forward to seeing what form will take the vast discussions in the first legislative proposal.The Commission's report confirms that, aside from Germany, state aid to businesses are increasing.This only worries the Commission from the point of view of the conditions of competition.For our part, we place ourselves from the point of view of the interest of laborious classes.The company does not gain anything from these enormous transfers of public funds to private companies.Look at the automobile, where subsidies and various aids of states increased by 24 % during the reference period.What to do?It is not to preserve jobs.All of these companies have made job cuts, or even layoffs.It is not to improve working conditions, because by producing more workers, working conditions worsen.Do these companies need the help of states to survive?No, car companies have had colossal profits for years.State aid is not only perverse, because, as the Jonckheer report recognizes, they lead to a hunt for subsidies by relocations from one country to another, they are unacceptable because they devote public money to the enrichment of a handful of private shareholders.It is because everywhere we promote the richest with state money that everywhere in Europe we reduce social protection, we abandon public services, we close hospitals.The meaning of my vote against the Jonckheer report is to assert the need for another policy, that is to say the cessation of all aid to private companies and the use of money thus saved to develop public services and hire staff.Mr. President, the debate that we hold today is of extraordinary importance because the principle of competition has probably been the cornerstone of the domestic market.Pursuant to the principle of competition, the regulations have developed articles 85 to 94, properly said competition policy, the revision of all state aid and tax provisions likely to distort competition.

In the next resolution of the CIG, the Parliament will have to deal in depth the issues of diversification and flexibility.If we cannot create that system with concentric layers proposed by the liberal group, we will endanger the expansion and integration process.My colleagues, the honorable Frassoni and the honorable Honesty, have already expressed a somewhat skeptical opinion on some aspects of the question we are dealing with;I would like to manifest my concern regarding subsidiarity, not so much as regards the relations between the Union and the Member States, but rather for the relationships between the individual Member States and the Regions who, within them, enjoy administrative autonomy.It is a topic on which it has not been reflected enough and which is a source of concern from many points of view.I would like to point out above all one of the consequences that the expansion will have on this parliament.A roof of 700 deputies has been set, which represents the maximum number of members with which Parliament can continue to work as a deliberating assembly.By applying the principle of digressive proportionality (six seats for each state and then one more seat for every half million inhabitants) we already reach a situation for which Luxembourg, with 367,000 inhabitants, sends more deputies of Wales in this parliament, region which, within the United Kingdom, enjoys a partial administrative autonomy;Scotland, who has 5 million inhabitants, today has 8 deputies to the European Parliament, while Denmark and Finland, with the same population, have 16. What will happen now if we keep the roof of 700 members, we gradually increase the population of the European Union of 26 percent and then we adopt the proposal (in my opinion unhappy) of the Commission to form a list of candidates on a European basis?What will happen to a country like Scotland that I represent here?It will become completely invisible!Given the circumstances, the deputies of this Parliament should not be surprised if, discussing these issues, public opinion, in Scotland and in other countries that are in the same situation, begins to ask whether the expansion should not take on the form of an admission of new member states belonging to those already existing.In Scotland an ever stronger current of opinion is being oriented in this sense.Mr. President, he has often heard that the European Union is at a crossroads.This time it is the truth: we have started - with great success - the single currency and the expansion awaits us.We wonder if we head prepared or not towards the expansion.Will it be an expansion on the surface or in depth?This is the hazel of the debate when it comes to the intergovernmental conference, the agenda and the method.Evidently the Council has chosen, for now, to expand without deepening.This is a danger to expansion;A danger to any perspective of political union.Public opinion will have difficulty understanding.The advice must realize that, if we want the future of the union to be built on the foundations of a solid expansion, it is necessary to go much further in the next intergovernmental conference.

The crisis of the Commission was, in fact, a crucial point of the relationship between Europe and its citizens, and the low participation in the European elections was a worrying sign.Even deeper, however, is the sense of insecurity, the feeling of unpreparedness in the face of a new world that advances, a world that changes totally, which through globalization ends up changing even our reference points.It is not a completely new fact in history: already Europe has already found itself in front of an similar change, an explosion of its markets, to a change in the reference parameters, to a different perception of the world.I am referring to the sixteenth century, after the discovery of America, in which everything has changed.Some countries - such as France and Spain - have been able to respond to the challenge giving life to the great national states;Other countries - such as Italy - have not held up to this challenge and lost all the primates who in the first part of the millennium had accumulated: primates of science, technology, economic progress, defense and military organization, thought and literature.Today Europe is faced with a similar challenge, and we know that, as history has not forgiven in the past, so it does not forgive today.In this perspective of great changes, to prevent our national states from disappearing in the face of globalization, which places unprecedented dimensions and challenges in our history, an economically strong Europe is necessary, because globalization imposes unity, because every day there is news of new agreements worldwide and every day there is news of changes even at European level.But even more necessary it is a Europe that feels strong in the political field.In past years the single market and the single currency have been the fulcrum of our action, the main element of European life.Today, the new frontiers of European integration are political borders: foreign policy and common security, justice and internal security and - in order - the crucial question of the fundamental political values ​​on which our coexistence stands.For this reason, the Commission approved the 2000-2005 strategic plan, a plan that was immediately sent to the European Parliament, which you already know and which, therefore, in this speech of mine I will not resume in detail.Someone may consider it perhaps too synthetic, but no political structure produces detailed five -year plans.This is the European Union, it is not the Soviet Union.Our plan identifies the great reference points, the great directions of intervention: first, the development of new forms of government for Europe;second, the expansion and enlargement of the peace, freedom, security area;third, the launch of a new phase of economy development;fourth, the protection and improvement of the quality of life.These are our great action directives for the next five years.Regarding the first - the new forms of government for Europe - you already know that the Commission has committed itself to presenting a white photographer, and not a complete legislative text since, in the face of the great problems that structurally change our way of being together, the commission first prepares the debate;Then discuss the content with you;Hence a political document, finally a legislative document was born.

It will then be necessary, as I pointed out, to change the paradigm and to forget the post-colonial paradigm to give a more European dimension to development policies.From this point of view, I think (like some stakeholders) that the new convention called to replace Lomé conventions constitutes an important instrument for renovation and new dynamics in the approach of a partnership with such a large group of countries in the South, at the time when there is stability around the negotiation processes on an international scale, like those who characterized the first cycle of Seattle negotiations.I feel a certain degree of frustration in many contributions to this debate.I made before you a declaration on behalf of the commission which, I think, offers a useful framework for this discussion.We will provide more detailed information directly linked to all consistency issues.This debate is not new.We are working there for the time in the Commission and, the work completed, I will present a report in the matter, since many were those who asked if it was possible to see the report on consistency.I have no doubt that, due to the growing political attention granted to these problems which clearly emerged from today's debate -it will be easier for the Commission and the DG of development to place the question of coherence at the top of our work order.This also requires the introduction of new additional mechanisms within the commission system which may very well include, as some political groups of this Parliament suggested, the establishment of a special interservice working group and a form of coherence control within the Commission.I read - and heard during the debate - that consistency is used as a kind of miracle formula that suits everything.I think it is important to leave it to the relatively well defined discipline rank aimed at trying to reduce inconsistencies where they really exist, and there are most certainly.This is largely linked to a real disagreement between sectoral interests in each Member State, as has been said with great honesty in this assembly.People identify in a way with their spheres of interest, which is legitimate.However, I would like to warn against the illusion that the inconsistency results from a certain mechanical disability of the system.This happens but represents only a small part of what we are talking about.Most of the debate relates to the well -known differences in interest established between the sexes and so on, and there is the problem.Mr. Mulder said that no farmer will begin to produce anything if the price is too low.This is true in our part of the world, but our partners and beneficiaries in Africa have a slightly different perspective.They are farmers, not only to earn a living, but also to live, that makes a difference.

Just recently we had the opportunity to resort to the precautionary principle to prohibit phthalates in soft PVC toys and of course we apply it in numerous environmental sectors.Mostly it is used when it comes to environmental problems, but of course even when human health comes into play.We will therefore try to define the cases in which this principle must be applied with extreme clarity.Mr. President, Mrs. Commissioner, as regards the relationship between science on the one hand and appeal to the principle of precaution on the other, in communication it is argued that the use of this principle always requires a political decision in the event of lack of scientific evidence.With this statement, great power to science is attributed.We can ask ourselves who the experts who will provide the required documentation and what a position will defend.The communication also reads that even a sufficient and recognized minority of scientific experts can invoke the precautionary principle.I would like to know then what is the definition of recognized minority.How can you give a description of this concept?How do you create a recognized minority?If then it is a political decision, I would like to know who will adopt it.The Commission?The advice?What will be the role assigned to the European Parliament?What is the role of scientific committees?What will be the role of the authorities in the food field that will be designated shortly?Finally, will the decision -making process occur to the sign of transparency and advertising?These are the three questions that I would like to ask.This is the right, Mr. President, the problems have been many, complex and sometimes dark, but I will also try to respond.Who will you have to decide and what are the decision -making centers?It depends on those who play the role of legislator;It is part of the management of risks.For example, we will need to consider the concerns of public opinion on a specific problem and judge according to the scientific tests available for a certain case.It is true, however, that a strong majority of the scientific community is not necessary to resort to the principle of precaution;It is sufficient that there is evidence made by a minority, or that science is not able to give precise answers.In this way, a balance is maintained between the use of this principle as a political tool and science.It is not always easy to precisely describe the performance of this process, but it is not a question of changing the scientific method.We resort to experts to acquire as many information and scientific facts as possible before making a decision and it seems to me that in the future it will be good to behave in this way.This method must be considered as a tool for the management of risks: it must be decided, for example, if you have to allow the population to be exposed to any risk, or if you want to protect the environment.It is therefore necessary to take into account the available scientific data.We must evaluate all these factors and evaluate what science tells us, and then decide whether or not to adopt a measure, whether to act or not.There is therefore no answer to all questions, but this does not change the scientific system we have today, nor the way we use the experts today.

Amendment n.18 refers to Directive 96/71 relating to the minimum wages, a directive that already finds application for which no changes to the text is needed.If the Commission welcomed amendment no.17, this would imply the introduction of a simple notification obligation in case of non -release of a valid card.It is evident that this provision is in contrast with the interests of the Member States on public order.We cannot also welcome amendment no.19 For the considerations that I have already presented in relation to amendment no.10. The position of the Commission is substantially the same also in relation to similar amendments presented for the second proposal.I also allow me to add that amendment no.10 The second proposal is absolutely unacceptable.Compared to amendment no.15 relating to the definition of self -employed workers, as I have detected a few indeed, the Commission will seek an adequate solution that takes into account the objections raised.I now come to the observation of Lord English.He referred to the existing borders checks for the United Kingdom.In this regard, I would like to note that there is no obligation by virtue of which a Member State - and therefore also the United Kingdom - must abolish or modify the controls on the still existing boundaries.This applies, as I said, for the United Kingdom, but also applies to Belgium, where the problem has recently emerged.As for the observations of the honorable Karas, I have the impression that he refers to the possibility that workers from Poland will be employed in his country.The Commission would like to propose a solution applicable to all companies established in the European Union that employ workers from third countries.The problem is if the two cases must be addressed simultaneously.In my opinion, the question falls within the debate on the expansion of the European Union and perhaps should not be addressed here.On behalf of the commission, I would like to confirm to Honorable Karas that he is at his complete disposal if he needs more information on this really important point.Finally, I would like to thank Parliament for the extremely constructive debate dedicated to the most important aspects of these proposals and, of course, express my gratitude to the rapporteur, honorable Berger.Thank you very much, Commissioner Bolkestein.The discussion is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, at 11.00.Court of first instance Mr. President, I would like to start congratulating myself with the speaker for his relationship which, at a first reading, gives the impression of limiting himself to confirming and accepting.Behind this relationship, however, there is all long and effective work that has already produced some fruit;In fact, the commitment to expand the agenda of the intergovernmental conference to understand the study of a future modification of the organization, composition and competences of the Community courts was included in the document of the Finnish presidency of 7 1999.I therefore express my recognition to the work of the vice president Marinho.Mr. President, the reform of the Community judicial system has become an urgent necessity if in the future you want to do justice within reasonable terms, if in the future the European Union wants to have justice at the height of the political project already started.

Mr. President, the Commission's proposal regarding the further controlled and gradual opening of the postal market to the competition is essentially late due to the reorganization of the services and the re -attribution of the Commission's skills, as well as the need for the new College REASAMINI these problems.As for the different resolutions of Parliament concerning the postal sector, my colleague, Commissioner Bolkestein, has already responded to the main observations during the hearings that were organized last year by Parliament.In addition, as regards the consultation of the Parliament, Commissioner Bolkestein will meet, next Monday, the Commission for Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism of Parliament.Studies were sent to this commission in September 1999, as well as to the parliamentarians who requested them, and are still available.These studies can also be consulted on the Commission's website.I am sure that Commissioner Bolkestein will pay due attention to all the observations of Parliament.The Commission, Mr. President, is firmly convinced of the need for a new proposal for the further development and evolution of the postal sector.In addition, the presentation of a proposal constitutes a legal obligation.They are able to confirm that it is a firm intention of Commissioner Bolkestein to present such a proposal to the Commission, to transmit it to Parliament and the Council, within the first half of the year.The date established for the realization of the next phase, on 1 January 2003, remains the ambition of the Commission.The proposal will take into account the studies carried out, and in particular of the need to ensure the universality of the service, the development of efficient safeguards for consumers, the creation of a climate favorable to new jobs and the solution of the problems related to competition.The role of the opening of the market, in view of the further modernization and improvement of postal services of the whole union with new technologies, will also be examined in view of the potential benefits for the industry as a whole.The proposal, when it is presented, will take into account the points of view expressed by the Member States, by Parliament, by users, by the loans of universal services, their competitors and other parties concerned, with which in -depth consultations have been carried out.The goal is to guarantee the proper functioning of the internal market of postal services in the interest of consumers and companies in the whole union.Mr Markov, he will be granted the right to intervene between 5-6 minutes, but in the meantime he has the courtesy not to interrupt the honorable colleagues.Mr. President, here is a mystery.What happened to the postal services directive that was approved on December 15, 1997?From that moment there has been a heavy silence from the Commission.I'm sorry that the Commissioner Monti has to answer.I respect him a lot and I think he is one of the most diligent and active commissioners.Unfortunately I can't say the same for some of his colleagues.In this period no progress has occurred in relation to the postal services directive.Commissioner Monti said that this must be partially attributed to organizational reasons and the re -attribution of skills.

This second option has prevailed and I congratulate myself, but I hope that, in the future, the coordination between the two institutions and the council is closer so that our work is more understandable, more fruitful and more productive.Mr. President, our objective by establishing a framework for investment funds and other OICVM is to guarantee the maximum benefits for the savings of our investors without subjecting them to large risks, which is why I want to refer to the issue of derivatives in my observations today.I firmly believe that the prudent use of derivatives can contribute to consolidate more safe and higher benefits.Despite their dangerous reputation, derivatives are generally used by asset administrators as prevention.A contract that, for example, pays a substantial sum, if, say, the NASDAQ or CAC 40 index falls, causes an additional payment by the investor if the Nasdaq or Cac 40 index rises. Is that speculation?At all.Imagine that we have dedicated several months to create a portfolio of assets of companies that inspire us confidence: they are companies that have good management, good perspectives and represent a good investment.Then we are concerned that the entire stock market may fall, as happened in 1987. In that case we will have the option of selling everything and turning it into cash, but that would mean losing everything we have investigated on the winners.It would also mean incurring all the transaction expenses involved in the sale of our participations and then buy them again after the fall.The solution consists of taking out a derivative that compensates for us if Nasdaq or Cac 40 falls. But even with custom -measure or OTC derivatives, which would be cheaper, that they could ensure a relative fall of our portfolio with respect to the index, we would continue to have the portfolio and the participations, but we would have protected ourselves against the dangers of a plumme.In return, we may have undone of some of the most raising values ​​in the market.In that case, which may be the most widespread use of derivatives by asset administrators, we reduce our possible reward, but we also reduce our risk factor.It is a desirable development in a well -managed fund.History shows that investors benefit from a liberal and light approach.An authoritarian system - a prescription of how private sector administrators should invest and where they should invest - will only reduce the benefits for investors.The pension funds that are subject to the regulations on where they can invest and where not, as required for our state bonds, obtain benefits of annual 5.2%, barely half of the 9.5% annual benefits that obtained free funds between 1984 and 1996. We are naturally talking about benefits after having deduced all losses.Let's not confuse the real concern for the interests of investors with a populist fear of a new, innovative and liberal approach that is worth it.That's what we should take here today.Mr. President, the report that is presented to us aims to end the free movement of financial investments in Europe, even in its most sophisticated forms.

What can the European Union do in a context that, without interference in matters that are the exclusive competence of the Cypriots, can encourage the search for a right and lasting solution to this dramatic problem that affects a country linked to the European community for almost 30 years, which will be called to join the European Union in the coming years?I listened, in particular by the Council, proposals or somewhat ambiguous silences, which in my opinion must be clearly precise.I think it is up to us first to remember the main reference for the whole international community, i.e. the resolutions of the United Nations.According to the Security Council, the solution to the Cypriot problem must be sought in the framework of a bizonal, two -ome federation, in other words a unique state - Commissioner Verheugen has made an allusion to you - which entails two local mandatory administrations of the two communities.Sovereignty, international personality and citizenship must be unique and this state must be demilitarized.In this way the international community clearly indicates that it refuses the fact accomplished by force.Secondly, the European Union gains, I think, of reducing the position of interpretation of the position defined by the European Council of Helsinki as much as possible.The solution of the Cypriot problem cannot constitute a preliminary condition for the adhesion of Cyprus to the Union, as the honorable Poos recalled, otherwise it would in fact confer to Turkey a sort of veto right regarding the adhesion of Cyprus to the European Union, which is unacceptable.Finally, thirdly, the position of the European Council of Helsinki cannot instead lead to a reduction of the efforts we make to solve the cypriot problem before the entrance of the country in the Union.From this point of view, Helsinki's other decision, that is, the recognition of Turkey's candidacy for the Union, gives the fifteen a new responsibility while offering new possibilities to the Union.In my opinion, the dialogue with Ankara can and must integrate the determined will to obtain from Turkey the expression towards the dialogue between the two Cypriot communities of a constructive attitude, respectful of international legality and which allows you to get to the reunification of Cyprus and peace in the eastern Mediterranean.Mr. President, if on the importance of financial support in Cyprus and Malta we are practically all in agreement, the same cannot be said regarding the budget address book to draw on the necessary funds.The Council and the Commission propose to insert the protocols in Rubric 4, a proposal that is in line with the budget decisions adopted by Parliament last December;The speaker returns to his position and now proposes to enter the financial support in Cyprus and Malta in address book 7. For his part, the Commission for Budgets even proposes to postpone the approval of the Brok report until the Council decides to raise the ceiling of address book 7, but this is an extremely risky strategy because, without the preventive vote of Parliament, the financial protocols cannot be activated.Cyprus and Malta therefore find the costs of a political game conducted by the Council and Parliament on the ceilings.Moreover, what is the point of establishing ceilings if, then, at each new action, are they continuously high?

The presidency takes note of its concern and will forward it via the corresponding channels.Violence between the population groups in Mitrovica and the location of the Albanian prisoners in Serbia, especially the Flora Brovina case).(Fri) Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues!We have not signed the present compromise closure application for two reasons.First of all, one of our colleagues, who is known for his open and tolerant attitude, made Mr. Sakellariou - as not to name - inserted his vehement veto against it because he wanted to defend their moral values.I do not doubt, and you will probably not doubt that this is a newly important contribution that he makes to the fight against racism and against intolerance.Second, the present application for a resolution is unfortunately not of very large scope.Through a number of tricks, it was possible to carefully avoid the treatment of the central question, namely the final status of Kosovo.Probably none of them should assume that Kosovo could one day belong to Yugoslavia.Likewise, none of them will accept that Milosevic could last for a long time if the international community would finally find a solution to the question of the final status of Kosovo.After all, none of them will believe that in the current situation Milosevic will have no interest in doing everything possible to destabilize Kosovo, which he does and what we have already experienced.Finally, in my opinion, none of them can believe that the current status quo only contributes to the stability and thus to the development of Kosovo.Incidentally, it is interesting to read a lapsus undertaking in the compromise application, which has undoubtedly missed them.They condemn the first immediate attack on KFOR members.I don't want you to be misfortune, but I'm afraid that you will ultimately be if you don't treat the real problem, and I make you fully responsible for what can happen.In my opinion, we have to ask the Commission and the Council, which is unfortunately absent today, to emphasize the question of the final status of Kosovo, the growing number of small states in this region, the development according to Dayton and finally the question of real stability, which finally enables the development of democracy in these countries.In conclusion, I would like to point out that we had asked for a determined action on the part of the Council and the Commission for the release of the 3,000 Kosovo-Albanian prisoners as well as Ms. Brovina, Mr. Kurti and Mr. Hoti.I find that the Union is facing a certain relaxation of the sanctions without so far only one of these prisoners have been released in return.For what reason?Mr. President, what is happening in Mitrovica in Kosovo is terrible and reprehensible.Violence leads to violence, revenge creates revenge.The police forces sent are not strong enough to put an end to the processes.The senior police commissioner, Svend Frederiksen, has
