It represents the possibility of maintaining a European identity in the 21st century, an identity that blamed the echoes of division, war, poverty, opportunity, of poverty Dans I realized it.And besides that, and this is more prosaic, Madam President, means that we have the ability to learn from previous political initiatives and put it into practice in new programs that are broad, that are transverse and that benefit our creative industries as long as necessary.The program encourages mobility and opens the doors of culture to the socially disadvantaged and excluded.I only regret that we do not have enough funds to encourage this program according to our aspirations and to make everyone reach.Mrs. President, Ladies, we have already reached the end of a long journey.After the conciliation stage, our institutions can already officially approve the new "Culture 2000" program.Thus we will have a totally suitable instrument to carry out, during the next five years, a clear, well -structured and -Toy -fruit -fruitful action in favor of the cultural sector.I welcomed this Happy End today and express my thanks to your lordships.I thank all who in this Parliament have worked for a good end for conciliation to be possible.I want to express my particular thanks to the Commission of Culture, Youth, Education, Media and Sports, and in particular to its rapporteur, Mr. Graça Moura, to its president, Mr. Gargani, to the Delegation of the European Parliament and the leaders of the political groups, to the Conciliation Committee and its President, Mr. Imbeni.All of them have made a constructive, balanced and decisive contribution.Throughout this whole negotiation, they have represented a great help and it should be said that the difficult, sometimes painful, negotiation has been done, despite everything, in a minimum period.Now we have a-Marco program, the first of this class for the cultural sector, which allows us to consider our action from a new angle and work for culture more globally, but also more complete and deeper.I would like to congratulate myself together with their lordships of these satisfactory results that, despite a budgetary situation that is not up to our ambitions, should allow us to consider the future in a totally positive way and would like to highlight what President Gargani has just said: the commission has made a statement on the It is no longer sustainable that the community must pay the damage caused by individual people, often with criminal activities.We must introduce responsibility for those who cause all sorts of damage to our environment, because so it will think twice before carrying out crude oils with a oil tanker on the point of breaking.Over five years ago, in 1994, when I became a member of the legal commission of this parliament, I was assigned the drafting of the report on environmental responsibility.It is from that day that I await an initiative of the commission that gives me the subject to work.It is necessary to put an end to this scandal as soon as possible, and I hope that in February the discussion on this dossier is not updated for the umpteenth time!- (de) Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, after all the storm that marked the turn of the century should lead us to reflect on some problems.It has been clearly seen that man, today as always, is unable to escape natural catastrophes.Natural catastrophes have always been there and there will also be in the future.It is natural that in this regard it is necessary to prove solidarity.It is out of doubt that a pan -European civil protection service is needed, and a budget line for natural catastrophes must be foreseen in the European Union budget.But the most important thing is to recognize the principle that in the natural-man relationship is always the man who is wrong, perpetuating his mistakes sometimes for centuries.Nature never misses, because it can't make mistakes.The damage, in the case under discussion, depend on the housing density, the shape of the infrastructures and obviously on the many monocultures, if we talk about forests.It is evident that we must give all the help possible, but by doing it we must keep in mind that electrical and telephone cables in the future could be buried more often.We must shorten the cycles and guarantee the reforestation with mixed woods, more stable of monocultures.The most important debate in this context is that on the climate.In Europe we are privileged because we have the Gulf current and because this still works.America and Southeast Asian are much worse than we are in terms of storms.Fortunately, we have the Gulf current, but we too like the others are subject to the greenhouse effect, and the latter is partly caused by man, however difficult it is to demonstrate climate change mathematically.We must pay more attention to the recommendations of the Kyoto conference on the environment.We must reduce CO2 emissions, use renewable energy sources and in this context ask us what the health status of European forests is.Mr. President, I believe that what we must deplore before anything else is the loss of human lives.An irreparable loss.Secondly, we welcome the solidarity that emerged among the French departments and citizens, as well as the one manifested by other countries to France, the most affected state.Given the very little time at my disposal, Mr. President, I will limit myself to emphasizing two aspects of our resolution.The first aspect seems implicitly recognized to me by the commissioner, when asking if they are natural disasters or not.

In this context, the various references to regional cooperation with neighboring countries take on a significant political meaning.The agreement also is of particular importance because it will be able to and have to take on an exemplary character also for the other countries of the Balkan area.However, this process is necessary to be supported by a real political will of approaching the European Union to these countries.We know that for some of them, democratization processes are underway, in others the state democratic authority is yet to be affirmed, while others owe their balance to a military presence in the area.In all cases, these countries are aware of now on to have the possibility, overcome the difficulties, to create a concrete link with the European Union.Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, honorable deputies, I do not intend to join the unanimous chorus of colleagues.I think the relationship is a small masterpiece of hypocrisy.In paragraph 4, the exemplary character of the agreement is mentioned.We know that, from Lithuania to Turkey, there are thirteen candidate countries and that there is only one black hole in Europe, the Balkans, and while these countries are denied the possibility of applying, we would like to make them believe that the agreement is miraculous.In paragraph 11 it indicates that symbolic measures can replace the political agreement, the political perspective that represents the fact of being a candidate.The report is not only a masterpiece of hypocrisy, but also an aberration, because, honorable colleagues, even if the negotiations begin tomorrow, the agreement will be concluded in a year and will come into force in three years.I challenge you to doubt that, among the Balkan countries, questions of adhesion in the due form by Croatia, Macedonia, Bosnia are not submitted over these three years.A few days ago Racan announced the request for formal adhesion of Croatia for the end of 2000. I am sure that we will have other applications for membership and that therefore this beautiful work, this beautiful intellectual architecture will crumble, because it will be overcome by the events, as we have been in the last twenty years by everything that has happened in the former Yugoslavia.All this would not be serious if the problems we know in this region of Europe did not exist, if there were no problems that are addressed, but have not yet been solved by the new government of Macedonia, the problems of cohabitation between the Macedonian majority and the Albanian minority, with the issues related to Kosovo, if there were no well -known economic problems, the problems of neighboring with a particularly powerful mafia in Serbia, if there was no problem, if there was no problem,consisting of a veto that should be denounced for what it is, the veto of Greece who, after almost ten years, continues to prevent this country from being called with its name, and I hope that the interpreters have not used the term ERIM when I was talking about Macedonia.All this is absolutely absurd.I think it is an offense primarily towards Greek colleagues, towards Greek citizens.It is urgent to find a solution to this issue.Finally, for a very happy case, I learned of a letter sent by Georgievski, president of Macedonia, to Commissioner Fischler, on March 8, in which, referring to the article or, having become article 49 of the Treaty, he requests that Macedonia can join the European Union.

In addition, a huge warehouse has been built, the building permit and, moreover, the company "Drogheda Corporation" is to consult the other infrastructure.How can the Commission guarantee that this type of development, funded thanks to the structural funds, does not jeopardize the efforts necessary for the conservation of nature in the region?Is the commission willing to interrupt any funding pending a revision of the regional planning plans?.(SV) The Commission is aware of the construction of this port, but it had no knowledge of that of this warehouse, nor of the other infrastructures cited by Mrs. La MP.The construction of the port is subject to financial aid from structural funds, and has the main consequence of dredging the mouth of the Boyne river, and the provisional storage of the sediment masses collected on the stegrennan vase leash.The perimeter around the Boyne estuary was classified special protection zone under the directive on wild birds.This means that any operating activity practiced in the river estuary, or nearby, must respect the protection rules that have been set for this region by the community directive on natural habitats.Since 1998, the Commission has received a number of complaints in which the construction of the port would be said to damage the Stegrennan vase leash, which is now part of the protected area, and that the applicable protection rules had not been respected.After examining these complaints during the year 1998 and at the beginning of 1999 - a period during which the project did not receive aid from the structural funds -, the Commission acquired the conviction, during the summer of 1999, that the protection rules had been taken into account for the construction of the port.A detailed study of environmental consequences had been carried out.The most negative consequence of the project, namely the loss of the Stegrennan vase of vase, is only temporary, the entrepreneur in charge of the works being required to rehabilitate the site.At the request of the Commission, the Stegrennan vase leash was formally included in the special protection area of ​​the Boyne estuary, of which it was not before.To compensate for the negative effects of this provisional disappearance of the vase leash on the populations of birds concerned, it was also planned to improve other sites of establishment of these species in the estuary area.However, since the summer of 1999, the latter measure has been the subject of a dispute.The Irish authorities first returned to the initially planned improvement measure.Then they put it into force, following a complaint filed by an ecological non -governmental organization before an Irish court.However, the new provision included minor modifications which led to a new complaint.Given that Ireland has committed compensation measures, and that a number of other problems have now found a solution, the Commission cannot today propose to freeze financial aid from structural funds.Nevertheless, it is ready to examine with the Irish authorities the question of compensatory measures intended to improve certain natural habitats, in particular in the light of legal action which is still continuing before an Irish court.

social conditions as calmly as possible.Mr. President, it seems that postal services and mail offices are a very fashionable issue in Parliament at this time, and rightly, given its importance.Last week without going any further, in the Parliament of the United Kingdom in Westminster, the newly elected deputy of our European Free Alliance, Plaid Cymru, the Wales Party, made its inaugural speech on that issue.Also in the Scottish Parliament, a debate was maintained ago in which special reference was made to the function of post office, especially in rural areas, in relation to the provision of services and the continuity of rural communities.Liberalization is not the only potential threat to postal services.Postal offices in Scotland, as we have heard, take care of much more than merely dispatch the mail.Governments and some local administrations have been traditionally using agencies for the payment of pensions and other benefits, in addition to centers for the collection of housing rentals, local tax collection, etc.But as the modernization of public financial systems makes more and more direct money transactions to and to bank accounts, the viability of rural postal offices are threatened.If you close a rural post office, normally linked to the only local store, a serious threat to the continuity of the community and for social inclusion can be derived.Instead of allowing postal offices to be under impaired by liberalization or by modernization of systems, governments, and also the commission, they should be promoting and supporting the extensive network of postal offices and considering them as a good that can be used, to provide public information and services from an accessible place for the inhabitants.Mr. President, the postal service has the task of ensuring that everywhere, both in the city and in the most remote rural areas, the mail is distributed every day with the same rate for everyone.One hundred and fifty years ago Correos services were a public issue and, therefore, like public transport and energy supply, they constituted a fundamental task of public administrations.These tasks, very useful and recognition, gave citizens a reason to vote.They currently show a much lower interest in an administration that no longer deals with these tasks.I have heard a democratic politician in a town in the Netherlands: "The mail belongs to everyone and, if they take it away, they will be stealing us."Meanwhile, existing postal services were losing democratic control and more and more step was given to competition.New arrival companies are only interested in those aspects of the work where they can get the highest benefits with the lowest and low -price costs.The only way they have to be the cheapest for some time is based on quality loss for customers and staff.These companies have always existed, but before they were prohibited and now praise them as a sign of progress.

Altener (C5-0333/1999 - 1997/0370 (COD)).Mr. President, I thank Mr. Langen - Although he is not himself here present - for the work he has accomplished to have the program adopted both in Parliament and at the Council.The project was long and difficult.We must continue to promote in particular the studies devoted to the analysis of the use of renewable energy sources.Even if the new directive conceals many advantages, it also has faults.An example is the use of peat.Peat should not be classified in the same category as fossil fuels.If peat cannot be directly classified as a renewable energy source, non -fossil, it must be defined as a separate class, especially for environmental taxation.It is not fair that we apply the same criteria to peat as to the coal for example.The promotion of renewable energy sources is a partial solution in order to remove the dependence on the union with regard to imported energy.

Several questions remain unanswered, however.Thus, the program does not seem to give any priority to the fight against AIDS.The situation on this plan in Africa has today become so serious that AIDS kills more than armed conflicts.I hope the minister will devote a little of his time to this problem.Drugs exist in the United States, but the United States markets it at an too high price for African populations.I would like to ask the minister what he is doing exactly about the situation that develops in Ethiopia, where drought has settled, causing the loss of crops, and where, in six months, will inevitably happen again the scenario that we have already known a few years ago, with famine and people dying by thousands.Meanwhile, Eritrea and Ethiopia have war and European arms industry does not hesitate to send rifles, after which we will send bread.Mr. MP, you will understand that I do not agree with the reading you make of my colleague's intervention during the meeting of the Development Commission;There is no contradiction between these positions, on the contrary.Unless we show megalomania, we could not engage in our program of the presidency to a sort of exhaustive inventory of all possible and imaginable situations concerning all the major questions posed, in particular within the framework of external relations.You will understand that nothing would have been easier.It was enough to take a glossary on development and to note all the points one after the other.We are responsible enough to see that we must only take the points that we can manage within the framework of our presidency and what is - we must be always aware of it - the capacity of governments within the Council.We must see what are the limits to management, in particular national indicative programs.The deputy mentioned the issue of Ethiopia, which is part of the national indicative programs, but as you know there are different community actions to combat AIDS.You are right on this point Mr. MP, the United States will probably not do better.Furthermore, in terms of development assistance policy, I think that Europe has no reason to worry simply because our behavior in the matter has nothing to envy that of the United States.The question of the deputy stems from the question of the problem of armament, it is a broader question of political nature, which seems to me not to fall within the framework of this question but that the council will obviously envisage in the future if it wishes and if it decides to replace it in a specific context.Is the Council aware of the social problems caused by the export of food products by the European Union to developing countries below the production price?

On the one hand, if we establish shares of women, why not also create shares based on age or ethnicity, quotas of Catholics, workers, people with glasses.The establishment of social shares in favor of the most modest categories would no longer be strange than the establishment of women's shares.With such a philosophy it would no longer be necessary to organize elections or administrative competitions.It would be enough to determine the composition of ministries and assemblies based on statistical calculations.The policy of the quotas can only increase the disaffection of the voters towards politics by providing them, once again, the impression that everything happens without their knowledge.On the other hand, such a policy highlights a profound contempt for women.These must not have access to political or administrative functions based on automatisms linked to certain shares, but based on the recognition of their merits and their skills.Would you perhaps be honorable colleagues, so without pride that it is ready to accept a ministerial or elective assignment based on the exquisitely mathematical calculations of a shared system?Women are worth much more than a share.Only based on the principle of meritocracy will we improve the quantitative and qualitative presence of women within the decision -making process.Lady Minister, Mrs. Commissioner, I applaud to your words even if some of the male colleagues still present in the classroom has perhaps something to complain about.I know that there are also women who do not want to hear about shares or positive actions because they believe that these positive discrimination are humiline and stigmatics forever in their career.However, the statistics demonstrate it: positive actions, or shares - if they are not applied blindly and without discernment - have increased the number of women in the decision -making process.This is why it is legitimate to note that the use of the shares, as a transitory basis, contributes to balance the participation of Men and Women, especially in political life.I would like to seize the opportunity that is offered to remind me of the commissioner of the commissioner some requests and initiatives of the European Parliament to which his predecessor has not yet been followed and that they are more to the heart of the shares.First of all, it is about our report, approved last year on the occasion of the International Women's Day in Strasbourg, who asks the Commission to submit to the European Parliament for a new proposal to amend the 1976 directive relating to the implementation of the principle of equal treatment of men and women.Following the Treaty of Amsterdam, the need to maintain positive actions in terms of derogation to the principle of treatment equality that recognizes only an individual right and not a right that belongs to society that wants to achieve such equality democraticly.In the current state of affairs, it should be undeniable that the right of equality of women and men is a fundamental right of a democratic company that requires that equal treatment and equal opportunities are carried out through a set of active measures, including positive actions.

What proposed to us Mr. Giorgos Katiforis and was suppressed from the report?He proposed an ambitious report, in an optimistic Europe, which intended to establish goals in figures for the results that was intended to obtain.And Europe has advanced with methods of figures.Why, for example, was the proposal that the active population of Europe evolve to 75% of the population, when we currently have 60% order levels?An active population of 60% is very low compared to that of Japan or that of the United States and we cannot produce the same as those countries with such a low employment rate.Therefore, we need to increase the employment rate with competitive jobs.As advocated for the Summit of Lisbon, we must prepare labor with scientific training for new technologies.And we need investment to increase to faster rhythms.This idea that Mr. Von Wogau defends and according to which what is needed is flexibility of labor is an argument that we know very well.I would like to oppose the Portuguese example, in which labor laws are not flexible and in which the unemployment rate is less than 5% -and has not stopped decreasing in recent years -because investments increase (with community support, as is obvious) to rhythms much higher than the community average.Therefore, what we want is a Europe with economic growth, but with social concerns.Mr. President, I want, like others, thank Mr. Katiforis for this interesting report.When reading it, an image of the EU economy is achieved that, in my opinion, is quite alarming.Investment levels are too low, unemployment is still too high and growth is insufficient.Therefore, it may not be too strange for the euro to continue losing land in front of other currencies, although it is rumored that the European Central Bank buys euros in hidden to stop its fall.The rapporteur verifies that stability itself is not an objective, an opinion that I share.There is too much talk of stability, convergence and coordination, but too little of the factors that promote innovation and development.For me, the UEM collaboration is like a huge colossus, unable to follow the rapid movements of the economy.My conclusions are absolutely different from those of the previous speaker.I think we must bet on human resources, on the one hand, through a macropolitics that creates demand and new sources of work and, on the other, with measures such as training, business democratization and good social conditions.I see that, in these matters, the EMA project has its greatest weaknesses.We cannot lift European economies from above, as if we were a new Baron von Münchhause.On the contrary, we must mobilize workers and peoples in member countries.

In Tampere, the eye was made to distribute operational skills.We are still calling for a revision of the agreement to bring in better parliamentary and judicial control options.The agreement should also be viewed critically in terms of Eurodac.The parliament modified the contract text.It must be ensured that the council goes compliant with the procedure of parliament.Unfortunately, no initiatives have yet been launched on the other topics.We are currently waiting for it.Europe as a space of freedom, security and law has so far been an area without a clear regulation in important areas.However, we owe this to the citizens of Europe.After hearing the words of Interior and Justice Minister, I am optimistic.I assume that we will succeed in the next six months.President, Mr. Commissioner, revered colleagues, I think Ms. Terrón I Cusí's oral request hit the mark, because six months after the newly elected Parliament has been appointed, we have to be able to send out a decisive political message to European citizens.In my opinion, the Portuguese presidency can contribute in a positive way.In the meantime, we all know what infinitely large expectations our fellow citizens have in terms of freedom, security and justice, especially social justice.The disinterest of the citizens, their distance, sometimes even their aversion to politics force us to take concrete measures in view of their difficulties.This is the essential prerequisite for reconciling citizens with politics.In order for Europe to become a symbol of peace and fraternity, we need a brave and generous policy to get the weakest to help.A real plan to combat unemployment must be implemented, because this scourge is the breeding ground for racism, xenophobia, nationalism and right -wing extremist racist movements.The weakest are - and it is important that I go into this point - the immigrants and the refugees.In this way, the almost continuous inability to inherit the criminalization of asylum seekers can no longer be tolerated.Every asylum seeker must have the right to a fair hearing and appeal.Last week I was more by chance at Roissy Airport witness to a scene of hard -to -surviving violence, in which two young women who had probably entered secretly were deported to Conakry.They were treated like serious criminals.They were naked, were dragged over the ground on the hair and guarded by a Horde CRS standby police officer.The Portuguese presidency must put an end to such barbaric practices.On the contrary, our task is to accompany those who escape a dictatorship, to help them, help them and offer security.The Commission proposed the creation of a European fund for refugees.The parliament welcomed this proposal very much.Instead of debating the middle equipment provided for this fund, you should take the decision to set up this fund.The presidency and the council can concretize the points that were rejected in Tampere for inexplicable reasons, even if tampere forms an important basis.Likewise, we cannot be satisfied with the fact that xenophobia increases in Europe and discrimination is becoming more and more common without taking comprehensive countermeasures.

Finally, the demand concerns the future competencies of the European Parliament in the areas of competition policy and state aid for debate with a view to the government conference.In our report, as you know, Mr. Commissioner, the idea is represented that the co -decision procedure should apply to the adoption of basic legal texts on state aid.President, Herr Commissioner, my very worshiped ladies and gentlemen!My part in today's debate concerns the steel aid code.These are public aids in Europe that were awarded according to this code and which the Commission has checked.That is a total of 27 cases in 1998. The Commission submitted its own report on these cases.The EGKS contract will expire shortly.Therefore, the question that has to deal with today is, in particular, the one how the steel aid will be handled in the future.The European Parliament's decisions, which are presented in the report, are welcomed, including the decision to reclaim funds in a specific case and thus apply Article 88 of the EGKS contract.The competitiveness of the European steel industry is also the content of the recent communication of the Commission, which we have not yet advised in parliament.As in other areas, the general aid ban according to Article 87 paragraph 1 of the EC Treaty applies to the iron and steel industry.According to this article, state aid is generally incompatible with the common market.Exceptions are only allowed in precisely defined cases.According to Article 88, the Commission is obliged to control state aid.In 1998 the greatest case was the supply of equity to Preussag in Germany of 540 million euros.In addition, the Member States of the Commission have to provide their aid project beforehand.For the area of ​​the steel industry, the applicable rules were set up on December 18, 1996.According to this, aid in favor of the steel industry can only be awarded in certain, precisely defined cases.Research and development aids, environmental protection aids, social aid to promote the closure of steelworks and aid for final operating tasks for non-competitive companies.In addition, there is a special regulation of up to 50 million euros for the Member State of Greece.Obviously, however, there have been problems in the practical handling of the steel aid code in recent years, which were not completely discussed in the report.From the point of view of parliament, it is important that today there is already talk about a connection regulation after the expiry of this steel aid code.A softening of the existing basic lines of the steel code must not be decided.Nobody wants an uninhibited subsidy race in Europe.This would significantly affect the internal market even after the steel industry consolidated in recent years.Therefore, the parliament considers it necessary that the steel subscription code is changed with regard to the unequal treatment claimed by industry and that the Commission submits a succession plan to the Council.It is known that the Council has previously refused to decide on such a succession plan.This is also due to the fact that if the steel aid code expires, you can do what you want without the annoying control by the European Commission.We therefore demand that after the contract has expired, the steel aid must be regulated by a council regulation according to Article 94, because only this is the necessary legacy and clarity.

their economic and social policy, their democratic deficit or the involvement of their Member States in the dramatic beam client.This disagreement gives even more weight to today's recognition: it is exceptional in that the risk of rebirth of a contradictory neo -fascist component in Europe is extraordinary.This danger does not affect Austria, but Europe.We speak of ourselves, not Austria.We know the social causes that, together with unemployment and uncertainty, help to stir up in this direction;We know the cultural adjoining causes such as peoples and racism, but we cannot avoid that the inability and the lack of will of those right -wing extremists can create an explosive mixture in Europe for settlement with fascism.It is about the Alpine region, about all of our countries: conditions are created from which a danger to democracy and European civilization can grow again.The chairmanship has made it clear with his statement that he is aware of this dramatic situation for civilization.Europe proves that Auschwitz has not forgotten;Europe meets a soul.Now, however, it should be consistent and act accordingly, and the first thing that would have to be consistent would have to be consistent, which in this case has shown an unclear and undecided attitude through which the importance of the opinion of the council becomes even more obvious.In this sense, the action of the Commission must be corrected.Mrs. President, values ​​and colleagues, as to what the democratic basic principle of respect for human rights as well as freedom and sovereignty of the peoples, which conflicts every new or old fascism, Nazism or communism - and all of the previous speakers have spoken about the sovereignty of the Austrian people - we find that this sovereignty is being denied by our parliament today.

Nothing to prevent the expansion of unemployment, nothing to protect employees, nothing to prevent the large companies from only to pushing part of the population into misery!If this report is due to earnings, it is that it has made it clear that the working majority of society has nothing to hope for with regard to maintaining or even improving their conditions of existence..(FR) By voting against this report, we speak for all those who have expressed their rejection of a world in Seattle and everywhere in Europe that is reduced to a pure market logic.We vote against this report in the name of the development of public services, especially in memory of the victims of the train accident of Paddington, whose death was not inevitable, but was in the account of the absurd striving to give competition where regulation would be necessary.This report is basically a primitive elaborate that is inspired by nothing else than the law of the jungle, because the competition cannot solve any of the problems that humanity faces at the beginning of the new century.Be it the balance of the biosphere, the promotion of culture or cooperation with the Third World, the uninhibited competition is a factor of regression and uncertainty.Do you think that the 18 million unemployed in Europe are victims of being too tentative of this competition policy?We are convinced of the opposite, and we also do not believe that the state aid are generally too high.According to which iron rule, according to which effectiveness criteria should you be?After Seattle, do you think it is serious to support a larger role of the WTO?So much throatness only fits the legal advisors of the multinational corporations.Report Jonckheer (A5-0087/1999).(FR) I welcome the quality of the seventh report on state aid in the EU, the annual publication of this report and the fact that the general directorate on its website spreads general information that is intended for the public.I am happy about the rapporteur's approach with regard to the state aid.Too often, one tends to scourge state aid as a violent measures.Certainly, an efficient competitive policy is a prerequisite for the proper functioning of the internal market and the economic and monetary union.Nevertheless, as the rapporteur emphasizes, such aid is often essential, not only as a contribution to the survival of one or the other company, but also for sustainable development (Article 6 EGV), to the service of general interest (Article 16) and on economic and social cohesion (Article 158).But of course they have to be checked, and this is the task of the European Commission.The aid granted annually by the eum-member states to the sectors that came into consideration in the period 1995-1997 to a total of 95 billion euros, of which 40 % of whom went to the processing industry.These aid has decreased significantly compared to the previous period 1993-1995 (decline by 13 % of the total amount and 3.8 % to 2.6 % of the aid volume for the processing industry).The decline in the aid is essentially explained by the reduction of the aid for the new German federal states.

It must also be clarified what to do if state aid is declared illegal.How can we ensure that illegal state aid are repaid?There are no common regulations in this area at the moment, and we are emphatically asking the Commission to harmonize the regulations for repayment.This is the right way to create similar competitive conditions.As already mentioned by some colleagues, we also suggest a register and also a "scoreboard", from which it can be seen which level the countries have with regard to state aid.Here, Mr. Monti, we have taken up your suggestion regarding the internal market index regarding.This inspired us to propose the same for state aid.I very much hope, Commissioner Monti, that you will support this proposal and I look forward to your comments and your opinion.Finally, I welcome the XXVIII.Competition report of the Commission, which, like previous reports, was well done.However, as I said, our primary goal must be transparency and openness.It is important to constantly develop the transparency and openness of state aid and to direct our efforts to these areas.This is not least important for the upcoming expansion.I would like to thank Mr. Jonckheer, who deals with the associated problems very thoroughly in his report.He examines how we can ensure that these countries meet our requirements, but also how equal competitive conditions are created.Of course, liberal and green different views are about how the world should be, but we largely agree on the goals and will try to find a reasonable solution to our problems.President, Mr. Commissioner, we simply have two questions to answer.Are state aid for companies or agreements between companies in a market economy legitimate, and who should control these exceptions from the absolute rules of the market economy?At the first point, we clearly say that if the requirements of sustainable development that the European Union strives to be taken into account, state aid must be granted to the company, be it in the form of tax exemptions, of differentiated taxation or simply by direct aid.It is also legitimate that there are agreements between companies or self -limitation agreements that make it possible to reduce the negative effects of the competition with regard to social or ecological demands.So we say clearly and clearly, yes, it is legitimate that there is aid and that there can be conventions, but we also say that each of these agreements must be expressly justified.The Wogau report suggests that the control of the legitimacy of such measures are transferred to the national responsibility.We see a certain danger in this, but we will still vote for it, because we see that the Commission cannot do everything.We demand that the greatest transparency be kept and that the Commission granted more reconciliation to check the legitimacy of these exceptional regulations afterwards.Mr President, once again we debate about the competitive policy of the European Union.But - under what conditions this pronunciation actually takes place and what conclusions should we draw?

with the greatest possible weight.Europe is not there to wage war somewhere, but to work together so that there is peace and stability all over the world.I thank Mr. Solana very warmly and give the word Mr. Poettering on behalf of the group of the European People's Party European Democrats.Thank you, Mr. Poettering.It goes without saying that a contribution by Commissioner Patten would be to speak later.) Good, thank you.Ms. President, Mr. Commissioner Patten, Mr. Javier Solana!Usted no es una persona loca, Todo lo contrario.We welcome the quick progress that were reached after the Helsinki summit.It is known what important role you played.I am also pleased that in this context you mentioned Mozambique and the great humanitarian aid that can be provided with these means.Of course, we cannot talk about foreign policy without mentioning Chechnya.My friend Jacques Poos will speak in the name of our faction afterwards.At this point I want to concentrate on Kosovo.The situation in Kosovo shows all too clearly that military means cannot bring about a long -term solution to the crisis there.The KFOR armed forces have performed important and invaluable services there and continue to do so, but armored cars and rifle defense cannot solve political problems and ethnic contrasts in the long run.

The Council consults us and the Parliament provides its opinion.We want an intergovernmental conference, but not this.Is a CIG needed?Of course, but not of this type.It is necessary to go much further in the agenda, it is necessary to be much more daring in the themes that the intergovernmental conference will face, more transparency and greater democracy are needed.Greater democracy means ensuring greater participation of Parliament, allowing the Commission to exercise even more - yes - its initiative capacity.It is also a question of placing clear objectives.The functionalist method has exhausted, for better or for worse.So far we have arrived with the functionalist method.We have undoubtedly achieved results, but now we have to make a qualitative leap;In politics, Mr. President in office for the Council, this means persuading the other community partners that now the worst would be myopia.Mr. President, honorable deputies, at this point, arrived at the end of the debate that I listened to with great attention and interest, I would like to formulate some reflections to complete the guidelines and speeches that I had the honor of keeping in front of you in the past few weeks, alongside President Prodi.Mr. President, honorable deputies, your two speakers, the honorable Dimitrakopoulos and Leinen, in their report, the result of an extremely precise and serious work, have proposed the adoption by the Parliament of a formal opinion, pursuant to article 48 of the Treaty, so that, thanks to the adoption of this opinion, the intergovernmental conference can actually start on February 14, as proposed by the Portuguese presidency.For our part, having, pursuant to the same article 48 of the Treaty, developed the opinion required of the Commission, we are satisfied that this conference can be started, among the other before what we had initially imagined.We know, and I am also aware of this, that the next few weeks will all be extremely useful.I would simply like to formulate some observations based on reading the opinion project and on the interventions of the oratories of the various groups.First of all, the Commission includes honorable deputies, the fears expressed by many of you regarding the breadth of the agenda of the conference.I understand this concern and the fear that the agenda is too rich.However, I believe that we can work, as I had already affirmed at the following Helsinki in front of the Constitutional Affairs Commission, on the basis of Helsinki's mandate.It is in this perspective and in the field of this mandate, using all the sentences and all the interlinees, which the Commission has worked on the development of its opinion.We have not limited ourselves to what are improperly called the three left-over.Like the honorable Corbett, I also do not like the term "left-over", which transmits the feeling that it is three minor or importance themes.Instead, these are three extremely serious, important and difficult issues, so demanding that Amsterdam was missing the collective political courage to treat them thoroughly.For our part - I reply to the honorable Seguro, who expressed a few indeed his concern about this question -, we were not satisfied with dealing with these three aspects, while considering them priority and worthy of being treated now.

This is consistent with the fundamental principle of non -discrimination enshrined in the founding treaties of our Union.Marinho Report (A5-0003/2000) :.(SV) The main task of the intergovernmental conference that is approaching is to reform the EU against the incorporation of new member countries.That is why it is obvious that we support the formal approval of the European Parliament to the realization of this conference.However, we believe that the Intergovernmental Conference should be limited to necessary issues for the realization of the extension.We held the same in November 1999, and, for this reason, we want to refer to our vote explanation of November 18, 1999..(FR) In the opinion that has just adopted about the next intergovernmental conference, the European Parliament appeals to "launch a constitutional process."This will to put all nations under a legally superior text is also expressed in the first meetings of the scope responsible for the elaboration of such a called letter of fundamental rights, which is actually an undercover constitution.It is even expressed in the incredible derives from the European Parliament that today, through the vote of a resolution, aims to erase the result of the free elections held in Austria.The same will to bring nations to the level of mere subordinate administrative regions transparent in all pages of the opinion prepared by the Intergovernmental Conference Commission.The main idea is to generalize the voting by qualified majority, while the content of this qualified majority is modified to transform it into a double simple majority, of the states and the peoples, in order to increase the margin of maneuver of the commission and to reduce that of the minority states.The French will undoubtedly have much interest in knowing, incidentally, that the commission asks for the modification of article 67 of the Amsterdam Treaty to establish the vote by majority and the codecision with the European Parliament.Recall that this article, which deals with the transfer of immigration policy in the community field, provided that for five years the decisions had to be taken unanimously by the Council, which would later be in charge of appreciating the possible opportunity to modify the system.In France, in the National Assembly and in the Senate, at the time of ratification, many parliamentarians calmed down saying that the Council would be free to choose and that it could conserve unanimity.However, today, the European Affairs Minister who prepared the Amsterdam Treaty and that after the years it has become a European commissioner, Mr. Barnier, proposes that in the next intergovernmental conference it is decided that the council treats these matters by majority.This is the type of gear to which we are incessantly subjected when European integration is played with the Brussels institutions.The French must be aware that not only the end of all these operations is to make their The two great resources of the Atlantic coast, closely interconnected: fishing and tourism, have been seen harshly affected.There is a risk of losing the season and dragging at the end of the year an extremely serious crisis.Therefore, it was fully justified that our Parliament elaborated a new resolution to which our group has contributed very importantly, emphasizing some points that we consider on the terrain as of the first order.The first of these is that who pollutes must assume all their responsibilities.In our resolution, the application of two principles is requested: that of "who pollutes clean", since it is not admissible that the cleaning of the coasts contaminated by a cargo of hydrocarbons does not run in charge of the owner, but of the public communities, that is, the taxpayers, that is, the victims.The second principle is "who pollutes pays."Its responsibility, as required in our resolution, must also cover the sectors and companies of fishing and aquaculture.It is essential;This wants to say that the pollorer cannot pretend to limit the amount of the compensation of the victims depending on the maximum set by the fipol, that is, depending on the goodwill of the large oil companies.If the maximum limit of the fipol is insufficient, and is clearly underestimated, it must be increased.This is requested in our resolution.And if the increase is insufficient, the polluter must finance the rest.It would be particularly wicked that an oil company, whose benefits amount to ten billion francs this year, would refuse to indemnify 100% of its own victims, the vast majority of which consists of small businesses and workers.Malparada populations, Mr. Commissioner, hope that concrete signals of solidarity will be manifested at Europe.In our resolution, the commission is requested to take measures to contribute to repair the damages caused in the fishing sector affected by the consequences of the catastrophe.Blue Europe, the PPC, must now show that, beyond the obligations imposed on fishermen, solidarity is not a word that ignores.The European Union must also participate in the recovery of the environment in wet areas and affected coastal areas whose biological value is of interest to the entire union.Mr. Fischler has just told us that he would favorably welcomed France's requests, something that congresses me.In this essential theme of marine pollution, we must act as Acicate.Twenty years after the catastrophe of Amoco Cádiz, the laxism and irresponsibility in maritime security, along with their fruits: new black tides.This time inertia should not succeed.A general maritime security framework must be defined by respecting the principle of subsidiarity and finally ending with this infernal spiral of generalized irresponsibility.Mr. President, the economy of the West Atlantic is affected, covered by the Fuel-Oil of the Erika.Fishermen, ostricultures, mollusc breeders, tourism professionals, local and I too would like to congratulate the honorable Hudghton for his relationship and support his changes to the original proposal both in relation to the question of compensation and as regards the development of a vaccine.I think the amendments from n.7 to n.13 are not acceptable and in particular I believe that amendment no.13 Not only is in contrast with the purposes of the proposal, but can make the situation even more difficult than it is, with the currently in force rules.With this I do not want to deny the importance of environmental considerations in relation to fish breeding.Mr Hudghton has already mentioned the final report of the joint British working group composed of government and industry on the infectious anemia of salmon and on the important measures for all fish farms, and not only for those affected by the virus.Secondly, since the proposal for resolution on the Katiforis report will be approved tonight, paragraph 28 is of particular importance.This paragraph asks the commission and the Member States to intensify the measures aimed at combating the possible negative effects of aquaculture on the marine environment.Thirdly, in line with what has been said previously on the collection of fishing data, I hope that the Commission will want to start projects and studies by looking at aquaculture in the environmental context;This is the approach that will have to be adopted in relation to the environment and not that suggested by the amendments by n.7 to n.13, that I hope the honorable deputies will reject.Mr. President, honorable colleagues, do not agree with the satisfaction choir expressed by my colleagues who rejoice in softening a directive that respects the precautionary principle and that adopts provisions to protect consumer health.The infectious salmon disease, caused by an orthomyxomicrovirus that decomposes the blood of salmon by making it die, spreads very easily in salted water through mucus, etc.The 1993 directive allows you to break down not only the sick fish, but the entire breeding, exactly as, when a cow is sick, for reasons related to the precautionary principle, the entire herd breaks down.Now we are proposed to soften this directive to ensure that all the breeding is not demolished, but only the declared sick fish.As for the others, the course of events should be awaited, acting according to the local circumstances.I think it is very serious to proceed in this way and, in this regard, I would like to attract the attention of colleagues because we cannot please us to affirm that a temperature of 27ºC presents all the advantages for mankind and that, therefore, men don't risk anything.And the women?Studies have not been conducted in this sense on human tissues.There is also a risk for the environment, because we know that in salmon the disease has a period of incubation and that, therefore, when these fish are consumed, they can be healthy carriers of the virus, thus constituting a danger.And it is not the only risk that the environment runs, as the disease is transmitted, as we have seen, to non -breeding fish.All this led me, together with colleague Patricia McKenna, to deposit some amendments against the Commission's proposals.

We would like to go further on a number of points.This is why we will vote for amendments 102, 103 and 104 proposed by the Green Group, and which seem to us to further improve our position on these questions.Regarding the policy relating to the price of water, it sometimes happens that extreme situations present themselves which require that there are exceptions in relation to the principles decreed in the report.For my part, I believe that the amendment 43 proposal of the Environment Commission provides for the necessary exceptional possibilities, and that the formulation on this subject is even more satisfactory in the amendment 105 proposal.I do not think useful to provide exceptions applicable to other cases than those indicated in these two proposals.But opinions on this subject are shared within our group.The amendment proposal 107, which relates to this question, has been accepted by a number of us.In a global way, I believe that the proposal of the Environment Commission, as it was submitted to us in the Lienemann report, is valid, and that it can constitute a good basis to achieve a difficult compromise.Mr. President, each photo taken by the satellites proves that we live well the blue planet: this abundance is however an illusion.The very recent disaster that has happened on the course of the Danube reminds us that rivers and rivers are the vital arteries of our planet and that pollution has no border.Water is a renewable and limited natural resource.It becomes scarce when it is not well managed and when the geographic and climatic conditions are not favorable.Within the Union, this question arises in crucial terms in the Mediterranean region, but also in other European countries where we are witnessing the progressive drying up of wetlands.Sensitive, humid or arid areas, inequalities between states, inequalities between the different regions within states, climatic, economic, geographic, geological particularities, are as obvious as we wish to recall, but which must not lead to distortions of competition in the community.However, we have filed amendments to recall the importance of the specific relationship of water agriculture, a capital factor in occupation and enhancement of the territory.It is understood that the needs of agriculture in the South are much superior and that this specificity must be taken into account in this framework directive.It is not only in the States of the Union that we are looking for solutions to these problems: the countries of the Euroméditerranean partnership in October in Turin, asked for the southern coast of the Mediterranean a Marshall plan on water.Fortunately, we are there.In Europe, there are however droughts, desertification in certain regions, but also floods, and the directive highlights it.We have suffered recently in France, and also in the Rhine valley and central Europe.We need this framework directive as an essential element of a sustainable development policy which will have to make the different uses of water compatible.But it is necessary to integrate into this new management the protection and conservation of biodiversity.The "Water" file will not be closed today.Indeed, the question of enlargement and climatic developments open up new perspectives.

In addition to water quality, its quantity is also important, since this is not sufficient throughout Europe, especially in regions with very arid areas.I regret that the curator who is in fact competent in this matter, Mrs. Wallström, cannot be here, since it is of course an extremely important directive, in which the commission has been working for a lotYour adhesion.We have been working for ten years on this issue and this broad approach only became possible after a hearing promoted and organized in 1994 by the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Commission.From that moment to today's second reading, many people have worked hard on the issue in the European Parliament, the European Commission and the Council of Ministers.We managed to reduce the 243 amendments of the Environment Commission to 27, to which they have now been added again, however, another 30. As you can see, many aspirations are at stake and these are very diverse.Some propose to harden the provisions, others pursue greater precision, many are marked by national interests.Also in my political group, the European Popular Party Group (Democraticristians)/European Democrats, had naturally different points of view.Our line is to try to establish realistic objectives and solutions applicable in practice.Some of the amendments that myself and some and some other colleagues have presented in the name of our group improve without a doubt, from that perspective, the requirements proposed in the common position.Some amendments, which we support, propose to strengthen the negotiating position of the European Parliament in the subsequent reconciliation with the Council of Ministers.We clearly reject all the unrealistic demands, which undermine the credibility of the European Parliament.Among these I include the demand for a null entry of hazardous substances, that is, the requirement that it is reduced to zero by 2020. This would mean the end of any type of agricultural activities and many industrial activities.In this context, I would like to highlight once again that, in spite of everything, we have already achieved considerable progress with national and European laws on the protection of the current waters, however incomplete they are and although the member states have respected little.I just want to remember that we now have salmon in the RIN, something that would have been unthinkable 20 years ago, and that even in the Elba, which suffered a particularly high contaminant load, salmon will be re -introduced.Which does not mean that we do not have to continue making enormous efforts to continue improving the protection of water and to preserve surface waters and groundwater still in good condition, which will also take rigged, which doubts, high costs.Precisely in recent days many concerns have been expressed from the agriculture sector.Agriculture also needs to have non -contaminated water in sufficient quantity to develop.With the orientation that our group has maintained in the negotiations with the Council of Ministers it will be possible to achieve a favorable solution for agriculture.

We need more police forces;The available forces are absolutely insufficient.We need independent justice - which will certainly be difficult to set up - as well as funds for the High Commission for Human Rights.All this must be done, and quickly.If we do not quickly bring our aid, the situation will deteriorate and it could result from new conflicts and crisis situations.This is why I think we have done well to act quickly, accept the urgency and release funds.Only, we want to see the acts and successes won in Kosovo and I pray to the Commission to ensure the good implementation of these resources, in particular with regard to the development of the police and the implementation of justice.Mr. President, I first thank the deputies, and in particular the rapporteur, for the promptness with which they dealt with this subject.This will undoubtedly allow us to quickly pay help and to face the concerns of which Mr. Swoboda as well as Ms. Pack told us.It seems to me that three types of fundamental concern emerge from this evening debate.First, although we have progressed a lot in this regard, we could cite the customs administration, the banking administration, the tax administration, it is true that we still have a way to go.To finance what?This is the first point where there is a certain divergence.In one of your amendments, you suggest establishing more limited the kind of institutions to which the Union financing contribution.For example, amendments 3 and 5. Nevertheless, in our eyes, we should allow, in both cases, a greater margin of handle at the United Nations administration which knows the situation on the ground than us better.We believe that predetermining the destination of resources at the moment would create additional practical difficulties.Ultimately, we will have to trust those who, in the field, can make certain decisions better than we do.The second concern, which some of you share, it seems to me, it is Mr. Bourlanges who expressed it first, but others also expressed it concerns the problem of other donors.Does the commission make an excessive effort when others do not put their cooperation in work?Some amendments in your report go in this direction.Amendments 1, 2 and 4, for example.I would tell Mr. Bourlanges and those who raised this point that the fundamental problem does not reside in the mind, which we are completely sharing.The fundamental problem is that it is true that the distribution of the effort between the various donors is currently based on the declarations of the High Level Steering Group, but it is no less true that they have no legal value, they constitute only a political commitment.This is why we would ask, we have also provided a note to Mr. Brok in this direction, that amendment 1, whose spirit we accept, is written otherwise, so that it does not suppose conditionality to the supply of community resources.

although Parliament has been demanding this for a long time.In practical terms, this means for the next time for these regions that it will be degraded into a deteriorated zone edge .(In) Mr. President, approval by the Council of the Project of Agreement regarding judicial assistance in criminal matters between the Member States of the European Union is approaching.The predominant opinion is that it was time.According to the Action Plan to fight against organized crime, adopted by the Council in April 1997, the work on the agreement related to judicial assistance in criminal matters should have ended before ending 1997. And it must still spend more time until the agreement enters into force, since it must be ratified by the Member States.In spite of the new norms introduced by the Amsterdam Treaty, which provides the entry into force of the agreement as soon as it has been approved by at least half of the Member States, I would like to urge the Member States not to escape efforts to accelerate its ratification.The experience of previous cases of ratification of the European Union agreements in the field of judicial cooperation in criminal matters is unfortunately disappointing.This agreement will not create a new or different system of mutual assistance.On the contrary, its objective is to improve the already proven and experienced mechanisms that have been in force for a long time, such as those provided for in the European Council Agreement on Mutual Assistance of 1959 and the Benelux Treaty.The project that has prepared the Council contains provisions on a series of issues that have been debated by several deputies.One of the outstanding achievements of the agreement is that, as far as possible, the Member States that receive the request for assistance must follow the procedures and procedures indicated by the Member States that submit the application.This is especially important regarding the possibility of using the evidence obtained before a court.Likewise, applications may be made directly among the competent authorities, without the need to go through the central administration.In general terms, there are two types of provisions: those that establish the obligation to provide assistance, such as provisions on the telephone and videoconferences, controlled deliveries and about the intervention of telecommunications;And those in which this obligation is not established and that only a legal framework for Member States who wish to cooperate in the prescribed manner, for example, provisions on mixed research equipment, undercover investigations and shipping and notification of procedural documents.The Commission welcomes with special satisfaction the inclusion of provisions related to new or modern investigation techniques, given its effectiveness in the fight against the type of crime that is more likely to take advantage of the opening of borders;Organized crime.It is too easy to get carried away by the obvious need to improve the effectiveness of criminal investigations.However, we must not forget a common aspect to any action related to criminal procedures;The right to defense.I greatly value that Mr. Di Pietro's report, whom I congratulate for the excellent work he has done in such a short time, includes the right to defense as one of his main points.Currently, Member States are the only ones responsible for guaranteeing respect for this right, subject to the control of the Human Rights Court of the European Council of Strasbourg.

The reproach is not new.Since Europe has been trying to do something in terms of development cooperation, efficiency and quality of this assistance have been disputed.Hope for improvement is threatened with disappearance if the committee continues to refuse to look in a mirror.Why was the critical report on the consistency of the development cooperation policy was not disseminated outside?One of the essential conclusions of this report concerned the internal contradictions of European policy.In the agriculture and trade sector in particular, European policy is in contradiction with development cooperation policy.We do not manage to provide serious help in the development of the least developed countries.This is due to the differences in points of view between different countries of the European Union with regard to development cooperation.We no longer have to consider development cooperation as an instrument of foreign affairs or external relations, but rather as an autonomous political field.I plead in favor of a policy of cooperation in transparent, united and efficient development.As long as the European approach to the problem of development cooperation remains a cause of ineffectiveness and waste of money, it is preferable that this role is devolved to the Member States.Finally, I would like to ask the Commission to transmit as soon as possible in Parliament the document I have spoken of, so that we can think positively about the solutions that it would be possible to provide.Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Dear colleagues, I think this initiative is a relevant and completely supposed initiative.As many colleagues have already said it before me, we often see very contradictory situations between what we claim to do with the development and cooperation policy, on the one hand, and what we defeat, on the other hand, with other sectoral policies whose interests are contrary in terms of development of these same countries.We are not only talking about the concrete impact of our common policies, tourism, the environment, agriculture, fishing and industry.We are generally talking, what is more serious, of contradictions between our economic and commercial policies, on the one hand, and our defense policies, on the other hand.Finally, there is a set of contradictory situations.In my opinion, contradictions are not so serious in terms of community policies;They are more serious with regard to certain objectives and certain industries of a few Member States.We must be aware of it.On the one hand, we often adopt resolutions on the peace processes in other parts of the world, as we have done very recently in the case of Indonesia, a case to lift the embers in heaven, and then we note, on the other hand, that certain European countries supplied this country with arms and war material.This is in my opinion what are the most serious contradictions in this area, more serious than the contradictions of a certain incompatibility of sectoral policies, which of course exists.It is obvious that there are always contradictions between the different policies, even in a given country.It's normal.At the European Union level, we must also be aware that there will be contradictions between the various common policies, in this case in the development policy.We must be aware that these contradictions exist and that it is necessary to minimize them, this objective of minimizing contradictions being a fair and wise objective, at the base of the presentation of this resolution.

In the same way, as regards the judicial and criminal matter, of which we discussed today, I believe that they should not only be coordinated the different criminal, judicial and administrative legislative systems, but that it is also necessary to finally reach the formulation of common rules: what is crime in Italy must also be such in Britain, Spain and so on.I believe that we, parliament of the European Union, representatives elected by citizens, must be given the greatest impulse to reach a European Union that provides for the regulation of all sectors of citizens' lives, including that of justice, as well as that of pensions.We will vote against this relationship;In fact, allowing the cross -border interception of telecommunications and overturning the burden of test, the agreement will offer a favorable legal context for large -scale electronic espionage operations in the EU.This means making an electronic espionage system such as the American operation Echelon in Europe perfectly in Europe.This agreement will be a source of serious abuse against individual privacy rights.It is a terrible threat to civil freedoms in the European Union.The following points are also unacceptable for us: common investigative teams, supervised deliveries, infiltration operations, inaccuracies of the text on the extent of the agreement, failure to respect for the principle of proportionality and deficiency of democratic guarantees.Resolution on the strategic objectives 2000-2005 of the Commission, the president of the Prodi Commission has stated that "the responsibility for Africa falls on us" and not, apparently, on the United States or on some other great country.I worked in Africa 30 years ago;It was then a poor and underdeveloped continent, but later his problems worsened in a catastrophic way.Last year in Africa two million people died of AIDS, while about 200,000 died in war.In Zambia, 25 percent of teachers died of AIDS.In some countries, in the field of basic education and health care, children had better perspectives twenty years ago.Our Policies for Africa lacks consistency: there is an uncontrolled overlapping of initiatives, and above all the debit boulder still barrs the way to real development.It is clear that Africa is now a forgotten continent.In his communication on the strategic objectives 2000-2005, the Commission reiterates the need to make Europe a "global actor" who makes his voice heard in the world strong.What should be the goal of this global actor?The citizen probably expects an answer that provides for a better defense of European countries, since this is the essential and traditional mission of the political association.Well, a similar answer does not appear anywhere.There are general phrases on the "strategic partnerships" and the new possibilities for the development of the exchanges that would apparently derive from the complete integration of Europe.That the main objective is omitted is a very indicative fact that highlights one of the serious gaps of the European Union - a little known gap, almost always implicit, but which largely explains the disaffection of citizens.In the work program for the year 2000, attached to strategic orientations, there is a very significant passage in this regard.

During this visit, as requested by the honorable deputies and by others, I will inaugurate the European representation in IME.The deadline set for the conclusion of the negotiations is December of this year, but everything will depend on large extent on the goodwill and determination of negotiators.The agreement could enter into force within three or four years, taking into account the time necessary for the ratification in the parliaments of the Member States.I would like to express some comments in short on several points contained in the resolution project.We recognize that the agreement must to a certain extent serve as an example for other such agreements, even if we take into account the fact that we deal with different countries, each of which has its own identity and
