Mr. President, I have had the privilege of listening to the commissioner to demonstrate on several occasions on this matter and I agree with his approach.However, I would like to ask something different.We have just heard the commissioner Barnier that he has a great interest in improving communication with the population and focusing the commission's information policy towards the main issues that the community will be held during this year.Would the commissioner be arranged to defend that part of the commission's budget is destined to inform and consult citizens on this issue of citizens' letter?It is very important that the population feels participating in this process.I know that the agreement will have a great impact in this regard, but does not have the resources available to the Commission.Will the commission study the possibility of using your budget to ensure the participation of society in this debate?The commission policy is to promote an open and broad debate on the letter of fundamental rights, not only with non -governmental organizations, but also with citizens, especially in the case of a project of repercussions as broad as it is the case of this letter.I can assure you that the Commission will do everything possible to promote the debate on the future letter of fundamental rights.The best means of making the most of it is to have a clear text, a text that citizens can read easily and, at the same time, a text that serves as a legal instrument.Both are not incompatible at all.The challenge we face is to combine both concepts in the final version of the letter.I am very happy to know that I can count on your support in this regard.Question No. 40 Formulated by (H-0095/00): Subject: Section 1 of article 6 and sections 1 and 2 of article 7 of the Treaty of the European Union section 1 of article 6 of the TUE stipulates that the Union is based on the principles of freedom, democracy and respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms.It is evident that, as can be deduced from the statements made over the last years, Jörg Haider and the Liberal Party of Austria do not respect human rights or fundamental freedoms of nationals of third countries and resident minorities in Austria.Thus, can the Commission indicate when you plan to verify, by virtue of section 1 of article 7, "the existence of a serious and persistent violation by a member state of principles contemplated in section 1 of article 6", and urge the Council to which, by qualified majority, suspend certain rights derived from the application of the treaty to Austria, in particular the right to vote of the representative of Austria in the Council?Mr. President, lordship, allow me to begin by remembering the position adopted by the commission - and this morning the Roman President Prodi- has reiterated again regarding the composition of the new Austrian government, of which ministers from the Austrian Liberal Party of Jörg Haider.I naturally refer to the statement that the Commission issued on February 1, 2000 and whose essential lines I will begin by remembering.

It is important in my opinion that the Community initiative can be started promptly and that the report receives the approval of a large majority, so that the Commission is also induced to take into account the constructive proposals of the European Parliament.In fact, it should be remembered that Parliament has enrolled Equal's funds in the reserve, so that even the opinions of the deputies could be reflected in this community initiative.The insistence by the European Parliament is therefore justified so that any modification of the priorities is possible only on condition that the Parliament will be consulted again.I am firmly willing to make the Equal initiative worthy of the name.It should ensure equality of opportunities to all people disadvantaged in the European Union and prevent social disintegration.It should also prevent exclusion from continues to be a daily reality.Finally, it should offer everyone the opportunity to benefit from a community initiative, regardless of age, sex and origin.This is what I propose to do and therefore I invite the assembly to express a convincing approval to the report!Mrs. President, the simple fact of keeping today's discussion on the new Urban Community initiative constitutes in itself a not negligible success and it is no small thing for your rapporteur to be here tonight, since Air France has canceled my flight at 14.10, but I did it the same!A year ago, when the Commission presented the proposals for Agenda 2000, cut the Urban initiative.However, we politicians knew of the growing wave of support in favor of the continuation of this initiative in 2000. Parliament can therefore take the merit for the positive outcome of the campaign in favor of Urban and for having convinced the Commission and I recommend returning to its steps.Policy for urban areas has always been in the top of the community policies.In my Member State, by way of example, we are developing a strategic approach in a white paper and a government taskforce on urban areas has been commissioned to follow the problems of urban communities.Since eight out of ten Europeans live in urban areas, it is legitimate to help our communities less favored to face limited problems, such as indigence, social exclusion, unemployment, crime, drug addiction and all related problems.In my region, for example, Manchester, the Urban Community initiative has achieved enormous successes.The funds as Urban were invested in one of the poorest neighborhoods in the United Kingdom, Moss Side.Thanks to the Park of the Millennium Park for young people (Millennium Youth Park), we try to involve young people again in activities intended to revitalize their communities and also thanks to support for small businesses and social policy we begin to see a clear recovery in an urban community that was very disadvantaged.The work done in the context of this Urban program was then released to an extensive community through communication initiatives and information campaigns in local supermarkets and in the famous British pubs.We would like these examples of good practices to widen to the whole union through information and awareness campaigns.The specific guidelines of the initiative are essentially intended to promote local and regional diversity.

These services are also a strong and not negligible element of civic ties.In fact, as has been remembered on several occasions, is the postman is not the last contact in the territorial areas that define themselves in depopulated or disregarded, whether it is isolated geographical areas or the peripheries at risk of our cities?I quote as an example the initiative of the French Poste, who made the commitment to ensure the presence of interpreters and public scribes in the post offices of degraded urban areas.Without considering the loans in the induced, the European public posts currently give work to one and a half million employees, that the spectrum of brutal and uncontrolled liberalization jeopardizes.The European Parliament is proud to have managed to reconcile the opening to the competition and the constraints of a universal service that respects employment needs.We rejoice, but we want all this to continue.For this reason, we can only deprecate the fact that the European Parliament is held today on the margins of the decision -making process that supervises the destinies of the postal sector in Europe.It is deplorable that to date - as is underlined in the resolution - the Commission did not take into account the resolution of January 14, 1999 which imposed, we remember, that the European Parliament was associated with the processing of the expected measures and that the reliability of the impact studies on liberalization was increased.These studies are necessary to evaluate the effects of any type of uncontrolled liberalization not only from the point of view of the economic organization of the market, but also as regards the human and social dimension.The delays accumulated by the Commission affect the proposed calendar and the 2003 date must absolutely be reconsidered.By defining a sector reserved for public postal operators, on the basis of weight and price limits, the postal services directive allowed gradual and controlled liberalization.The drastic reduction of these limits questioned the balance between the obligations of the public service and the economic validity of postal services.In a context of globalization, in which the logic of profitability and profit is increasingly opposed to the concerns of balance of the territories and social cohesion, it is essential to remember our attachment to the European public service, be it post office tomorrow the day after tomorrow health.Mr. President, I intervene to protest, like other MEPs who represent Scotland, against everything that would decrease the quality of life in the most remote rural areas.The service and post offices are an element of vital importance for rural communities throughout Europe and, in particular, in Scotland.It would be a disaster if, intentionally or not, we were to start actions that would damage them.I don't think someone intends to do it, as I don't think the commission has decided to declare war on the islands of Scotland or Greece.However, the commission could involuntarily cause very serious damage to these communities.The point is to determine at what speed and with what methods the gradual liberalization of postal services should take place.

Social, economic and cultural phenomenon, tourism concerns the majority of European citizens, whether as beneficiaries or as very diverse service providers.Each year it is nearly 200 million Europeans who leave their usual place of residence for a time in order to do tourism, most often in other European countries.In addition, Europe remains the main tourist destination of third countries, even if it has to face increasingly strong competition and an increasingly diverse and attractive offer.As soon as the treaties do not provide for a specific legal basis for the implementation of a real community tourism policy, the European Union must help improve and encourage cooperation in this sector, while respecting the principle of subsidiarity, in order to concretize the potential that tourism offers in terms of employment.Vocational training, the mobility of the workforce represents essential instruments of an unemployment control strategy in Europe, in particular, with regard to tourist service providers, in order to meet the multicultural demands of demand and in order to provide appropriate customer services.Tourism employment is, often, highly seasonal and precarious, which is an obstacle to its sustainable development.It is therefore all the more urgent to acquire and disseminate know-how in terms of management and technology in order to promote new production methods and to promote a tourist offer that best meets market development.The adoption by the Member States of tax measures favorable to SMEs in order to reduce, in particular, the charges that weigh on the work factor would, as the report indicates, an excellent way to promote employment growth, in sectors with a high intensity of workforce and, therefore, in the tourism sector.This field of activity is also a decisive element of the economic and social development of the least favored regions: I am thinking in particular of the ultraperipheral and island regions, whose assets in the matter are not questionable.Let us not forget that, in these UlTraperipheral regions, tourism represents the first industry in terms of revenue.The revenue and employment induced by tourism contribute to a large extent to reduce imbalances and encourage a convergence of their economies to the average rate of community development.In addition, tourism can promote a certain cultural and economic rapprochement, insofar as it allows greater awareness of different European cultures and thus contributes to the development of respect for European lifestyles.It goes without saying, therefore, that tourism, developed wisely, in the long term, must represent for local economies a source of sustainable income while safeguarding and valuing landscape, cultural, historical and environmental wealth.Finally, I would like to emphasize the primary role that the European Union should play in favor of new tourism forms, in new places: I think precisely and in particular to introduce Europeans, continental, the most distant European destinations, the Ultraperic regions.Mr. President, we have launched a great debate on very little because, ultimately, the basic document is nothing more than a communication from the commission which follows the conclusions and the recommendations of a high -level group on tourism and employment.Not only is a question of little but, in addition, the document we are talking about is a bit old, since it is dated April 28, 1999, that is to say almost a year ago.

I therefore address an appeal to those ministers so that this agreement does not frustrate, achieved with great effort.I would like to invite the Commission - and I am pleased that the Commissioner Solbes is present tonight - to promptly present this multi -year funding program, with the relative report, as the Parliament asked, so that it can be taken into account in the development of the preliminary project of the next budget, in line with what has been promised to us.Finally, I would like to remember that, despite having just agreed 35 million, we know well that it is an insufficient palliative;As soon as possible, we must reach an agreement on a multi -year program for the necessary reconstruction of Kosovo.Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I apologize for the delay, due to the other theme which unfortunately also appears again on the agenda today.The Commission for Foreign Affairs, Human Rights, Common Security and Defense Policy recommends freeing 35 million euros because money can really be used for the benefit of affected people.Although the reasons for criticism - essentially the lack of the will to help Kosovo's populations - are not very serious, we will continue to be critical.The procedure would certainly find itself in a much more advanced phase if the Administration of the Council had not forgotten to promptly inform the European Parliament and to transmit the documentation through the official channels and had not thus prevented us from opening an in -depth debate on the matter.I undermine the administration to take the necessary measures to avoid similar omissions in the future.In fact, we give up on the necessary consequences from what has occurred only because the interest of the affected populations is careful.Before freeing the funds, however, it is essential to fix some conditions.The first is that the money must be destined for reasonable initiatives and not to those who could use it for other purposes.That is, the money must be truly assigned to the sectors of competence of Mr. Kouchner and not to others.Even if the Commission and the Council have taken on a different position due to the difficulties of realization of our proposal, we then believe that the other donors must also honor the commitments made.It is a mission led by the United Nations and it is not acceptable that the only one to respect the commitments is the European Union!In the interest of the victims, other donor countries must also honor their promises within the course of time.This leads me to support the need to deal with the question much more in -depth way, not only in reference to this specific project, but with regard to all aid for the development of South -Eastern Europe.In fact, they show that the European Union is willing to help allocating funds, but that the concord of political leadership is missing.We have such a large number of coordinators, called to report to such a large number of superiors, which we will soon be called to establish a coordinator coordinator.Perhaps, however, a meeting between the competent authorities of the European Union and the other institutions, from the ISCA to the United Nations, may prove to be more constructive, in order to sift and establish a new unitary and coordinated procedure to provide effective aid to local populations.

I would like to request what new initiatives can take the advice to preserve the interests of these farmers in the next world trade negotiations, in particular in the face of large-scale and industrial style production of the United States and New Zealand, where economies of scale make it extremely difficult for European family farms to remain competitive and where, of course, European food security standards do not apply.I fully understand the concerns of the deputy and I can see that we need an effort and a certain coherence including within the European Union with regard to this matter.It is also necessary to think of the consequences, especially in terms of financing and compensation for farmers.However, as you know, this question depends on the European Commission, which will have to develop it.The council has a limited intervention capacity in this area.Mr. President, allow me to congratulate me on the presence of the president in office in this enclosure.However, I do not think he answered my question which specifically concerns the treatment of the problem of the homeless and the accommodation.I also asked if the Portuguese presidency planned to meet non -governmental organizations actively engaged in this area.I appreciate and make mine without reservation on the need for multiple policies and a multidisciplinary approach, as well as on the need to combat the underlying causes of exclusion, which can cause homelessness, not to mention drug addiction.My question concerns the homeless more precisely.It is to know if a new presidency could take a new initiative to try to overcome some of the difficulties to which the President in office alluded to the intergovernmental aid.I have the feeling that Europe can play a very active role in this regard, if only using forum where the Member States can exchange their experiences and the practices that seem to give the best results.Mr. MP, with regard to the possibility for the presidency to support the actions of non-governmental organizations, in particular in the specific case of the fight against the problems of the homeless, I would like to say that this type of initiatives is welcome and we can no longer open to any possibility of supporting them.We have collaborated with Portuguese non-governmental organizations and with some of their initiatives presented in the action of the Portuguese presidency, which we connect to all the concerns underlying our own program.We have no concrete specific initiative in the matter, we are therefore not closed to the hypothesis of an initiative of non -governmental organizations which would be offered to us in this area during our presidency.Initiative which must be part of the capacity of the council.But it must be understood that everything that could affect the right of initiative of the Commission will of course go through the Commission itself.Mr. President in office, you have told us a lot about the future: what the Commission will do, what the presidency will do in Lisbon, etc.And you made us an announcement that terrifies me, Mr. President.

Instead, a minimum of certain rules is absolutely necessary, valid within the community, with an obvious increase in guarantees at the maximum levels, precisely also to precaution in view of the expansion.I think of what this community could be, these conventions or judicial relationships if, for example, a fascist country like Turkey adhered to the European Union: I would be truly perplexed.It is necessary to have a corpus juris - and everyone said - and common rules, especially procedural, which guarantee a state of common law throughout the community.It is obvious that this is mainly the subject of the CIG and that it is an aspiration for which Parliament can contribute in a limited way as it all depends on the Council and the Commission.I believe that this first semester, in which the commissioner is Portuguese and the presidency is held by Portugal, is an excellent opportunity to give a first impulse to this common aspiration.Precisely for this reason we are in favor of the amendments nos.78 and 79, which already prefigure a minimum of certain rules on interceptions and videoconferences.On the one hand, we look forward to the outcome of this vote with great attention, just to prevent there from being a total emptying of this convention - which, I repeat, already establishes minimum rules - and, on the other, we are also in favor of waiting for any proposal that comes from the Commission so that this minimum community right is finally realized.Mr. President, in the face of the growing crime phenomena organized internationally, the Member States should undoubtedly collaborate with each other as much as possible, indeed, the institutional conditions should be placed to start a concrete and effective process of cooperation in the judicial field: the process that must however face all the stages necessary to prevent them from being inappropriate to the detriment of the legitimate national indications in the field of justice,sovereigns, and above all to avoid forcing that end up trampling on the fundamental rights of citizens.It is therefore necessary to proceed with caution in front of a document like that of the Council where, as underlined also by the speaker, after years of discussion it is now claimed to resolve everything in a few months.Furthermore - and I agree with the assessments of the honorable of Peter - the text of the Council appears all too rich in contradictions, inconsistent formulations and gaps.And justice, more than other sectors, cannot obviously be treated in an inconsistent and contradictory way.In our group's opinion, the report also appears as a whole still very questionable, despite the introduction of some corrective amendments, sensitive to the protection of personal freedoms and respect for national sovereignties.In the report there are too heterogeneous disciplines, there is no graduality and we proceed by approximation.In conclusion, we will vote against this report, reiterating that the Europe that we hope must be a Europe of rights and guarantees: rights and guarantees that demand gradual and responsible reflections, as well as very serious insights.First the general rules must be established, the institutional certainties, and only afterwards can the establishment of practical conventions be carried out.

Finally, I would like to point out the question of liability.Not only with regard to the maximum amounts that, in my opinion, the North American must be similar.We have set $ 180 million;In the United States, one speaks of one billion dollars as an upper limit for compensation.I believe that we have to increase the current amount and approach a level that is similar to that of the United States, but that we also have to rethink the amount of insurance and thus the liability of the shipowner and involve those liability those who charter the ships, the owners of the freight.As long as one does not require the responsibility of the freight owners, the problems will not be finally regulated in my opinion.I come to the end, I don't want to go further.We will have the opportunity to do this.However, as a speaker said - and I thank everyone for their absolutely constructive and apt contributions - we must not allow us to say again in one or three years in two or three years that we would not have done what we should have done.On my part, I can say that after I have discussed this in the college of the Commissioners that the Commission is ready to present the legislative measures, the changes and the guidelines that are necessary to provide us with the highest possible security standards.The political will of this parliament - and I find that I can count on it - and that of the Council of Ministers.Thank you.Mrs. Commissioner.We have taken note of your willingness.According to Article 37, Paragraph 2, I received eight decision -making applications to conclude this declaration from the Commission.The pronunciation is closed.The vote will take place on Thursday at 12 p.m.Storms in Europe According to the agenda, the Commission's explanation of the storms in Europe follows.The word has the word on behalf of the Commission.Mr. Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your words, especially for the very concrete suggestions for the victims who expect a lot from the European Union.Personally, a few days after this terrible storm, I asked you to request an adaptation of the Ziel2 areas from the French authorities so that all regions damaged by the storm are eligible in France and in other countries under target 2.I think that has happened because they didn't say anything about it.We all know that if you do not meet the criteria of goal 2, you have the greatest difficulty to get help.So it is better to help this problem immediately.They also know that this problem not only faces itself in the short term, but also means and long -term.Let me explain that.I was in Lorraine when this terrible storm destroyed about 20 % of the deciduous forest.Damage of 20 % means an enormous loss for some forestry communities.For example, we know that a tree is only fully grown after 150 to 200 years.The loss for these communities will therefore not extend over one, two or five years, but over a much longer period.

However, much attention should be paid to your viability.For this, we must take into account natural base emissions that are not influenced, as well as diffuse emissions, difficult to control, which also substantially contaminates the waters.Mr. President, in the 21st century we have to assimilate the fundamental notion that our relationship with water has been completely modified.In the twentieth century, the aquatic medium was for us a free system for spilling and elimination of poisons, special waste, chemicals, etc.The consequences are already visible!We have to modify this way of thinking and recognize that water is one of the most important elements for our life and our responsibility in this aspect extends far beyond our current generations.The directive must also be explained in this context and the population must be able to clearly understand what we intend to do in this area and that the commission is proposed to do.Water protection is also in the background a social issue, and a decisive social issue.This is why it is necessary to strengthen the application of the principle that "who pollutes, pays", otherwise everyone has to carry the consequences.In view of the progressive deterioration of water resources, it is important that we do not limit ourselves to preserving its current state, but in tomorrow's vote we seek to ensure a real qualitative improvement.Mr. President, about six years have passed since our colleague Karl-Heinz Florenz, supported by Ursula Schleicher, asked that all policy be reorganized in the field of water.It has already been done.It is not an easy matter and I think that the effort made by Mrs. Lienemann deserves all our respect.The decision -making process around this framework of the Water is in a very important phase.The issue has been raised in accordance with the codecision procedure and in the first reading we have already been able to adopt important and more adjusted legislation.The community position that was raised at the end of last year already meant an important improvement with respect to the original proposal.It is very difficult to adopt policies in this area because the differences are very large.I want to say the following to my Spanish colleague: in northern Europe we have had to fight very often against floods, and also against water pollution, produced by the industry, while the problem of colleagues in southern Europe is usually that water must be transported through long distances, simply to supply drinking water or water for agriculture.Let me abound in two elements of this proposal.First, quality.The Netherlands are greatly influenced by European policy on waters.A very important part, a third of the drinking water we consume, is extracted in the Netherlands from surface waters.The Netherlands are located downstream, in a delta, and therefore the quality of the surface waters that reach us is of the utmost importance.Another important point of debate is the establishment of standards on water quality.In a series of amendments, questions have been raised regarding the proposed standards, especially to the OSPAR standard for 2020.

The new element in the Urban II initiative is that it has been designed for small cities and for urban neighborhoods.This is important, because precisely small cities often have worse possibilities of obtaining promotion resources.On the other hand, however, in such cities, precisely, the problems that lead to the renewal become necessary are concentrated in a special way.In order to increase the effectiveness of particular measures, the number of Urban II projects has been limited to 50.I consider it important that this numerical limitation is not maintained rigidly, arbitrarily established, but is left to the hands of the Member States in how many projects they want to distribute the corresponding promotion resources.However, it is necessary to ensure that precisely in small member states are not only the neighborhoods of the big cities the beneficiaries of this aid.In them Urban II would be nothing more than a drop of water on a red stone, it would have a doubtful success and faded.It is also important, in my opinion, that they do not expand excessively, and consequently, the selection criteria for Urban II are not distorted.Precisely a catalog of rigorously delimited criteria is the previous condition for projects that are subject to promotion to have model projects and can be transferable in the future to other cities with problems.Finally, from my own experience in communal politics in a region, industrialized for many years and with many problems, I would like to ask for, dear colleagues, which especially support two points of the report that I consider essential next to the socio -political aspects.In the first place: the aspect of environmental protection is inalienable for sustainable urban development and, consequently, should be a general requirement for the financing of a project.Secondly: the prevention and the fight against common crime and against the crime of drug trafficking in cities must be included locally.These are inalienable for the elevation of the quality of life in cities and, consequently, must also play a central role in the Urban II initiative.Mr. President, distinguished speakers, dear listeners, I congratulate the speakers, who have made very documented reports in a short period of time.However, within my group, the calendar of the work of preparing the parliamentary commission has been criticized.The reports arrive late and, in addition, their processing has been very precipitated, at least in the Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism Commission.Therefore, we have lost a good opportunity to talk about the results of the previous programs, their deficiencies and the appropriate execution methods.In the field of the Interreg program, my group highlights cross -border activities and, particularly, cooperation with territories outside the borders of the Union.Important regions are, among others, the Balkans and the Adriatic area, but I think that we should not forget the cooperation we carry out with Russia.My group wants to bring out the control of the use of the funds and wants to highlight the need for better coordination of interreg, tacis, ISPA and Phare programs, among others.

The courtyard indicates that these problems now appear and it designates measures that can be taken now to mitigate the problem.However, as Marinho pointed out, we need more, but that must wait for the CIG.In my own country, mythology talks about the swarming hordes of faceless bureaucrats in Brussels but it is never mentioned the number of European judges.There are less than three dozen at the head of the European judicial order - which is far from excessive given the responsibilities relating to their tasks to the curriculum of the European legal system.Their great importance can be noted at the level of political implications of the delay taken in the resolution of the suffering conflict between France to Great Britain with regard to British beef and which has aroused so much anger in my country and so much frustration due to the functioning of the procedures for resolving the Union conflicts.This situation has been aggravated, this is what some of the people who advise me believe, by the French Code of Procedure which places non -French nationals almost in the impossibility of translating the French Government into court.The thing is certainly perceived de facto as being impossible.This situation offers a very unfavorable contrast to the British courts where Spanish fishermen has successfully brought to justice the British government in very similar circumstances.Mr. President, what is happening in France seems primary to be a case of discrimination against other EU nationals for reasons of nationality and, consequently, this situation seems to constitute a violation of the treaties.I would therefore like to ask the commissioner, who was kind enough to comment on my remarks during the previous debate, to examine this and to share his conclusions in Parliament and to myself.I would be grateful to the commissioner if he could confirm, in his final intervention, that it will be so.Mr. President, on behalf of the President of the Commission, Mr. Prodi, I would like to make the following answer.The Commission takes note from the point of view adopted today by the European Parliament as to the request of the Court of Justice and of the Court of First Instance which aims, on the one hand, to entrust the court to examine certain appeals which are currently emerging in the exclusive jurisdiction of the Court and, on the other hand, to increase the number of members of the court.On behalf of the Commission, let me add that I listened with great interest to the arguments that have just been put forward in this enclosure and that I very well understand the concern that underlies these arguments.The concern is legitimate.It has also been said that a delay in justice is a denial of justice.The Commission includes these considerations.Understanding them, I would like to continue my response as follows.As your parliament knows, the Commission is convinced that, without a deep reform, community legal bodies run the President Arafat will meet the Council of Ministers next week.The meeting will represent an excellent opportunity to deal with the need to take courageous actions in order to improve the Palestinian administration and strengthen the rule of law.The Commission is actively involved in such efforts.The Commission also increased the support for regional cooperation projects between Israelis and Arabs.Last year we engaged over 20 million euros for these projects.The package included renewed assistance for people-to-people and cross-border cooperation as part of which Israelis and Arabs meet at the level of experts and non-governmental bodies.The deputies will remember that the European Union is the greatest financial donor in the field of global efforts aimed at reconciling the population of the Middle East.Numerous issues naturally emerge as potential additional objectives of Community support in the next phase of the peace process - among them, to encourage the consolidation of a settlement in the Golan contributing to the safety agreements and supporting the deserting work and reconstruction of the Golan Hall Communities.Syrian economic development will require assistance for the transition from an economy of war to an economy of peace.The reconstruction and restoration in southern Lebanon, the only Middle Eastern area with an ongoing military conflict will also require significant efforts.We must also continue to provide our support for economic reform and social development in Lebanon as a whole.It is necessary to find a solution to the problem of Palestinian refugees, which constitute the largest group of refugees in the world, reaching almost 5 million people, an indicative figure of the arduous challenges that await us.We must support initiatives aimed at increasing the availability and improving the distribution and management of the very low water resources of the region.Last point, but perhaps the most important, we must encourage closer regional cooperation in different sectors, bringing together all the countries concerned in a joint effort to deal with their common problems.It is already evident that the financial resources currently available for community assistance in favor of this part of the world will not be sufficient for the level of support that will be necessary in the event of permanent peace.I want to underline this point.I want to remember with a certain insistence on the Council and, if necessary, to Parliament, that we must not continue to allow a gap between our rhetoric and what we are actually able to do.I repeat that a modification of the Middle East policy will require a turning point in support that we will be called to provide and we will expect from us.I hope to add that we would like to provide it.We have made progress in recent months and weeks, as Minister Gama has said a little earlier, but it is inevitable that it will be a hard process of difficulty and disappointments.We will do everything possible to encourage a positive conclusion of the process and to cope with the obligations and challenges that will achieve it.Finally, I will repeat for some coordination and evaluation of progress made within the framework of social policy and that of the job market.

In many respects, the treatment inflicted on the original inhabitants of the United States of America goes against the most fundamental human rights.The history of Dineh Indians is significant.With the discovery and - certainly - the exploitation of black gold and, later, uranium and oil, all means were good to chase these populations of their land and send them to regions offering few other perspectives than poverty, deprivation and pollution.The Arizona region, which must become the new Dineh Indian territory was affected, in 1979, by the largest nuclear disaster known by the United States.We therefore plan to send the last 4,000 Dineh Indians to these lands.The struggle of these Indians is supported by more than 250 NGOs and we were made aware of this situation thanks to the action of the Belgian organization for Mother Earth.It is also significant for American society which has hardly heard of it.They are very careful about wars and genocides taking place in other parts of the world but they unjustly ignore the genocide which takes place in their own country.Today, the Dineh Indians begin their last fight for their right to land, their right to dignity and, above all, their right to choose their lifestyle.However, there are only a few while their opponent is a very powerful economic fact.Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I join the many remarks made by the previous speakers but I would still like to emphasize a few elements.The Dineh people are one of the Navajo Indians in North America.They have been faced with exclusion and have been fighting for survival for decades.They have lived for many years in heartbreaking conditions.The conditions of poverty in which they live forces them to give in, on the ground floor, to the financial and economic pressure exerted by the mining industry.The reimplantation law introduced in 1974, which aims to a new distribution of the Navajo reserves, authorizes the displacement of population groups.These re -implantations are naturally unacceptable because human rights are flouted, both economically and culturally.The Dineh Indians are moved like pawns and lose in the adventure not only their history and their essential land for them - the land of their ancestors - but also any prospect of work and source of income.The reimplantation law was pushed to the congress by a group representing the mining industry.Congress has never asked itself the question of where the inhabitants of the region should go and what influence would have this re -implantation on their lives.The population did not have a voice in the chapter.It looks like human trafficking.The reimplantation was carried out and the Dineh people were moved to a region polluted by uranium.After the rupture of a barrage in the New Mexico in 1979, and the release of 370,000 m3 of radioactive water and 1100 tonnes of pure uranium, this place is one of the most polluted regions in the world.

dissupped.The most effective prevention is to run the risk of receiving strong financial sanctions to all potential pollution.Katiforis Report (A5-0017/2000) we agree that fishing activity is one of the most interested in promoting respect for the marine environment.But it is necessary to take into account that many causes contribute to the degradation of marine spaces: pollution by oil tankers and other maritime transport, industrial activity, the pressure of human activity over coastal strips and, naturally, uncontrolled fishing activity.However, it should be noted that small -scale coastal fishing is a good illustration that it is possible to combine a fishing activity with sustainable and non -aggressive development for the marine environment.We consider that it is possible to However, I think that we should do everything to limit the transport of dangerous goods as much as possible, and this in all countries, whether they are regions of transit or not.Mr. President, I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Koch, of his magnificent work and his positive collaboration with the Commission to improve texts, present this report and this proposal;In the end, only an amendment was presented, which relates to the requirements applicable to the aptitude examination of security advisers for road transport, by rail or by the navigable of dangerous goods.We believe that collaboration, common work on the part of the two Parliament and Commission institutions is important and that the cooperation that exists with the regional policy commission, and concretely with the transport group, is magnificent.The common position includes practically all the amendments accepted by the Commission, harmonizes the minimum requirements applicable to the examinations of security advisers and, second reading, we can accept the proposed date, much more realistic than that projected at the start by the Commission, knowing that this has already been debating this question for several years.Very briefly, I would also like to thank the various deputies for their interventions and say that security is a priority of the commission in the field of transport.As Mr. Simpson said, it should never be considered that the process is acquired, that it has resulted.The process of increasing margins, safety guarantees in transport is a process that should be improved day after day.In this sense, I would also like to tackle the problems of the tunnels very briefly, to which MM.Rack and Swoboda have referred, and which, in the case of Austria, undoubtedly constitute a very sensitive subject, which is why it is necessary to make efforts to see how to increase their security.During one of the major accidents that occurred lately, the goods transported was not dangerous in itself.Margarine and a few pounds of painting which did not present any risks, caused a real disaster.It is therefore necessary to study the way in which the requirements can be adjusted even more in order to guarantee maximum security.Finally, I would like to say that it is necessary to approach the safety of all types of transport.This week, we will organize a debate here to talk about the security of maritime transport, following the Erika disaster, and we will have to discuss objectives throughout this year in terms of security, air transport.But I want to say, ladies and gentlemen, that security is a priority objective of the Commission.As I will say during the debate on Erika, we do not expect that a disaster occurs to devote body and soul to the aspect of security, but we work on it on the sidelines of these circumstances, which only highlight the urgency of an effective response to this type of problem.

This is a subfolite for European citizens who have often expressed their concern in view of European politics in the food sector.Her concerns that our European Parliament took up were heard.The European Commission caused the debates on the precautionary principle as well as questions of traceability, responsibility and transparency to publish a white book on food safety.This white book shows several considerations, and above all it suggests the creation of an independent European food authority.All of this is part of a European strategy to regain the trust of consumers.Now, the European managers, we have to prove that the internal market and free transport of goods must be reconciled with food safety!Report Cederschiöld (A5-0008/2000) Mr. President, I voted for this recommendation for the redesign of copyright protection law because I consider this to be one of the most important areas of the activities of the European Parliament.In my opinion, the product of intellectual work is much more important than the finished constructions, the objective products that we can see and touch without any doubt, while spirit and science produce results that cannot be touched by hand, which are, however, invaluable.As a European community, we should therefore support them far more powerful, not only by the way of patent protection, but also by promoting and supporting the scientists, those who, using their knowledge, do everything for future generations to offer much more than we used to have.In principle, we are against the fact that the European Community concludes contracts for copyrights on behalf of the Member States.

And finally, and I end with this, the requirement is relative to the future powers of the European Parliament in the matters that occupy us, the policy of competition and state aid, in the perspective of the intergovernmental conference.Our report, as you know, Mr. Commissioner, defends the idea that the codecision procedure is in force for the base legislation on state aid..(De) Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Lords, my participation in this debate has as its subject the code of aid to the siderurgy, that is, the public aid granted in Europe in accordance with said code and controlled by the Commission.In 1998, a total of 27 cases were examined, on which the commission has prepared its own report.The CECA treaty will expire very soon.Therefore, the issue that today should worry is above all of the future application of the aid to the Serurgy The European Parliament hosts with satisfaction the decisions presented by the Commission in its report, including that relative to the return of an aid received in a specific case, in application of article 88 of the CECA Treaty.The most recent communication of the Commission, which has not yet been discussed in Parliament, also refers to the issue of the competitiveness of the European steel industry.The general prohibition of public aid established in section 1 of article 87 of the CE Treaty also applies to the ferrosist industry, as well as to the other sectors.In accordance with this article, state aids are incompatible in principle with the common market. Exceptions are only admitted in exactly defined cases.In accordance with article 88, the Commission has the obligation to control state aid.In 1998, the most important case was the contribution of its own capital for an amount of 540 million euros to the PREUSSAG company in Germany.Member States must also communicate to the commission the aid that are proposed to grant.The standards applicable in the Siderúrgic Industry sector were established on December 18, 1996. In accordance with them, only aid in favor of the steel industry can only be granted in certain exactly defined cases.This is: research and development aid, environmental protection aids, social aid to promote the closure of steel facilities and aid for the definitive abandonment of the activity in the case of non -competitive companies.In addition, there is an exception for Greece, with a maximum limit of 50 million euros.In recent years, there have been, however, obvious problems in the practical application of the Serurgy Aid Code that are not exposed in all its details in the report.From the point of view of Parliament, it is important that you begin to discuss a consecutive regulation for the moment when the current code of aid for the siderurgy expires.The fundamental lines of said code should not be softened.No one wants to open the doors to uncontrolled competition based on subsidies in Europe.This would seriously affect the operation of the internal market, even after the consolidation of the steel industry in recent years.The Parliament considers it necessary, therefore, that the code of aid for the aid is modified as regards the inequality of treatment denounced by the industry and that the commission present to the Council a consecutive regulation.

Mr Pietrasanta illustrated the reasons why we support some aspects of the Commission's proposal, in particular those relating to the development of a vaccine and the introduction of compensation for breeders who are forced to bring down their fish.However, we are not happy with the prospect of changing the demolition policy.It has been said that Norway has done a better job than ours in controlling the salmon infectious anemia epidemic and that the proposed changes will align us more to the Norwegian approach;It must be said, however, that there is more than some differences between Norwegian and Community politics, which will also be applied in Ireland, my country of origin, in the unfortunate event that similar cases should occur.There are other differences between the two policies regarding the inspections on the disease, the periods of inactivity, the restrictions of movement of the fish and contaminated materials, and so on.Before falling to copy the Norwegian demolition policy, we must try these methods to see if it is possible to reduce the extent of the disaster.In the past there has been talk of ESB, and for many years the Greens asked to face the problem related to this disease.If you had done it, they could have saved many breeders and he would have spared a lot of money on a community level.The problem also concerns the protection of the environment, breeders and public health.I would like to thank the honorable Hudghton for the excellent report on the infectious anemia of salmon and for having supported the measures proposed by the Commission;I also thank all the speakers for intervening the debate on the subject.The Commission's proposal is aimed at ensuring a more pragmatic approach towards the control of a disease that has the potential to cause large losses to salmon farms.This approach, however, will not have to affect in any way on our goal of reducing and, if possible, eliminating the disease and cannot be adopted if the proposal contains a threat to public health.In addition, it is necessary to seriously consider the environmental implications.Experts say that the infectious anemia of salmon is considered a non -pathogenic disease for men and mammals.From the moment of his appearance, in 1984, no case of infection in humans or mammals has been ascertained.The virus affects cold -blooded animals and does not reproduce at a temperature of over 25th centigrade.Although it was present in fish intended for human consumption, it would be made inactive once ingested.In any case, infected fish cannot be intended for food use and, as an additional precaution, I confirm this concept to the scientific committee.During the debate, several important issues were raised in relation to our disease control strategy, including that of compensation.I regret a lot of the losses suffered by the Scottish salmon industry.As you know, starting from January 15, 2000, the Member States can promote the eradication of the disease in aquaculture with the help of a new financial instrument aimed at providing information on fishing.The commission services are developing some implementing rules that will allow the practical application of this tool.The decision of the Council 90/424 constitutes another Community financial support tool in the event of the onset of diseases.

Madame Rothe, I'm going to express myself as follows: I am convinced that the current context has improved to reach such agreements.I have no commitments at the moment.I do not wait for them either before we started direct discussions.They will come later.The context has changed that Helsinki's decisions made a large number of things finally possible and above all that the participants completely changed their political strategy.I have always thought that the old position, according to which Cyprus would only adhere once the political conflict has been regulated, received a weakness, in the sense that it did not convincing the Turkish Cypriot community to really get involved, because, faced with this strategy, the Turkish community had nothing else to do their arms and wait.The question of the membership of Cyprus would not have been raised.Now, the Turkish community must seriously count with the risk that Cyprus really integrates the European Union, with the growing prospects of well-being and security which result from it for the Greek community, while the Turkish community, already much less prosperous, would continue to be distant.I am therefore firmly convinced that the motivation to link the peace process to the settlement of the conflict has increased enormously from Helsinki.It was also the underlying idea.After a few weeks, it is still too early, Madam, to already deliver an assessment, but I have no reason to assume that the new course of action will fail.There is no reason for that.There is still no reason to say that we will succeed but I can really say that the conditions for progress have improved considerably.Last point, the Cypriot question obviously plays a role in discussions with Turkey.During my meeting with the Turkish Foreign Minister a few weeks ago in Brussels, I naturally asked Turkey to adopt a positive and constructive attitude towards this issue.However, I issue the following reserve: we cannot be certain a hundred percent - I would like to know if the document that the committee has just presented provides for such a clause.Thank you very much, Inger Schörling.These are two important questions.I am happy to have the opportunity to clarify them.No, we should not start with a cost-benefit analysis, but to base ourselves on an evaluation of what we know, what science can teach us and how we must consider it in relation to the risks that we believe to exist for the environment or for the health of men and animals.On the other hand, when we have decided to take a certain measure, we must then choose one that has a good cost-effectiveness, so as not to adopt completely absurd measures from the point of view of efficiency.So do not start with a cost-benefit analysis.The other question concerns the reversal of the burden of proof.It is quite correct that we need to apply it in some cases.I took the case of the strategy with regard to chemicals as a good example of a domain where it is necessary.This is indeed this area, but we can say that this communication on the precautionary principle is horizontal;It concerns all specific political areas.This is the reason why it is not particularly a question of reversal of the burden of proof in this regard or what the burden of proof will look like, but it is rather the political decision-making and the foundations of it.However, it is absolutely exact that we must, for example, when it comes to chemicals, take care to obtain a reversal of the burden of proof.Mr. President, I think that, to function, the precautionary principle should be quite radical, otherwise we are constantly lost in the tortuous meanders of interpretations.Take an example: it is shown that an anticryptogamic product gives birth to blind children;He is therefore teratogenic.Very well, it is an anticryptogamic, an antimstotal.It is a British laboratory that has proven the teratogenic effect, the only one perhaps, however, to have done tests.Well, in my opinion, since the threat is also serious for health, the precautionary principle requires that the product is immediately withdrawn from trade, as did New Zealand for example.I would therefore like to ask the following question: when human health is at stake, or when serious effects on human health are possible, should we analyze costs and profits?A blind child is too high a price in my opinion, no profit could compensate for it.I would like to know if, ultimately, the precautionary principle as you understand it, the commissioner, would presuppose in this case that the product is removed from the sale until other laboratories provide the contrary.Mr. President, I am the first to hope that we can use the precautionary principle so that it is considered radical in terms of protecting men's health and the environment.
