judges, when it is the national judges,apply the European competition law;From the commission I expect that it focuses on the essential elements in the fulfillment of his mandate as a maximum custodian of the European competition policies.I am curious to see which form the wide discussions will take when they up to the first legislative proposal.The Commission report confirms that, with the exception of Germany, state aid to companies are increasing and this worries the Commission, not only from the point of view of the conditions of competition.As far as we are concerned, we set ourselves in the perspective of the interest of the working classes.The company does not take any advantage from these enormous transfers of public funds to private companies.Just look at the automotive sector, in which various grants and aids of the states increased by 24 percent during the reference period.For what purpose?Not to maintain employment, because all these companies have suppressed jobs and proceeded with layoffs.Not to improve working conditions, because by making a fewer number of employees produce the working conditions worsen.Did these companies need state help to survive?No, businesses in the automotive sector collect colossal profits for years.State aid not only have perverse effects, because as they recognize in the report of the honorable Jonckheer cause the hunt for the grants through transfers of activity from one country to another, but are also unacceptable, because they use public money for the enrichment of a handful of private shareholders.The fact that wherever the richest with the state money are favored has led in the whole of Europe to deteriorating the social state, to the abandonment of public services, to the closure of hospitals.

Faced with this world framework for change we have to find the position that corresponds to us.Fortunately, EC's help evaluations give us an important means of improving what we are doing and hopefully also overcoming the challenges I just mentioned.To occupy in more detail the results that the evaluations have given, I would like to mention the following problems: the objections of community policy are too numerous and too imprecise and that negatively affects coherence.This situation is due to the complexity of our own structures, but also to some very clear inconsistencies between sectoral policies and interests of the Member States.The Commission has a help system that is too complex and that is too fragmented in terms of instruments, procedure and institutional mechanisms.Often the policies are more determined by the instruments available, than by the objectives they had and for clearly defined priorities.Human resources are too scarce in relation to the volume of aid that we are supposed to manage.On average, for the management of ten million dollars of aid there are 2.9 people in the commission, compared to 4.3 at the World Bank and between four and nine in the main Member States.This raises a real problem: there are many and very different financial instruments, each of which has its own characteristics and particularly a series of different budgetary titles.It is difficult to harmonize this situation with the needs of an effective management system.In order to face these problems and solve them, the community has to establish an effective dialogue with the Member States and Parliament.It is absolutely indispensable that we address the issue of coherence in a realistic and pragmatic way, which means that we must sustain the debate in the appropriate institutional framework, that is, in the Council and in Parliament.The lack of concerted action between the 15 Member States and between them and the community also requires study.If we focus on the community development policy on strategies and objectives agreed at the international level, we will prepare the way for a better complementarity with the Member States.This largely coincides with what the Amado Minister has just said.When we talk about policies today, we are referring to a convergence process.This already gives us a part of the solution.We are in the process of formulating new regulatory guidelines and we have to identify priority spheres for community action.Everything is increasingly complicated.The same can be said of development cooperation.There is not a single donor that is in a position to deal with the entire range of issues, ranging from macroeconomic issues to the regulatory framework or from sector policies to a diversity of new interrelated issues such as gender, the environment, good public management and institutional reforms.It is important to find flexible mechanisms that can accommodate a division of labor according to the technical knowledge and the ability of the various donors in each developing country.This must be done at the level of the Member States and should lead us to the formulation of sector policies for community action.That is what we want to get.To identify the priority areas of support of the CE, the specific characteristics of the community in relation to the Member States and with international institutions must be taken into account.

This current economic context is very present in our mind, since the objective of these restructuring is to rationalize the management of companies.While it is plausible, from the economic point of view, to make structural modifications to be more competitive and gain market share, this analysis can be condemnable when it is carried out at the request of the financial, often shareholders, with the only purpose, unconstable, to increase the financial values ​​of these companies, and thus be able to increase the benefits that they will obtain.In this sense, the different recent ads, mentioned by my colleagues, both in the case of Michelin and in Goodyear, are symptomatic.A rationalized management, as well as an improvement of the results -in my opinion, and by order of priority, must be at the service of the company and, therefore, of the workers, and then, eventually, the financial consequences that arise from it.However, today we attend a phenomenon of concentration, regrouping of companies and relocation, with the consequences we know - both with respect to the quality of the products and the social plane specifically - from the point of view of unemployment, of more difficult working conditions, of greater flexibility, consequences that are dramatic in the human level, especially for the family cell.There is, therefore, the danger of the planet becoming a two -phase: on the one hand, poor countries, labor suppliers and, on the other, rich countries, capital suppliers.Should Europe be the barrier to maintain some balance between greater profitability and greater well -being?Do not forget that what basically makes a company work and have good results is human capital.To conclude, I will remind you that the third letter of the name of the EDD group, to which I belong, means "difference."Europe has the duty to make its voice heard as an alternative to non -planned restructuring and with a view to "all benefit", the voice of the difference in this uniformized wave of restructuring.Mr. President, last month in the United Kingdom, in a region adjacent to mine, the Michelin group announced a considerable number of layoffs at its Stoke-on-TRent plant due to the company's restructuring and the increase in global competitiveness in the world market of tires.I, like all the deputies present, regret this loss of jobs.In the same way, I regret the announcement made by Goodyear that has led to this resolution.But, certainly, I doubt that a European Employment Council would have been able to change this business decision.This assembly is very good by issuing resolutions and legislating and sometimes, in this institution, we forget that Europe cannot survive alone.We need multinational companies that base their businesses on our continent.In the few months that I have been amazing here that while we all talk about encouraging companies to grow in the EU, practically all the resolutions that we approve encourage them to abandon it.In our last plenary session of Brussels we vote the directive on vehicles at the end of its useful life and we try to make their standards retroactive, adding huge costs for European car manufacturers that could not have planned.Two days later, Toyota, who employs several thousand people in my region, announced that this directive would not only increase the cost of cars but also could lead to dismissals in his derbyyshire plant.

And this, because this agenda is limited to only three subjects which concern in a fragmentary manner only two of the institutional bodies of the European Union.I will not repeat them, moreover, since they are known to everyone.This finding is justified on the one hand because of the permanent demand which is made, sometimes very intensely by European citizens, and on the other hand because of the enormous dimensions of this large company in which the European Union has already launched, that of enlargement.With this data, the new intergovernmental conference cannot fail to include subjects on its agenda whose treatment would guarantee the regular functioning of all and not of a few European Union institutions.As also he should understand subjects that affect daily life, and therefore obvious in the eyes of the European citizen.Mr. President, dear colleagues, the European Parliament, during numerous discussions and having regard to the many reports established so far, has openly formed in favor of the summons of the intergovernmental conference.At the same time, I ask, however, that subjects that improve and complete the reform, and I repeat, of all institutional bodies be included.But it would also be necessary to add subjects which directly concern European citizens.As for example, health, energy, culture, transport, even tourism.On the one hand, the question of whether the extension of the agenda will be achieved is still under discussion.And at this stage, I would really like to emphasize the political conduct of the Portuguese presidency, which, repeatedly, has committed itself before the European Parliament to deploy all its efforts in this direction.On the other hand, the question of the increase in the number of discussion matters in no way decreases the importance given by each member country to the intergovernmental conference because the institutional framework on the basis of which will evolve Europe in the future is the fundamental principle of European integration and therefore is of supreme national importance for each member country of the Union.Mr. President, dear colleagues, I ask the Assembly, having read this data, to approve the opinion that Mr. Leinen and I presented before you, so that the work of the intergovernmental conference begins on February 14 and that our two representatives to it, Mr. Brok and Mr. Tsatsos, can, in accordance with the opinion of the European Parliament, undertake the difficult work that awaits them.The same goes for the European Commission, and I would once like to thank the Commissioner Barnier for his contacts with the European Parliament and for the very constructive proposals he presented to us.Mr. President, the group of the European People's Party is not satisfied with the outcome of the Helsinki European Council.The agenda seemed relatively insufficient to us, because we were based on the logic of the treaty and, more specifically, on the protocol relating to the institutions of the Union.In Helsinki, governments have agreed to say that as long as the Union is made up of less than 21 states, minimis reform would suffice, but that with more members, it would be necessary reform.

Ladies and gentlemen, this decade maybe, I would even say must be, that of Europe.Madam President, the Chairman of the Commission, dear colleagues, the group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats welcomes this debate and we welcome what the Commission has filed a document to prepare it.We also salute the conclusions we find in this document.In addition, we salute, in broad outline, the speech that the president of the commission, Mr. Prodi, has just pronounced.The conclusions of the document indicate that the five -year mandate of the Prodi Commission will be a major change period.Europe will progress in its integration and the Union will, at the same time, engage a phase of enlargement which will ultimately lead to the reunification of our continent.It is ambitious, we could even say prophetic.Mr. Chairman of the Commission, we wish you that this can succeed in this way.But we also say that the present is the foundation of the future and that we can only shape the future if we are proving in the present.I say it seriously and I say it with concern!I thus discuss the current discussion on the conflicts which divide the European Union at the moment.We, the European Union, are a community!We belong to the same set, even when there are problems.It is not the time not to isolate but to bring together and to carry out, together, this work of unification of Europe!Mr. Chairman of the Commission, in recent weeks, you have represented and defended the European Parliament on several occasions.You have considered yourself the Guardian of Treaties - which is your role.We expressly show you our respect, recognition and support for this, including for the letter to the Federal Chancellor of the Republic of Austria that you mentioned.(Applause) Mr. Chairman of the Commission, we agree with you on the objectives: in the 21st century, we want a strong Europe, which has the capacity to act and which is democratic.A Europe that defends its values ​​of human dignity, democracy and the rule of law, both inside and outside, and which at the same time ensures its interests in the world with dignity, patience and convincing confidence.The message of Europe, of the European Union, in the world cannot be arrogance or even European nationalism, no;Rather, it is to fall under cooperation, partnership and peaceful development.Globalization therefore represents, for us, the possibility of organizing this world which is getting closer more under the sign of peaceful competition and solidarity.Seen from this angle, globalization presents more chances than dangers, more comparisons than separations, more mutual enrichment than limitation.But we also know that we cannot meet these major challenges of globalization that together as Europeans.Globalization is not only an economic process but also a cultural process.We therefore say that we want a partnership in the world, we do not want - as some predict some - of a confrontation of cultures, of a clash of civilization;Rather, we want partnership, meeting, exchange and peace.

In this area it is also proven that the structure of the economy differs from one state to another and that the roads by which the current level diverge has been reached.Therefore, it is not good for a single policy to be applied, which would probably be full of exceptions and adaptations.It would mean that the Member States be private without apparent foundation of some tasks that correspond to them and that the Brussels bureaucracy intervenes without the need for it.It is preferable for Member States to adopt themselves measures that foster employment.Obviously, they understand more of this matter than the commission.Hence my reluctance regarding the adoption of community measures regarding employment promotion, even when it comes to the tourism sector.It would really cause us a great disgust that, despite everything, the Parliament tried to achieve this goal unofficially extending its competences.Mr. President, as you will understand, we cannot subscribe the resolution in front of us in your current version.First, I would like to thank Mr. Viceconte for all the work done in this report.It is a very extensive report.We pleasantly greet this report as we greet the original report on which it has been based, the high -level group report established by the European Commission.I trust that the European Commission does not forget this.Having established it I hope that the European Commission effectively uses it and, therefore, does not allow it to languish in the halls and be covered with dust.Tourism consists basically small businesses and therefore constitutes a very fertile area for job creation.As already said in this debate, three million potential jobs for the next ten years is something that is worth fighting.Europe can no longer reject recognition - both in economic terms and political action - that the fastest growth sector of its economy deserves for its economic and social position.We need a more dynamic vision based on the contribution of tourism to job creation.We must recognize a sector that predominantly relates to cross -border activities and therefore deserves a European policy with a stimulating, innovative and active approach for sustainable business development.I know that the commissioner is very interested in computer science.He has convinced me of it.But their computer and tourism portfolios, in fact, marry together.There are various reasons why tourism is an ideal breeding ground for integrating job creation strategies.Let's look at some of these reasons.The importance of tourism for the economy and its growth potential is evident.Several sectors of the population are used by the tourism industry, especially the most vulnerable groups such as young people, women and workers without qualification.I am not saying that it is not necessary to improve the qualification within the sector - since we have to do it - but we first consolidate the jobs.The availability of non -qualified, temporary and seasonal work is very important in some economic areas of the community.

I will just mention only a few: our ability to combine development policy with commercial policy and to ensure that there are synergies between help and economic cooperation;our neutrality and defense of supreme community interests;The fact that we represent a critical mass and are in a position to face relatively large challenges compared to what each of our member states can normally do.I do not forget our presence on the ground: fundamentally it seems to me that the maximum value we represent is the fact that, being how we are a regional cooperation company that acts successfully, we can see us as an associate neutral and desired for that experiment worldwide;That is something that nobody, apart from us, can pretend.It is essential that community policy be more effective and that we develop a more cooperative strategic framework.That double challenge is the one that the Commission has to face, for which in the coming months you will have to prepare a proposal in the form of a general policy declaration.We will initiate a broad and open consultation process in order to gather the opinions of all the different stakeholders.I consider that this process is almost as important as its content, and we will assign all our resources to an active participation and we will invite everyone to participate with us.At the same time we have also embarked on the process of improving coherence and clarifying and openly highlighting the real or imaginary problems with which we stumble in that regard.That will be a continuous process that I consider as a kind of permanent effort of quality control, and I invite the Parliament to participate in that continuous effort destined to improve the coherence of what we are doing.Mr. President, first of all, I thank Mr. Amado, as well as Mr. Nielson, his words.I am also glad that Mr. Amado has referred to the Fed.The problem is not found here, in this Parliament, and neither in the Commission;The Council must take the necessary steps to establish the Fed budget, therefore, this sermon must really pronounce on the Council.Mr. President, I also thank Mr. Nielson.He has referred widely to the new Lomé Agreement, but this is certainly not the matter of this morning's meeting.We wanted to talk about coherence.That is the subject.Since the early 1990s, the European Parliament, the Commission and the Council of Ministers have recognized that the coherence of European policy does not operate properly, especially in the field of development policy and other policies of the Union.Attention has been requested for this problem on several occasions: in 1992, in 1995 and 1997. All examples appear in the resolution before us.I have asked questions about this issue for years.The obligation that there is coherence is even introduced to the Amsterdam Treaty in 1997. In addition, in 1998 it was agreed that the European Commission prepared an annual report in which the advances made should be collected.But what have we seen since then?Good words, also today, but no report.It is too ridiculous to explain it.

To speak frankly, a hierarchy of oppression was created.And as long as citizens are not equal before the law, this inequality leads to discrimination and erosion of human rights.In our process of expanding within the EU, we have focused, with reason, on human rights and the protection of minorities.We must not derogate from this commitment.But we must also look at us in the mirror and recognize our own imperfections.Yes, conventions have been signed, but we must act.I would recommend that you carry out continuous audits concerning human rights practices, constant vigilance, not only outside our borders but also inside.This is why I would appreciate an annual report on the part of all Member States having to report any complaint concerning him and the action undertaken, because what is happening in a Member State touches us all.What is happening in another part of the world affects us.The case of Pinochet in Chile is as important as that of Haider in Austria.Human rights and civil freedoms are inextricably linked.Human rights do not exist in isolation, they are linked to our development policies, to our economic policies, to our internal affairs policies;They are in fact at the height of our democratic functions.I will repeat what Mr. Patten said: We must commit, we must inform, educate and therefore make real and lasting changes.Mr. President, "Europe represents ideals, values ​​and principles. We must honor the intellectual history of Europe. We must rehabilitate the values ​​that unite it. Intellectual life is part of Europe to spread throughout the world. We must live with our conscience."Thus was expressed three hours ago, in this hemicycle, the Czech President Mr. Vaclav Havel.In a particularly edifying discourse, marked by the knowledge of men, wisdom, historical knowledge and understanding of the intellectual and Christian heritage of Europe, he indicated the sources of inspiration to which our work in favor of human dignity and human rights should draw.We must be grateful that our Europe has heads of state of the caliber of Mr. Vaclav Havel.I would like to mention two subjects.It is first of all that of civil society.Mr. Vaclav Havel said earlier that the communist regimes of Eastern Europe methodically destroyed civil society: popular movements, churches and independent unions.This is what happens in China, with the Falun Gong movement and the Catholic and Protestant churches.This is also what happens to Tibetan Lamaism.We must never forget to defend civil society.I would also like to mention the question of the death penalty.The EU, just like my own country, Sweden, has the basis of a vision of the world centered on equality between men and on the unique and inviolable value of human existence.Starting from this principle, one must always leave the man a chance to return to his actions.It must be said to the government of the United States, the Russian government and the Chinese government.Mr. President, Mr. President in office, Mr. Commissioner, in my opinion, the approach of the EU member states in Geneva should aim to place the situations of Kosovo, Mexico, Saudi Arabia, Sierra Leone and China.

Hence, this first agreement with Macedonia is crucial, since it will be the model.I am convinced that the other four countries wonder: what will happen?What will the European Union do with Macedonia?Will it do the same with us?As that model constitutes the first advance, it is so important.Macedonia is also a model in another sense.The rapporteur has already pointed it very clearly.The question of inter -ethnic relationships.It is not necessary that we reproduce it here in a too idealistic way.During the presidential elections it seemed that it did not work at all so well, but compared to the rest of the region, it could be discussed the Macedonian model.It would earn a lot if we managed to export that model together with the Macedonians to the rest of the Western Balkans.This prototype is also valid in the field of regional cooperation.I agree with the rapporteur as long as a balance must be achieved between, on the one hand, the promotion of regional cooperation and, on the other, maintain the opening to Bulgaria and Greece, and not close it.Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, if we take this first step, he will have won a lot.If we spoil it, it will have lost much more.Mr. President, allow me to record in the first place that I have no problem to approve, in principle, this well -elaborate report.I just want to attract attention to an issue that, in my opinion, has not been discussed in the report and that constitutes a serious problem for Macedonia and for the effectiveness of financial and other help that the EU provides.I speak of the sanctions to Yugoslavia.So that there are no misunderstandings: I also consider it necessary to address the problem of the Milosevic regime with decision.But, in the first place, these sanctions affect a broad and negative measured to many neighboring states, among which Macedonia is, which are in a very complicated economic situation.Secondly, in a politically counterproductive way, the entire Yugoslav people of Milosevic and its clique are responsible, thus violating human rights.Consequently, I believe that, as stated in amendment No. 10, the topic that is discussed today should lead us to quickly end this sanctions policy.Mr. President, ladies, it has not been necessary to end the Kosovo conflict to conclude that, after several wars in the territory of former Yugoslavia with its innumerable negative consequences in the stability of the Balkan zone, a global and lasting strategy for the entire region would be necessary in order to guarantee peace and stability in the sweaty Europe.This strategy, which became a form in the stability pact, approved on June 10, 1999 in Colonia, considers the region of Southeast Europe, but at the same time recognizes diversity and inequality in the development of the various countries that compose it.The contribution of the European Union in the field of stability pact, embodied in the so-called "stabilization and association process", represents the development of the regional conception that the European Community prepared in 1996 for the five countries of the region -bosnia-Herzegovina, Croatia, Federative Republic of Yugoslavia, the former Yugoslava Republic of Macedonia and Albania- and whose most important aspect consisted of the establishment in the establishmentof political and economic conditions aimed at supporting the execution of the Dayton Peace Agreement, which should contribute to regional stability.

Within the Member States, regional disparities deepen dangerously.Just dwell on the data contained in the sixth periodic report to realize the strong acceleration recorded in the last ten years by the regional springs.The attention dedicated to the colossal problems of the union of the union is laughable, when not even non -existent, just as the infrastructure deficiencies in terms of transport, communications and energy condemn these areas to the desolation.Not only regional policy is responsible for this state of affairs, but also the economic and social policies implemented in general by the Union.Vast layers of the population condemn these policies as dangerous and repressive.Unfortunately, the new guidelines do not mark any change of route and nothing lets hypothesize that, with their application, something can never change.Mr. President, honorable colleagues, I am allowed to intervene briefly to highlight two points of the relationships in question, which cover an essential strategic importance in our vision of the union.The first concerns the essential and central importance that we continue to attribute to economic and social cohesion.Therefore, the voices according to which the importance of this objective would be stupid in the Considerations of the Commission are concerned.We continue to think that economic and social cohesion is a central objective of the Union.The second is in agreement with the comments expressed by a colleague on the question of the islands, and I would like to attract attention to the ultra -repenering regions.In the future we would like to be able to ascertain greater courage in the treatment of issues concerning the ultra -aperitical regions such as, in the case of my country, the Azores and Madera islands.I take this opportunity to ask the Commission to explain to us the reasons for the delay of his report on the ultra -aperitical regions that Parliament has been waiting for for a long time.Mr. President, I thank first of all also for the availability to welcome our suggestions in the relationship.Mr. President, honorable colleagues, Mr. Commissioner, the guidelines are intended to provide the Member States with an orientation to achieve the reform objectives in the framework of the programming.However, contrary to the claim to provide guidelines, the indications of the Commission on the matter represent a catalog of possible measures within the framework of the various intervention sectors.Their original sense would instead be to indicate the direction and the priorities.I share the opinion of the rapporteur according to which the Commission document unfortunately contains insufficient recommendations to the Member States to proceed with administrative simplification.I also subscribe to the requests to focus attention during negotiations with the Member States on areas such as the promotion of a favorable environment for small and medium -sized companies with high labor intensity, setting clear objectives in favor of the creation of alternative financing sources, including the programs regarding risk capital and private funding, support services for new companies as well as new information technologies and investments in innovative sectors.In particular, an amendment presented by the political group to which I belong to point 10, aimed at ensuring adequate participation by the private sector in the planning and execution of the projects.

In the fourth place, the Parliament, considering the merits recognized in Life, has enrolled in its annual budget growing amounts intended for this program, so that the approval of the proposal supported by the Council and the Commission would entail an unacceptable turnaround.Our concerns, however, are not limited to financial aspect.Climate change and water resources management policy are a source of great fears for European citizens and have already enjoyed great attention from this assembly.We therefore believe it is essential to approve our amendments nos.5 and 6, aimed at defining the concepts of sustainable management of underground and superficial water and reduction of gases that produce the greenhouse effect, including them among the objectives of Life-Environment.I conclude to congratulate me with the honorable Lienemann for the relationship elaborated and I take this opportunity to communicate to her that, although our preference for the accompaniment of Life goes to a consultative committee - as has been demonstrated unequivocally within the Environment Commission -, we will vote in favor of its amendments on the Committeeology because we do not want to contribute to the realization of the Council's proposal, which we consider frankly.Mr. President, honorable colleagues, Life is the most important financial instrument, the only financial instrument, in reality, of which the European Union disposes that it is intended exclusively for the environment.This tool must therefore absolutely respond to our ambitions, ambitions that undoubtedly have a price.The nerve point of the discussion with the Council will obviously be the allocation for Life III.The common position provides for a package of 613 million euros for the period 2000-2004, an insufficient figure.The liberal group is in favor of the increase in this sum for 850 million euros.Consequently, we will support the amendment of the honorable Lienemann, which underlines how the funds intended for Life have not been the subject of any increase at the time of the last expansion of the Union, not to mention the new round of candidate countries.The funds we request do not represent a mountain of unnecessary expenses.On the contrary, they still do not reach the levels necessary to cover the actual needs.A drop in the sea, I would say, compared to the structural policies of Europe.The environment definitely plays a second floor role within the European budget, although it represents first of all an investment, an investment in natural resources, certainly, but also in employment, since it has been shown that an active environmental policy is able to create new jobs, as it is evident from the great success achieved by Life: a success for NGOs, companies, local authorities, third countries.Almost a third of the 8,500 questions joined were satisfied with the required conditions and about 1,300 projects received a co -financing between 1992 and 1998. A success that, according to the precise will of this parliament, must last over time.Which is why we support amendment no.14 which defines, broadly, the fourth phase of the life of the Life project.When we talk about the environment, investment and ambitions they are realities that must exist on the long term.The future of the new generations is at stake.?(FR) Mr. President, Mrs. Commissioner, perhaps I will repeat what has already been stated by colleagues, but I think it is necessary to reiterate for the umpteenth time, for the benefit of the Council, what we think of Life.

I believe there is an agreement on the fact that the waste and residues of the ships must be disposed of in ports.The logical consequence, it could not be otherwise, is the following: the number one rule for the conservation of seas clean is that disposal on the high seas must no longer be advantageous.This is the point, and we discussed it in this parliament by reaching a majority.In January, Mrs. Commissioner, we held with her a very comprehensive debate on the consequences of the accident of the oil tanker Erika and on this occasion we once again reviewed all the fundamental points to guarantee safe ships and clean seas.Even the directive on port systems for waste and the load residues we are examining concerns precisely what can be done because the seas are cleaner.A single data, by way of information: every year, only in the North Sea, 70,000 cubic meters of waste is illegally discharged and, vice versa, only at the Maxim 5-10 percent maximum of the ships follows the correct procedure, or provides for the disposal of waste in ports.A similar scandal is also unacceptable for the Council.The Council also maintains that all ports must have adequate collection systems and must equip.The conflict in practice only concerns the issue of costs coverage.In the first reading, the Parliament, in a large majority, had argued that the same ships must contribute at least 90 percent to the extent.Here is the difference with respect to the Council which instead proposes a non -defined contribution, but such a contribution could also be equivalent to half a euro, that is, evidently too little in this case: so it would not change anything, there would be no economic pressure on ships to take on a consequent line of behavior.A flat -rate contribution to disposal for all ships is necessary, regardless of the actual use of disposal systems, or the economic incentive to download at sea must fall.In the Baltic Sea this was possible - some colleagues have already remembered it - thanks to the Helmkom convention, which provides for a no special fee system.If it worked there it should also be able to work in the other European seas, because only the environment is not at stake, but the clean waters, tourism, and, fundamental, alongside the environmental considerations, neutrality in terms of competition is also involved.The conditions applicable in ports to ships must be the same for everyone and only if these conditions are set together by Parliament, Commission and Council can be restored the neutrality of the conditions of competition for ports and ships.I believe that the credibility of the union and particularly of Parliament is also at stake.People are tired of the hypocrisy of Europe and ministers in the face of catastrophes, as we have seen in the case of Erika.When the oil is poured on the coasts, the politicians, the ministers appear, and they are busy, each with his own nice bucket to clean the beaches, but when, after two weeks, it is at the age of the day a severe directive, the beautiful words of the day before are already forgotten.

The nature of the Union has not changed.From the beginning, it acted according to some dozens of large financial and industrial groups and the related lobbies.But the Prodi Commission now wants to transform the European Union in order to nominate it to the direction of the world alongside the United States, while entering with them in competition and in conflict.This new imperial policy presupposes the reorganization of European and national institutions, the consolidation of state power, greater competition, the establishment of a European army and the redistribution of financial resources.That you still dare to invoke the defense of a "European social model" is a shameful lie because the more the European Union fights the United States, the more it becomes a clone.We will therefore vote against these objectives as we oppose this policy both within the classroom and on the streets.The elaboration of a European Fundamental Rights Charter would be the only glimmer of light within such a policy, but once again nothing has been foreseen so that the peoples of Europe can be able to deal with democratically.We abstained to vote for the resolution for the following reasons.First of all, the resolution does not report with sufficient clarity the somewhat vague nature of the priorities and commitments formulated in the commission program.Secondly, we believe that, as part of the definition of priorities for the next 5 years, the main question that the Commission must face concerns its role in the framework of interinstitutional relationships within the European Union - and in this context they are not mentioned neither the program nor the resolution.In our opinion, there is a factor that will condition the role that the Commission will play in the near future and which is connected to the return of the European political initiative by the governments of the Member States following the failure of the Santer Commission.We believe that this aspect is extremely positive, since in this way the national parliaments, on which governments depend, continue to be able to claim the essentials of their democratic mandate in the construction of Europe.The truth is that the European Parliament continues not to conquer trust and not even the interest of public opinion, which insists not to think in European terms, as evidenced by the percentage of abstention recorded on the occasion of the last elections.Therefore it is necessary to strengthen the mechanisms used for the purposes of cooperation between the governments of the Member States, giving them greater consistency, transparency and democracy.We welcome the commitment of President Prodi aimed at improving the public image of the Commission and we agree on the need for the latter to consult with Parliament and Council.In our opinion, however, the maximum priority to the reform of the government cooperation mechanisms, in particular through the creation of a Council of evaluating imports and exports.Otherwise this would not be achievable.Despite the apparent wisdom of the Tobin Tax, this hides several obstacles and, personally, I think it will be difficult to find an agreement on its introduction.It must be remembered that today money is above all information and that in the future the world economy will be based on it and human resources.That's why the uninterrupted flow of capital between the world financial centers has not only a mere speculative character without any link with the real economy.If with tax tools such as the Tobin Tax you will try to influence this feed-back mechanism, which offers operators freedom of choice, the economic consequences would have an extremely high price and higher than the proceeds that could be obtained with the tax.Having said that, I repeat what Mr Karas rightly said, namely that our group definitely opposes the adoption of the Tobin Tax.Madam President, I speak as supporter of a tax movements of capital mirroring through currency borders.It seems to me completely lapalissian that it is necessary to intervene.In the last 30 years the volume of currency transactions has increased by 83 times: first of all, the total global reserves of all the central banks barely amount to the value of the operations carried out in a single day on the change market;Second, the annual global exchange of real goods and services is equivalent to just three and a half days out of 350 of activities of the changes of the changes, that is, 1 percent of capital movements serve the exchange of goods and services and 99 percent are intended for speculation.The dimensions, unpredictability and irrationality of the global changes of changes have made it increasingly difficult to manage national and regional economies.The purchase and sale programs managed via computer have transformed any bip into an avalanche, which has overwhelmed jobs, lives and businesses all over the world.The only arguments disadvantage are: first, the tax would jeopardize the efficiency of the change market - a little imaginative in the light of the speculative follies that we have seen to destroy jobs all over the world, in the East Asia, in Europe and in Latin America.Chirac described people dedicated to this type of operations, the AIDS virus of the world economy.It is necessary to throw some sand into the gears of currency speculators, stock exchange agents and financial operators.It is obvious that this cannot be done in one country, nor in the context of a single currency area, but it could be done internationally with a global cooperation.

The communication of the Commission that we examine today and which constituted the basis of discussion from which the Council has spoken in November reflects in a balanced manner in which we can improve the discussion, to expand our knowledge of the challenges that the Member States will face in matters of social policy in the coming years, during which we will witness the aging of the populations as well as to the consequences of the enlargement.Many member states are already experiencing serious social problems today and are faced with significant social spending at the level of their public budgets.If reforms are not introduced, we risk eroding the economic basis on which social policy is based;However, a strong and competitive economy is the best guarantee of good quality social security.We are therefore delighted that these themes are on the agenda.The expression "social convergence" is often used during discussions relating to the coordination of social policy within the EU.As a liberal deputies, the concept of social convergence is a concept that we accept insofar as the EU is a question of establishing large common objectives that states must endeavor to achieve through their national social policy.It is therefore not a harmonization, but of common objectives.It is a fact that the EU member states organize their social policy in different ways.We have different traditions, different cultures and despite many points of resemblance, the character of social problems and their magnitude also differ from country to country.This is why it is important to underline the fact that social policy represents a national prerogative.National policy is obviously subject to a certain number of common managers, whether minimum social rights established by the treaty, the guarantee of free movement of workers without losing their social rights, the coordination of economies as well as economic cooperation.Coordination and cooperation are elements that must be added, but convergence must be based on objectives and not on means.I would also like to thank the rapporteur, Mr. Jan Andersson, for the very constructive efforts he has made with a view to trying to reconcile different points of view and thus guarantee support for his report.I will vote for his report, but there are a few points that are not entirely for my taste.I do not agree with the point which requests that the Commission intervenes against what is called unfair competition between social and tax systems if such intervention is intended to curb innovations, the evolution and improvement of the efficiency of our social systems or if it aims to prevent a reduction in the tax pressure too high in many Member States.I am skeptical about the detailed regulations which could result from the intervention of the Commission with regard to the extent and quality of child care plans and the care to be provided to the elderly and I am skeptical about the value of a common threshold of poverty.

I would like to remember all of this - we are in the election campaign, there are no twenty -five days until the elections.It is a consolation for the Lord Commissioner that these elections will take place in twenty -five days, which is why he probably does not be asked for inquiries of this kind.But I think it is important to say that Andalusia will receive 50 % more in the common framework and that Spain also holds a record with regard to the use of the structural funds, which means that the distribution is strictly based on the implementation provisions and is handled by the regional development plans and the various framework of the community support.Finally, I would like to make a specific request to the Lord: does he consider a change in the implementation regulations for the structural funds necessary, or does he consider the current distribution criteria to be acceptable?I find this debate very revealing.It is clear to me that there is a dimension that is not exclusively common in nature.Regardless of this, one has to put up with the fact that elections are constantly taking place in all countries of the Union.

Perhaps it is no coincidence that by the conservatives there is no one now here because what has been defended here as freedom of the market has nothing to do with the worthy principles of the market social economy that have provided us with so much well -being in Western Europe during the past decades.Well, if we follow the way - and this is ideology - to declare financial markets as sacrosanct and even affirm that any intervention in the functioning of these markets is opposed to progress and economic growth, we will be on the wrong way and this can adopt really dangerous dimensions.The owners of cash assets are currently accumulating gigantic heritage that in turn urges to be reinvested.We are faced with an Asset inflation of world magnitude.In this way, in financial markets, speculative bubbles originate that cause increasing economic instability, which in turn endangers the entire economy.It is precisely the small and medium enterprises and many workers who suffer from the consequences.It is possible to oppose this.The minimum that should be done for this is to finally carry out some thorough studies on the subject, not only by the Commission but also of renowned economic institutes throughout Europe.This is also feasible.And finally, the wolf should not be taken to take care of the sheep.It is not true that Tobin Tax is not technically viable.It is possible in the era of computers.It cannot be ignored that fiscal oasis are often nothing other than hard -to -line memoras of large European banks here.In summary: we cannot allow real capital and financial capital to move away both among themselves, otherwise, we will be faced with a situation that we have already lived several times in the last century in this continent and has led to large catastrophes.Mrs. President, distinguished colleagues, apply taxes on capital speculation, because this will not have unprecedented consequences.This tax would affect those who must be taxed: speculators.Who defends these speculators, while nurses and teachers pay very high taxes?Article 73 C of the European Union Treaty regulates the possibility of tax transaction.Those who oppose capital tax support tax evasion centers, tax havens, which total a total of 62. The Union should reach a fiscal agreement that, initially, could be signed by any country.The moderate Tobin tax would not cause major tax evasion problems.The statement that if everyone does not apply the tax is curious, nothing can be achieved in this field.The European Union was founded thanks to the thrust of some countries, and you can see what we have become today.Actually, the biggest problem is political: the capital is not wanted to tax, but to raise citizens' taxes.And it is that the capital tax would politicize the antidemocratic and powerful global finance system.

He described globalization as a positive process in which I agree with it.In my opinion, globalization has contributed to the fact that numerous countries that have previously been excluded from world trade have now been integrated into the world trade system, and as far as I know, not a single country has been worse off by world trade.In other words, such as Mr. Gasòliba I Böhm, I also consider globalization to be positive and believe that it has contributed to a new international division of labor, as has been sought by many for years.Second, Mr. Gasòliba I Böhm has not yet proven that it has not yet been proven that the exchange rates are stabilized by the Tobin tax.He is right in it.I am also not aware of any reasons, which is why the collection of a tax on speculative currency transactions should lead to stabilizing the exchange rates.In my opinion, these are two important comments, and that's why I repeated them here.Allow me to determine, Mrs. President, that none of the speakers established a connection between the Tobin tax and the functioning of the European Union this evening.We all know the Roman contracts: The four basic freedoms that are anchored in them are known to include free capital.Mrs. President, I can assure her parliament that in my daily work I also try to achieve the full integration of European financial markets with my agencies and my colleagues in order to largely facilitate and flexible capital.In other words, due to my office, I am against all measures that would make international capital difficult.You can then hardly expect this commissioner to agree to a tax that would affect international financial transactions.In my opinion, the Tobin tax is in contradiction to the Roman contracts, and this is an important theoretical objection that was not brought up by any of the speakers this evening.According to these very fundamental comments, there are now practical reservations against Tobin tax, as they were expressed by Mr. Karas, but also by other speakers.It was pointed out that the European Union - unfortunately, as I have to say, could not agree internally on certain tax measures.This proves how difficult this matter is.If we couldn't get any agreement internally, how should we then convince the other trading partners?That should be a tedious process.Mr. Jonckheer said this was one of the measures that could cause stabilization of the financial markets.However, this addresses a symptom while we should pursue the causes, and in my opinion it is better to combat the causes than to treat the symptoms, which is probably not possible at all and, as I said, certainly violates the Roman contracts.To remedy these causes, the situation in the countries concerned must be visualized.Can these countries boast of what is called good governance in English?Are there low inflation and low interest rates in these countries?Do the markets of the production factors, including the labor market, work flexibly?That is not always the case.So if we are looking for the reasons for the exchange rate stability, we have to focus mainly on the elements that are part of good governance.

The European Union voted against said proposal.The position of the European Union on the attitude to be adopted with China in the Human Rights Commission was confirmed again in the General Affairs Council of March 21, 1999: absence of the Initiative of the European Union with respect to China or Copatrocinio of a resolution of China, vote of the European Union against the proposal of non -interference.It is not true that, if the resolution had been voted, the cohesion of the European Union would have been maintained.The United States of America presented a resolution project relative authorities are making arrangements to the countries and institutions of the European Union in the sense that they refrain from supporting the initiative of the United States of America.That initiative is in debate at the Union, but a decision is not expected shortly.It is interesting to the European Union not to rule out any option as far as possible, in any case until after the meeting that will be held on February 25, 2000, in the field of European-China Union dialogue on human rights.In the light of the modifications in the composition of the Human Rights Commission, it is estimated that the vote on the proposal of non -interference will be tight.Therefore, it is important that this year the countries of the European Union also reach a consensus on the position to be human rights the presentation of a resolution in the Human Rights Commission in Geneva is automatically excluded.The European Union unequivocally considers that, even if it is a very valuable 12.00.Transport of dangerous goods on the road, the agenda bears the report (A5-0104/1999) presented by the honorable Koch on behalf of the Commission for Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism on the proposal of directive of the European Parliament and of the Council [com (1999) 158 - C5-0004/1999 - 1999/0083 (COD)] which modifies the Directive 94/55/EC.legislation of the Member States relating to the transport of dangerous goods on the road.Mr. President, Mrs. Commissioner, honorable colleagues, the directive that entered into force on January 1, 1997 concerning the rapprochement of the legislation of the Member States relating to the transport of dangerous goods on the road contains some transitional rules whose validity is completed and depends on the conclusion of some norms of standardization by the CEN, the European normalization committee.The delays in the works of the CEN have led to problems in the application of the aforementioned directive.In particular, the attachments could not be adapted to the most recent developments in the technological and industrial sector.This is in my opinion deplorable and forces us to intervene to remedy other people's defaults.I therefore accept the proposal to modify Directive 94/55/EC under discussion.A non -intervention by the European Union would oblige Member States to modify their national legislative provisions for a short period, or until the conclusion of the works of the CEN, which would entail unnecessary costs and uncertainties.

Mr. President, I thank colleague Langen - although he himself is not present - for the work he did to get the program through both parliament and the council.The project was long and difficult.The study to record the use of renewable energy sources must continue to receive great weight in the future.Although the new guideline contains a lot of positive things, it also has defects.An example of this is the use of peat.Peat must not be classified in the same group as fossil fuels.If peat cannot be classified directly as a renewable, non -fossil fuels, his own class must be defined, especially in view of the environmental tax.Peat must not be measured with the same level as hard coal.The development of renewable energy sources is a partial solution in order to end the depreciation of the Union's energy imports.Research also plays a particularly big role in relation to the next EU.The dependence on energy imports primarily affects Eastern European countries, whose economic structures still suffer from the dependence on Russian energy created during the Soviet period.The EU has to stick to the Kyoto climate agreement.We all worry about the environment and the future of our children.The proportion of renewable energy sources in total energy production must be increased, but in a reasonable manner.We must not forget that we can no longer build the main part of our energy generation on renewable energy sources for long.To do this, we need climate -friendly energy, nuclear energy.Mr President, for the Spe parliamentary group, I welcome it that we have come to a result in the mediation process for the Older II program.First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, the colleague Langen, for his really good work on this report.I would also like to thank the head of the delegation in the mediation committee, the colleague Provan.Because as Mr. Langen said it was really a hard fight in the mediation committee.But we can see today that the result of the mediation also clearly shows the manuscript of the European Parliament.Mr. Langen has pointed out that a number of content and demands of the parliament were taken over, and at the most important conflict point with the council, the financial resources of this multi -year program to promote renewable energy sources in the community, we have already been able to meet with which the council almost met.This is not satisfactory, I would like to say that very clearly.But we have received this compromise because it was important to us that this program can now be started really quickly.Because in the next few years the proportion of renewable energy sources in energy consumption should be doubled to at least 12 %.That is the declared goal of the European Union.The Altener program as the only EU program with the exclusive objective of the promotion of renewable energy sources is now really a key role.With this new five-year program, the actions from the Altener I program must be expanded.This includes, among other things, the deepening of the exchange of information and experience of actors in the area of ​​renewable energy sources, including the expansion of local, regional energy agencies, the development of new and the promotion of existing networks.These are just a few examples.

First, improve the effectiveness of your development policy.As is known, in 1995 a global evaluation exercise of development policies was made and during the German presidency it was possible to present their conclusions.The main conclusions underline the need for a more coherent policy of the European Union and a general strategic vision of the European Union in relation to development problems.The aspects related to the need for greater coordination and greater complementarity between the policies, of harmonization and simplification in the organizational framework in which the Cooperation Policy of the Union, the need to make the management of help and review, in particular, its intervention mechanisms, the need to strengthen the evaluation system and make the way in which the help process develops more efficient.A second aspect worth mentioning reinforces the need for greater complementarity between the European Union and the policies of the Member States.It is known that an important part of the aid is in charge of national policies of the Member States, not always complementary and not always coordinated;Much of the waste or the inefficiency of aid from the European Union is due precisely to that inability to coordinate and complementarity between what each Member State is doing and what the European Union institutions are proposed or do.From our point of view, it is also absolutely indispensable that as soon as possible we can contribute to strengthening mechanisms of complementarity and coordination between the policies applied by the Member States and those of the European Union.Third aspect worthy of relief: strengthening and coherence of its policies, the issue of debate proposed today.In the first place, we all have the idea that it is not enough to improve the conditions of aid and that it is necessary to better articulate other policies of the European Union so that the objectives of development can be achieved not only by the way of help and assistance, but also and especially through a more integrated vision of the different policies that contribute to its consequences.As is known, in June 1997, a resolution of the Council was approved and the Commission remained to present evaluation reports: the first one, in which some aspects of policy coordination are already established, in particular in the sphere of the construction of peace, food security, fishing and migrations, it was communicated to the Council in May 1999. But, as it is also known, a communication of the commission on coherence is expected.development".It is natural that in the coming months, still during the Portuguese presidency, this debate can be enriched in the light of the contributions that the Commission proposes to submit in that regard.The coherence of policies will always be - it is evident - limited and it is natural that some contradiction between policies is also an element of balance and weighting between contradictory and conflicting interests that move in the space of the Union and that only in that way it is also possible to regulate some contradiction between policies.

However, today I want to talk about prevention.In the Gulf region a new war conflict is being prepared.The Iraqi government, as you know, has refused to fulfill the 1284 resolution of the United Nations, and this negative will predictably mean, within the next six or seven weeks, the denial of the input visas to the commission that must control the destruction of nuclear, biological and chemical weapons.In that case, the United States government and the British Majesty government have clearly understood that they are determined to resort to military measures.My visit to Iraq and meetings with the leaders and personalities of the Iraqi Administration, in particular with Mr. Tarek Aziz, have convinced me that there really is a possibility of convincing the Iraqi government to collaborate in the application of resolution 1284. However, it is necessary that the authorities responsible for the western countries clearThe embargo will lift and that trade relations can be normalized.I would like to know what Europe and you, Mr. Solana, or what you intend to do in the next future, to move this war threat that, today, can be prevented: tomorrow it could be too late.In this context, I would also like to know if it is not possible to do something to induce the Iraqi government to take a humanitarian step, that is, to provide information about the 615 missing Kuwait or to free them in case they were under their control.Mr. President, Mr. Upper Representative, Lord Commissioner, we have all observed the particularly moderate and almost conciliatory reaction of the international community in general, and the European Union, especially, on the war in Chechnya.Now, what has happened and what still happens in Chehenia resembles a genocide.If not, how can the complete annihilation of a regional capital of 400,000 inhabitants be described, the constant and excessive bombardment of localities, neighborhoods, where it was, mixture perhaps with some checkpoints, the entire civil society?How should we qualify the sinister filtration fields, assimilable to concentration fields, where the population suffers from the worst humiliations and where healthy men, aged 15 to 65, rarely come out alive?How can violations, looting, volunteer fires, deportations, called "cleaning", which remember the worst episodes of the European Middle Ages?And what can be said about the hard situation that Russian and international journalists are going through, as well as expulsion, from the places where the killings, humanitarian organizations and all international research commissions occur?If that is the Real Politik, if we do not really have media, then, Mr. Alto Representative of the PESC, Mr. Commissioner, I address both: let's use the means we have, that is, the programs of help to Russia.

Commissioner Monti and his colleagues have before them a tremendous challenge and in the Eldr group we are concerned that there is a weakening in the impulse of competition policy both in the examination of mergers and in the supervision of restrictive methods.Delegating in the national authorities is very good, but we would like to underline what Mr. Von Wogou has said in his report on the need for periodic supervision of the national authorities to ensure that there is no reduction by the European part and we would like to ask in particular the Monti Commissioner to reassure us, in the sense that there will be random checks in this regard.Mr. President, in the small time I have, I want to support the work done by all the speakers and share many of the things that have been said here, particularly by my partner Jonckheer, criticizing the excessive grouping of data and the need for transparency and socio -economic balance of the aid.I also share the criticism that there has been no emphasis on the development of article 82, especially when we can attend abusive behaviors in a context of market concentration.I want to formulate, as deputy of the Basque Country, my total support for the measures to apply due market competition.I say it in case any doubt for the criticisms that we have directed to the Commission, in general, and Mr. Monti, in particular, for their persecution of incentives to Basque companies and for the fact of considering them as state aid.Our discrepancy subsists to the extent that the Commission still does not understand the character of the general and co -responsibility system of our concert, which make our Basque fiscal norms have the same nature, foundation and purpose that the norms of the states of the Union, and that are generally applied to all taxpayers who, by virtue of the connection points, are subject to them.Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner.Yes, we certainly need competition.We need to compete in the field of maximum reduction in unemployment, the improvement of health care, social justice, demanding social norms and also-the previous ones are criteria of political-economic competitiveness-we also need to compete, naturally, in the business economic sphere: highest quality of products, comparison of market access conditions for all companies, offer of products respectful of the environment.That is, we must be able to combine the necessary criteria of political-economic competitiveness with the criteria of the business economy.Sometimes I have the impression that, unlike what happened in my country-in GDR-, where it prevailed above all competitiveness from the political-economic point of view, without paying attention to business competitiveness, now it becomes very often the opposite and society thinks almost exclusively in terms of the business economy.I say it from my entrepreneur position absolutely interested in this aspect.But a system cannot work like this.The only possible way is a combined approach.

In the postal sector, the first phase is already started, suppliers of the universal service having engaged in a modernization process.Rather than the process of liberalization of the sector, it is new technologies and logistics that constitute the essential factors influencing employment.With regard to the availability of studies, point raised by Mr. Staes and other deputies, copies of each of these studies were sent to Parliament in September 1999. They are all available on the Commission's website since August 1999 and the Commission is willing to provide a copy to any interested person.Studies have been the subject of some criticisms, particularly on the part of postal public services.I am aware that all the studies started have experienced difficulties in collecting adequate data.This did not surprise us because the operators of the universal service do not always have detailed mail collection systems.Doesn't that say long on management capacity?No unique methodology allowing access to the cost and financing of the universal service is accepted by all parties.However, Mr. Bolkestein is convinced that the studies undertaken are clear and precise enough to constitute the basis of the decision -making process.I finally come to three interventions on a subject that I am supposed to know better than postal services: competition.Mr. Purvis, I found that your remark on the call for tenders, provocative on the methodological level, was interesting and was certainly worth explored.Mr. Medina Ortega, I am just as convinced as you that we will have to be even more vigilant after liberalization, because we do not want the disappearance of public monopolies to give birth, for lack of control of concentrations, to private operators.This applies both to the postal sector and other sectors.If I can give you an example of this type of vigilance, I will quote the case of the "Deutsche Post" for which the Commission began, following complaints and a legal action, an official procedure for examining state aid in July.We have just received the German government's response to the observations issued.The procedure for examining state aid covers the issue of cross subsidies between monopolistic mail services and commercial messaging activities as well as the financing of recent and numerous acquisitions of the "Deutsche Post".I will not enter into details because of the lack of time but it may illustrate, among other things, the fact that the Commission does not stop its work with the progress of liberalization.In a sense, this is where his work begins.Finally, it goes without saying, Mr. Radwan, that limits must be put in competition and these limits exist.If we consider in particular the question of competition and services of general interest, when a Member State defines a public service mission, it is important to quantify the costs generated by this mission and state aid which compensates for these costs are certainly not a violation of competition.I do not quite agree with the terms you used, Mr. Radwan, saying that it was time to take into account the needs of citizens rather than exclusively the need for competition.

Mr. President, honorable colleagues, nine million vehicles are sent to scrapping and disposal every year in Europe.Although they are no longer able to circulate, the aforementioned nine million vehicles have the characteristic of being marketed and transported also beyond the boundaries, not only of intra -community ones, but also of non -EU ones.Therefore in principle it is correct that the European Union Sancisca of the common norms regarding the recycling and treatment of these nine million vehicles.In our opinion, the Directive presents some weaknesses that Parliament wishes to touch up, thus preparing a tool that actually indicates the way to be taken for the future.For this reason, numerous amendments have been forwarded.I believe that the scope of this directive pushes too much.Do not judge that period vehicles are included in the directive.I don't even think that motorcycles should be included in this directive, because in this sector a culture of recycling is rooted such as to make a European directive superfluous.Also as regards special vehicles, I do not consider it appropriate to aim for a very high recycling percentage.For special vehicles such as ambulances I would prefer a high recovery rate.This is my main concern in this field.In my opinion, the Directive corrects the obligation to prove how a vehicle intended for disposal is treated in Europe.In this case we can transpose the proposals of the Commission.Member States mean that special collection centers are established that empty the liquids contained in vehicles, for example by disposing of more than 32 million exhausted oils, removing the brake fluid, etc.An important aspect treated in the directive is represented by the question inherent in the destination to be given to the parts used and the products of the scrapping.It is not possible to ignore the fact that the percentage constitutes an important element, but not the only one, of recycling, recovery and anything else.In fact, it should not be forgotten that, as regards the mobility of a vehicle, 80 percent of environmental pollution depends on its circulation, 1 percent on reuse and 19 percent on the construction.Therefore the percentages do not represent the only parameter to be applied in relation to environmental compatibility, but are only one of the many parameters to keep in mind.I am of the opinion that we need clear objectives.But the percentages must not become a goal in itself;We must realize the importance of the global perspective connected to the environmental pollution caused by a vehicle.I prefer to think that from a vehicle that today weighs 1,400 kilos and on average it runs 200,000 kilometers we will go to a car in the future that will weigh only 1,000 kilos, but will continue to be able to travel 200,000 kilometers.In this way, for 200,000 kilometers, 400 kilos would still be transported.This is the real progress in terms of environmental policy, because it will lead to a substantial reduction in CO2 emissions and, if I correctly understood the Kyoto protocol, it is the essential point.For this reason, we believe that the vehicles for whose realization in the future will be used optimally and demonstrable to construction methods that reduce their weight will produce less CO2 and therefore a special preference must be assigned as regards the percentage of incineration.It is not up to the individual Member States, but to you, lady commissioner, together with your staff, it is up to decide whether to such light vehicles - many also speak of three -liter vehicles - a special preference must be attributed.

This is also characteristic of American society, which itself learns little about it.The Americans are rightly outraged by war and genocides in other parts of the world, but are wrongly silent about the genocide in their own country.Today, the Dineh Indians face the last struggle for their right to land, for their right to dignity and, above all, their right to their own way of life.You are only a few, but your opponent is an economic power.Mr. President, revered Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues!I agree with the explanations of my previous speakers, but I would like to highlight a few more things.The Dineh are among the North American Navajo Indians.They are excluded from society and have been fighting for survival for decades.They have been living under miserable conditions for years.These poor circumstances force them to bend against their will to the financial and economic pressure of the coal industry.The resettlement law issued in 1974, which includes the redistribution of the territory of the Navajo Reserve, allows the resettlement of the population groups.These resettles are of course unacceptable, since human rights are violated in economic, social and cultural terms.The Dineh Indians are pushed back and forth like chess figures and not only lose their history and the extremely important soil - the bottom of their ancestors - but they also have no view of finding work and sources of income.The resettlement law was enforced in the congress by a group that represented the coal industry.The congress has never thought about where the people who lived in the area should or how the relocation would affect their lives.The population had no say.This is almost human trafficking.The relocation was carried out and the Dineh was implemented in an uranium -contaminated area.After breaking a dam in New Mexico in 1979 and the release of 370,000 cubic meters of radioactive water and 1 100 tons of pure uranium, this place is one of the most contaminated areas in the world.The government of the United States, the coal industry and we all have to face our responsibility and ensure an acceptable alternative: either the soil is decontaminated, or the Dineh Indians are assigned a place worth living, and every necessary support is provided for psychological, social, cultural and financial level.The rights of the Indians must finally be observed.Therefore, we ask to vote for this decision: We must not be intimidated by American interests in Europe that are asserted by financial, religious and industrial groups.So we best send an urban ratio to the United States!President!In terms of human rights, there is of course a lot to be criticized in Chechnya.According to human rights organizations, Russian soldiers have killed civilians, old women and men, in Grosny, apparently even executed.Civilians are said to have been burned alive in protective cellars.We insist that these human rights violations are examined.Contrary to the promise, the violations of human rights committed in Alfanjurt, for example, were still not examined.International government organizations and non -governmental organizations must be given access to the area.The Council General Affairs of the Union decided on December 6, 1999 to send representatives of the Member States to Inguschetia in order to examine the humanitarian situation, and I am, to say the least, curious about what comes out.

However, on a structural and general level, all of us, regardless of the place where we find ourselves, from the social class, from the race, from religion, within the domestic walls as at work, in any area of ​​society we are subject to man - with some individual exceptions, as it is perhaps right to clarify.In my country, Sweden, in recent years several political parties have spontaneously decided to introduce a share of places to be allocated to women in the assembly bodies.This has translated into an increase in the presence of women in the decision -making process, and in turn that this has led to a modification of political priorities, and a modification of political priorities naturally also involves a change in the decision -making types.When it comes to the altitude yesterday, men systematically possess even the most indefinite skills.In short, being a man would be synonymous with having greater competence.And such a vision seems to me to prove the high degree of
