initiative, concentrated on violence against women and female poverty in the whole world.In conclusion, I want to say, how Commissioner Patten in conclusion of the discussion held a few indeed, that the ideal policeman would be a color grandmother.We have no such policemen, yet they would exist!Mr. President, the role of women in politics is an important question that deserves something better than the politically correct relaunch to which we witness.There are probably few women engaged in politics, although it is not said that this is attributable only to the dominance of men in the party systems.In France, 95 percent of the elect are municipal councilors, whose vast majority is not affiliated to any party.In institutions at the level of the department, the first party of France is that of non -members, both on the right and on the left.To get on the local councilor, just want to want it.Now, on the inclusion they offer these mandates often depends on national liability access.The UEN group warms up a fair representation of men and women within the organs of the European Union.That's why we reject the policy of quotas and positive discrimination, which it expresses itself in favor of women or alleged social minorities.The policy of minorities, neglecting the deep unity of the human family to establish superficial divisions, seriously threatens the cohesion of the social body and the balance of our democratic model.

been presented to the court mentioned above, NATO is accused of serious violations of international humanitarian law and intentional killings.Is the advice of the opinion that such allegations have to be left to the judgment of the International War Criminal Tribunal in order to be subject to a detailed judicial investigation?In the event of a judicial investigation of the allegations against NATO, the council intends to proceed with the general secretary/high representative of the common foreign and security policy, who held the office of NATO general secretary during the decisive period of time?Is there a procedure to give it from his tasks until the allegations have been examined in court?President!The question of Mr Alexandros Alavanos stimulates general considerations.The Council has already stated that the application of strict measures taken by NATO was necessary and justified in order to counter extremist and irresponsible actions, which represented a clear violation of the resolutions of the United Nations Security Council.I understand that NATO's approach and the legality can be different.Everyone is free to represent such points of view.In my homeland, the individual parliamentary factions represented different opinions.Things were like that and no different.In any case, there is the clear point of view of the council in that the air strikes carried out by the organization of the North Atlantic Pact in the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia with the aim of ending the human disaster caused by the Belgrade regime in Kosovo.This goal was expressed formally and comprehensively by the point of view of the "General Affairs" Council on April 8 in Luxembourg.These measures of NATO, that must be said, were not taken lightly, but as a last remedy, when it became clear that the possibilities of a negotiating solution were exhausted and that the Belgraders' authorities concentrated their armed forces in order to drive away the Kosovo albanium from their homeland.The MP has surely learned that the recent visit to NATO when she recently visited NATO, the International Tribunal was obliged to investigate all charges, including those who were raised against NATO, especially Canadian pacifist groups.This mandatory examination takes place to the extent that these charges are raised.In any case, I have an explanation of the woman's indictment with me, in which she says that there is currently no investigation against NATO from the office of the prosecutor of the International War Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia and that there is no formal examination procedure on NATO's procedure in the Kosovo conflict.All information that has been received in the past six months from both individuals and groups to apply for an investigation of the NATO actions during the Kosovo conflict were registered by the prosecutor.The prosecutor will of course examine all other information and, in due course, inform you whether there is an opportunity to act.

Tomorrow it's about a few points.First, we know that the transport of people and goods with the ship is the most environmentally friendly in relation to other transport types.At the same time, we know that the ships contribute to the pollution of the oceans through garbage, load residues and oil sludge.The fuel for ships is once heavy oil, and we know that 1 % to 3 % of this heavy oil remains as an oil sludge, and this is classically disposed of in the sea.I think we agree that ships have to dispose of garbage and residues in the ports.And from this follows - and there can actually be no other logic: The top priority for clean seas is that illegal disposal on the high seas is no longer allowed to be worthwhile.That's what it's about, and the majority we debated here.In January we had a very detailed debate about the consequences of "Erika" with you, Ms. Commissioner.We have collected all the points for ship safety and clean seas.And also with this guideline on port access systems for load residues, the question is how we get the seas cleaner.Just for information: We know that 70,000 m3 are disposed of in the North Sea alone in the North Sea in an illegal way, and we know the other way round that a maximum of 5 % to 10 % of the ships are now going properly, namely to dispose of their trash in the ports.This scandal is also not acceptable from the point of view of the council.The Council also says that all ports have to hold up the appropriate harbor access systems and have to be equipped with it.The conflict is ultimately about the question: How is paid?In its first reading, the parliament with a large majority said that it must be a significant contribution to the ships, namely at least 90 %.And that is the difference to the council that tells us that it must be a contribution.But a contribution can only be half a euro, and in this case God knows too little.Then nothing changes.There is no economic pressure for the ships to behave accordingly.A disposal flat rate for all ships, regardless of the actual use of the disposal facilities, is necessary, that is, the economic incentive for disposal at sea must be omitted, which-as it was already explained here-in the Baltic Sea-with the Helmkom Agreement, with the no-special feet system.What works there must also work for the remaining European seas, because it is not just about the environment, it is about clean water, it goes up to tourism, and - what is crucial - in addition to the environmental question, it is also about competition neutrality.The ships in the ports must all be able to comply with the same conditions, and only if Parliament, Council and Commission create these conditions together is this neutrality of competition for the ports and ships.I think it's also about the credibility of the Union and especially parliament.I think people are tired of experiencing disaster hypocrisy from Europe and the ministers, as we saw it in "Erika".

There were examples in Spain: Michelin, ABB-Alstom, and there are examples in Italy that my colleagues will name.There is also another hidden formula of dismissal, and in Spain, for example, it is practiced by the ERICSSON company under the name "outsourcing" (precise words are avoided, such as the word "release").The outsourcing of services means commissioning services for contract companies, which means that stable and fixed jobs are canceled at any time, without union and social rights.In reality, this is another veiled form of discharge.Mr. Commissioner!If the European institutions believe in what they say about full employment, they have to take up clear measures: the guidelines to ensure the participation of the employees in these negotiations, reduce the directive on mass layoffs, to reduce working hours, bind the European subsidies to maintain jobs and bind the social and labor law clauses into the international benefits subordinate to the European Unionto record.Mr President, once again this parliament has to deal with the restructuring of companies in Europe.Once again, the workers are at risk of loss of their workplace.This time it is about Goodyear's employees in Cisterna di Latina.As already mentioned, around 600 employees and just as many families who could be robbed in a month of their only source of income are affected.Despite their accommodation and professionalism, thanks to whom the company in Cisterna is one of the most productive in Europe, these workers threaten the risk of being emitted from the production cycle, while the Goodyear company, after it has been received for years, can close the goals and completely unhindered.I really think that is unfair: unfair to the employees of the branch in Cisterna and unfair to all those citizens in Italy and the Union, which, albeit indirectly, have enabled taxear to enjoy this state aid.The European Commission and the Council must finally fully commit themselves to their responsibility, both in terms of acceptance of the common point of view regarding the information and hearing of the entrepreneurs and as far as the community grants and state subsidies are concerned, which are only to be granted to the conclusion of long -term agreements for the preservation of jobs.Today we ask the Commission to protect employees from the Goodyear branch in Cisterna and therefore exert every conceivable pressure on the company so that there is an agreement as soon as possible to ensure the continued existence and the further operation of the branch in Cistern.Finally, I would like to point out that Mr. President and Mr. Commissioner, that the time really urges and therefore all the measures that are considered - including those already mentioned by the Commissioner in his introductory words - must be taken immediately and in time.President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues!The European companies, if they continue to remain existence, undoubtedly want to adapt structurally in order to be able to better counter the new challenges.Today's economic background is quite aware of it, because the aim of the intended restructuring is to rationalize corporate management.

and that, in addition, as stated in the resolution, "Women's Day must have an international character and its preparation will have to be thorough."It is also worth noting that Women's Day was later prohibited in all countries in which fascism and Nazism achieved power in the interwar period.The year 1910, the female vote was in the agenda.Today we take care of how women can participate in the decision -making process.Women do not constitute a homogeneous collective.Women belong to all social classes.Women have individual needs and interests.However, in a structural and generalized way, regardless of the place where we are, regardless of class and religion, at home or at work, in all segments of society, we are subject to man, although it should be added that there are some made to suitability.The interesting thing is that suitability criteria are rarely defined.It often seems that men, today as yesterday, always have the most indefinite suitability.Being a man would therefore be equivalent to the possession of the greatest suitability.This perspective, in my opinion, is a proof of great incompetence by those who today make decisions.This year, in this assembly, we have requested that March 8 become an international holiday.While we hope this is completed, I want to take the opportunity to desire all socialist women in their Women 'S World Marches, which will begin in spring, International Women's Day.This is a worldwide activity that focuses on violence against women and the poverty of women in the world.Finally, as the commissioner Patten pointed out when the previous debate ended, I mean that the ideal police would be a color grandmother.We don't have it, but there are!

The president, let me remember that tomorrow will be the second anniversary of the Cermès tragedy.Indeed, two years ago, in Cavalese in Italy, an American plane from the NATO base located in Aviano, stretched, during a low altitude exercise - below the safety limits -, the cables of a cable car, causing the death of more than twenty European citizens.The families of the victims, who did not feel that justice has been made as soon as the responsible pilot did not incur the slightest sentence, at least expect from the United States, rapid economic compensation.I therefore invite the president of this assembly and the chairman of the commission to guarantee, alongside the American authorities, immediate compensation, to defend the rights of the families of the victims.Madam, thank you and I take note of your intervention.Agenda The agenda calls for the fixing of the work order.Following the request which was sent to me in this sense by several political groups and following the meeting of the Conference of Presidents that we have just had, I suggest you include a debate of an hour and a half on a news problem, urgent and major importance, in accordance with article 50 of our rules, relating to the reaction of the Union with regard to government negotiations in Austria.

There is no direct passage from Interreg II to Interreg III and this, in fact, involves uncertainties in programming and gaps in funding.It is a shame because in this way valid projects are certainly endangered.In the execution of Interreg, coordination and synchronization with the other financial instruments concerned must be guaranteed.This is particularly important to increase the efficiency of the funds used and however involves some problems.The difficulties are mainly due to the annual duration of the funds that are assigned on the basis of the projects, for example in the field of Phare, while the contributions provided in the Intergeg area have many years of duration and are assigned according to the measures adopted.In the future this will determine practical problems and I hope that all this does not prevent an satisfactory implementation of Interreg.Mr. President, honorable colleagues, the leading community initiative has proven to be a valid tool to give impulse to innovative developments and pilot projects inside and starting from rural areas.Therefore it is certainly positive that this community initiative has been maintained and re -proposed in renewed form in the context of the leader+program.The new leader+ program is now implemented in the entire rural space of the European Union and this offers greater possibility of financing projects.It is certainly important to ensure the coordination between leader+ and other support interventions of the European Union, but it is equally important to ensure coordination with other forms of promotion at national level.On the one hand, it is necessary to avoid the fragmentation of support interventions and, on the other, to be able to exploit the synergistic effects.From this point of view, the goal of increasing the network connection between beneficiary areas of the leading program is certainly welcomed.The agricultural sector is one of the main axes in the rural space and must be able to participate in the leading initiative;The structural changes that invest agriculture can also be accompanied through the leading initiative, contributing to the creation of new jobs in the rural space.As part of the leader+ program, it is necessary to take into account all economic interconnections in the rural space and the possibilities to achieve the optimal result only through a common commitment.At this point you will have to move on to the leader's implementation phase.Operational programs must be approved as soon as possible by the Commission, that is, it is necessary to guarantee the practicability and efficiency in the treatment of financing requests and the utmost timeliness in the assignment of assignments.Five months are planned: too much in my opinion.We should shorten the times.Those who have elaborated and developed a project, in fact, are in a hurry to move on to the realization phase.Although he is fully satisfied with the new guise of the leading community initiative, I would like to draw attention to an aspect that is particularly close to my presentation: in its presentation, the EU Commission, asked for an observatory of the leading program+ without entering exactly the implementation of this proposal.In my opinion, the following issues ask themselves: who will work there?How will these people be selected?Above all: where will the necessary funds be found and where such an observatory should be based?They are of the opinion that the leader+ program no longer remains a penny to be allocated to further administrative expenses for tasks which, in itself, should be carried out by the Commission.

To justify this, we invoke the next enlargement of the Union.It surprises me because it is a bad interpretation.A federal and centralist EU which always directs the Member States is in fact less likely to expand.A flexible EU which focuses on less numerous, but essential areas that respects national differences and national democracies is more likely to encompass many more countries.To the point D of the proposal for resolution, a more effective and more transparent economic policy is required at the level of the EU.However, it is impossible to talk about this without speaking of the monetary union.In the current text, nothing is said of the big democratic and political problems linked to the monetary union and the central bank - it is not defensible.If you want to have a more democratic EU, you have to review the entire design of the UEM.The central bank must be placed under political control so that monetary policy can be led by a political objective such as the growth of employment or well-being;For this, the transparency of the central bank must be improved.The fixed and failed monetarism of the stability pact must be re-examined and rejected, if we want to be able to have a homogeneous policy which places the objective of well-being in the foreground.Article 56 of the Treaty, which prohibits any intervention in the free movement of capital, monetary speculation, must be deleted so that dangerous monetary speculations are refronted thanks to political control.Most EU countries today have governments dominated by Social Democrats.It is remarkable that none of them requires a change in the orientation of the monetary union, now that they have the possibility.The fact of declaring that the monetary union could constitute a counterweight to the globalization of capital also does not affect credibility.In resolution, the European Parliament is required to obtain greater power over the intergovernmental conference.However, it is important to emphasize that the intergovernmental conference is and must be a conference between the Member States.It is the Parliament of the Member States, or of the people in popular votes, which must direct the development of the treaty.It is therefore excluded that the European Parliament is given any formal influence in the negotiation or ratification process.Mr. President, the Constitutional Affairs Committee presented a substantially positive text for which I will vote, even if I myself introduced several enlargement amendments.However, what happened in recent days shows that all those who have expressed substantive criticism of how the expansion and revision of the treaties were organized were right.We cannot envisage a union of twenty-eight member states without facing the question of whether Europe shares certain principles, certain common values, if it is reduced to an economic zone of free exchange or if, on the contrary, it has a greater aspiration: to be a supranational union, according to aspects to be defined, also eager to draw a new path of civilization and democracy in the world.

The two proposals constitute a coherent whole.The first expands the range of tools with which a "collective investment body in securities" (OICVM) can operate.As already mentioned during the discussion, these bodies must be counted among the main actors on modern capital markets;Their presence guarantees a greater number of simple investors the possibility of operating on these markets in compliance with the principle of the distribution of risks and protected by adequate checks.Since diversified forms of investment are allowed, private investors can exploit all the advantages offered by new investment techniques.The second proposal expands the role that these important intermediation bodies can play on the capital market of the European Union as regards the development of the sector of investment funds.By allowing the creation of sectors and the performance of certain transfrontier level services, these bodies will benefit from the freedoms provided for by the Treaty of Rome, of which they have not been able to take advantage so far.The Commission appreciates many of the clarifications proposed by the Commission for economic and monetary problems and will implement most of the ideas advanced by it.The Commission will welcome the amendments - I use the last numbering - nn.2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 9, 13, 19 and 21 relating to the first proposal and nn.23, 28 and 32 concerning the second, since they represent useful clarifications and improvements.Furthermore, judging ideas favorably - even if they must be properly formulated - contained in the amendments nos.1, 10, 11, 14, 18 and 20. Also support the concept of the maximum percentage of the risk of the counterparty at the basis of the amendments nos.17, 36 and 45. I can then accept the idea expressed in the second paragraph of amendment no.47. All the amendments mentioned so far refer to the first proposal.As regards the second proposal, it is possible to transpose the ideas presented in the amendments nos.24, 25, 29, 30 and 41 and some parts of amendment n.27, which contain interesting suggestions, even if they must be properly formulated.The commission is willing to welcome them, provided that some changes are made in their formulation.I also take note of the Commission's request for economic and monetary problems to codify the entire text once approved - amendment no.7 of the first and n.22 of the second proposal.The Commission is in favor of a coding and within a short term, after the adoption of the proposals and reserving the right of initiative that belongs to them, it will be committed to developing a coded version;However, I cannot accommodate the current formulation of considering.The Commission also believes that some amendments presented by the Commission for economic and monetary problems would radically change the content of the first proposal.Therefore the commission, albeit reluctantly, cannot be transposed the following amendments relating to the first proposal.Amendment no.8 is not acceptable, as the generic reference proposed to the investments "indicated in this directive" to replace the most precise reference to the tools "referred to in article 19 of the directive" makes the implementation more difficult.Furthermore, this amendment could lead to different interpretations in the Member States, which perhaps would seek tools mentioned in other articles of the directive.

We think that poverty and segregation are the main threats to peace and freedom.Although I agree with what my party colleagues and with the spirit of his document, I would like to attract attention to two deficiencies that must be corrected in the future.The first of them refers to women, gender or women's rights.You referred to the female contribution to increase production and growth.This is important, but equal opportunities between men and women is not only necessary for productivity, but also for democracy in our societies.That is why it is surprising that the words equal opportunities, gender or woman do not seem in shaping the new Europe.In your speech you refer to the woman, but it is not appointed among the strategic objectives.Is this, Mr. Commissioner, that mainstreaming are already consolidated in the commission that is not necessary to mention women?How do you explain this feminine absence?The EU should not become a junction with a male face.My second question refers to Africa.Nor is Africa named the New Europe, but all other continents.In Africa there is the greatest number of refugees, the greatest poverty in the world and there is a cruel AIDS epidemic.I know that Commissioner Nielson and others do a good job, but it is necessary that the entire commission, including its strategic objectives, pay greater attention to this continent.Finally, I want to welcome the statement of the commission and that in it, for the first time, it is said that the EU is prepared unilaterally to take measures that favor the access of developing countries to our markets.My question is: when will this be realized?Mrs. President, Mr. President of the Commission, Lords, we have before us a fundamental document for the future and destiny of Europe.However, among all these aspects, we are especially raised, closely linked to each other: peace and stability in Europe and outside Europe.These are objectives that have to prioritize themselves.For a long time, we all share this idea, but we must also clearly affirm that these objectives cannot be achieved without the extension, although it can behave some costs.Today we have to choose for the next decades between a perhaps less rich but lighthouse of peace and civilization for the entire planet and a perhaps more opulent Europe, but without prophecies.However, these goals can be achieved only if the intergovernmental conference that will end this year, will start a constitutional reform that attributes adequate and real powers to the commission that may no longer be the simple executor of the decisions of the Council or the codecisions of Parliament, but must play the role of true government of Europe.The first courage of this reform should be Parliament if it wants to really expand its role as an interpreter of the will of Europeans and acquire that importance, typical of an authentically democratic and strongly integrated union.

For the light of the events of the past few days, we may wonder what these intergovernmental conferences and these changes in the treaty will be used, when the heads of state and government - in reality, the European Council - take a position in relation to a sovereign Member State by intervening in the democratic process of this Member State.Everyone is free to have their own opinions on Mr. Haider - Personally, I consider him a very dangerous political figure - but we do not have to intervene in the democratic process of a sovereign and friend country.During intergovernmental conferences and when we will re -examine the modifications to be made to the treaty, we will have to take into account the fact that the EU evolves every day, in particular, as we have just seen, in a way contrary to the treaty.I welcome, in this enclosure, this afternoon, at Commissioner Barnier and the Portuguese Presidency this afternoon.February 14 will see the launch of the CIG which will end by the end of the year 2000. The task is enormous but it can be accomplished.I think that all the groups present here this afternoon generally agree that the agenda of Helsinki will not be enough to cover the reform necessary to prepare Europe for enlargement.In other words, we have to go further than the important "Amsterdam reliquates".These include the extension of the qualified majority voting - we accept this in my country, except in the fields relating to taxation - the respondation of the vote within the Council in order to promote the largest states, and the number of commissioners in an enlarged Europe.Regarding the last point, Ireland wants the right to appoint a full -fledged member and without discrimination within the Commission, regardless of the number of Member States that adhere to Europe.We are willing to consider responding to votes within the Council of Ministers, provided that the largest member states accept that each member state has a full member and without discrimination within the Commission.When I lift this specific point, I know that I speak in the name of a large number of smaller states.During the CIG, we should also debate the possible sharing of the treaties in two parts a political field and a field relating to the Constitution.We are ready to accept this sharing if it does not limit the control that the smallest member states had in the renegotiation of all the policies of the treaty.In other words, if we are not fully represented in the Commission, we will not contribute to political discussions.So we follow all this question very closely.We are delighted with the idea of ​​the charter of fundamental rights and impatiently await its content.Mr. President, the Treaty of Amsterdam has set the number of deputies in the European Parliament at 700 and we must debate, within the Parliament, in the way in which these 700 seats will be distributed within extended Europe.Mr. President, I fervently recommend the adoption of the Dimitrakopoulos/Leinen resolution.This clearly expresses not only our disappointment in the face of the insufficiency of the agenda, but also our desire to see the intergovernmental conference stand as soon as possible.

I believe it is an important step, even if with an impact not particularly evident for national systems.Unfortunately, causing a displeasure to the speaker, I must communicate that my group cannot welcome amendment no.3As regards amendment no.6, in the Commission we had presented a similar amendment.I am a little surprised when I think that you of the PSE group, on that occasion, did not support it.We now intend to support your amendment n.6, but, as I have already said, I wonder why you have not welcomed ours into the commission.I also hope that transparency will be introduced, and that it is possible to proceed with a comparison between the fastest and most effective procedures in the various states.Mr. President, honorable deputies, first of all the Commission underlines that the proposal for the regulation in question this evening constitutes only a reformulation of the agreement relating to the insolvency procedures of 1995. It is known that the aforementioned agreement is the result of long years of discussions, often difficult, often laborious and that for this reason it represents a compromise between the principles of unitary and territoriality, thatlegal systems regarding bankruptcy law in force in the Member States.The awareness that the evolution of the global economic situation and, in particular, of the internal market can make a more frequent use of insolvency procedures that many times have a transfrontier character fully justifies the fact that the European Union, as such, is qualified by the binding legal tools indispensable to ensure that the insolvency procedure is carried out in compliance with a set of common structural principles and guaranteeing rapid execution.Unfortunately or fortunately, the declaration of bankruptcy by the companies will become increasingly common in our daily economic life.This will constitute a factor of renewal of the corporate tissue which must not be blocked due to the existence of slow or obstacles bureaucratic procedures that prolong the agony of companies that are no longer vital.Therefore it is important to try to identify a legal framework of reference adequate to the new needs of the globalized economy.The proposal for the regulation in question was made not by the Commission, but following a joint initiative of two Member States - Germany and Finland - pursuant to the right of initiative they share with the Commission in this field.The Commission believes that the regulation in question does not imply any substantial modification with respect to the text of the Convention.Already in 1981 the Commission had expressed its position in favor of the adoption of the principle of unity of failures.Furthermore, this perspective had been implemented in the proposals presented by the Commission regarding a parallel procedure concerning the liquidation of companies.Instead, the 1995 Convention ends up authorizing the opening of secondary procedures, creating derogations from the general rule that the Commission would like it to be accepted.Following the entry into force of the Treaty of Amsterdam, the Commission would therefore have preferred that a new text was adopted that expressly married the thesis of unity.

a pronunciation about the security of maritime traffic due to the catastrophe of Erika, and we will also have to discuss the security goals in air traffic in the course of this year.I want to express that security is a primary goal of the Commission.As I will say in the pronunciation about the Erika, we are not waiting for a disaster to deal with the security aspect, but we are working on the sidelines of these events.However, these show us the urgency of an effective answer to problems of this kind.I would like to thank all speakers and especially the rapporteur, Mr. Koch.The pronunciation is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow at 12 p.m.The report (A5-0104/1999) by Mr. Koch follows on the road on behalf of the Committee on Regional Policy, Transport and Foreign Affairs for a Directive of the European Parliament and the Council (KOM (1999) 158 - C5-0004/1999 - 1999/0083 (COD)) to change the Directive 94/55/EC to adjust the legal provisions for the member stateDangerous goods transport on the street.President, dear wife commissioner, dear colleagues!The guideline that came into force on January 1, 1997 for the adjustment of the legal provisions of the Member States for dangerous goods transport on the street contains some transitional regulations, the validity of which is limited and linked to the conclusion of certain standardization work of the CEN, i.e. the European Committee for Standardization.Delayed delays in the work of the CEN now lead to problems when using this guideline.In particular, attachments cannot be adapted according to technical and industrial development.I regret this because we have to work because others have not done their work.In this respect, I accept the present proposal to change the Directive 94/55/EC.A non -acting of the European Union would oblige the Member States to change their domestic legal provisions for a short period of time, namely until the CEN's work is concluded, which causes unnecessary costs and uncertainties.The change in the directive on today's agenda does not change the harmonization of dangerous goods transport in the community.It only extends transitional rules by moving appointments, it no longer strokes provisions, and it regulates the procedures for a) ad HOC transports of dangerous goods as well as b) the decree of less strictly national regulations, especially in the transport of very low amount of dangerous goods on locally strictly limited areas.The change of the directive is therefore in the sense of subsidiarity;Member States receive more powers.The EU Commission decides whether the Member States can issue certain regulations.It is supported by an expert committee for dangerous goods transport according to the regulatory procedure.The modalities for the exercise of these implementation powers assigned to the Commission were re -regulated by the council decision of June 1999.

Mr. President, I would have a question relating to a concrete and real case in which the precautionary principle could be applied.It concerns the fireproof substances added to the bromine.The problem only comes to the fore, with high concentrations both in the environment and in the human body.Many argue that these substances involve serious risks, others instead tend to minimize.Recently, within the Council, both Sweden and Denmark have urged the Commission to take the initiative to prohibit fireproof substances at the bromine.I therefore wonder if such a prohibition is in preparation and if this initiative could not frame itself perfectly in your vision of the principle of precaution itself.Mr. President, I thank the honorable Sjöstedt for asking this question: the problem of fireproof substances added to the bromine is a serious problem.It has been raised recently within the "Environment" Council by a series of ministers who ask the Commission to study the terms and indicate how to intervene.Now we are examining the question of establishing what the current state of knowledge on the subject is and what can be done.However, I would like to remember that the appeal to the precautionary principle is not necessarily synonymous with prohibition and total tender.A series of different measures can be hypothesized: one cannot immediately speak of prohibition.As regards now to the fireproof substances added to the bromine, it may be that, over time, one of them are reached, but it is important to remember that the precautionary principle allows to resort to the entire range of political interventions and possible measures.This is a problem of maximum topicality.The Commission will have to carry out its work by scrupulously examining the question before expressing itself on what to do.You said that the precautionary principle should not become a disguised form of commercial protectionism.Is there an agreement on this point on the two sides of the Atlantic?I think we will have problems, especially for the meat to the genetically modified hormones and crops.Are we sure that on this principle the interpretation of the Americans coincides with ours?Mr. President, I am pleased to be able to communicate that in Montreal we have signed a protocol on biological security.At that time, we managed to achieve international consensus around the definition of the precautionary principle.I believe that having managed to sign that protocol represents a decisive step forward.I believe that it will make school in view of future discussions around the principle of precaution and that it will be able to act as an example of interpretation of its principle, principle to which a role of instrument as important as it is effective is recognized.Mr. President, I would have two questions that I will try to exhibit with the utmost brevity.My first question concerns the application of the precautionary principle.I seem to understand that some uncertainties exist regarding his interpretation.Do you have to first conduct a risk assessment, including costs and benefits analysis?If so, I find it truly disturbing, because precisely the analysis of costs and benefits should not have been used as a criterion to decide whether or not to resort to the precautionary principle: it is the principle of precaution that has precedence.

On this point, they are the opinion that only a Council regulation will offer the necessary legal security and guarantee the formal prohibition of any help not contemplated by the code.For all these reasons, I voted in favor of the report of Mr Langen and I am now waiting for the Commission to answer our questions and requests.(The session, suspended at 13.05, resumes at 15.00) Sea polluted by oil in France the agenda bears the declaration of the commission on the sea polluted by oil in France.On behalf of the commission, Commissioner Loyola De Palacio has the right to the name of the intervention of which the discussion opens.Mr. President, I intervene in the name of the PPE/De group but also as an elected Breton, directly involved and shocked by these events.With Françoise Grossetête and the PPE/de, we presented a resolution proposal.Today, we are faced with a compromise proposal and I am happy.The shipwreck of Erika is actually a European question because it mutilates and insudes some of the most beautiful European beaches with very serious consequences for tourism, for those who carry out a maritime activity, for the defenders of the environment and then because regulation and control are in question whose natural dimension is clearly European.Certainly a catastrophe of this reach would not have been possible off the American coast.Why?Because the Americans were capable of learning from the catastrophe of the Exxon Valdez and in 1990 they have drawn up the Oil Pollution Act which confers greater responsibilities since it can imply the responsibility of the rented, it is more binding and above all provides for a better control through various regulations and in particular through the body of the American guardos.If we had had similar provisions, I repeat, the catastrophe would certainly not have verified.For this reason we believe that it is necessary to review the applicable legislation and in particular the 1992 protocol that exempted the rentals, in this case the oil company that has rented, from any responsibility.

which I would have liked to formulate yesterday before the vote - is that Parliament, like other honorable colleagues, recalled yesterday, can operate in a truly effective way only if he works in close cooperation and synergy with the European Commission.We should also have the humility to admit that if we had wanted a strategic discussion accompanied not only by a presentation and a clarification by the President of the Commission, but equally from a five -year program, we would have had to organize ourselves in detail before - and do not wait until the week before the discussion in the classroom -, so that we can debate and report our desired commission to the Commission.I would like us to teach a teaching from this experience: whenever in the future, discussions of great importance between Parliament and European Commission will be put on the age of the day, all the details regarding our mutual expectations should be clarified at least a good month in advance, first of all between the political groups of this Parliament and then between the Parliament and the Commission, so as not to find us at the last moment in the unpleasant position of causing an institutional relationship in vain.After giving a last to the articles published by the press last Friday, I seem to be able to say that the Commission, in the person of its president, has given proof of commendable moderation in commenting on the facts and I appreciate it immensely.I hope we will learn the lesson and avoid repeating such an experience based, in my opinion, on an incorrect interpretation of expectations, rather than on the bad faith by one of the two institutions.

The Commission reaffirmed and reaffirms today that shares the concerns underlying the declaration of January 31 of the Portuguese presidency.These concerns are legitimate and grounded.It will not be necessary to remember here the political trajectory of Jörg Haider and his numerous public statements, xenophobes and racist and, therefore, antieuropeas.That a clearly extremist, racist and xenophobic party comes to power in a Member State of the European Union cannot stop worrying the remaining states participating in the European project, nor does it leave indifferent to the European Commission.Second, the Commission reiterated and reiterates its commitment to continue exercising its duty as a guarantor of the treaties, particularly in relation to articles 6 and 7 of the Treaty of the Union.One of the important innovations of the Amsterdam Treaty was precisely the explanation of the fundamental principles that are the common heritage of the Member States and the institution of a mechanism to control their fulfillment and reaction in case of violation of one of these principles.The Commission thus demonstrated, in practice, its attachment to one of the basic principles -that of the rule of law -that imposes on the commission the obligation to act within the limits established by the treaties and in that framework the declaration of February 1 is located.The commission is not a state, it cannot and should not act as if it were.But to answer specifically to the question of his honor, I must remember that the mechanism instituted by section 1 of article 7 of the Treaty of the Union requires, to be activated, the verification -cito- "of a serious and persistent violation of the principles enshrined in article 6".Serious and persistent violation is - I repeat - the indispensable condition for the commission to propose to the Council the adoption of measures against a Member State.It seems clear to me that the conditions for its application to the situation in Austria are not met.For the rest, we all want - I don't think I fool myself in saying it - that these conditions of serious and persistent violation of human rights and democracy never come to be given, or in relation to Austria or in relation to any other state of the Union.But I want to guarantee him here, today, my personal effort and that of the commission, as President Prodi has reaffirmed this morning, to do everything that is needed so that it is not necessary to apply the device of article 7. But I also want to assure his lordships that we will not hesitate to apply it, if necessary.Too nuclear and essential values ​​are at stake so that contemplations or compounds can be admitted.Men and governments must be judged more for what they do for what they say.And in the case of Austria, the statements are at least contradictory.On the one hand, any of us can collect a set of incendiary phrases from the leader of the Austrian Liberal Party.On the other, the program of the new Austrian government renews its commitment to the defense of democracy and human rights.

In March of last year, a member of the Sam Raininte party was assassinated by a group of men in military uniform in the province of Kandal.In September, two members of the party were arrested on the grounds that they were involved in an attack on the arugula against the Prime Minister.Note that it is the only Cambodian party who does not have a military wing.In October, a parliamentarian of the same party was removed by men in uniform and was only released after payment of a ransom.The intimidation scheme is clear.But other things are still going on in Cambodia;Torture of prisoners, involvement of the army and the police in the trafficking of women and children, excessive preventive arrests.All this is on the agenda.Even more serious is the government's refusal to have the leaders of the Khmers Rouge judged by an international court.It is true that the civil war in Cambodia is over and that political tensions are less.However, the way in which the political opposition is treated at present causes us deep concerns and, if this continues, this must have consequences on the relations of the Union with Cambodia.Mr. President, a new doctrine is being trained in international law, according to which no state will no longer be able to deal with its citizens and people living in its territory anyhow and the sovereignty of a state can no longer prevent third parties from intervening in the event of aggravated human rights violations, even in cases where the leaders of a state have been legally or even democratically elected.Living examples of this were the case Pinochet-Ugarte and Kosovo or, less flagrant but within the Union itself, the debates on the formation of the new Austrian government.This development will now be compromised in Cambodia if the former management of the oppressive regime cannot be prosecuted.At the same time, we endanger the fight against impunity.The situation should also remind us of the fact that the ratification of B5-0173/2000 of the deputies Papayannakis and Sjöstedt, on behalf of the Gue/NGL, B5-0179/2000 of Schroedter deputies and others, in the name of the green group/ALE on the environmental disaster in the waters of the Danube.Mr. President, this week, we discussed the framework directive on water and the disaster in Romania shows us once again how seriously we have to take the protection of water.This disaster has raised a certain number of important questions that concern us as a European.We are delighted with the promise that rivers will be cleaned with the help of the EU.The strengthening of environmental consciousness, both in Romania and, more generally, in central and eastern Europe, is at least as important.We salute the speed of the visit of Commissioner Wallström on the spot because it can contribute to this awareness.In the end, it is a candidate state and this disaster adds to the already existing concern to know if all the candidate states will in time satisfy the EU environmental rules.The polluter must pay.I wonder if the European Union can pass on this kind of costs on environmental cowboys that work in what is called wild by using the weakness of environmental legislation on site.I would be favorable.Mr. President, the Commissioner, the ecological disasters follow each other and, unfortunately, are alike.There is enough to be dismayed, once again, by this serious pollution which today defiles the fourth wetland in Europe in order of importance.The Danube delta is in danger.As in Spain, in April 1998, as in Brittany and Vendée since last December, this time again, an exceptional natural site which is seriously threatened.In its resolutions, the European Parliament continues to draw attention to the dangers of this type that threaten our environment, upset our ecosystem and weaken, once again, the populations.This new catastrophe poses the problem of integration of the community acquired in environmental matters for candidate countries.The authorities of these states must overcome, still very fragile from an environmental point of view, are numerous.First, they should be able to prevent this type of spill more by developing the most critical industrial sites;Then, they should be able to have sufficient technical means to stop such pollution and reduce its magnitude;Finally, they should be able to implement programs to restore the most affected and sensitive sites.Today, the banks and waters of more than four rivers travel over four states are polluted.This is why the European Union must concentrate its efforts and pressures on the imperative need for all candidate countries, to align themselves on community environmental protection standards.But beyond that, it is the technologies and the means put in to prevent, and to meet this type of disasters quickly and effectively, which are involved.

To conclude, in relation to the Charter of fundamental rights, European citizens must become aware of their citizenship.The euro and occupation are not enough, nor safety.They need a "European soul", as an distinguished Spanish professor said.Mr. President, unlike some speakers intervened previously, I want to return to the words spoken by the Portuguese ministers and the Commissioner Vitore.The words of this trio were music for our ears, as Mr Ceyhun said.As with any type of music, the motif played must be intoned and adequately orchestrated.Many of us deputies are very optimistic about the next six months.The reason that will be played will be what European populations will listen to and want to hear the right type of melody.As mentioned this afternoon, it will serve to make some of the unpleasant melodies that we have listened to during the European elections and over the past few months.The Treaty of Amsterdam and the Council of Tampere were based on this project of a space of freedom, security and justice in the European Union.However, a sector is very important and Parliament must be involved, that is to say that of verification.There are many laws - and I really welcome the Portuguese program that was presented to us last week - but we must be absolutely sure that there is a control, that the members of Parliament and those of national parliaments as well as European citizens are aware of everything they entail.In addition, we must ascertain that the details are applicable, adequate and relevant to the various countries.I would like to draw attention to some aspects of the resolutions examined this afternoon, one or two of which have already been mentioned.I express my satisfaction for the tendency to recognize judicial systems in the various countries and cooperation in the fight against crime.It is a sector to which European citizens will respond with interest and of which they will be satisfied.The Commission and the Council must know, however, that many of us in the classroom nourish reserves on the Eurodac system, for example.We accept the predominant role of the Council in this area, but there are some reserves and I am sure that the Council will listen to the words expressed by European parliamentarians when the topic will be deepened.Mr Schulz said before not being sure about the definition of "scoreboard".Anyone who is English or British or follows the cricket knows what it is.A scoreboard serves to indicate the score and must be updated, clear and visible.I am sure that Commissioner Vitore will make sure that it is.At the end of the six months I hope that music continues to play and that Europeans are still listening to.Mr. President, I would like to welcome the President in office for the Council and his colleague of the Ministry of Justice, Mr. Costa, thanking them for the reception reserved for Lisbon last week to the commission I presided and for the construction meeting we had.Amsterdam and Tampere have given us a lot of work to be done together, as evidenced by the excellent resolution proposal presented today by the honorable terrón I Cusí.

To do this, a European Commission is needed, which, beyond good intentions, gives greater clarity to its directors and is committed to a maximum of control on the commitment of these resources by the Member States.Italy, for example, in recent years has had problems in using structural funds, above all due to excessive bureaucracy, a lack of information and the low involvement of economic and social operators at the local level.There are therefore two points on which I would like to attract the attention of the Commission: in the first place, it is necessary to make the best use of concertation as a method of coordination and participation in decisions by all local and regional operators, precisely to avoid imbalances and inequalities;Secondly, an authentic work of simplification and transparency of administrative processes is needed, which too often are unnecessarily long and complex to the point of affecting access to funds, which are especially complained of small and medium -sized European enterprises.I conclude, Mr. President, saying that it is quite serious that in the communication of the Commission a little attention to the territorial pacts and above all to the methods of fighting female and youth unemployment has been paid.Mr. President, in the same way for the honorable Evans, it is for me a particular pleasure to be able to stand up for my first intervention in this parliament during the discussion of a theme of this importance, especially since I represent the West Midlands, a region of the United Kingdom who has so far benefited from the funding reserved for objective 2. However, the relationship in question is a clear example of how we are not very cautious,who seem great, but which instead are devoid of consistency and therefore prove to be useless for those who should immediately benefit from it.The intent of the relationship is good but, as often happens when we deal with these issues, its objectives are not clearly defined and lacks a solid basis that can make it of some use.For this reason the reason my group and I propose three amendments and substantial additions to the text, aimed not so much to remove something from the proposal, but to make it more relevant for those to whom he must serve as a guide.I want to illustrate what our reasoning is.First, we want to ensure that the resources of the structural funds and the cohesion fund are used adequately.The past experience teaches us that we, as elected representatives of European taxpayers, must be demanded for prohibited and financial transparency in the disbursements and control of these funds.Therefore our amendments and additions are aimed at finding profitability indicators in the process of granting and spending on funds.Second, too often large sums of money are spent for projects whose results at the beginning of the programming are inevitably vague.But in the middle or end of this period there is no effective way to stop a project that proved to be useless.Therefore our additions ask to predict interruption strategies impossible to practice, so that not only is there the necessary guarantee in relation to current expenses, often poured on the taxpayer, but that we can also avoid the well -known syndrome for which you continue to spend money to carry on a project that has already proven to be a failure.

in the literal meaning of the term - with the proposed directive.On the one hand are the interests of the economy and also of the individual.In my considerations of the assumption that it is an honest individual who does a good job.On the other hand are the interests of the Member States that, in the face of those affected, perhaps should start from the idea that it is a Worst Case.If we are inclined to one of the extremes, namely the interests of the Member States, they are undoubtedly sufficient reasons to subject the service provision card to relatively strict conditions.From this point of view, it is legitimate to introduce the obligation of prior declaration, even when the use of the card is implanted.If I opt for the other extreme, that is, for the least amount of procedures as possible, it runs the risk that the procedure is staying in borage water, since, in that case, this directive will surely not have the approval of the Member States.I mean, one of two.Or I have a directive regarding the service provision card that does not really allow the card to be issued to anyone, since the demands imposed on the economy are too rigid, or I find myself without a directive.Both results are unsatisfactory.Perhaps this is the reason why, as they tell us, negotiations within the Council are also in dead road.We have struggled to find a point of intersection between one interest - the public order - and another.We have struggled to find the simplest solution.We want a solution that imposes demands on the economy, but that, once these demands have been exceeded, guarantee a simple application.

I should suggest, Mrs. President, that Parliament first waits for whether the party of Mr. Haider will influence the policy of that country.Then and only then could they judge whether human rights are affected.This parliament could consider suitable measures to counter this situation, and then, and only then, could it consider to interfere in the constitutional matters of a country of the European Union.Mrs. President, as a member of the Freedom Party, I respect the concerns of some colleagues about democratic development in Austria.You may be surprised about my reaction if I find that the special sensitivity to Austria in questioning human rights, the awareness of responsibility towards my own past and the stability of democracy meets my personal understanding.Austria has the often dubious image, which prevails abroad or unjustifiably, is responsible for itself.The years of refusal to admit our governments, our complicity to the horror of World War II, and the refusal of the governments of just reparation towards the Jewish victims and the forced labor have contributed significantly to this negative image.Now this FPÖ has entered a government coalition with the ÖVP due to an election order dated October 3, 1999, when the old government was elected.This is the right of the citizens of a state because it is the basic principle of a democracy.After the talks between the SPÖ and the ÖVP, the socialists tried to form a minority government and asked the FPÖ for support.We were offered three ministerial posts - you only need to read this in the newspapers -, of all people, of all people who is denounced here as a fascist!When we suddenly rejected this offer, a passionate agitation and propaganda began, which we still have not understood.The FPÖ is a party established in the political landscape of Austria.She puts the governor in one of the nine federal states and is involved in all other governments.Why, so many Austrians are wondering today, their democratic decision is suddenly interpreted as an expression of the fascist attitude, why did the agitation only began when the freedoms rejected the support of a minority government of the SPÖ?Here there is a preliminary conviction that - without responding to our program - reduces the cruelest epoch in European history into a political spectacle.It increases my disgust when some of our opponents take advantage of the million -dollar deaths in the gas chambers of the concentration camp for cheap propaganda, such as the Italian MP Bertinotti, who accused Herr Haider on Italy yesterday that he would deny the Holocaust.Ashamed, Mr. Colleague!Even if you assume all political arguments, you don't have the right to use the murdered for your cheap propaganda.You don't become an anti -fascist here if you denounce a democratically elected politician as a Nazi!On the contrary, they mock the true victims of National Socialism and trivialize the fascist dictatorships.They act because of their own prejudices, forego every political discussion and act exactly in the style they pretend.The attack against the new government of Austria, the attempt to influence political influence in a member country is an insult to the Austrian population.

We cannot afford to delay.An ambitious objective for the schedule is essential.I do not consider this to be too bold, if we assume that in 2020 there will be no more introductions to water and that we will strive for zero level in relation to contamination and the emission toxic substances.It is about doing what is technically possible, of course not more, but we have to be sufficiently ambitious.I would like to go into a problem that has already been addressed.In my opinion, the environmental committee has made the question of redistribution of water too tight.This is not just a problem in Spain, it is also due in the Nordic countries.I sincerely hope that national solutions will be trusted here, provided that they are better from an environmental and economic policy perspective than the solutions provided for in the directive.President, Ms. Commissioner!I would like to congratulate Ms. Lienemann on an excellent work.Water and air surround us everywhere.We share them with all the people on earth.Water is a prerequisite for human life that is more and more popular.Ms. Schleicher indicated this morning that clean water was an unrealistic demand.Nothing could be more incorrect!It is unrealistic to gradually worsen the water quality and thus the prerequisites for life.This is particularly unrealistic for agriculture, which is most dependent on a clean nature and clean natural riches.That is why I would like to appeal to the MPs of this parliament, to see that a clean environment is the greatest realism in the long term.Mr. President, we - and that also applies to me personally - support Ms. Lienemann's report as well as the goals set there and the guideline for debate.Nevertheless, we should take a closer look at some aspects.For example, the redirection of rivers and the build -up of water through lakes are major problems, alleged development projects, which in reality actually cause considerable dangers for the groundwater, the groundwater level and the surface waters.Regardless of whether we will ultimately agree on who can decide such diversions, the regulations must apply equally to everyone and are extremely strictly applied.In my opinion, the jumping point, Ms. Commissioner, is the planning of the restoration of the groundwater level and the natural river runs as well as the natural state of the lakes, which can be achieved within the time frame of ten years.Such projects should certainly be granted so that they can be funded financially, because ultimately such a restoration could prove to be a very excellent development policy measure.Mr. President, basically this is a good measure.It specifies realistic norms on which the principles of subsidiarity and the management of the water catchment areas are based.It pursues the right goal, which consists in the guarantee of good water quality for humans and animals, for the environment and economic purposes.The avoidance of water pollution and the deterioration in water quality, as well as the ability of the management at times of dryness and flooding, are desirable goals.

One of the reasons we were very interested in presenting it was that, we like it or not, the European Union is known for fraud and poor administration.Sometimes it is exaggerated about it, but it is.We have to do something about it.Some of the measures that we have adopted in the past have not been applied by some member states ... and we must not forget that the Member States are responsible for the approximately 80%application of the EU budget.Many of them have not signed, they have not ratified the agreement on the protection of the financial interests of European communities, so it was clear that something more radical had to be done.We must take this task seriously.It is necessary that people who commit fraud against the European Union can be processed.The question is: Who processes?That is when we really find difficulties.Who corresponds to that task when it comes to an organ that crosses so many borders?We must also be sensitive to the concerns of the Member States.The proposal for the creation of a European Fiscal Ministry is very delicate.We all know that a totally federal approach and a situation in which a European judicial authority has priority over national judicial authorities is a too advanced step for some.But it is necessary to initiate the debate about it, so we are going to ask the CIG to start the debates about it.Of the greatest importance for Parliament, as custodian of the European Union budget, it is how to address the issue of people working in the European Union institutions.At a time when we are examining the entire reform process, it is of decisive importance that we send the close signal.Citizens must understand that, if they commit fraud, they will be processed and at this time it is not.Mrs. Palacio has exposed in general the question of whether we have the legal authority to do so.I would like to say clearly that my group will propose an amendment to suppress details about how the commission should address that issue.We know that it is a delicate debate.We know that the commission may need a margin to negotiate a situation that was acceptable to all parties.Let me say clearly that in this case it is not a commitment to a corpus juris, a commitment to a federal European prosecutor.But of a clear commitment to change the status quo, which is totally unacceptable.Mr. President, I would like to start congratulating Mrs. Theato for her report.I think it is a great report that will largely be supported by my parliamentary group.I only have the feeling that deep down she wanted to have yet gone a little further in this stadium.Taking into account the debates of the last five, six months, it could have been the case.We all know that in 1995 it was agreed that a better criminal protection of the financial interests of the Union had to be implemented.

I refer to the intention expressed by Cuba, on February 2, to integrate as a full member in the ACP countries.In the last meeting of the ACP-EU Joint Assembly in Nassau, a Cuban delegation participated and vice chancellor Dalmau appeared before the Plenary, with whom a living debate occurred to which numerous conversations followed with many of us.After Nassau, a delegation of our Parliament, headed by Mr. Corrie himself and by the president of the Development and Cooperation Commission, Joaquín Miranda, visited Havana, producing a series of exchanges of very clarifying opinions.I have the impression that this mission of the European Parliament was the final push that convinced our Cuban friends of the appropriate to step forward in the mechanisms of cooperation with the European Union.We are facing a situation of remarkable political importance and I hope that from the European Parliament we will promote the relevant favorable vision and a generous attitude by the Union, which within the shortest period involves a positive response to the aspirations of Cuba.That will be important, at least for three reasons.It will be in the first place for Cuba, for the development and prosperity of its people and to definitely break the blockade imposed by the United States, which has been repeatedly condemned by the European Parliament and the United Nations.Secondly, we must keep in mind that Cuba's candidacy has been led by all ACP countries.If from the European Union, the recommendation of our associates is positively answered, we will be giving proof of respect and consideration towards said associates that will have positive effects throughout the framework of our cooperation with them.Nor can the value of a decision like the one I propose be ignored, as proof of coherence and autonomy of the European Union and its non -repeditation at any pressure.Accepting Cuba in the ACP community we will demonstrate that we are not a Europe immersed in the unworthy dynamics of paying but not playing, and that when we outraged ourselves before nonsense such as the Helms-Burton law we did not do it hypocritically but willing to act until the last consequences.In a few weeks the ACP-EU parity assembly will meet again and I am sure that this issue will be addressed in its bosom.It would be desirable that, in that procedure, the representation of the European Parliament lends its support for Cuban intentions as the parliamentary colleagues of the ACP countries will.Cuba must comply, naturally, with all the planned conditions as well as any other partner.That is known by Cubans and surely assume it.It must also be clear that Cuba is not going to be asked more than what has been requested to other interlocutors.Welcome to the will of adhesion of Cuba and welcome be Cuba to this circle of ours.I say it with all my heart but also with the deep conviction that, as well as the blockade has only produced misery and, as a consequence of it, tension and hardening by the Cubans, the integration that we are supporting here and the prosperity fruit of it will result in the distension and openness that we all want and of which all, especially the people of Cuba, we will benefit.

We took fifteen years for the economic and monetary union.We can take fifteen years for defense and security policy and foreign policy, but the process must be clear.I also think that you should not undervalue, this is a question that I ask you, the stranglehold and the strength of the lobbies of the Ministries of Foreign Affairs.We know the strength they have acquired during these forty years of community construction.Today, they would have everything to lose a communitarization of foreign policy, and I think they work in this sense.Finally, on the question of Kosovo - Mr. Cohn -Bendit was right to insist on this point - I believe that it is urgent that the European Union raises the question of the final status of this territory.Without this status, there will be only instability, murders, provocations on the part of Belgrade, and the European Union should be said on that urgently.Finally, I thank Mr. Poettering because I believe that the initiatives of Belgium, as they say in a little clear language, are starting to do well.I think that many Member States, among the fourteen other Member States, would have many reasons not to collaborate in the European Union meetings in matters of justice, for example.Four years from the arrest of Mr. Dutroux and others, we still have no trials, we still do not know what is happening.In terms of tourism too, many would be, among these fourteen member states, those which could question the opportunity to discourage the holidays of parents with young children in Belgium, for example.So, it is time, and I invite Mr. Solana and Mr. Patten, to share with the colleague, Mr. Michel, that perhaps, he does a little too much and that ultimately it risks, which I hope, to turn against him.Mr. President, I would first like to wish a very good March 1 to Mr. Solana, when a whole series of structures relating to European security and defense policy have been started.But I wonder to tell the truth, what he thinks.In the documents, there is a question of good collaboration with the high representative.You even said earlier that you discussed it during lunch;It would still be the height that you did not discuss it and that there is no good collaboration between the new structures and you!But don't you suffer from not chairing these structures yourself and not being at the center?I would like - like more than one within the Parliament, in my opinion - that you are the engine of these structures and that you do not risk being dismissed in any way.In recent months, especially during discussions with the members of the NATO assembly, the High representative Solana and Commissioner Patten have endeavored to delimit the defense policy of the European Union and that of NATO.

I have to recognize the immense work that you have done: the close rhythm of the meetings, the efforts made to establish a quick intervention force, the concrete actions aimed at preventing, management or resolution of crises through civil means and, where necessary, military.I would like to take advantage of his presence to ask them two questions that pertain to the contents of future actions.The first concerns the next European councils of June and December as well as the extraordinary Council of Lisbon.What are the fundamental and priority developments that would like to see made during the next leaders?And above all, what does it need most of these leaders?My second question is different, although it is somehow connected to the previous one.It concerns the next cig.Do you do not believe that the agenda of the CIG must contemplate the question of European security and defense policy in order to complete the treaties, if it should emerge that the current formulation of texts does not allow the implementation of an authentic defense policy?I believe that the president of the Italian Council raised this point during your meeting on February 24th.Can you illustrate your position on it?Mr. President, Bosnia and Kosovo have awakened Europe.The European Union finally recognizes that it cannot allow itself to always leave the political and military initiative to the Americans.The decision to create its own peace strength is excellent.However, if Europe, in a crucial moment, wants to be able to intervene on the military level, it is necessary to insert a flexibility clause in the treaty.Mr. Solana can play an important role.He is not a madman, certainly not.He is a busy and competent man.However, it is necessary to ask yourself if this accumulation of functions is not excessive compared to its skills.In addition to being a secretary general of the Council, Mr. Solana is a secretary general of UEO and high representative for foreign policy.He also holds the function of head of the political planning unit and prealling unit.Submerged by all these tasks, will he find time to rest, Mr. President?I believe that, from a democratic point of view, this accumulation of functions is substantially unacceptable, especially if we consider that Mr. Solana is not a democratically elected politician, but a high -level official who is not called to account for his work in front of any parliamentary assembly.His position threatens to overshadow that of Commissioner Patten, as it was also remembered today.The impression is that, with the development of European security and defense policy, the Commission and Parliament find themselves excluding from this process.I believe that this exclusion is also unacceptable.Evidently nothing should be left out that can make European politics more efficient, but this cannot lead to an undesirable concentration of power.Mr. Solana must awaken Europe without being caught by tiredness himself.Mr. President, the European Union was created first of all for peace.I am pleased that Commissioner Patten and Mr. Solana have underlined it several times.

Corporation" company have authorized the construction of a new port in the ZPS, and even the elimination of a mud plain located near Stegrennan which has been recently integrated into the ZPS on the specific insistence of the Commission.In addition, a huge deposit has been erected - regarding which it is proving to be difficult to obtain acex to the relevant building license - and the "Drug Correction" is planning the construction of other infrastructures.In what way can the commission ensure that this type of development, financed through structural funds, is not in conflict with the needs of conservation of nature in the region?Is it the commission willing to completely suspend funding, waiting for a review of the development plans concerning this area?The Commission is aware of the construction of the port, but has no information on deposits, nor on the other infrastructures appointed by the honorable parliamentary.The realization of the port is financed by the structural funds and substantially entails the dredging of the Estuary of the Boyne river and the temporary deposit of the dredging residues on the mud plain located near Stregrennan.The region of the Estuary of the Boyne river is classified as a special protection area pursuant to the wild bird directive.This implies that, for each exploitation activity conducted in the river summer or in its vicinity such as to be able to affect the special protection area, it is necessary to comply with the provisions for the safeguarding of the sanctioned area with the Community directive on habitats.
