Mr. President, Mrs. curator, the measures provided for in this Directive cover from the elaboration of water management plans, broad rights of information and consultation, and greater cooperation between the Member States, to the fight against water pollution for particular harmful substances.Knowing the years that this camera has been trying to get a framework of these characteristics, I congratulate myself that today we have reached this point and I would like to congratulate Mrs. Lienemann, who has been fortunate to present this report today.However, it also seems extremely important to verify an aspect that many consider, in fact, obvious.Still I would like to highlight it.The directive does not offer any legal base, in any way, to divert water from the territory of a Member State against its will.In order to confirm once again this point, I have presented an amendment - with great support from the PPE, that I appreciate - and it would be a great satisfaction for me that it obtained the affirmative vote of the Assembly tomorrow.Its purpose is to make it clear that the water - as it has already been repeatedly highlighted today - is not a current merchandise, but a good that belongs to the population of the corresponding Member State of the Union and that it must receive a protection and treatment that this fact takes into account.I know, and the speaker that has preceded me has stressed, that some states of the European Union have water problems.I believe that all of us have the possibility of better managing water in our countries and promoting less pollutant use of water.No country can be exempt from this effort.Only when each country has made the maximum effort to conserve its water resources, when in the country itself it has really been done as much as it could be done, only then we can contemplate, in my opinion, a solidarity of water, if necessary.Mr. President, Mrs. curator, should be a reason for joy that the second reading of this directive was already on the table.However, I have to say that I am not very happy because I think it is a directive that does not have great quality, that it will raise many application problems and that it has many deficiencies.First, I think it is an excessively hard and simplistic directive, reductionist.No other directives have been fulfilled many times that already existed regarding water and governments and the commission on many occasions have not imposed discipline as they should have done it, although I know it is not pleasant.It is not a matter of having a much harder regulation because the problems in many cases are management, of assuming the powers that one has and not transferring to the legislative the big problems that the water system has, whose complication we all know.A reductionist directive has been made;They cannot be put in the same sack countries that have navigable rivers along with others that have water, whose land opens with large cracks because they lack it and that are at 55º or 60º in the sun.

The second problematic aspect concerns the data to be collected according to the regulation.First, as regards economic data, amendment no.2 provides two changes.The first is aimed at ensuring that the collected data are limited to the objective to be pursued.The second modification consists in replacing the reference to sales products and other financial revenues, subsidies, interest collected, etc., with a simple reference to the volume of sales.It is thought that without these changes the Member States may have to bear too high costs for the collection of data and the problem of confidentiality would also be presented.In line with these changes, in amendment no.5 The reference to accounting items has been suppressed.Secondly, as regards environmental data, the original proposal only speaks of biological and economic information.The Commission, however, clarified that it intends to engage in studies and more wider pilot projects in the environmental field and that it may want to expand the series of data collected by the Member States at a later time.Amendment no.3 The data necessary to monitor the changes of aquatic ecosystems is included in the regulation.This obviously will facilitate the introduction of a new regulation on environmental data, and could even make it useless.It should be noted that the amendment does not oblige the Commission in any way to include the collection of such data neither in the minimum program nor in the extended program, but gives the Commission the possibility of doing it.As has already been said, the Council decision proposal can be divided into two parts.The first concerns the financing of the Member States for the application of Community programs.The second provides that the commission itself can finance studies and pilot projects.There are some amendments of minor importance, such as amendment no.2, aimed at ensuring that the financial contribution to the Member States can cover not only the costs of the collection of data, but also those of their management, compilation, aggregation, etc.The amendments nos.3 and 6 aim to accelerate the times of application of the regulation and to allow Member States to know the content of the programs as soon as possible.Furthermore, these amendments aim to align these implementing times with the dates and with the regulation.The amendments nos.4 and 5 are aimed at ensuring that financial information is continuously provided to the budget authority.More in particular, through amendment no.1, the Commission for Fishing welcomes the recommendation of the Commission for Budgets that asked to put the funding under the 1b address book instead of under the book 3 of the financial perspectives.Although in the preliminary budget draft the Commission had placed the allocations in the 3 "internal policies" section, Parliament created the new Budget item B1-500 to finance the measures we are discussing, in order to ensure that the necessary resources continue to be available.Mr. President, I consider it appropriate to fully agree with the honorable Attwoll who, at the beginning of his excellent report, said that the two proposals of the Commission, aimed at knowing more in depth the scientific and socio -economic situation of the fishing sector, arrive at a critical moment.

There are two reasons for our refusal.It is, Primo, a terribly complex and very sensitive legal question, and the proposal presents, in my eyes, certain risks for legal certainty which has not been aware.This reason is sufficient in itself to explain our refusal to vote the proposal, but there is a second reason: even if it is an agreement, that is to say a collaboration between states, the proposal gives off very clear trends, namely the creation, in the longer term, of a common European jurisdictional space, a common European penal code and a common common administration of justice.We are opposed to this evolution, we are against this mantra "a space of freedom, security and justice", which consists in creating in a barbaric manner of community systems, certain legal traditions linked to these sensitive and important questions, which are above all national prerogatives.Mr. President, I too think that the convention that we examine today is only a small step, still too small, in the construction of this common space of freedom, security and justice that - we hope - Europe will be one day.Europe is today a space for the free movement of goods and people where crime knows no borders, while obstacles that are difficult to overcome still stand on the way to those who have to fight it.A small step - I said - but which is welcome.The Committee on Freedoms and Rights of Citizens, Justice and Internal Affairs has precisely wanted to prescribe other limits and protections in the name of the defense of the fundamental rights of persons, which are in force in the States and within the Union, even if they are not yet devoted to a Charter of the Rights of the European Union which, we hope, will soon see the light of day: just limits and protections because the rights in forcerespected by all public authorities of all states.In certain passages of the commission's proposals, no doubt we have exaggerated in terms of precautions as when you wanted to give the accused the choice to accept or refuse his temporary transfer to another Member State of the Union for the requirements of the instruction.Personally, I cannot accept, for example, that Mr. Pinochet is authorized to choose to be transferred or not to Spain for a confrontation.Or, when you wanted the witness or the expert - and not only the person under investigation, the accused - is entitled to a defender for remote interrogations.These are slight faults, not wanted by the rapporteur, to which will remedy - I hope - the vote of this assembly.The rapporteur has done a work worthy of praise, which I take note of which I thank him for.The overall result is appreciable and I hope that the council will take fully into account.Like other deputies have already pointed out, a point - the most delicate - remains unresolved: it is article 18 of the convention concerning the interception of communications which intervene in a Member State, carried out directly by another Member State without requesting mutual aid of the State where the interception takes place, proceedings made possible today thanks to modern technologies.

The European Council of Helsinki approved the enlargement to 13 Member States.There is therefore inconsistency between the opening of membership negotiations with these 13 countries and the wish to proceed only to a minimis reform.As far as we are concerned, located in the logic of the treaty, we want the agenda of the next intergovernmental conference to allow a much deeper reform of the union.That said, Mr. President, the Parliament is holding this debate today because he did not want to delay the start of the conference.Theoretically, we could have done it.We could have voted on the 17th of this month, so that the conference could not have started on the 14th. But we did not want to do so, because we wanted to send a clear political message to governments and countries candidate for membership: we want to carry out this reform to facilitate enlargement.Mr. President, I am delighted to be able to say it to the Portuguese presidency, because she has acquired great esteem in this assembly.The Portuguese presidency shares a number of aspirations of this Parliament and is committed to doing their best so that the agenda of the intergovernmental conference includes other subjects, which are absolutely necessary.I want to say, Mr. President, that this aspiration of the European Parliament is disinterested.The latter, in any case, will be politically reinforced by the treaty from this intergovernmental conference, simply because during this intergovernmental conference, in accordance with what was decided in Helsinki, we will examine which matters currently subject to unanimousness will pass to the qualified majority.The number of matters decided by qualified majority will therefore increase.However, the community acquired already provides that the legislative matters decided by qualified majority will also be subject to the codecision of the Parliament.Consequently, if there is an extension of the qualified majority, there will also be expanding the codecision of the Parliament.But the Parliament would not accomplish its task of supranational European institution if he did not think of the political project of the Union.We are going there.We believe that other questions should be tackled with a view to this Union political project.Among other questions, those linked to integration into the treaty of security and defense problems, subjects that have progressed a lot lately but which should be introduced into the treaty.The same goes for the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, of course, of which we started the editorial staff yesterday, and I believe that this beginning was carried out in a very positive way.We will work seriously so that Europeans see that being European represents a plus and that European citizen has fundamental rights which bind the institutions of the Union.Consequently, Mr. President, our proposals, which we will concretize in a new report, will constitute, with the proposals of the Commission, which produced an excellent document I am delighted to provide it here to Mr. Barnier, documents of the conference.

First of all, I would like to emphasize that the debate on issues concerning social protection began within European institutions several years ago and that, in 1995, the first communication entitled experiences between the Member States regarding the most successful programs.Thirdly, as regards the four aspects on which the communication in question is concentrated, namely the paid work, the sustainability of pension systems, social integration and the quality of health, there is a horizontal approach to the female question, given that in each of the four sections, as reported by the creation of a database for better coordination of policies.As reported by many parliamentarians, I think an important step has already been taken: the CIG the issues of social protection will be I would like to formulate three observations.The first is that a mature dialogue between Council and European Parliament is essential.Just six months have passed since Amsterdam has imposed our two institutions to work together;We studied each other, we had some small bickering, but we actually need to work together.Let's stop not taking things seriously.We abandon the elaborate charades and respect the duties that the treaties impose us and the times granted for a truly democratic discussion.Involve us in your discussions on policy and evolution of the process.We do not pretend that national parliaments can carry out an effective democratic control power of government activities in this sector.My second observation is that a commission with adequate resources is needed.We have constituted a new general management, yet in everything it has only 70 people.There is an agreement that plans to double this number, but as far as I appear so far no new resource has arrived.We are entrusting the commission a very heavy task, not least that of drawing up the scoreboard.Council and Parliament must cooperate to provide the resources that the Commission needs.Finally, regarding the content of the discussion, I willingly welcome the fact that the presidency has placed the space of freedom, security and justice at the top of its program.The three seems to be the number that distinguishes positive things, especially in the European policy sector.Two hundred years ago they were freedom, equality and fraternity and everything went well until the governments of the left made equality prevail over everything else.Now these are freedom, security and justice, and I hope that the current left -wing governments take into account the words of Commissioner Vitore and resist the temptation to raise security, however important it is, above the equally important needs of freedom and justice.Mr. President, I would like to join my colleagues in welcoming the representatives of the Council and the Commissioner.I thank them for the declarations they provide to the assembly.Instead of returning to the topics that have already been covered, I would like to dwell on a specific theme: the question of drugs and the way we deal with the spread of drug culture in our societies.I hope in particular that the Portuguese presidency exploits part of the enormous work done by the Finnish presidency and present plans and actions coordinated between the Member States.At international level, there are already struggle programs against drug trafficking, recycling dirty money and so on, but also, from a more properly human point of view, programs to provide assistance to those who try to get rid of drug addiction, with adequate controls and mechanisms for rehabilitation;second, to ensure coordination between the police forces and the judicial systems regarding common penalties and laws;third, to undertake an information and awareness campaign for young people;And to end once and for all to the very dangerous terms of "normalization" and "damage reduction" and demonstrate that any weakening of our determination to prevent the drug from being legalized must be for the good of all.

required to take these factors into account and to enable the continuation of a universal and affordable postal service.In the name of all of our remote and island communities, wherever they may be in the European Union, and not only on behalf of the population in Scotland, I request that you receive the vital line that the postal service represents.President!I consider it a privilege to be able to represent my colleague, Commissioner Bolkestein, in a qualitatively high -ranking debate about postal services.I want to try to give an answer to the questions raised in the discussion based on the information that Commissioner Bolkestein sent to me.I would like to repeat that Commissioner Bolkestein will be available to the parliamentary committee for regional policy, transport and tourism on Monday.Some MPs, as Mr. Stenmarck, complain that there were delays with the new proposal.Others believe that it is not bad if a little break occurs after the first liberalization step.This is the opinion, for example, Mr. Berthu.The commission's point of view is that the delays in connection with the new proposal are mainly due to the main problems that should not be completely unknown to Parliament.However, we think there is a legal obligation that a proposal will be submitted.It is Commissioner Bolkestein intention to present the Commission such a proposal for acceptance in the first half of this year.January 1, 2003 as a planned date for the implementation of the next steps is still feasible.The proposal will take into account the studies carried out and, in particular, check questions such as universal service that I will come back to.As for the valid guideline and its implementation, most Member States have taken the necessary legal measures to implement them.A number of problems are related to the structure of the regulator and its independence.The appointment of the implementation for the Member States is January 2003. Further liberalization will be carried out afterwards.The competition already takes place in some areas, for example in the parcel service and in the press service.The quality of the services has generally improved, especially in cross -border traffic.The quality of the services so important for consumers was the main concern of all speakers, and some of them, like Mr. Rübig, were very clear on this question.The experiences in the countries in which liberalization has already progressed, such as Sweden, Finland and the Netherlands, show that the quality of the service, if the liberalization runs properly, can be increased as a result of the requirements for a higher quality of the service placed by national regulations and the following measures.So there is no sale of the service and its quality.Often liberalizations lead to guaranteed standards, and the continuous standardization of the measurement of the service quality also contributes to this, since these standards better reflect the actual performance.This allows sensible benchmarking and, as a result of the bundled pressure, regulators, competitors and customers an improved customer orientation by the responsible operator.

tightened conditions for the issuing of the service certificate must be met.The requirements of proper employment, legal stay and insurance cover must not only be given at the time of the exhibition of the ID, but during the entire validity period of the ID and three months later.This should guarantee the reception state that the employee or the self -employed person returns to the sending state after the order made and is covered with insurance law in the event of illness and accident.The entry and residence situation should also be clarified before issuing the service certificate, as part thinking here of the flagship program.The name of the Republic, Mr. President, is still a problem due to the Greek susceptibilities.I leave from the principle that the Member States will feel more and more free to use in their own language the name suitable for the Republic.If some countries wish to keep the words ex-Yugoslavia, it is their business, others should not be obliged to it.There is no Is the application of a tax taxation base based on alcohol equivalent?The question of excise duties, which refers to the honorable parliamentary, is the responsibility of the Member States in question.The Commission does not have any tool to impose a reduction or increase in excise duties on alcoholic beverages or other products.Towards the end of the year, the Commission will present a report on the differentials of excise duties between the Member States.It is out of doubt that such a relationship will arouse a discussion both with Parliament and with the Council, given the substantial differences in the level of the rates of excise duties between the Member States.For example, it seems to me that the honorable parliamentary referred to this aspect, in France there are no excise duties on wine, while in the United Kingdom yes: this determines a distortion of the single market because the wine is marked by France in the United Kingdom.The question specifically focused on the relationship between excise duties and alcohol tenor in the assets subject to excise duty.The Commission does not have tools to intervene.In the case of Sweden, in fact, excise duties are used to reduce alcohol consumption.Although this measure entails a disparity of excise duties between Sweden and the other Member States of the Union, - and this in turn increases the transfrontier contraband of alcohol - it is a legitimate tool to reduce the consumption of alcohol.Obviously there is also the elasticity of the demand, in our case the elasticity of the price of the demand.I'm not sure what the value is, but it is not the same as zero and therefore produces an effect.My question would have been practically identical to that of Mr Purvis, but I allow myself to insist.Given that, as you say, excise duties are a prerogative of the Member States, the use of this prerogative in a way that produces an unjust discrimination of manufacturers in a region of the community compared to others, it could still be in conflict with the principle of the single market.Returning to the example of the honorable Purvis, and I think in particular of the production of whiskey of malt in the highlands, - an ultra -aperitical region of Europe, deeply depressed, with an entire agricultural community that depends on this production as well as the distillery sector - the widespread practice of imposing higher excise excuses on the alcohol contained in the Scottish whiskey, in the Dutch GinDanese compared to alcohol in beer or wine seems to me a discrimination and a discriminatory use of a faculty that is declaredly prerogative of the Member States.I can confirm to the honorable Maccormick and the other honorable parliamentarians that the current situation, namely the existence of diversified excise duties between the Member States, in fact does not favor the proper functioning of the single market.We must not only limit ourselves to alcoholic beverages.In the case of gasoline, for example, excise duties in Germany are different from those in the Netherlands and consequently Dutch motorists cross borders to go to the full in Germany.It is obviously a distortion of the internal market.

The civil war is over in Cambodia and has relaxed the political situation, but the way the political opposition is now treated fulfills us with great concern.If it goes on like this, this must also have consequences for the relationships between the Union to Cambodia.President!In international law, a new doctrine currently prevails that no state may treat its citizens and the people living in his field as he wants, and state sovereignty is not an obstacle to an intervention from outside due to gross human rights violations, even if the government itself has been chosen legally or even democratically.Objection examples of this are the case of Pinochet-Ugarte, the Kosovo conflict and in a weakened form the debate on government formation in Austria in the Union's own ranks.The same danger now exists in Cambodia if it is not possible to legally responsible for the former leadership of the regime.At the same time, the fight against impunity, the impunity of those responsible, is endangered.This situation should also realize us that the ratification of the contract to establish an international criminal court is slow.President!We had an extremely useful debate about human rights yesterday.I am pleased that there was now an opportunity to illuminate a number of areas in the world - Kosovo, Angola, Chechnya and Cambodia - in which the protection of human rights is a particularly great challenge.First to Kosovo.The Commission fully shares the concerns expressed in the defense designs with regard to general politics towards Kosovo, with regard to the ongoing ethnic acts of violence and with regard to the prisoners in Serbian prison.Our efforts in Kosovo and the other region are aimed at short and medium-term recovery of the situation and long-term stabilization.In particular, we support the development of a free, democratic and multi -ethnic society.Our aid programs in the fields of democratization and human rights should be continued in order to create trust in general and in particular in order to create trust between the different communities as possible.We have always condemned ethnic violence, regardless of which ethnic group is perpetrator or victim.We consider them just as unacceptable to the minorities of the Serbs and Roma, as we have thought in the past to be unacceptable to the Kosovo Albanians.We support the efforts of the Unmik, the KFOR and OSCE to build up a functional civil administration and to ensure law and order.In this context, we are emphatically advocating the latest appeal from the high representative to the Member States to provide more police officers for the UN Civil Police Mission in Kosovo.This point was addressed in the pronunciation of several speakers.Hopefully this makes it clear that we have to devote ourselves to both the non-military and military aspects of this policy in developing a common foreign and security policy.We have to have clear objectives for our control activity and the establishment of institutions, but it is just as important that we have clear objectives for a military capacity.We are still very concerned about the fact that so many civilians are currently being recorded in the expectation of their procedure or after their conviction in Serbian prisons.

My answer is perhaps little satisfactory right now, but I would like to assure your honor that the Commission will make that decision in a matter of weeks.I ask for your understanding for this small delay in the decision of the Commission.Mr. Commissioner, do you have any reason, for public health reasons, to make a difference in the tax rates that are applied, for example, on the Scottish whiskey or the French Burgundy Wine or even on the Bavarian beer of my colleague?Is it possible to provide for the application of an equivalent base for alcoholic beverages in the European tax system?The question of tax on specific consumption taxes, referred to in the honor, is a prerogative of the Member State in question.The Commission does not have instruments to apply an increase or reduction of special taxes on alcoholic products or on any other product.By the end of this year, the Commission will submit a report on the differences that exist between the Member States in the field of specific consumption taxes.The report will undoubtedly trigger a debate with Parliament and with the Council on the current situation, which reflects the existence of great differences between member states in regard to special tax rates.For example, in France - and I think it is what your honor referred to - the wine is exempt from special taxes, while in the United Kingdom it is not.This produces a distortion of the internal market, which results in the smuggling of French wine in the United Kingdom.The issue is relative specifically to the relationship between special taxes and the degree of alcohol of products subject to specific consumption taxes.The commission has no means at its disposal to intervene in this area.In the case of Sweden, the instrument of specific consumption taxes is used to stop alcohol consumption.Although this practice results in inequalities in special taxes between Sweden and other member states of the Union -which only increases cross -border smuggling of alcoholic products -is a legitimate instrument to reduce alcohol consumption.There is naturally elasticity of demand, in this case, an elasticity of the price of demand.I am not very sure of what is exactly, but it is not zero, therefore, it has to have repercussions.My question would have been almost identical to what Mr. Purvis has asked, but I would like to insist a little more on the subject.Okay, as you say, specific consumption taxes are part of the prerogatives of Member States.However, the use of that prerogative so that it unfairly discriminates against the producers of a part of the community with respect to those of others could violate the principle of the single market.For example, if we take the case where Mr. Purvis and I were thinking, that of the highlands where the malt whiskey is produced -a very peripheral area of ​​Europe that is in a difficult situation, in which an entire agricultural community, in addition to the distiller community dependsOr the Danish Aquavit with a type higher than the alcohol of beer or wine alcohol, it seems to me that it is discrimination and that makes discriminatory use of something that, I recognize, is part of the prerogatives of the Member States.

Next week I go to Bundestag, in Berlin.I have already gone to the French Senate.Thus, throughout all that debate, whenever I can, I will go directly to see the national deputies.It is not, regarding dialogue with citizens, to propaganda or advertising or communication even.I would like it to be a real dialogue and that, after the exhibition of a small filming in which the imperatives of the institutional reform are objectively explained, those present in the stands can intervene and respond with the open microphone.We are going to carry out -repito- that dialogue initiative in sporadic or structured cooperation with the Member States and ardently desire that the governments of the fifteen, with the support of their lordships, participate, according to the modalities they consider more appropriate and adequate, in that dialogue initiative.Mr. President, I would like to add to the Circle of Studies of Mr. Barnier composed of the 700 fellows to have those who debate.It is not very fun to have to discuss the government conference and transparency with oneself.Regarding the government conference, Mr. Barnier said during his presentation in the Parliament that social policy was not subject to decisions by majority, however, when taking a look at page 63, I see that the fight against discrimination, the right of free circulation and establishment -that is, the directives on stay -, all social security, the renewal of regulations no.1408, of measures in the field of social policy - with few exceptions - they will submit to qualified majority.Doesn't Mr. Barnier produce repair to touch with it the spine of the electoral processes of the member countries?It is these issues that make the population go to the polls and those that lead to a new majority in the Danish Parliament and other parliaments.Can they be regulated from Brussels?Is this starts from the decentralization process of the one that Mr. Prodi spoke this morning?I experienced great satisfaction when last week I learned that the Commission will pay special attention to the concept of subsidiarity, and its reference, not only to relations between the Union and the Member States, but also between the Union, the Member States, the Regions and the Cities.I hope that in the search for dialogue by the regions of Europe, Commissioner Barnier deepens that thought and learns from what he hears.Mr. Commissioner, I mean one of your answers to the previous questions in which you have mentioned what I call the closing possibilities of the treaty to the risks of deviation and, in particular, the diversification of the sanctions that can fall on a Member State, in accordance with article 7, for violation of fundamental freedoms.Do you think that these proposals or proposals of that nature can be part of the CIG's mandate, as formulated in Helsinki?For my part, it does not seem to me.Don't you fear that such sanctions are diverted and do not serve to punish human rights violations, but simple divergences, opinion crimes or divergences regarding the dominant European thought?

have to talk about Corus, the merger made between Nederlands Hoogevenens and British Steel.I would like to frame the discussion in a slightly wider context, analyzing the relationship between that the general directions of the Commission and the various commissioners develop a wider vision of the corporate governments.I think this would be extremely appropriate in consideration of the programs presented in recent days regarding the good government in Europe, which also includes corporate policy.Also in Italy the government meets the delegation of the unions and delegates of the Goodyear to try to find a solution to the closing policy unilaterally decided by the North American multinational in an area of ​​Central Italy, Cisterna di Latina, already affected by other The time for questions to the Commission is closed.(The session, suspended at 7:30 p.m., is resumed at 9 p.m.) Community policy in the water field (continued) The agenda calls for the rest of the debate on the recommendation for the second reading relating to community policy in the field of water.Mr. President, the situation of soft waters in Europe is not as serious as in other parts of the world but, in general terms, it is a fact that the demand for water has continued to grow and quality, to decrease.To this must be added the problems of water pollution that strike the possible new member states of the East.Didn't a tank containing cyanide have just broken in Romania, threatening the aquifers who supply the population of Yugoslavia?I understood that Ms. Wallström, that I thank very much for her presence this evening, will go to the region.I believe that no country, no government and, of course, no member of this Parliament can deny the need for this directive to put an end to the fragmentation currently characterizing water policy and facilitate the start of a program of measures specific to each hydrographic basin.Gestation was difficult and complex, the interests at stake are multiple and the opinions, shared.I have no doubt that the rapporteur in this legislature, Ms. Lienemann, has made a big effort and a lot of time to reconcile and reconcile the positions and she has largely succeeded.Nevertheless, knowing and correctly assessing all situations and perspectives is an almost impossible task.I come from a country, half of which looks at the Mediterranean and where the availability of water historically responds to the whims of a changing climate and a difficult configuration of the terrain.The Mediterranean region had to fight for its development by trying to overcome this adversity century after century, year after year and day after day until today.This is why the practical application made by the directive of the obligation, taken up in article 164 of the treaty, according to which community legislation must take into account the diversity of its regions, seems essential to us.Precisely in application of this principle, the Spanish delegation of the European People's Party will oppose amendments 4 (considering 21), 13 and 49 (article 11, letter D) because they imply a serious limitation in a field of exclusive management of Member States such as the regulation of their water resources.The community could very difficult to determine the conditions of its regulations in the different regions, given the different internal balances which are always at stake and which in any case require an in -depth knowledge of the different areas and interests concerned.Similarly, we reject the amendments which aim to include the total cost of water for 2010. We must undoubtedly set water prices which encourage its effective use but which, at the same time, allow to maintain the competitiveness of the production sectors in the most disadvantaged regions and which do not prevent their legitimate development.

I have the pleasure of giving a hot welcome to Mr. Javier Solana, to whom I immediately grant the word.- Mrs. President, as her honor can imagine is for me a great pleasure to be again with her lordships here in the European Parliament.Since the last time, ladies, gentlemen deputies, who appeared before their lordships to tell them about the issues related to foreign policy and security in our continent, many things have happened.Sometimes we would think that too many have passed.I would like this afternoon to share with you some ideas, fundamentally about common foreign policy and security. It is true, as I said, that the world has moved a lot in recent months and a good number of events have taken place, but I will leave for the time of questions and answers to specify, if your lordships have it well, some of the questions that you want to ask me.Throughout these months, since the last time I appeared before their lordships, important events have taken place here, also in the European Union.Let me remember two.One very dear to all, members of Parliament, and especially for the Presidency: the inauguration of the Intergovernmental Conference and the opening of negotiations with future members of the European Union.Without a doubt, Kosovo's events and in general in the Balkans have mobilized all our hearts and our intelligence;Important matters in the Middle East, where the president of Parliament has played an important role in her last trip;Some important events to unlock the summit between Europe and Africa, in which I had the satisfaction of participating in cooperation with the Portuguese presidency;The great meeting that took place in Portugal, in Vilamoura, with the eighteen Latin American countries to also try to build a deeper end of my intervention, after an important conversation that I have had this morning with the representative of the Council of Europe, Mr. Álvaro Gil-Robles, about the visit he has just made to the region.But I understand that their lordships have asked me for this appearance to speak to them more directly about foreign policy and especially about the security policy in Europe after Helsinki.I am going to refer briefly;If your lordships are good, asking questions in the question session, I will gladly answer them.Let me remember that in Helsinki, the summit under the Finnish presidency took place not a century ago, but scarcely two months ago.In Helsinki, fundamental decisions were made for foreign and security policy in our continent.

While restructuring to improve competitiveness and conquering market shares from an economic aspects are commendable, such a measure can be reduced if, at the request of the financiers, who are often the only shallow holder, they are the only purpose of increasing the asset of these companies in order to be able to achieve greater profits.The different announcements of my colleagues in recent times, be it on the part of Michelin or Goodyear, are symptomatic in this regard.In my opinion, rationalization of management and better results must primarily serve the company and therefore its employees, although there may also be financial effects.Today, a process of corporate mergers and mergers as well as relocation of production with their known effects on product quality as well as with the human level, especially for the family as a core cell of society, dramatic social effects, in particular unemployment, difficult working conditions and greater flexibility.So there is a great risk of a division of our planet: On the one hand, the poor countries that provide workers and on the other the rich countries that procure capital.Doesn't Europe have to offer protection to maintain a certain balance between higher profitability and social well -being?We should not forget that the human capital presents the basis for the operation of a company that ensures good results.Finally, I would like to point out that the third letter means "difference" in the name of the group that I belong.Europe has the task of raising its voice as an alternative to the exclusively profit -oriented restructuring, which are not subject to rules, which points in this uniform current of restructuring in a different direction.President!In one of my neighboring regions, the Michelin Group announced extensive layoffs in their work in Stoke-on-Trent last month due to the restructuring of the company and increasing global competitive pressure on the world market for mature.Like all of the MPs present, this loss at workplaces is saddened by me.I also saddle the announcement by Goodyear, which gave the occasion for this resolution.However, I very much doubt whether a European works council would have been able to change the decision of this company.This high house is really very good in writing resolutions and laws, and sometimes we forget in this institution that Europe alone cannot survive.We need multinational companies that have their business basis on our continent.After the few months I am here, I find it astonishing that we all talk about the need to promote corporate growth in the EU, but with almost all of our resolutions, the companies actually cause the companies to leave.At our last plenary conference in Brussels, we voted on the Altakuto Directive and brought about a retrospective law that has huge additional costs for the European motor vehicle manufacturers that they could not foreseen.Two days later, Toyota said that with several thousand employees in my region, this guideline would not only increase the costs of cars, but could also mean layoffs for his work in derbyshire.In a world in which there is certainly less regulation, we apparently believe in this house that we can expect more regulation and more costs to the companies and that, without the temptation of other locations, they will remain in the European Union.

We cannot therefore completely tell each other dissatisfied with what was obtained.Of course it is always better to be able to have more resources - I will continue to insist on this point - and in faster times.I consider, however, that this program offers good prospects to many others.I would like to emphasize that culture is not financed exclusively starting from this fund.Culture is not only part of the chapter that bears this name, but falls into numerous other areas.Huge resources in favor of culture are also available within the structural funds, an aspect that we must take into consideration and highlight.Fortunately for me, I am part of the Commission for regional policy, transport and tourism and therefore I was able to use me so that this aspect receives the attention it deserves.I also believe that it was decided to support the position according to which the expected budget is sufficient.If, in fact, the proposed changes will not go through, citizens will pay the consequences.I have always supported the speaker from this point of view.I consider, however, that it is necessary, as the speaker reiterates, to reach a modification of the codecision within the cig.In this case it will no longer be essential to resort to unanimity.We evaluate the numerous improvements that have been made extremely positively.We no longer speak of megaprogetti, space is left to cultural networks, and the attention shifts to the promotion of reading and translations, very important themes for the smallest linguistic areas.I would like to congratulate the speaker and the honorable Reding for this text on Culture 2000. We have developed parks everywhere, which constitute a key element of the Life program.The fact remains that these parks, made with few financial means, without signaling, have no effect and are useless.This is why I invite Parliament and the Commission to give this question all the attention it deserves.Mr. President, Ladies and Gentlemen, since the beginning of 1999, discussions have taken place between the institutions regarding the proposed regulations concerning a third stage for the instrument for the environment - Life.I would like to congratulate the Environment Commission and Ms. Lienemann for the excellent and constructive collaboration that we had in this area.Thanks to this, I can confirm that the Commission can accept in full or in their nine principle of the fourteen amendments that have been adopted by the Environment Commission.The Commission approves above all the amendments 1, 2, 7, 8, 9, 11 and 13, relating to the comitology procedures.Parliament has, in this case, fully taken into account the objections of the Commission against the common position.The Commission may also approve in principle amendment 4, which must however be introduced in another way into the text.With regard to amendments 5 and 6, I would like to emphasize that the project for a sustainable exploitation of groundwater and surface water, as well as the project to limit air pollutants which contribute to the greenhouse effect are largely taken up by Life.However, the Commission considers that mentioning this apart goes against the initial decision to center the proposal on some priority points.There is also a risk of overlap with other community programs such as the fifth framework program for research, technological development and demonstration actions.The key measures of this program - the quality of the water, the city of tomorrow and the innovative products and processes - partly use the same subjects.As for the budget, I am delighted with the confidence shown by the Environment Commission.Amendment 12 offers a larger budget than that set in the common position.I am also convinced that Life has enormous potential.This instrument could finance good projects with credits higher than those mentioned in the budget proposal.The amount fixed in amendment 12, however, does not comply with the budgetary plan established on the basis of the 2000 agenda. Allow me to add that if we increase the budget it is obvious that we will also require the environment directorate that it deals with a growing number of projects.It is also necessary to take into account other programs, for which decisions must be made within the framework of the CODECISION procedure.The Commission sticks, in this stage, to the amount fixed in the common position.With regard to amendment 3, which we did not adopt during the first reading, I would like to emphasize that each program has its own objectives, eligible costs and requests.

Social integration, which requires a firm commitment in economic, political and social terms on the part of the responsible authorities, is the only way to prevent these events from happening again where there are already important communities of immigrant workers.We are all immigrants.For generations, the human being has not always stayed inside the borders of a nation state.There have constantly had migratory flows.Geographic mobility is not an invention of the 20th century, nor their economic and work reasons.We are all immigrants, whether personally or by a member of our family or one of our ancestors.However, instead of being at the origin of events that we condemn here, these migratory flows must be generating social, cultural and economic enrichment.We believe that what has happened to El Ejido, which is unfortunately not the exclusivity of this locality of the European Union, requires, first of all, the clear and clear conviction of the brutal racist and xenophobic explosion of certain residents of El Ejido against the immigrant workers in the region, empowering, criminalizing and aggressing a whole community for an isolated fact.Second, this requires immediate action of all administrations;Coordination between them is essential in order to fight this type of xenophobic and racist acts.More concretely, the local authorities, the mayors, have a direct responsibility in the prevention of any racist or xenophobic demonstration, all the more so when it implies violent events against people and their property.These authorities also have the obligation to promote difficult agreements between the parties present and not to prevent them, as is the case of the mayor of El Ejido.Thirdly, this requires that political parties assume a direct responsibility in the political exercise of their public functions and prevent any act or declaration of an individual nature contrary to the principles and values ​​of cohabitation and tolerance expressed by the European Union.Finally, this requires from the European Union a responsibility for monitoring the application of its principles, preserving its territory from any racist or xenophobic manifestation, its support and collaboration with the rest of the national, regional and local administrations as well as with associations and non -governmental organizations in the application of these principles as well as in the context of a continuous action to combat racism and xenophobia and in favorof the integration of all immigrants residing in the territory of the European Union.Mr. President, at first, our group did not see the need to present this proposal because it seemed to act of a local phenomenon.However, the events of El Ejido constitute a symptom of a phenomenon which crosses all of Europe and which deserves the greatest attention.We thought we were getting rid of the horror of intolerance that racism had unleashed in Europe, but as the years spend why not say so social degradation in our Europe is combined with the increase in migratory flows from the countries around us and a greater awareness of human rights, and this climate of racism and intolerance increases.This is why what seemed to be a local phenomenon - to El Ejido- becomes a worrying symptom which coincides with the rise of parties like that of Haider.This is the reason why we propose, from the European Parliament, the adoption of urgent measures which attack all the factors involved and which are of immediate application: respect for human rights, tolerance and multiculturalism, the increase in budgets and action lines in social and health matters.

The question, is, honor, an issue that we must all consider and I have recently done it diplomatly, it refers to the consistency of resolution 12/99 of the Security Council.I know it is an extraordinarily delicate issue, but we must all ask about the logic underlying that resolution and the possibility of its application.We are supporters of its full and total application: now, we have to examine that resolution -and probably that is something that the United Nations Security Council will have to do, sooner or later -in the sense that, as happened in the past in other frames and other world strategic scenarios, it can be examined whether or not to maintain in the future certain type of procedures and certain type of logic and equilibriathe balances to which the approval of the resolution was due.What we must do, what we are doing by the European Union, is to guarantee to Mr. Kouchner all the media and their honor is right, we are obliged, before our citizens, to explain them periodic and clearly to what extent those means are used well or not.On the part of the Council, we propose to facilitate during the Portuguese Presidency information about it.Mr. President in the exercise of the Council, I totally agree with you.The problem is not Mr. Kouchner, it is the legal basis on which he works, that is, Resolution 1244. That said, I believe that the responsibility of the Union, that is, yours, but also ours, is to start working to overcome this provisional nature of resolution 1244 and imagine a future scenario for the entire region.I think it is the lack of definition of this scenario that causes or favors the excesses, accidents, the murders that Mr. Alavanos has spoken.Does the advice think of the question of Kosovo's definitive statute?And if so, do you plan to do it in a general redefinition of the region, avoiding the maximum multiply the microstates, as some have a tendency to do, and reunifying the parties, in this case, Kosovo and Albania?Since its author is not present, question No. 7 decays.Question No. 8 Formulated by (H-0796/99): Subject: New Interreg initiative in point 1 of Annex 2 of its Interreg Communication Project entitled "Promotion of urban, rural and coastal development", the Commission authorizes the renewal and development of historical urban centers through a joint cross-border strategy of which, however, it is expressly excluded to housing.Given the high number of houses of historical interest that exists in rural areas, including small country houses, and considering the need, for several reasons, to maintain the population of rural areas and attract new inhabitants to them, don't you think the council that these objectives could be achieved if projects will be financed in favor of housing in areas covered by Interreg?Mr. President, the Council - and we could even say the Portuguese presidency in particular - is extremely aware of the importance of the problems addressed by the honor in his question and I mean that we always dedicate all the attention to the community policies of development of rural areas.

It has been demonstrated, as we have denounced since 1995, that this transfer has been an absurdity.It seems right to us that Portugal and France want to reach an agreement, but those anchovies must be caught in Portuguese waters and not in the Gulf of Biscaglia.Today scientific studies show that the population of anchovy in the Gulf of Biscaglia is in danger of extinction.And now the restriction measures of the amount of anchovies that can be fished in the Gulf of Biscaglia arrive.I don't know if you have realized the responsibility that, as Council of Ministers, you have had in these years, and that you will have in 2000, against the thousands of families who live in the fishing of the exciusa in the north of the Iberian peninsula.I would like to point out, honorable deputy, that with the sentence of 5 October 1999 the Court of Justice of the European Communities decided that this transfer, which had been approved, complosed the principles established in the Council Regulations no.3760/92, and in particular in paragraph 1 of article 9, which provides that the Member States can exchange the totality or part of the availability of fishing that have been attributed to them.The Court also declared that the principle of relative stability had not been violated, since the share of anchovies attributed to Spain in subdivision 8 was maintained at 90 percent and that of France at 10 percent.Furthermore, honorable deputy, the Court is of the opinion that the transfer operated between Portugal and France does not violate the principle of rational and responsible exploitation of living and aquatic living resources, since the fishing pressure in subdivisions 8 and 9 does not increase or negatively affect the global share of the resources attributed to Spain.In consideration of all this, honorable deputy, the Council reiterates that without the transfer in question, in the Gulf of Biscaglia there should be an increase in the possibilities of fishing from the Eccour by France.Therefore, honorable deputy, the Council confirms that the fishing pressure would be greater and more dangerous for the fish heritage than with the solution for which it was opted.In concrete terms: 3 000 tons represent 57.5 percent of the fishing possibilities of Portugal in 2000, against 5 008 tons, equal to 73.9 percent, from 1999. These figures represent, in our opinion and in the perspective of the Council, a real improvement in terms of conservation, if compared to the 80 percent altitude established by the Council Regulation no.685/95.Question n.6, of the honorable (H-0788/99): subject: measures to meet the incessant ethnic cleaning suffered by the Serbs and Roma in Kosovo, the NATO defense ministers have launched (2,12.1999) a strong appeal for the cessation of ethnic cleaning against the Kosovo minorities.Even the European Parliament, with a resolution on the terrible acts of violence against Serbs and Roma, stigmatizes the continuous violence against the Serbian population and invites the heads of the Albanians of Kosovo to fully respect the UN resolution 1244.The resolution of the PI also highlights that previous persecutions perpetrated against the Albanians "cannot be adduced to pretext for murders, kidnappings, detention, intimidation, fires, looting, destruction of goods, occupations of houses, etc.".

Honorable deputy, I take note of his declaration and the existence of this common resolution.If the Presidency services confirm that it has been deposited, it goes without saying that it will be taken into consideration.The discussion is closed.The vote will take place on Thursday, at 12.00.(The session ends at 8.14) approval of the verbal process of the previous session Mr. President I would just like to transmit information.This morning in Madrid there was a terrorist attack.They put a bomb in a car.A person is dead.I would simply like, on behalf of my group, to condemn these terrorist acts once again.Thank you, Mr Fraga.Indeed we have received news of this deplorable fact.Unfortunately, once again, assassin terrorism affects the Spanish society and the presidency of this session, being Spanish, welcomes its words, as will be able to understand, with particular intensity.(The verbal process is approved) resumption of the session declare the session of the European Parliament, interrupted on Friday 21 January 2000. Lady president, allows me to remember that tomorrow the second anniversary of the Cermis massacre occurs.Two years ago, in fact, in Italy, in Cavalese, an American plane of the NATO base in Aviano, during a low -altitude exercise - beyond the safety limits - treshed down the threads of a cable car causing the death of more than 20 European citizens.Since then the family members of the victims, who have not had the comfort of justice since the pilot responsible for the act has not had criminal consequences, await the United States at least a prompt economic compensation.I therefore address an appeal to the president of this assembly and the president of the Commission to ensure that they are guaranteed, to the US authorities, of an immediate compensation, and this in defense of the rights of the families of the victims.Thank you and take note of your intervention.Agea of ​​the day Mrs. President, I intervene to support the decision of the conference of the presidents and I take the opportunity to detect that, after publicly criticizing the presidency last January, this time I consider appropriate - also on behalf of the socialist group - the declarations pronounced by the presidency on the topic in question: we share them on the merits, in the form and in the times.We could not find more appropriate debate to apply article 50 of the regulation.This is a topical debate, urgent and of considerable relevance.To leave him space, we therefore believe it is necessary to modify the agenda.(Applause) Is there an intervention against the proposal?Mrs. President, I intend to intervene against the proposal for a matter of principle that I consider fundamental and which concerns respect for the treaties, in particular of article 7 of the Amsterdam Treaty.Mrs. President, honorable colleagues, so far, on the basis of the provisions of the Treaties of Rome and Paris who have established the communities, later became the European Union, we believed that this union was an association of free, independent and sovereign states.Although numerous evolutions raised several doubts, we had believed, despite everything, in their opportunity and even recently we had alluded, albeit to a lips, we must say it, at the principle of subsidiarity.

You have begun in a bold way, emphasized, rightly, in the need to focus on the so -called "central tasks."As you said today, that means that you must also identify the tasks, policies and programs that are peripheral or irrelevant for the main vocation of the commission.Perhaps many of the current policies and programs of the European Union have simply exceeded their expiration date or have proven heavy and difficult to direct or ineffective when applied at European level.Now the challenge is to have the value of returning as many non -central tasks to lower levels of national, regional and local government.If we want to persuade a skeptical European society of the advantages of greater European integration, we must be able to demonstrate that we stay as active in the return of unjustified community competences as in the development of new EU competencies.We must not allow those who criticize European integration to claim, as they currently do and not without some justification, as we have been able to hear from Mr. Bonde, that the increase in community competences occurs in a single sense.It must be demonstrated that it is a two -way process, in which the current community policies and programs that are not clearly justified for reasons of subsidiarity and proportionality are returned and revoked.If you are able to secondary these aspirations with actions in the coming years, you will make an unprecedented contribution to the future of the European Union as a whole and, as we have heard today, you can have a broad support of this European Parliament.Mrs. President, Mr. President of the Commission, I totally include myself in the logic of the proposals made by my colleague Heidi Hautala regarding the strategic objectives of the Commission for the next five years.For my part, I will stick to an issue that has not addressed and that was planned, which is the work program of the Commission for this year 2000. I am aware of the limits of the exercise since we work within the framework of the current treaty and we are limited by its operating rules -especially in a special issue such as that of tax issues.But I would like not to talk about these.I will begin to greet a series of proposals that you make for this program of the year 2000. I think of all those proposals in food security that are ambitious and important, and I also think about maritime security, after two black tides that we have met along the Breton and Turkey coasts.It is good for the Commission to react rapidly on this issue.On the contrary, for other issues, I consider that it could be more ambitious, walk faster.And I would like to make a series of positive proposals, I think especially in the social sphere, in the environment and in the follow -up of Seattle.A previous observation: You have said that it is necessary to reconcile the European citizen with the institutions, it is evident, and therefore I think it is important to ask about the priority concerns of citizens.I believe, for example, that in social matters, it is not enough to announce a communication on a social actions program.

By not introducing this environmental dimension in data management, the Commission could prohibit unilaterally, and at its discretion, the use of this or talaltro fishing tool.Amendment no.4 specifies the obligation that falls on the scientific experts to elaborate and transmit all the data to the competent authorities, including national and regional authorities, in order to contribute to the decision -making process.Amendment no.5 allows you to soften the Commission's proposal.In fact, the information requested from the authorities must be reasonable, in order to allow to reach an operational knowledge of the fishing activity without harming the fundamental right to confidentiality, for example in the tax field, where there is no community competence.Amendment no.6 aims to make the commission's participation more binding in the control procedure.It is necessary that all the data are transmitted annually and that the Commission regularly takes the point of the overall results.Finally, amendment no.7 obliges the Commission to draw up a report by the end of 2001. Since the reform of the common fishing policy is set for 2002, all political actors must view the information on which the Commission's proposal will be based.HUDGHTON report (A5-0036/2000) - (FR) the modification of the directive, as presented to us by the Commission, is important, since it deals with a specific pathology, the infectious anemia of salmon, a contagious viral disease that is transmitted through water through organic substances such as blood, feces, mucus, etc.There is no scientific tests that confirm the possibility of a vertical transmission of the disease through eggs or fish milk.However, we know that other species, such as trout, eel or herring, can be carriers of the virus without being affected by it.This pathology was isolated in 1984 in Norway and in 1996 in Canada.In any case, since the virus does not survive at a temperature greater than 26ºC, it does not represent any danger to humans.The disease, which mainly affects the Scottish Salmon sector, has been identified in this region in May 1998. Today, ISA affects 240 salmonid manufacturers and it is therefore important to circumscribe the disease in order to prevent all companies operating in the aquaculture sector in the various Member States of the European Union.The Council's proposal is aimed at establishing a progressive elimination system of fish affected by the disease and a vaccination program.As for the progressive elimination system, we can only be in favor of the proposal.It is essential to help companies interested in "cleaning" the outbreak of infection, thus avoiding the spread of the disease and promoting the commercial movements of live fish.As for vaccination, it should be remembered that the directive initially prohibited the use of vaccines against ISA.With the new proposal, the commission would be in favor of authorizing its use, but for the moment, no vaccines of this type have not yet been discovered.The usefulness of the proposal is therefore at least limited, if only in the short deadline.Canada has a vaccine that proved to be effective in 76 percent of cases, but, since the Canadian strain is different from the European one, the vaccine in question cannot be used as it is in Europe.

The forced convergence of different systems, in addition to clashing with the principle of subsidiarity, Mr. President, I do not think will lead to the desired result, because ultimately there will always be the way to get around the system, with harmful results for the environment.Mr. President, five million solid waste every day are thrown out of the ships.These waste float for the seas and end up on the beaches, causing serious damage to the environment and marine flora and fauna.The consequence is that millions of birds and one hundred thousand marine mammals and sea turtles die every year.The Marpol Convention aims to prevent pollution caused by ships but it is clear that legislation is also required to guarantee its application.Hence the relief of the directive in question and that's why tonight are happy with the progress made during the Council in view of reaching a common position that obliges ships to deliver the waste produced by them to structures for the collection of waste in ports.I also congratulate the speaker, whose commitment reflects the strength and passion with which our commission faces this specific problem and the strong transversal desire for parliamentarians of all political groups so that it is put an end to these disastrous practices for the environment.I welcome with particular favor to its fierce support for the proposal according to which the environmental requirements should apply to all ships regardless of the flag that beat and that in all the ports of the community should be made available adequate structures for the collection of waste, all this in order to improve the prevention of pollution and to avoid distortions of competition.An aspect on which the parliamentarians of the British Labor Party do not agree with the speaker is the way in which to apply the principle of the "polluting pays".We strongly support this principle, but we believe that its application can be made more efficient if the Member States will keep the freedom to decide what the tariff system most suitable for particular circumstances is.For example, in the UK we have a system that works well, according to which the ship pays the operator in charge of the collection of waste every time it makes use of its collection structures, without any involvement of the port.This system is based on a consent achieved by all interested parties, with the participation of ports and environmental organizations such as RSPB and WWF.However, in the same way as the speaker we absolutely do not want different tariff systems to increase the risk of pollution of the seas.Here is the reason why we support the Council with its proposal to strengthen the revision clause, to ensure regular control of the impact of the directive.Mr. President, those who have been able to witness the ruinous effects on the environment from the Enerika disaster will certainly not be able to vote against a relationship that has as its object the disposal of the combustible residues of the boats.It is a relationship of exceptional importance.In this regard, it should be emphasized that what is missing most is no legislation.All EU countries have signed the so -called Marpol Convention, while the countries overlooking the Baltic have also signed the Helsinki Convention.Both respond in order to avoid exhausts at sea.However, it is necessary to improve access to reception systems and create the incentive to use it.

Mr. President, estimated and dear colleagues, Mr. Commissioner Nielson, the conclusion of the new EU-ACP agreement is an important step towards greater coherence.And it is positive that in this new opportunity.This, Colega Modrow, is also applicable to Cuba.I greet that Cuba approaches this process, but some transformations have to occur in that country.We all know the reports of Amnesty International.It may be that you, as one of the last holders of the power of communism, possibly see it differently from most of this assembly and that you see problems in the Good Government.However, it is an important criterion for the European Union.I want to refer to a second topic.We are talking here about coherence.Many colleagues have exhibited examples of to what extent the various policies are not consistent.But, from my point of view, the development policy itself needs some more coherence.It is not consistent that the coordination with the Member States remains without working, that in developing countries member countries of the European Union carry out in part some very opposite projects.Nor is it consistent in front of the European taxpayer that we carry out a development policy that is regulated in the Budget of the Union but that the Fed is still outside.Mr. President of the Council, if you get that these 13,500 million euros are subjected in the future to the control of Parliament, of the Budget Control Commission, are subjected to mechanisms such as the OLAF, then I think it will raise the degree of acceptance.I think this should also be a requirement to the Intergovernmental Conference: the establishment of the Fed in the European Union budget.Mr. President, ladies, as a whole, this text seems effectively well intentionally and, however, we do not vote in commission nor will we vote in the plenary, for two reasons that, otherwise, gave rise, of our part, to amendments that I would like to develop here quickly.First of all, the Development and Cooperation Commission wishes to the community of the European Development Fund and it is evident that in this regard it is wrong.Cooperation is and, in our opinion, must continue to be an intergovernmental exercise.At the time Europe prepares its extension, a community of the European Development Fund would allow some to easily hide their lack of commitment behind the community budget screen, not counting, on the other hand, that in this way a fruitful and promising way to associate our cooperation policy to our southern partners is suppressed.Finally, the Commission demonstrated, recently, as Mrs. Maes, the difficulties she experiences to manage the funds she dedicated to its development and humanitarian aid programs has just remembered.

While we thought the discussion ended, dazzling amendments reach the plenary, for which I would like to reject.After that, for example, we should finance the art treasures or promote marine tourism with the meager household of fishing.Other amendments, such as number 4, which require the financing of biological recovery phases, also prove a great ignorance of fishing regulations if they demand measures that are already in force, even if everything is still in need of improvement.I therefore ask you to reject the four amendments brought in and to conclude the chapter on fishing and environment with the idea presented in the debate in the committee, namely that both are in close relationships and suffer from the effects of the same attack on the environment.As I have said so many times, fisheries are more victim as the cause of destruction of the sea ecosystem, and tomorrow, in the pronunciation about the Erika, we will have the opportunity to prove this.President!The report by Mr. Katiforis had preferred a message in which the Commission was limited to listing a number of good wishes, but to admit their inability to their practical implementation, to fill with liveliness, polemics and controversial spirit.What Mr. Katiforis was not missing was the courage to demonstrate the measures that, in his opinion, could contribute to the relaxation and maintenance of the natural resources of the sea.I say this from the non -understanding of many of his suggestions because I am one of those who believe that not only resources are important in fishing - they are - but also the people who have had this job for centuries.I agree with the rapporteur that a stronger coordination of European fishing and environmental policy is required.But what we basically miss is courage and political determination on the part of the Commission and the Member States to make decisions and apply the already valid regulation.Not only fishing and the environment should be integrated, but also maritime traffic, employment or energy.With regard to the structural funds, I could mention a number of examples here, but I will rescue that for another opportunity.The European Parliament is aware of the limitation of resources and the need to carry out responsible fishing.It demands strictness by the Commission and the Member States to comply with TAC and the quotas defined according to objective scientific criteria and demand that everyone is measured with the same level.As Mr. Katiforis says, the repellents are a waste of resources that we must not accept.Twenty million tons of non -usable catches are thrown back.The fleet must be equipped with fishing devices for ever more selective fishing.This parliament has already opposed the drift nets, and yet we determine how certain states not only disregard the obligation of their elimination, but also increase the number of ships with this fishing device or simply do not transmit any data in view of the passivity of the national and community authorities.We socialists believe that the defense of common fishing policy means to stand up for regulated and controlled fishing activity.It is essential that the Commission initiates an information campaign via the GFP with this message.

The next point is the actions we have undertaken.As you know, the Portuguese presidency has already composed a high -level group, which will present its first report in June, at the summit.The Portuguese presidency focuses on two issues: on sustainable pension systems and social insertion.I believe that the proposal on a group corresponding to the Parliament level is very positive and can contribute to advance one more step after the approval of this high -level group.In certain observations on the role of social protection systems and on their cost, and on the role that these systems play in the competitiveness of the Member States, I would like to observe that what they try to combine policies in the European Union is competitiveness and social cohesion.Naturally, we must take into account the issue of competitiveness, and social protection planning must be done in such a way that social protection is a factor of economic expansion and employment.And I think this is evident in the text of the communication.Ladies and lords, the objective is that next year, after the unanimous decision of the Council, we advance in a first level of coordination, exchange of opinions, registration of social problems, creation of a database for the best coordination of policies.As many of the Messrs. Deputies have expressed, I think we have taken an important first step.Already at the Intergovernmental Conference the social policy issues are faced in a broader way, and I think we are in a new phase, where social policy will constitute, to a large extent, a European policy.Thank you very much, Mrs. Diamantopoulou.The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Wednesday at 11.30 am.WIPO Treaty In accordance with the agenda, the recommendation (A5-0008/2000) of Mrs. Cederschiöld, on behalf of the Commission of Legal Affairs and Internal Market, on the decision proposal of the Council (com (1998) 249 - C5-022/1999 - 1998/0141 (AVC))) isof the Ompi Treaty on copyright and the Ompi treaty on interpretations or executions and phonograms..(SV) Mr. President, we are going to make a decision in an important issue, an international agreement, an issue that may have an influence on the development of well -being in many countries.In my country, Sweden, concerns one of the largest export sectors.The bouquets affect are those of music and phonograms.This is the copyright of the artists, to protect their artistic creations.This is the WCT (World Copyright Treaty) and the WPPT (World Perfomance and Phonograms Treaty).Without copyright protection, economic incentives and creativity are stopped.The falsifications are Big Business.It is believed that only in Europe revenues of four thousand five hundred million euros are lost due to pirate copies.The problem affects many jobs in the entertainment world.This treaty is historical, since the EU is one of the parts that has signed it.That's right, although the members of the organization are the states of the Union and not the EU.
