commission.A concerted strategy to modernize social protection.The communication of the Commission takes as a starting point the implementation of the EMA, which with its claim of stability and growth creates the basis for member states to affirm their social security systems.The report is left sitting that modernization does not mean to reduce the level of social protection, but to better make the existing resources.In addition, we have also noticed that in the exposure of reasons it is established that a modernization also does not mean a harmonization of social security systems and that also a harmonization would be harmful since it could require higher levels in weaker Member States and, at the same time, for reasons of competition, it could press the socially more developed states to make reductions in the social security system.A situation with which no one would benefit.In both the communication of the commission and in the report of Mr. Andersson, it is underlined that they are the Member States responsible and with it who decide the content of the Social Security systems.The collaboration in these issues under the Auspices of the EU must provide added value, based on the exchange of experiences, the mutual evaluation of policies development for setting a better practice..(SV) We believe that the report contains many good practical proposals, to which we give our Still today there are no certain answers on the control of atomic plants in the republics of the East.It is therefore necessary to have resources to be spent before proceeding with an expansion, to finally give life to a European control force, in charge of verifying quality and living conditions, in order to create a new world in which some tragedies no longer have to occur.I would also like to spend a word on Africa, lady president.The third and fourth world are abandoned: a dollar, one and a half euros, would be enough to save many children.Europe so democratic, so progressive, is silent and does not take care of these tragic problems, while half Africa dies of AIDS and other diseases.One last consideration as regards the Internet and globalization.The globalization of the economy cannot become homologation of products and qualities, as well as the globalization of politics cannot become flattening values, hopes, enthusiasm.The peoples who do not participate, and slowly move away, leave room for an oligarchy that takes power and leaves control to a few.As for the Internet: Europe finally has the courage to say that rules need.At this moment I allow me, by personal, to direct my applause to those pirates who, acting as they are acting, force the world to reflect on the only system that today has no rules.We are the world of rules: we also give rules to the Internet, thus giving rules and hopes to the future of our fellow citizens.Lady president, as a taxpayer from Padano I have already known the grip of the taxator Prodi, then head of government in Italy, to which Padania also fiscally subject to.I listened to it now with concern, when he mentioned new resources, a concept quietly translatable in the imposition of new taxes and new taxes, in sight, among what in Italy is known as a tax on Europe - only partially returned - have absolutely no intention, always thanks to Prodi, to pay another for someone else.Mrs. President, Mr. President of the Commission, commissioners, five months after his settlement, the Commission has put the direction in white in which he intends to push the European Union.The result is a certainly ambitious document, but also a pompous.Isn't it pathetic to say that "the world looks to Europe"?In addition, the European continent is not only composed of the fifteen Member States of the European Union.Say that you want to guarantee peace, democracy and respect for human rights in, well known, all of Europe seems to me somewhat ambitious and fascinates me above all to know how the commission intends to achieve this goal.The European integration model as a form of global government, I wonder if this means perhaps the export of a model based on the concentration of power on a large scale.The Commission believes that foreign policy can be successful as long as everyone knows exactly who is that he commands!But who is it that commands?

Mr. President, the Commissioner, the peace process in the Middle East is an extremely delicate question.The exact boundaries of the State of Israel, the only democracy in this region, can only be recognized by all if these negotiations lead.The implementation of the trade agreement between the European Union and Israel, which no longer defines the territory of the State of Israel, must be done in this context.Add to this the existence of a close link between economic activities on the Israeli side and those on Palestinian territory.To this end, the Paris protocol annexed to the Oslo agreements also provides for a customs "envelope" which includes the state of Israel and the Palestinian authority.In addition, the commission and the aforementioned parties have agreed that a joint labor group is set up to approach issues of origin, in particular the fact that the Palestinian economy felt of unilateral approaches from the European Union.Potential investors in this region have already said that they will retire if the joint ventures no longer have the preference.Mr. President, this assembly generally shares the concern raised in the question of Madame Morgantini.I believe that Commissioner Verorino clearly expressed the position of the Commission and, in my opinion, responded adequately to the concerns here aroused, but it seems to me that we should not stop there.This is why it seems to me that we could, from this assertion, expand the convergent points based on the precious information that Madame Morgantini and I were able to deduct during a visit to the region with the president of Parliament.I first believe that, despite the existing difficulties that we have seen in situ, we must reiterate our support for direct dialogue between the government of Israel and the Palestinian Authority, with a view to a fair, stable and final peace agreement.Secondly, I think that the two parties have an interest in ensuring the economic development of the region and in firmly facing the reduction of the significant wealth imbalances observed in the region.Third, finally, the Commission could perhaps take into account the usefulness of deepening the task of a trilateral working group, of course with the participation of the European Union, guaranteeing compliance with trade agreements and making us progress in the cooperation that the European Union offers for the benefit of all the parties concerned.I listened to the response from Commissioner Vitorino and I must say that I am satisfied.I think his intervention answers the questions contained in the question.I too believe that we must underline the importance, for the European Union and therefore, from the executive point of view, for the Commission, to promote tripartite activities, in particular with regard to the levels of economic and scientific cooperation, so that our quantitative presence in pecuniary terms can more often transform into a more significant presence in the Middle East.Here, I believe, the lesson to be drawn from this already old story.As for the specific object, I heard that Mr. Galeote referred to the visit of our president and Mr. Menéndez del Valle to that of the Prodi President in Israel and in other countries of the Middle East.

Mr President, I would like to thank Mr. Guterres for his explanations this evening as well as for his initiative with regard to the summit in Lisbon, which is very important to us.If we are honest, we have to admit that it was a long way from the employment summit in Luxembourg to the summit in Lisbon, and that we can now expect concrete results from this summit in Lisbon, so something tangible has to come out.Many European citizens sit in the grandstand tonight, and I wonder what they may think of today's discussion.I hope that these citizens will leave the plenum in the certainty this evening that the institutions of the European Union have now initiated a process that will truly lead to restoring full employment in the European Union.There are many challenges in front of us on the way to full employment.Some of these challenges will be difficult to cope with, but it is important that we have been implementing what we have been talking about for many, many years, namely full employment, a society without social exclusion, a society of innovation and knowledge.This lies the great challenge and the great importance of the Lisbon summit.I would like to briefly go into some key aspects, with the help of which we will be able to have our words follow.Firstly, we have to define corner values ​​and initiate a mutual evaluation process, we have to set goals, real goals that we can achieve, and we have to bring the governments to the courage that requires some courage, in which they say: "Yes, we do not shy away from the comparison, we will be measured with the rest of the world."Nobody pleasant.However, it is important if the summit in Lisbon is to lead to concrete results and not in a different direction - a direction that Prime Minister Guterres certainly does not want to strike because he is really interested in the fact that something is achieved at the summit in Lisbon.Other areas must also not be neglected.This includes the challenge of creating an "e-Europe" in which all citizens are involved and in which nobody falls by the wayside.Another area is the creation of a real internal market, which we still don't have, and qualification measures are part of the fact that it is of central importance for the introduction of an innovative knowledge society.This requires difficult decisions, but I would like to contact the citizens again in the grandstand who pursue this pronunciation and to whom I would like to give confidence that we will achieve a fully employed society that the summit in Lisbon will be at the end of a long way and will provide concrete results.I welcome the new strategic goal to make Europe the most dynamic and most competitive space.Who could question such an ambitious goal?However, I would like to point out that dynamics and entrepreneurial spirit as well as social cohesion are ambitious goals, not to mention the creative area of ​​tension between these two goals.

I do not believe that in Europe there is a broad consensus in favor of the introduction of the qualified majority on taxation, justice and internal and foreign affairs at the level of union.Pursuant to article 99 of the Treaty of Rome, the tax decisions approved at European level must be voted unanimously.I believe that this provision should remain in force, since a common tax code would instead reduce the functioning of the European Union.I am in favor of the expansion of the European Union.They are in favor of institutional changes that allow to implement expansion in a structured and simplified way.However, we must not forget that public opinion of 370 million citizens of the European Union is a fundamental factor to keep in mind if you want to change the treaties.The changes must not be introduced too quickly and must not be too radical, otherwise public opinion will oppose the ratification of any future treaty of the union.President President, I will speak on behalf of the Italian radical deputies.Mr. President of the Commission, you said a little while ago that no political structure produces five -year plans.This is true, if we think of the plans of Russia of the 1930s, but she himself a few months ago, at the beginning of his mandate, announced to the conference of the presidents who would instead have presented a legislature program, or the broad lines of the European government that you presides, and in whose exercise we are committed today.Then, if the government program or the tendential program must be, the analysis of the document that you have distributed us and the speech that has accompanied it is more than anything else a catalog of good intentions or, better to say, of problems on the carpet, without however giving the impression that the commission clearly takes a position on any of these points, that is, it absolves that task that is proper to the European Commission.In the classroom of this parliament, in the past, great debates on great strategic options that the Commission, by virtue of its initiative, launched, more than as a ballon of essai, as proposals that then made more or less road, but which still contributed to the integration and development of the European Union, had.In this case, Mr. President, we certainly have a decalogue: a whole series of problems have been enumerated but, he allows me, with the impression that on none of these the commission in some way dare to say "on this it would be necessary to do so".Only on one point it seems to me that you have insisted a lot - I think too much - that is, about the fact that almost the task you are prefiguring yourself as a priority is to dismantle the "unnecessary" activities.We are careful, however, Mr. President, because we had a crisis of confidence in the Commission and we focused on this commission - the majority, at least, of this Parliament he focused on this commission - precisely because, first of all, the reform of the Commission was linked to a strengthening, to a new identity, to a new awareness of being guided again by a safe hand.

.(SV) Mr. President, Mrs. Minister, Mrs. Commissioner, "women hold half the sky," said a man of success.But in the case of political decisions and priorities, female voices are absent.Women, which constitute more than half of the population, are not sufficiently represented in the political, social and economic sector.This is unacceptable in a democracy!The greatest abyss in terms of equal opportunities, jure and de facto, is found in the decision -making process.To achieve a balance, a specific action plan is required, with a fixed calendar.The benchmarking system would be an important part of this action plan, to ensure full female participation in power and decision -making structures.Therefore, I am satisfied that the curator agrees with a system of this nature.I propose that the objectives for women in the decision -making process are based on the average of the three member states that have obtained more success in each sector, and each Member State must inform annually.Subsequently, these reports must be evaluated.Women are the main victims of human rights abuses such as violations, sexual abuse, ill -treatment at home and white trafficking, but are not sufficiently represented in judicial and legislative bodies that judge those crimes.This implies that there are no priority to these crimes and that the authors are often not punished.Women are the main victims of armed conflicts, but are absent in actions to maintain peace, conflict resolution and reconstruction work.Therefore, in the resolution we urge the Member States to increase the proportion of women in activities to resolve conflicts and for the maintenance of peace.Female participation in equal situation is not only a claim of social justice and democracy, but it is also a duty, to achieve that the experiences and knowledge of women are fully taken into account.Not having the ability of women in the decision -making process is an unacceptable waste.Women should not only "support half of the sky" but also must have the right to assume responsibilities on earth.Mr. President, I want to congratulate the Presidency of the Council and the Commissioner for the excellent interventions they have made today.We expect much of your performance.We begin a millennium and a century that will be - we hope - determinants for women and for their possibility of occupying decision positions.We want this possibility to contribute important modifications to our life in society, that democracy is also synonymous with equality between men and women and that they are not excluded or socially, as still happens today.And that, thus, values ​​that are expensive to women - such as peace, fraternity, equality, justice, security, defense of the environment - predominantly orient life in the European Union and, if possible, in the world.For that, it is necessary to provide women with the opportunity to intervene against the inertia of a society so far imbued with male values.

This is a problem of compatibility between our VFU directives and old guidelines, among others the self-oil, which we voted for a few years ago.We can therefore be satisfied with the common sense of which the commission for the environment, public health and the policy for consumers, which reintroduced, to dispel any doubts, has proven the exception relating to the vintage cars that are part of our industrial and cultural heritage.To conclude, I will say that this directive is not sufficiently ambitious to solve the problems related to the current car park but instead it is rather hypocritical for the fate that reserves for abandoned cars that still clutters our forests, our lakes, our gardens.Once again the "polluting pays" principle is not applied and the taxpayer is always paying.Mr. President, Mrs. Commissioner, honorable colleagues, reading the leaflets distributed in recent weeks, one might think that we have been discussing the maximum acceptable ecological risk or on the death of the automotive industry in Europe.Neither hypotheses is exact.We must be objective: the directive in question is valid;It implies ecological progress in Europe and we can be proud to translate this directive into law and to launch it.In any case, there is a point on which we disagree.Perhaps, considering the dimension of the directive, it represents a small point, but it is on this that the controversy takes place.These are the costs related to recycling.In this regard, we clearly distance ourselves from the debate held in the council last year, during which the gratuity for the last holder and the problem of funding were mixed in a single cauldron, and the free of charge was questioned for the last holder.In February last year, Parliament decided - and to this decision we stick to the PSE group - that the gratuity for the last holder is out of the question!But who has to pay for vehicles to be disposed of?It is evident for us that in the case of new vehicles these costs must be incurred by the manufacturer, because in this way it will also be led to design and build easily recyclable vehicles.But what happens with the vehicles that are already in circulation?An example: if it were responsible for all its out -of -use vehicles, the Rover based in the United Kingdom would be responsible for 5.8 million vehicles in the European Union and should immediately set aside 250 million euros to face the costs related to recycling, while a Korean manufacturer who builds similar vehicles should only put aside of the "peanuts", as a representative of the Deutsche Bank said.These are distortions of the competition that have nothing to do with the protection of the environment, but affect only on the ability to invest and on the jobs of the European automotive industry.In this sense, we propose to create a fund for out of use vehicles with which to pay the costs inherent in the recycling of these vehicles, so as to respect the principle of gratuity.I understand colleagues from countries without automotive industry which argue that the entire burden should fall on the producers and that the problem of the distortions of the competition with the related provisions does not interest them.

For two years, such fears have materialized.The dispute of bananas is its most striking proof.The developing countries are asked to align on the liberalization of exchanges, despite the fragility of their economies.If the report of the Honorable Corrie denounces this situation well and reaffirms the loyalty of the joint assembly to the Lomé model, it does not underline enough, however, a second problem that, to be honest, derives in turn from the freedom error: the inconsistency of the regional commercial agreements concluded by the European Union.The cooperation agreement with South Africa is the best example.The Council, in fact, approved this agreement, negotiated by the Commission, at the same time when the agricultural chapter, although essential, was not yet finalized.As the honorable Paul-Marie Coûteaux, in his intervention of yesterday and in his proposals for amendment, was very correctAll this worries a lot, especially since it seems to promise an agreement of the same type also with Mexico.Likewise it is not possible to support the speaker when he requests the merger of the European Development Fund in the Community Budget.In fact, we want to maintain the clear commitment and responsibility of each Member State that only the intergovernmental character can guarantee.We have witnessed too many examples, unfortunately, of hijacking the collective aid of which no one feels responsible, and we do not intend to extend this disastrous practice also to the European Development Fund.Lady president, I welcome the Corrie report who represents a equilibrated evaluation of the work done last year by this assembly.The report comes immediately after the agreement for the renewal of the current agreement of Lomé, which expires at the end of the month.The new agreement provides for allocations for development for 13.5 billion euros over the next seven years;It is essential that this money is used in favor of the poorest groups and individuals of ACP countries.It is also necessary to work without stopping to eradicate corruption and waste and it is also necessary to involve civil society in the planning and application of these projects.The decision to include a clause that requires ACP countries to resume illegally emigrated people in Europe is worrying;This clause must be applied with extreme caution.I hope that before the expiry of this new Lomé convention we will be able to welcome Cuba as a fully member.According to the United Nations joint program estimates for AIDS, 33.4 million people affected by HIV were at the end of 1998 in the world.More than 95 percent of all infected individuals live in developing countries, and sub -Sasaharan Africa is the most affected region in the world.Only 10 percent of the world population lives in sub -Saharan Africa, but 70 percent of all people who contracted the AIDS virus in 1998. 80 percent of 13.9 million deaths caused by AIDS all over the world has occurred in this region.In Africa, AIDS is not only a public or private health problem, but it is a development node.

The sub -opening of women in politics, for example, continues to be a reality.Still, we all recognize the importance of an ever greater commitment of women in politics.Only women are able to invent policies capable of modifying structures elaborated by men for other men, because they are precisely the structural discrimination those with which women must most clash, whether they are politics or the employment market.It is therefore up to the European political parties to open up to women.The same article 191 of the Treaty (ex 138 a) underlines its role as, and I mention, "an important factor for integration within the Union".And the article continues by stating that "they [political parties] contribute to forming a European consciousness [as well as a European identity] and to express the political will of the citizens of the Union".Such a provision, although not having legal value, remains extremely symbolic, as it gives political parties an important role in the construction of a democratic Europe that could materialize, for example, in the implementation of positive actions and in the promotion of equality within our political parties.On the occasion of the European elections of 1999, some parties presented equal lists.Well, it is a good practice that is necessary to generalize.I don't know if there is a causal bond, but it is true that the proportion of the deputies to the European Parliament went from 25.7 percent in 1994 to 29.9 percent in 1999, not to mention that, from the 1999 elections, Parliament is chaired by a woman.I will end by resuming the conclusions taken from the Conference of April 1999 organized by the Commission, whose title was "Women and men in power".Equality between men and women is not a problem that only affects women, it is a challenge that involves all our society!It has recently been taken forward with the increase in female participation in the decision -making organs in the union.Today, in our institution, 30 percent of the elected representatives is made up of women, including the lady president of the European Parliament, while Finland has just chosen a women's president.On average, the governments of the Member States are composed for a quarter of women and national parliaments for more than a fifth.This is far from being satisfactory, given that the figures vary a lot from one country to another and that the Nordic countries have a decidedly greater female representation in key places in terms of responsibility and decision -making competence.It is above all a question of approach and respect for the quality and abilities that women can make to society, and not of a system of fixed shares.In general, my group is not in favor of the use of the shares since in the long run they could be counterproductive and even undermining the cause they intend to support.This is nevertheless recognizing that experience varies from country to country and that the use of said system could be justified as a temporary measure to rebalance the female presence where women are scarcely represented.We decided to vote for the resolution of women in the decision -making process that was adopted in commemoration of the International Women's Day of 8 March and in which ten amendments presented by the liberal group were incorporated and the references to the shares were attenuated, in line with the approach described above.

The measures are not limited to legislation.To promote and support the dialogue as a cornerstone of successful adaptation to change, the Commission is currently also dealing with the recommendations of the Lillehammer report by working on the establishment of a European observation center for industrial change.We also deal with another proposal of this group of experts, with the report on the management of change.Finally, let me go into some of the other questions that are addressed in the defense draft presented in this high house.As far as the connection between competition and social policy is concerned, I would like to remind you that there is a provision in the merger control regulation that gives employee representatives the opportunity to be heard by the Commission as part of the corresponding procedure.On the whole, we recognize the need that in the different instances of all aspects associated with such measures, including their consequences for employment, due attention is paid.As an example, I mention that the public authorities, in particular the Commission, on the way of guidelines for the national regional allowance, which took effect on January 1 of this year, have already taken action to ensure that the provision of public funds will continue to be linked to the recipients of regional allowances and consequently to the jobs associated with the investment.For this purpose, any regional allowance is made dependent on the existence of the respective investment for a minimum period of five years.The same provision was included in the regulation on the structural funds, so that it applies to all investments co -financed for all of the structural funds.The social cohesion and the interaction of politics at the EU level are the focus of the upcoming Lisbonian summit.I know we will come back to these questions in the future to see how best we can make sure that our policies will be adapted and reformed in order to support economic and social progress in Europe.Thank you very much, Mr. Commissioner.Mr. Gorostiaga Atxalandabaso, I see that you report to the rules of procedure.If it is a personal explanation, would you please wait until the end of this pronunciation?I would like to give you the word.President!It is a question of public honor in this parliament, it is not a personal explanation.This morning, the Parliamentary President, Ms. Nicole Fontaine, repeatedly refused to let me speak about the rules of procedure.Unfortunately, this is not the first time that the Ms. President behaved towards me in this inadmissible way.The President of the President has thus violated Article 142, according to which a request for rules of procedure has priority in front of all other requests to speak.She also violated Article 122, which gives all members of this house the right to personal remarks, with which the statements of another MP who are rejected by Ms. Vidal-Quadra.This partisan behavior of our president should be criticized with all reprint.I am always ready to accept the apology from the President of the President.Thank you for your explanation.Of course, we will ensure that the president is informed about her explanation.I can assure you that, according to my knowledge, the President is always reluctant to give a topic -related pronunciation in the middle of a vote.

.(SV) Mr. President, I think it is very important to show the guidelines for the use of the principle of precaution in this communication, as a way to refute the claims that we always apply it with protectionist objectives.I am sure that there will be more conflicts, for example, with the USA we cannot be naive and believe anything else.However, since we signed the Montreal protocol, we have an international recognition and a common definition established in a protocol on the environment, health and commerce.That is why it constitutes a good example.Let's not think that in the future there will be no conflicts, but then we can demonstrate that we do not arbitrarily apply the precautionary principle.Now there are a number of guidelines for their application and we have the strong support of our peoples to do so, which is very clearly corroborated in this communication.Thank you very much, Mrs. curator.The attention paid to the principle of political caution has made us debate it for almost two hours and that now this issue is considered, to put it in some way, more of ordinary administration, although, as we have been able to verify following the interventions, the questions and the answers, it is an issue that is attributed a lot of importance.The debate is closed.Intergovernmental Conference In accordance with the agenda, the report of the Report (A5-0018/2000) of the Messrs. As for China, we should not let ourselves be dissuaded by lifting the question only because the discussions on the subject could be blocked.In any case, it is imperative that the union expresses itself and acts as a single entity, and the threats of commercial sanctions should strengthen instead of weakening our determination.However, if you want to give full expression to the decisions that can finally be made in Geneva, the office of the high commissioner for human rights will have to be equipped with the necessary resources.The United Nations financial resources are distributed insufficient and consequently many crucial programs, to remain operational, depend on voluntary contributions.Resources are also necessary to promote practical cooperation and human rights, strategic planning, the definition of priorities and the strengthening of communications between the community of donors and the United Nations Member States.To this end, the high commissioner has recently launched an annual appeal to collect 53 million dollars intended to allow his office to fulfill said tasks.The European Union and its Member States should take the guide by offering a significant share of these funds.In this way, not only would we embarrass the United States by pushing them to take on their responsibilities regarding the financing of the United Nations, but we would also show that our commitment towards the protection of human rights goes beyond simple and sterile rhetoric.Mr. President, this discussion focuses on the preparation of the annual session of the United Nations Commission for the rights of man, which will be held soon, and on the role in this context of the Commission and the Council.I was allowed first of all to express my great satisfaction for the statements made so far by Commissioner Patten and the Minister.I am also happy that today we also discuss both China and Cuba. Cuba remains the last example of dictatorship in Latin America, and this is an aspect that we must not forget, despite all the sympathy that that country enjoys here and there.Cuba is a dictatorship, it is therefore not a democracy.In the two minutes of word I have available I would like to dwell on two countries with which I have a particular bond.The first is Indonesia.It naturally makes us very pleasure that Indonesia now has a new government and that the positions of President and Vice -President are covered by Mr. Wahid and Mrs. Soekarnopoetri.We are also happy that the situation in Timor is slowly evolving in the right direction.However, I must inform you that in the Molucche Islands, which are located a little further north of Timor, violence still is the master, after in the last two years there have already been thousands of deaths.Tens of thousands of people are now on the run.The situation is out of control.Tomorrow or the day after tomorrow Dutch television will broadcast a large program to which observers have been asked to intervene for pure and simple purpose of observing what is happening to the Molucche, so that it can be recorded all what has really happened, also for the benefit of posterity or commissions for human rights.The urgent appeal that I want to launch now concerns a point that has been inserted many times in our resolutions, that is, the possibility of sending observers to the Molucche.

In a country with little population like mine, Finland, going to Correos is a social event.In a world integrated into networks, mail service is the most democratic network, since it creates and maintains human relations.The common market in the postal sector will be carried out in accordance with the conditions of the market forces.For us, in the north, this means that the EU will destroy social infrastructure.Mr. Monti, the principle of competition does not fit in the field of human relations, and, therefore, we must develop postal services, and not end them.If we want everyone to have access to computer science and use it, the only way to guarantee this aspiration in society is through a public postal service.The postal service is democracy and can carry out these functions better than telecommunications companies.Within the framework of telecommunications, prices have risen due to the continuous sale of companies and that more than 50% of the business volume of these companies is intended for advertising.We have to make democratic investments to conserve democratic postal services.It is particularly convenient to be Mr. Monti who is responding to this debate, since the great dilemma that is raised with postal services is how to square an open market and a free and loyal competition, on the one hand, and the provision of a service that is universally available, even in the most remote and uninhabited region of the European Union.In the hills and valleys of Scotland, in the rural border area with England and the central belt, in the beautiful but fragile Howdent Islands, Orkney and Shetland, there is a real concern for the possible loss of this essential service.However, we all know that the quality of the service can only improve whether postal services, as well as all service activities, are given financial and management of the private sector and the acid of an open, even international competition.I will suggest a possible solution, which is already widely used in the transport sector.Air routes, ferry, train or bus that operate within the most remote areas and towards them are bidded.The bidder offering provides the specific service with a fixed quality level and with the lowest grade of subsidy takes the contract.Let's call it a "negative bidding franchise."This allows desirable competition to provide these services in accordance with a franchise system supported by public funds but totally transparent.Why couldn't the collection and postal shipping in a certain region be negative?The slightest subsidy would obtain the franchise for a certain period of time.Why could this type of negative tender be submitted to the post office of a section?It would correspond in that case to the democratically responsible, regional or national government body -probably under the general supervision of the EU -, establishing the criteria of the service and financial resources to meet this specific social objective.Otherwise, postal services can be subject to all market demands and impositions.Mr. President, commissioner, it is no accident that I am the fifth Scottish deputy of this assembly that takes the floor in this debate.This gives the measure of the importance of our postal services for us.

So if one comes to the problems of the new knowledge -based economy, the new digital economy - which, as far as I know, has only produced unemployment instead of employment instead of employment - it the internet-supported economy and the deficit of Europe is the lack of entrepreneurship that can be determined in the education system, in the actions of the governments and in the work of the institutions.And it has to proceed against this to guarantee the knowledge -based economy of the future.Mr. President!First of all, I would like to welcome you in the European Parliament, especially because with your visit you have already pointed out the symbolic, whereupon the chairman of the Group of the Social Democratic Party of Europe has already pointed out, that it is politically symbolic if you have also come to the capitals during your tour to hear the European Parliament.It is not for the first time that there is a different and politically invigorating relationship between council and parliament during the Portuguese presidency.However, as Comrade Barón Crespo has found, this is indeed a significant gesture, which we also like to take note of as such.Our attitude is clear: We support the initiative of the Portuguese government because it is serious and because we identify with the content, the strategic as well as the other goals.This is also very clear in the way this Council is prepared.On the one hand, the seriousness and thoroughness of the document presented in January.Then the individual preparatory conferences, the contribution that both entrepreneurs and trade unionists make for this summit.And above all, the latest contribution in the research area, which was made at the conference, on which Nobel Prize winners and Minister of Science and Technology came together.Here seriousness becomes visible, here an interest in the content of the summit preparation is visible.However, we also support the initiative in relation to the main goal already mentioned here, because it is not only the topic of employment and social issues for the first time again at the center of the European debate, but because it is again considered possible to "achieve the goal of full employment".For years, many said that this would be impossible that this would not be possible again in the new companies.I congratulate you, Mr. President, to put this topic back on the agenda without denying social cohesion and fundamental values ​​for us.These values ​​are not only the basis of the founding project of the European Union, but also the basis of our culture and, above all, our view of the extent of the solidarity required between all Europeans.

The lesson of experimentation in Europe teaches that it is right where the salary is weaker and the more flexible wage relationship that unemployment is higher while where the salary is higher and social relationships are better regulated the unemployment rate is more contained.Mr. President, this policy should arouse deep disappointment, certainly not hopes, in the hearts of European workers.With its resolution, our Commission shows that, in addition to the Commission, I recommend Ecofin and ECB, Parliament is also the proponent of an extremely neoliberal socio -economic policy, which has had many negative repercussions on the living and work conditions of employees and other large bands of population in the Member States.Our commission has firmly rejected any attempt by the speaker to give, in the motivation, a different dimension to the discussion on the economic situation in the European Union and to send certain messages to Commission and Council, different from that of Parliament, organ elected by the citizens of the Union.Even the positive contribution of international economic institutions and high -level experts, who contributed to reflection, received a miserable welcome.With this resolution, Parliament assumes serious responsibilities in the face of the citizens who have elected it, since it supports an extremely neoliberal socio -economic policy, which promotes generalized privatization, is said to be contrary to everything that is public, undermines workers' rights in the employment, wage, social and social security, imposes a rigid financial policy with strong anti -Popolar and anti -social connotations and,employers, asks workers to become more flexible if they want to find an employment.My group rejects a similar conception without appeal and therefore will not vote in favor of the resolution.Mr. President, the report presented by the Commission on the Union economy in 1999 seems to us nebula as it does not explain at all why our results remain desperately lower than the potential that the immense human resources of Europe should allow us to achieve.Of course, it is pleasant to note that the 3 -percent growth forecast for 2000, which could seem risky when the commission had formulated it in November 1999, today has serious possibilities to realize and this in the context of contained inflation, given that the peak of the 2 percent detected in January for the area of ​​the euro remains, however, lower than in the past.However, there is the impression that this growth, fueled first by the results of the United States, then by the increase in productivity of the new economy, as well as by new information and communication technologies, is driven by the general trend of the world, and this despite our disabilities.These handicaps, to which we must remedy with extreme urgency, we know them well;I am referring to the structural rigidity and excessive mandatory withdrawals that have always characterized us.However, let's not forget that, with the single currency, a new one has been added.In fact, the unification of monetary policies and the progressive alignment of the other policies impose further constraints of the Euro area, forcing them to behaviors that are not necessarily suitable for their structures and conjunctures.

I finish.I will not extend more: we will have the opportunity at other times.But, it goes without saying, as one of the speakers pointed out and I thank you all for your completely positive and relevant interventions, which we cannot allow ourselves to say again, in one, two or three years, that we have not done what we should.For my part, I can assure you, after having discussed it within the college of commissioners, that the Commission is willing to present in Parliament and to the Council the legislative measures, the modifications and the directives necessary to provide us with the highest security levels.The political will of this Parliament is necessary and I note that I can count on this will, as is that of the Council of Ministers.Thank you, Madam Commissioner.We have taken note of your availability.I have received 8 resolution proposals, filed on the basis of article 37, paragraph 2, of the regulation, to close this declaration of the commission.The debate is closed.The vote will take place Thursday at 12 noon.Storms in Europe The agenda calls for the declaration of the Commission on storms in Europe.The floor is to Mr. Barnier, on behalf of the Commission.Mr. Commissioner, I want to thank you for the words you have made, in particular for the completely concrete proposals concerning the victims who expect a lot from the European Union, from the aid that we can bring them.Personally, I sent you, in the first days which followed this terrible storm, a letter to ask you to request French authorities a readjustment of the perimeters of the objective 2, so that all the areas disaster by storms, both in France and elsewhere, can benefit from the objective 2. I think that it was done because you did not speak about it.We all know that if you are not in a perimeter of objective 2, you will have all the difficulties of the world in obtaining aid.So, it is better to remedy this problem right away.You also know that the problem is not just in the short term, but also in the medium and long term.I explain myself.I was present in Lorraine during this terrible storm which ravaged around 20 % of the Feuillus forest.Indeed, for certain so -called forest municipalities which are affected at 20 %, this represents an enormous loss.We know, for example, that it takes between 150 and 200 years for a tree to mature.The loss that these municipalities will be undergone will therefore not spread over a year, two years, five years, but on much more.The municipalities concerned estimate that it will spread over 40 years.I therefore think that it will be really very difficult to compensate for losses in terms of financial return of these rural communities by subsidies.I believe that it is an aspect to engrave in our memories so as not to forget it in our different policies.

If I could do my head, with a magic wand would harmonize excise duties throughout Europe, so the smuggling would no longer exist, except in cases where certain products are intrinsically more expensive in a given Member State.But I don't have a magic wand and I can't do my head.In this sector it takes unanimity, as the honorable Maccormick well knows, and if the Member States will not agree on the harmonization of excise duties, this will not be possible.I repeat that towards the end of the year the Commission will present a report on the situation of excise duties and obviously I am always available to discuss this relationship with Parliament.Community policy on water (continuation) The agenda bears the following of the discussion on the recommendation for the second reading on Community policy on water.Mr. President, the situation of fresh water in Europe is not as serious as in other parts of the world.However, the facts show that, if the demand for water has constantly increased, the quality of this resource is, on the contrary, decreased.To this should be added the problems relating to water pollution in the potential new Member States of Eastern Europe, as well as the recent rupture, in Romania, of a decanting basin containing cyanide, a disaster that could now involve the water pipes that supply the Iugoslav population.I understood that the commissioner Mrs. Wallström, whom I thank for being present tonight, will visit the area.I believe that no country, no government and, of course, no member of Parliament can refuse to recognize that this directive is essential to end the current fragmentation of water policy, as well as to facilitate the start of a program that provides specific measures for each hydrographic basin.The processing was difficult and complex, multiple interests and divergent opinions.There is no doubt that the honorable Lienemann, rapporteur in this legislature, has made great efforts and commitment to try to reconcile and reconcile the positions, reaching its objective to a large extent.However, it is almost impossible to know and evaluate all situations and expectations equally.I come from a country whose southern half overlooks the Mediterranean, a country in which the availability of water has always been linked to the whims of a fickle climatology and a complex conformation of the soil.Century after century, year after year, day after day, until today, the Mediterranean region has had to fight against this adversity in order to develop.This is why it seems very important to us that this directive reaffirms the obligation sanctioned in article 164 of the treaty which requires the community legislation to take into account the diversity of its regions.In order to see this principle applied, the Spanish delegation of the European People's Party will oppose the amendments nos.4 - considering 21 -, 13 and 49 - article 11, paragraph d) -, which seriously limit the sphere of exclusive competence of the Member States, as in the case of the regulation of water resources.For the community it would be very difficult to determine the conditions of this regulation in the various regions, given the different internal balances always present, balances that require, in any case, a profound knowledge of the different areas and interests in play.

Incidentally, in this situation, the political of the European Union has a high level of responsibility.Of course we have to adjust these systems.Especially in France, one has to stop taking up the financing of health insurance and pensions to the labor market alone.Furthermore, the archaic administration mode must be reformed, which represents a source of injustices, mismanagement and waste.In particular, we have to pursue family policy geared towards demographic growth, a economic, monetary and tax policy aimed at growth and reconquest of our internal market, which contributes to the creation of jobs.The commission's proposals and the report Andersson have nothing to do with social policy, but they are an instrument that gives Brussels excessive decision -making powers regarding financing, i.e. the organization and services of the social protection systems of the European nations.For this reason, we voted against this text.Social protection must primarily be an expression of national solidarity, and it is primarily and exclusively the responsibility of the nation states.Social protection must be based on the principle of national and common preference.Otherwise, he only serves the financial regulation of unbearable social conditions that represent a consequence of immigration, at the expense and to the damage of European citizens.We did not participate in the vote on the report by Jan Andersson on a concerted strategy for modernizing social protection.Our basic attitude to the European Union is positive.As Swedish liberals, we consider European integration as a possibility of solving cross -border problems, such as:B. questions of the environment, trade, international mobility, human rights and conflict resolution.Here the democracies of Europe in the world can show that cooperation leads to peace and prosperity.But we also believe in the principle of subsidiarity, i.e.h.that the decision must be taken as close to the person concerned as possible.For this reason, we actively work for a constitution of the European Union, from which the distribution of responsibilities is clearly visible to everyone.It must be absolutely clear to all citizens of the Union that the EU deals exclusively with the questions that it can best solve it - the cross -border problems.All other matters should be treated at local, regional or national level.Social policy is an example of an area in which the EU should only have a limited responsibility, except in cases that deal with the free mobility of people within the Union.Each Member State should have full responsibility and the right to self -determination for its social protection systems.Healthcare, childcare and geriatric care are clear examples of areas that are not directly borders.The same applies to employment policy.We do not consider a common European legal rules in these areas to solve the problems of the social security systems.It is important for us that the Union focuses on a few questions that can really be achieved.However, this does not prevent the Member States from working together and exchanging ideas in the social field.Social security and equality are traditionally high on the agenda of the liberals.That is why we can follow many of the proposals raised in the Anderson report at the national level without reservation.

Mr. Barnier, I beg you to apologize, but I have not fully answered the last part of my question about the great energy transport networks.Could you give an answer to that regard?Do you worry about your honor to know if the installation of nuclear centrals somewhere is going to be financed charged to structural funds?I am schematizing.We could say that there is no need to think about that.I have told him, honor, that, in accordance with the regulations of the structural funds, the selection of the projects remains the competence of the Member States.Therefore, the commission services are not systematically informed of all selected projects.However, his honor does well to ask me, it is his job and mine is to answer him.As has already happened in the past, Member States are forced to respond, to the extent that the commission interrogates or asks for details.Thus, I will go a little further than the confidence usually shared between the Member States and the Commission and I will see exactly what it is, in the specific case mentioned by the honor.The Member State or the interested member states must then respond and I will transmit their response to their honor, when you receive it.I seemed to have answered the question of the great networks.The energy situation is extraordinarily variable according to the regions of the European Union and the help of the funds, in certain cases and regions, it could be justified, in particular in case the connection to the basic energy networks is still underdeveloped.This is the answer I can give about that link between large energy transport networks and structural funds.- Question No. 46 Formulated by (H-0052/00): Subject: Structural funds and additional to the light of the attentive response given by the Commission recently to my written written question on structural funds and additional, could the commission indicate if you plan to modify in any way the norms related to additional?Would it be in favor, in particular, of modifying the norms in such a way that additional not only apply at the level of the Member States but also within them, in regard to the budgetary provisions between the central governments and the regions or countries with a statute of internal autonomy?I would like to respond to Mr. MacCormick that the Commission has not planned to modify the regulations related to additional, which, for the period 2000-2006, was in article 11 of the General Regulations of the Funds.As in the past, the principle of additional is applied, according to such regulations, to the relationship between structural funds and the whole - I say well: the set -of expenses of the Member State in Development.In that regard, it should be stressed that the expenses financed by the structural funds are those that must be additional.It is not mandatory that the co -financing provided by the Member State is, that is, that it is added to its expenses.While the Member State does not reduce the set of its own expenses, it can be considered, and we consider that the structural funds add up to national expenses and, therefore, the principle of additionality is respected.Regarding the budgetary provisions applicable in the Member States, between the central government and the regions or the countries that enjoy internal autonomy, they are determined by virtue of exclusively national considerations, so they are not affected by additional, in the sense formulated in the regulations.

So we will create a cooperative climate that has a positive effect on the quality of the reform.The representatives of the parliament at the government conference have to make it clear to the negotiating partners that we also take responsibility for their constitutional development with the institutional changes in the Union.You should therefore be aware that such questions can not only be decided by haggling.The topics of this government conference are extremely delicate.It may be easy to formulate solutions, but the question is to what extent these solutions can withstand history.I refer to two possible points of conflict.On the one hand, we have the previously preserved balance between large and small countries.Europe is not a classic federal state and can not become anyone.The solutions we have to be decided must submit to the basic concept of the European Union, which is a Union of the states and a Union of the peoples.The other field on which tensions can arise is even more complicated.In view of the upcoming admission of new members, we are calling for more efficient working organs from the future European Union.This means that you have to work easier and faster.However, the European Union is and remains a complex and complicated multi -state institution per se.There are certainly options for tightening and simplification, but there are also limits here.If we overthrow the goal in favor of one -sided efficiency, then the legitimation of the European Union is questioned.However, I am confident.Mr. President, the mandate of the government conference must be expanded.The most important question that needs to be added is the inner differentiation of the Union.Unfortunately, the European Parliament has not yet dealt with it at all, but this is necessary so that the Union can be expanded in the agreed manner.Former Commission President Jacques Delors has again publicly brought up the idea of ​​the European Confederation and also referred to the fact that the avant-garde countries at the top of the association should progress faster than others and that they should establish clarity for their own institutions.The current Commission President Prodi and the High Representative Solana have commented in a similar way.The faction of the liberal and democratic party of Europe positioned itself in the statement on internal differentiation that was assumed last November and proposed a system of concentric circles for Europe, the "onion model".In the next decision to the government conference, the parliament should really deal closely with the question of differentiation and flexibility.If we do not succeed in creating the system proposed by the liberal faction, both the expansion and integration are at stake.My colleagues, Ms. Frassoni and Mr. Onesta have already expressed a little skeptical about some aspects of the topic that we are currently advising.I would like to add a word of concern about the question of subsidiarity not only between the Union and the Member States, but also between the Member States and their own autonomous regions.So far, this has not been duly taken into account, although there are many things to worry here.I would particularly like to deal with one of the effects of the expansion in relation to this parliament.The upper limit was determined that this Thank you, Mr. Medina Ortega.I completely share the regrets you express.Would you have the kindness to write to me so that I can, proof to support, seize the competent authorities both of Air France and also of the French government?I believe that, really, it is no longer possible and it is absolutely necessary that we protest in the most energetic way.Madam President, I had the same experience yesterday as Mr. Medina Ortega.I think that the French authorities - who have the honor of welcoming the headquarters of the European Parliament to Strasbourg - must become aware of their responsibility to guarantee adequate links with all the Union capitals.Absolutely, Mr. Napolitano, thank you.Madam President, this is not a question here of aircraft delays: I would like to excuse the absence yesterday of my colleague from the Green Group, Caroline Lucas, who is British deputy.She could not be present, because she was arrested during an anti -nuclear demonstration in Glasgow yesterday morning.Her identity was noted: it appeared very clearly that she is a European deputy, it was nevertheless kept in detention all day.I believe that it is absolutely unacceptable and I will ask you - During last fall already, we heard Mr. Bernard Kouchner claim police forces.I am satisfied to hear that Mr. Javier Solana will bring together the interior ministers next weekend to discuss the question of police action.I hope that this discussion will first focus on Kosovo, so that we can offer a remedy for this desperate situation.Still with regard to the Balkans and Kosovo, I also hope that the Council will follow up on the wish expressed by the Parliament - and if I am not mistaken, also by the Commission - to see defined over several years a budget devoted to action in Kosovo.Mr. Solana, the events of Kosovo have brought us several lessons: we have learned, for example, the need, to deal with crises, to endow a military capacity that we have already used concretely.But it is advisable to learn another just as important lesson: namely that it is better to prevent crises, rather than being forced to intervene afterwards.The EU therefore also needs an independent and credible capacity in terms of conflict prevention.With regard to the Commission, Commissioner Patten has already taken several laudable initiatives in this direction.I am thinking of the proposal which would consist in setting up a rapid reaction FACILITY and a RAPID REACTION Force for non -military actions, as well as to create goals headlines for non -military actions and a CRISIS Center commission.The last question I would like to send to Mr. Javier Solana is the following: what concrete preparatory work has been carried out in this area of ​​conflict prevention?How were they organized in Mr. Solana's service, and how were they coordinated with the work of the Commission?Mr. President, Mr. Solana, you have the whole support and confidence of the Liberal group, but we want to remind you of the huge responsibility that now rests on your shoulders.Among other things, I think of humanitarian operations, recovery and peacekeeping.But I also think of responsibility, ² which is now yours, to ensure that the new European cooperation in defense does not create the slightest division between NATO and the EU, nor between the USA and Europe.Such a division would only rejoice the despots and rebel states that threaten freedom and human rights.You have, I think, heard the concerns expressed last week in front of our parliament by some members of the US Congress.You must ward off these concerns, Mr. Solana because, as you said yourself, if we are united on both sides of the Atlantic, we can do something.If we divide, we weaken ourselves and thus lengthen the sufferings of the oppressed.From then on, Mr. Solana, maintain the narrowest contacts with our American allies, without forgetting Norway, Turkey and Canada.It is also to a large extent thanks to them that we will not become paper tigers.We have, Mr. George Robertson often said, two million soldiers, but we couldn't even align 40,000 in Kosovo.It is perhaps our weakness and our lack of credibility that led to war.

But they distrust that the shot does not come out with respect to the workers and the unemployed, to whom it is repeated that everything is getting better and better, when they prove that their life does not improve, but, on the contrary, it worsens.This is the main ideological struggle for Europe that is presented to us.I think this debate summarizes it perfectly.The main political division has been evident tonight and it is no surprise that this issue has polarized the debate in an assembly that is known for its consensus capacity and distinctive policy, and I am pleased that this difference of opinion can be seen so clearly, because it is in this case a radical report.This report is a call to Europe to wake up.This report recommends radical measures that basically make personnel hiring easier.That simple.The reason why in Europe we have such exorbitant unemployment rates is because in many cases it is too complicated to hire personnel due to procedures and regulation and lack of flexibility of labor markets.It is the only way we can advance, because the authentic way of guaranteeing social justice in Europe - and after all is for what we are here - goes through the creation of prosperity and opportunities and jobs.This report clarifies clearly towards the most effective way to do so, because Europe has to wake up.You cannot create jobs only through public spending.You cannot create jobs through legislation to reduce working hours, as if jobs were a cake that is chopped and distributed among people.The real world simply does not work that way.And if Europe wants to be left behind, to be left behind in stagnation and unemployment and in statism and in corporatism, then, vote tomorrow against this report.But if they want Europe to advance and begin to respond to the population of Europe, then I would like to ask everyone to support this report, because it will provide those jobs and provide those opportunities and because it is the only means of getting it.Mr. President, Ladies, the Giorgos Katiforis report, in its original version, had the great value of extracting from the specific observations of the commission's document on the situation of the economy in Europe, strong indications for a European Union strategy capable of giving continuity and stability to the perspectives of sustainable development that arise in 2000 for all the countries of our continent.These indications referred to the need for an effective coordination of the economic policies of the Union, to overcome the separate management of economic policies and social policies that until now has represented a serious obstacle to the definition of a coherent strategy to fight unemployment, with a view to full employment.Different Mr. Von Wogau, it is this governance emptiness of the European economy that determines, at least in part, the weakening of the euro.The indications of the document also referred to the creation of a European Research and Promotion Area, in all states of the Union, of converging measures in research, permanent training and occupation, exceeding all forms of unfair competence between the states in fiscal matters.

Obviously the relationship with Armenia constitutes an element of these relationships with the outside, as proof of the agreement signed last year.We believe that Turkey, if she wants to get to share the fundamental values ​​of the European Union and the general framework of its relationships - regardless of the bilateral idiosyncrasies that can have towards another country - in general terms it will have to behave according to the basic models adopted by the European Union in its external relations.Moreover, we are sure that the question in question will constitute one of the priorities in bilateral relations between the European Union and Türkiye in the near future.Question n.6 of the honorable (H-0122/00): object: ethnic cleaning of Serbs in Kosovo from the end of the bombings against Iugoslavia by NATO and EU intended to prevent the ethnic cleaning of Kosovar Albanians by Serbia, and from the arrival of KFfor, on June 12, 1999, 200,000 serbs residing in Kosovo were expulsion and 768 were assassinated, with the 768,Result that an ethnic cleaning of Serbs has been recorded comparatively higher than that occurred by the Serbs themselves.In the last few days we have witnessed the assassination, as always unpunished, of Serbs by Mafie Kosco-Albanians.What decision does the advice intend to end to put an end, once and for all, to this ethnic cleaning and to guarantee respect for human rights to the whole population of Kosovo, regardless of the breed or creed?I would like to thank the president in office for the council for the response provided, but I would also like to remember that, statistically, in Kosovo there is more violence now than there was before the Bombardments NATO.It is worrying that the bombings aggravated the situation, and it should be recognized that NATO and the European Union have committed a mistake by making that decision.The president in charge of the Council spoke rightly - there is no doubt - of the faults of Belgrade, but it must also be remembered that the secret services of the USA, Germany, France, Italy, Great Britain have continued to provide weapons and money to the UK, to a mafia, therefore, to help create problems in the area.Therefore, we all have our faults.I would like to ask a complementary question about the global context.Do you think that it would be appropriate to remove the embargo from Serbia to return the area greater economic normality and allow Kosovo, as a province of Serbia, can benefit from it?Mr President, I am not a friend of Milosevic or his government.However, I have very serious doubts about the legitimacy of NATO action against Yugoslavia regarding Kosovo, both for the lack of authority of the United Nations Security Council, and because it would have been possible not to avoid by imposing unacceptable terms with Ramobouillet regarding the sovereignty of Serbia.The current situation in Kosovo, where the ethnic cleaning of Serbs and Roma has now been completed, is commented on to itself.NATO should not at least recognize the mistake of deliberately hit the Tower of the television of Belgrade and that of killing 20 civil journalists, these made these who remain a serious moral stain on war management and now open the embarrassing prospect of a possible incrimination for war crimes against western leaders?

This will lead us to make the citizens' program of culture 2000.This participation increased by our citizens, who hopes strongly, will have to be wide and fruitful as much as possible.For my part, I am committed to operating so that, over the five years in which the program will be divided, this participation becomes a tangible reality.I know that you parliamentarians, in your regions, in your countries, worked with the participants in the program so that all these small flowers, as a colleague said, become a vast multicolored carpet.I would like this program to become a tangible reality and that culture represented for us citizens not only a factor of enrichment, both on a personal and socio -economic level, but also a right that will have to be affirmed and the sign of an agreement found within the union.Here is the contribution of our European Culture 2000 program. It is not a competition for culture policies carried out in the various Member States, which are necessary and I would like to see them even more developed.It is simply a complementary addition, a bridge between the different cultures of our different countries.Expand and enrich the participation of European citizens in culture therefore seems to me to be an essential task that justifies our efforts.We must measure the success of our action and that of our union with the metro of culture.Many parliamentarians have argued very appropriately that, if a union is made only of economic elements, it was born dead, but if it is made of culture, civilization and participation, then it can live.This is the basis, honorable deputies, that I intend to develop, taking into account in formations, in the cultural sector;encourage cooperations between cultural operators;expand the public giving in particular great space to young people;Finally, safeguard and make the common heritage of European importance as well as the history of European peoples know better.I am sure that the new program, thanks to its structure and its organization based on transparency, efficiency and balance, will be a competitive and irreplaceable tool in the service of our action.Mrs. President, I thank Parliament for your support and for once again demonstrated the importance that attributes to culture in the context of the Union.I am sure that he will not be disappointed for having granted us his support and I am committed to personally inform him of the various phases of implementation of our action, of the action of our citizens, who I hope will be significant for the future of the Union.Thanks, lady commissioner.I believe that our rapporteur can be thanking once again.The discussion
