abusive use of preventive detention are made.All this is the order of the day.However, the most serious thing is that the government resists that the Red Jamers be prosecuted by an international court.It is true that the civil war in Cambodia is over and that political tensions have decreased.However, we are seriously concerned about the treatment that the political opposition is receiving.If this situation persists inexorably, it will have consequences for the relations between the union and Cambodia.Mr. President, within the framework of international law, a new doctrine is being molded, according to which no state can treat its citizens or the people resident in their territory, nor the principle of national sovereignty is a pretext that avoids the intervention of other countries in cases of serious violations of human rights, even if the State management is legitimate or even democratically chosen.

As for the internal reform, you know the commitment made by my committee on this point from the first day.I know full well that we will not be able to achieve any political objective if this deep and total internal reform is not carried out, if the Commission is not more effective in all sectors, starting with that where we have accumulated the most delay, that of external aid.Providing quick help where it is necessary makes it possible to save human lives;Providing late help can sometimes be worse than not to provide at all.When I speak of external aid, I think first of the Balkans, where we record some encouraging signs due to the commitment of our officials in the field, an extraordinary commitment in view of the organizational problems encountered.I also think of the efforts made by Mr. Kouchner, the stability pact that we energetically support, with absolute dedication, but also of new elements, for example in Croatia, where the situation changed in a few weeks.The European institutions immediately opened the door to a dialogue with this country, they welcomed these changes knowing perfectly well that the problems of Bosnia and especially of Serbia can only be resolved if democracy settles in Serbia.This is the new element that we must help to spread in the Balkans.We must be more effective in this region, we must restore traffic on the Danube.There is no need to provide help to Romania and Bulgaria and prevent these two countries from using their main resource.We have to decontaminate the river.To do this, the environmental commissioner will present specific projects in the coming days to control this serious problem.We have done a lot in the Balkans: our new European reconstruction agency for Kosovo, the Task Force for the Balkans, a new regulation aimed at accelerating procedures.However, we absolutely have to do more.We must liberalize exchanges in the region, as well as exchanges between this region and the European Union.We must contribute to the establishment of infrastructure links that break up secular isolation.We must intensify efforts with a view to construction in these countries of a democratic and pluralist society with institutions, public structures, police forces and the organization of civil society, but above all we must encourage these countries to collaborate in a unitary regional perspective, both political and economic.If we do not do it, we will fail to our duty.Remember the Marshall Plan, its effectiveness has not resulted from the only importance of its resources, it turned out to be even more effective because it forced us, Europeans, to collaborate in a new perspective, to give a new horizon to our policy and our economy.This is what we have to do for the Balkans.Europe must prove - from Balkans to all the rest of the world - its ability to expand the space of security, peace and freedom, its ability to act on the international scene.

And I will point out, before moving on to my question, that what is happening within the framework of the status of civil servants within the Commission, plays a fundamental role in terms of our responsibilities also as employers, because, of course, the staff of the European Parliament work under the same conditions.This will constitute part of the work that we will have to do and I am convinced that you will all want to engage in this process today.Well, I would like to resume two points with Mr. Kinnock, if you allow me.The first concerns the calendar of these important reforms.Mr. Prodi said in his very important opening discourse that he had identified serious problems within the Commission which relates to a level of low morality and to a low motivation, which clearly constitutes a major concern.We expect a lot from these reforms, both within the Commission and outside.And if we want to move forward, I would say that the reforms concerning the staff, early proofs of a change of culture, that a strengthening of powers and that a motivation of the staff must be done as soon as possible.And according to the original proposals - and I have the impression that the news will not differ in the matter - the general reform of the status of civil servants would not have been accomplished in 2002. Besides, some of the fundamental elements would not have been introduced in 2001. I think that the delay is too long, and we must really advance much faster than that.The second point I want to raise concerns information technology.Have you really taken into account the changes that the new information technology will bring to the level of staff structure, as they will be fundamental for the new management of these reforms.In terms of the second part of Mr. Harbor's question, he will see, during this year, that we will show, with greater precision, in what way the broader application of information technologies will facilitate change, not only in terms of personnel practices and conditions of staff but also in terms of the operation of the Commission, as the President has briefly underlined.Let me thank Mr. Harbor for his energetic commitment in favor of the subject for which he is rapporteur and to answer him by saying that we firmly believe that the moral, motivation and professional commitment of commission officials, already very high, will be improved by the introduction of global training, by the allocation of responsibilities, by improving management and by a number of other changes that will be introduced.Cultures are structural and systems products, and structures and systems have become old.By renovating them, sometimes in a very radical way, will help us those who, in the Commission, resolutely seek the European ideal and whose capacities are very high, to make talents expressing and what they manifest as never before they have done.I would like to make a last remark in response to Mr. Harbor.

Finally, I would like to add that I had my doubts about government formation in Austria last week.However, I have no concerns to discuss and criticize Austrian asylum policy.I hope the commitment of this plenary will be just as large.Mr. President, during the last financial foresight for the period 1994-1999 with a total of 13 different initiatives, was of great importance to the cross-border Interreg II initiative.In my opinion, the fact that the Interreg initiative is the upcoming round of the structural funds in the period 2000-2006 is a clear evidence of the rank that the EU member states attach to it.The Interreg-I program in the period 1989-1993 and the Interreg-II program in 1994-1999 have proven to be an outstanding success in terms of approaching social and economic development between neighboring Member States.In my homeland, the border counties in the northwest of Ireland, I have been able to pursue the important role that Interreg I and II have played in recent years, so I look forward to Interreg III with great joy.The Commission approved the Interreg III program of £ 67 million, which are to be used to continue the development of economic projects for municipalities on both sides of the border between the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland.The European Union played a major role in the development of these border regions in the many years.With its contribution of 80 million pounds for the International Fund for Ireland, the EU is the largest sole proprietor, and it also contributes 75 % of the funds for the program to support peace and reconciliation.All in all, Interreg, the International Fund for Ireland and the program for peace and reconciliation, have made a decisive contribution to promoting the peace process.Mr President, I will limit myself to some critical aspects with my explanations of Interreg, also to adhere to the speaking time at your disposal.We supported the new edition of this program and the expansion of the intervention areas, not only in the area of ​​cross -border cooperation, but also in the context of transnational and interregional cooperation.Regardless of this, we are aware that most of the resources - between 50 and 80 % - will be reserved for cross -border cooperation, i.e. the orientation A of the Interreg III program;That is why we are still of the opinion that the decision to consolidate the current cooperation spaces in this direction with regard to the selection of the eligible regions is wrong and inconsistent.We hope and wish that the Commission would go into the point of view of the position of Parliament and not only pay it to formal recognition.The cross -border cooperation continues to refer almost exclusively to the mainland borders, and in the cases where exceptions to the maritime boundaries have been made, the corresponding decisions are not transparent and often have to do with the fact that compensation to other fields of community policies should be created.The island areas that live in a regional situation that is inevitably connected to pure sea boundaries are particularly disadvantaged.This corresponds to continued discrimination, in the context of which the content of Article 158 of the contract, where the islands are mentioned in connection with politics to strengthen economic and social cohesion.

We understand that collaboration is important, common work by the two institutions - Parliament and Commission - and that the collaboration that exists with the Regional Policy Commission, and specifically with the transport group, is magnificent.The common position includes practically all amendments accepted by the Commission, harmonizes the minimum requirements of the exams of the Security Directors and, in second reading, we can accept the amendment on the proposed date, much more realistic than that raised in principle by the Commission, taking into account that we have been discussing this issue for several years.Bhisimly, I also want to thank the intervention of the different deputies and tell their laddies that security is a priority of the commission in the field of transport.And as Mr. Simpson has said very well, the process can never be taken for granted or culminated.The process of increasing margins, transportation guarantees is a process that must be improved day by day.In that sense, I also want to refer very briefly to the problems of the tunnels, to which Messrs. Rack and Swoboda have referred, which, undoubtedly, in the case of Austria, it is a very sensitive matter, so you have to make efforts to see how to increase their safety.In one of the great accidents that occurred lately, the merchandise transported was not dangerous.La Margarina and a few kilos of paint that, in principle, did not raise risks, caused a true catastrophe.Therefore, we must see how the demands can be further refined to guarantee a maximum security.Finally, I would like to say that security must be contemplated in all types of transport.This week we will celebrate here a debate to talk about the security of maritime transport, due to the Erika catastrophe, and we will have to discuss, throughout this year, about the objectives, in terms of safety, of air transport.But I mean, lordships, that security is a priority objective of the commission.As I will say in the debate about Erika, we do not wait for there to be a catastrophe to turn over the aspect of security, but we work on it apart from these circumstances, that all they do is show the urgency of an effective response to such problems.I want to reiterate my thanks to all those who have intervened and especially the rapporteur, Mr. Koch.The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow at 12 noon.Transport of dangerous goods by road In accordance with the agenda, Mr. Koch, on behalf of the Regional Policy Commission, Transport and Tourism, on a proposal of the Board of Directors of the European Parliament and the Council (com (1999) 158 - C5-0004/1999 - 1999/0083 (COD) (COD) (COD) (COD) (COD) (COD) (COD) (COD), which modifies the directiveon the approximation of the legislation of the Member States with respect to the transport of dangerous goods by road.

I would like to thank Commissioner Patten who, despite the short notice, wanted to participate in today's debate and answer our questions about Mozambique's extremely critical situation.As other speakers said, the television images of the Clean Valley left us absolutely breathless: we saw children who lost their parents and families defenseless and without hopes that have lost everything.As has already been said, all this was predictable and had been foreseen, and the fact that the response to the catastrophe is slow and inadequate - shamefully slow and inadequate - should make us understand that a big investment must be made in preparing a response to similar catastrophes.As the commissioner said, a mechanism and a prompt intervention force must be implemented which, in situations like this, allow us to face crises that have only occurred because we had not applied the appropriate strategies or had not made the necessary logistical preparations.This morning there were seven helicopters in flight, all concentrated in the Gaza region alone.The Save river also presents strong risk of flooding, but nobody has yet gone to the scene.85 percent of the rescue operations takes place within the area that can be reached in less than an hour from MapuTu and therefore are unable to evaluate the scope of the problem.I would like to point out to the commissioner that European citizens want to know exactly what Echo is doing.Most of us would not want to stop at 3 million euros;It will take much more, and I hope that the commissioner can return here with the promise to allocate more funds and with an initiative that can coordinate our efforts.Clearly it will be necessary to create a large air bridge.As has been said, there is a need for a large amount of food, equipment for the purification of water, curtains and blankets.I wonder if we are ready to deal with the next rescue and reconstruction phase that has been discussed, since this phase will also need huge resources.Are we ready to provide the indispensable financial coverage?Mozambique is one of the poorest countries in the world, but it is also one of those who have achieved the most results in Africa.The country has worked hard in favor of economic growth, the reduction of poverty and democracy, despite the enormous pressure of the public debt.Mozambique is a model country, but will have a period of great difficulties in all probability due to what he has suffered.Now we should try to understand how much the catastrophe to Mozambique will cost, and this will depend only on the quantity and quality of the international aid that will be provided.Thank you very much, honorable Kinnock.Mr Nogueira, we take note of his interest and concern for this question, but his group is not registered to intervene to the discussion and I landed on the regulation.The discussion is closed.Economy of the Union (1999) The agenda bears the discussion on the report (A5-0041/2000), presented by the Honorable Katifortis on behalf of the Commission for economic and monetary problems on the Commission document entitled "Revision of the Economy of the European Union in 1999" (C5-0081/2000-2000/2046 (COS)).The Commission report presents an assessment of the current European economic situation that it finds promising, in particular in relation to the recent recovery of economic growth which should lead to the reduction of unemployment to 8 percent by 2001.

It is worrying that the bombing has aggravated the situation, and it should be recognized that the performance of NATO and the European Union has been wrong to take that measure.Mr. Minister has spoken, rightly -I am agreeing to Belgrade's faults, but it must also be remembered that the secret services of the US, Germany, France, Italy, Great Brittany have been supplying weapons and money to the UCK, to a mafia, to contribute to the fact that there were problems in that area.Therefore, we are all to blame.I wanted to ask you a complementary question about its global context.Don't you think that it would be beneficial to lift Serbia so that there were greater economic normality in the area and Kosovo also benefited as a province of Serbia?Mr. President, I am not a friend of Milosevic or his government, but I feel very deep doubts about the legitimacy of NATO's action against Yugoslavia because of Kosovo, both for the lack of authority of the United Nations Security Council and because I believe that what happened could have been avoided if they had not imposed unacceptable terms for Serbian sovereignty in Rambouilt.The current situation of Kosovo, which currently has been ethnically refined from Serbs and Romani, corroborates what I have said.I think that the least that NATO should do is recognize its fault for the deliberate attack against the Belgrade TV tower, in which more than 20 civil journalists perished, and that constitutes a serious moral heel for the development of the war and now opens the embarrassing possibility that our western leaders are accused of war crimes.Honor, we do not have, at the level of the positions adopted by the European Union, an interpretation and a selective analysis of the military objectives, in particular of the initiatives adopted against a certain type of infrastructure that served as support to the political and propaganda system of Mr. Milosevic.Therefore, I cannot tell him whether or not we agreed with a specific action carried out by NATO.It is part of a global plan for which we agree.Some of these actions could be debatable and some were considered unfortunate even by NATO itself and others will be justifiable actions for tactical reasons, in the sense of preventing Mr. Milosevic from maintaining their internal propaganda campaign.In any case, I, in the name of the Council, do not want to make any value judgment regarding some concrete action carried out by NATO in the military sphere.Mr. President in the exercise of the Council, since I know the history of the Balkans, I would like to remind you that for many decades the peoples of Yugoslavia lived peacefully.The destabilization began, approximately a decade ago, with the dissolution of Yugoslavia, a process in which the European Union played a determining role.The crime of Yugoslavia consisted of being the only country of Balkans who had not requested its entry in NATO or the European Union.And so, now what was still standing, after the aerial incursions, is destroyed by the supposedly unarmed Uçk, in the noses of the KFOR, whose role of occupation force becomes increasingly evident.

I would like to ask the Commissioner whether this principle is actually applicable and whether we will receive any compensation from the people mentioned.The second question refers to the announced commission of the Commission on Environmental Liability, which is intended to ensure that the pollutant principle will apply in the future and that we have better opportunities to implement European environmental legislation accordingly.The white book admits that the cause can only be held responsible if it has been determined if the damage is quantifiable and a causal connection is undoubtedly proven.The accident of Erika is an example par excellence;This is exactly what the white book is about here.It can therefore become a benchmark of how to deal with problems of this kind in the future.The proposed guideline provides for a strict liability for damage that goes back to dangerous activities regulated by the EU.My concern goes there, and maybe the commissioner can comment on whether the white book for environmental liability is actually the right means of dealing with problems of the size of the Erika shipwreck.If it actually does justice to the requirements or will continue to get away from ship Shavaria on the high seas without having to pay for the damage.Mr President, we would like to express our sympathy and solidarity to the people and regions affected by the disaster.But good intentions alone are not sufficient, but a replacement must be made for the damage and the failures must be compensated for, both in terms of restoration of the environment as well as the mussel breeding facilities and the fishing equipment.We welcome that the Lord spoke of the fact that it is necessary to act and compensate for it quickly and retrospectively.We also complain about the careless control of the ships and support the creation of a European coast guard and in particular the demand for stricter legal regulations and for ships with a double outer skin.We continue to denounce the practice of pleasure flags in both merchant ships and fishing vehicles.Furthermore, we are shocked by the fact that the cargo was strongly carcinogenic due to the content of polyaromatic hydrocarbons of over 1000 ppm.This means that under the 15,000 tons of oil that came into the sea were 15 tons of highly toxic products.This is unacceptable.We also learned it too late, so that medical check -ups are now particularly necessary for the volunteers who have worked with great commitment to restoring the environment.In our opinion, the prevention against such risks and scientific research to prevent and eliminate damage must apply special attention.Numerous suggestions have been made that should be checked.Solutions for disaster cases cannot be found at the last moment, but it must mainly be traded in advance.Mr President, over two months after Erika's accident, the already cleaned coastal sections are repeatedly dirty.I would like to express my solidarity with the victims again and appreciate the high commitment of the volunteers and specialists who are still working on cleaning the dirty beaches.As a result of the mobilization on site, to whose mouthpiece our house made a debate and the assumption of a resolution on February 20, the announcement of a first package of measure has occurred.

In 80 percent of the market subject to free competition, the price has dropped.This shows that competition really works.My conclusion is: Get competition in the other 20 percent!In the light of these facts, they are increasingly demanding ... (the speaker is interrupted by Markov) believed that it was I who had the word.Possibly we can discuss this a little later.However, I find that it is precisely as I have stated, that is, that the price has dropped in the sectors where there is competition and has risen where there is monopoly.This is how it works almost always.Therefore, I recommend the formation of a commission that takes the necessary initiatives and occupies that there is competition in the postal sector.Mr. Markov, you will have a few minutes within five or six minutes.I would appreciate that he did not interrupt his colleagues.Mr. President, there is a mystery.What happened to the directive on postal services that was approved on December 15, 1997?The Commission has maintained overwhelming silence for the time since then until the current moment.I feel the Monti commissioner who is here today.I have a lot of esteem.He is one of the most diligent and workers commissioners.I am not able to say the same of some of his colleagues.There has not been, during this time, true progress in the directive on postal services.Commissioner Monti said that the organization and redistribution of functions are partly due.This was not done until recently.For more than a year the former commission could have worked something on the subject.The truth is that we have not advanced much.However, and since Commissioner Monti is here, I would like to transmit a message to Commissioner Bolkestin telling him what the directive about postal services was about.It was a gradual liberalization;It was a guaranteed universal service at an affordable price;He tried to make direct mail and cross -border mail remain in the reserved sector.These issues were fundamental in that report and should continue to be in any future directive.The postal service is not just for Christmas.It is for a lifetime.In the Scotland area of ​​which I proceed, it is much more than a simple postal service.It is a means of keeping communities together.The postal service is also the bus service.Postal service is also social service.The postal service is also the doctor.If we let the postal services derive towards complete privatization, then we will lose all that and many of our local communities - we vote on tourism - will lose their tourist activity.We will isolate them.Postal services are important.This message must leave here today.And the commission must listen to it.Mr. President, we are supporters of the liberalization of the Postal Services of the Union.This means first of all that customers will have a better service.This is what is intended and this must be the final objective.

The Financial Regulation is the legal framework so that the priorities provided in cooperations for Malta and Chipre accession can be launched.I can't start as long as I don't have it because I lack the legal basis.If the lack of coherence that is attributed has something to do with this point, I have to say that this regulation is only a legal framework and nothing else.The fulfillment of this legal framework can be found in the priorities of the accession cooperations that were agreed last year by the Commission and the Council and that now apply in the corresponding programming and management of the projects.I would say that there are many fields in European policy where you can complain about a lack of coherence, but in this case I claim for the commission and the council that we have developed a very clear and coherent policy..(Of) Mr. President, Mr. President of the Council, after Mr. Commissioner has exposed us in an extraordinarily coherent way that the lack of coherence was due to the powers of the former president of the Council and his Minister for Europe, could perhaps help us and Mr. Commissioner so that this resolution can be adopted?A great help solution would be if I answered positively to my questions about financial forecasts until 2004 and on category 7 or at least if I said that the Portuguese presidency of the Council intends to compensate for the lack of coherence of then by an effort like the one described, such as Mr. Commissioner, he will also try to be achieved in the commission.Mr. President, I believe that the question raised by the honorable honor and my friend Elmar Brok will be examined by the Council.It seems to me that the criticism made to the previous presidency is not pertinent.I consider that what the previous presidency did in the formulation of financial perspectives was excellent work, regardless of the people who participated in it.In any case, the issue raised is important and we, at the level of the Council, we will not stop supporting the proposals presented by the Commission in that regard.Mr. President of the Council, I have understood;Collega Brok referred to an even older presidency.Mr. President, I have raised Mr. Commissioner Verheugen a specific question about the Meda financing instrument he has not answered.I beg you to do it because your response also depends the voting behavior on various amendments that have been presented to us.Dear Mr. Poos, I beg you.Precisely in the place where you have asked me the question there was a dark appearance.In the case of Meda, the situation is in such a way that Malta and Chipre can participate in the supraregional programs, but not in the specific programs of the countries because the income is too high.Thank you very much, Mr. Commissioner Verheugen.The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Thursday.

It should also be emphasized that once again, the commission in fact is the problem of concrete actions in the equal opportunities sector.In conclusion, we are in the presence of a not particularly satisfactory document and, in certain points, disappointing.Berend report (A5-0107/1999) We agree, essentially, with the assessment and considerations of the rapporteur concerning the sixth periodic report on the social and economic situation, and the development of the regions of the European Union.We will therefore limit ourselves to emphasizing certain aspects only.First, as the Commission itself says, the fact that the per capita GDP of certain poorest regions has increased sharply between 1991 and 1996 is to a large extent to the inclusion of the new German Länder in the calculations of the community average, from the first year.This fact is obviously at the origin of a significant reduction in the level of the GDP per capita of the Union.Then, it is particularly important for us to note that the recovery of certain regions - where it took place - was accompanied by a minimum increase in employment, which therefore requires new development strategies, with a major concern for this area.This situation contradicts the slowness of the adoption of employment promotion measures exclusively reserved for the internal policy of the Member States, as the report does.Finally, but this is not the least important aspect, we will mention the rapporteur's proposal to include in the future in this type of report, among other aspects, an analysis of the interregional evolution of cohesion in each state.The multiplicity of situations and the differentiated evolution from one region to another, within the same state, impose an in -depth evaluation of this question so as to allow and guarantee the correction of regional policies (and others) in order to ensure cohesion also inside each Member State.Given the employment situation in the community and the ambition displayed by the European Union to resolutely attack unemployment, the analysis of the concentrations made by the Commission should take into account other elements than competition.I want for example the restructuring of the ABB-Alsthom Power company, including a large delegation of employees from all over Europe is present today in Strasbourg.The management of Abb-Alsthom Power, which results from a merger carried out in June 1999, announced a restructuring with already prospects for job cuts in a number of countries.This harmful situation for employment poses many questions, in particular on the information given to the European works council which has existed since 1996. This implies updating and strengthening the community directive on European works councils.This also implies control of concentrations which takes into account employment, the environment and consumers.The report of the Economic and Monetary Commission being insufficient from this point of view, I abstained.By claiming to apply the principle of subsidiarity at the level of the European competition policy, the Commission decentralizes for the benefit of the national authorities and courts the responsibility for decisions and abuse of dominant position compared to the business agreements which create distortions on the market, although the questions of concentration of companies and state aid remain in the notification regime.

The European Union and its Member States must set an example and contribute an important part of these funds.In this way we would not only place the United States in a embarrassing situation in regard to fulfilling their financial responsibilities regarding the financing of the United Nations, but also demonstrating that our commitment in favor of the defense of human rights is more than simple rhetorical.Mr. President, this debate aims to prepare the next annual session of the United Nations on Human Rights and the action of the Commission and the Council in it.In the first place, let me say that I am very satisfied with what Mr. Patten and the Minister have stated so far, and I think it is fine that both China and Cuba are subject to debate.Cuba continues to be the last dictatorship of South America and that is something that we cannot forget, despite all the sympathies that Cuba arouses in some circles.It is a dictatorship and, therefore, not a democracy.I want to ask for attention in my two minutes for two countries with which I am joined by a special bond.First, Indonesia.Of course, we are very happy that Indonesia has a new government and that Mr. Wahid and Mrs. Sukarnoputri occupy the presidency and vice presidency, respectively.We are also glad that the situation in Timor gradually evolves in good direction.However, I inform you that violence is not yet under control in Las Molucas, a territory that is northern Timor.There have been thousands of dead in the last two years.Tens of thousands of people have fled.The situation is not well controlled.I know that tomorrow or the day after tomorrow there is an important program on Dutch television in which observers are sent, only to precisely examine what happens there, so that, in any case, what is happening is found, also with a view to later, for human rights commissions.My urgent plea is, and it is something that we have collected in the resolutions, which we negotiate the sending of observers to the Molucas.The thousands of dead are already enough, thousands of injured, tens of thousands of refugees.My second country, and I want to be very brief, since Mr. Patten knows it very well, is Burma.It is unacceptable that we do not pronounce on this country.I have the idea that Burma has progressively falling into oblivion.Ten years ago the elected president is under house arrest.Ten years already, that Parliament does not work.Endless parliamentarians have been killed or fled and only a few live in Burma.Hundreds of thousands of refugees have left Burma to Thailand or India and, nevertheless, it seems that attention to that country is no longer paying.I think that this country must be included in the agenda, especially given the change in Indonesia.

It is a fact that a new agreement with the ACP countries has been concluded.In itself it is a positive fact, in particular if we take into account the pressures aimed at ending and that there were even several non -support member states of their continuity.At the time, we will have the opportunity to analyze more deeply the exact terms in which said agreement was established.Now, there is no doubt that European negotiators were more shy and fell short with respect to the proposals that we formulate, even when new and innovative elements appear in the new agreement.And they will have contributed some characteristics of political importance of the new association agreement.That has undoubtedly been the result of a complex negotiation in which the two parties have made substantial concessions, which is true in the case of the European Union, particularly in terms of good administration and trade.But it was above all the result of a strengthening of the ACP group, which manifestly found a new spirit following what happened in Seattle.I want to underline in particular that it seems to be emerging a new way of considering these issues, particularly in terms of trade, so an approach is very necessary in that regard.Finally, it is necessary to go further in the policies to support developing countries.In the financial-presupported plans, at the level of debt, in the support of delicate spheres such as food and humanitarian security or education and health and also those of the environment, investment or access to information and new technologies, as well as in the commercial sphere, simultaneously ensuring a full coherence of development policies with other community policies and also between them and the corresponding ones applied by the Member States.We cannot be content to give continuity to something that has been insufficient and wrong in the past.Mr. President, having heard the commission and the Council today, I have simply had to take a look at my order.Yes, there really appears: "coherence of the different policies of the union with development policy."However, we have not heard a single word about it and it seems extremely embarrassing.We have expected a report on coherence for years.It should have been written in writing here and having heard the intervention of Mr. Nielson, it is hard to imagine that I have found very powerful opposing forces in the commission.I know that the commissioner himself maintains points of view as solid as extremely sensible with respect to coherence and I would have liked to hear them here today.Since the common resolution proposal raises some effective mechanisms for guaranteeing coherence, I would like to limit myself within the very little time that I have to mention another, the obligation that the Commission also performs in this regard an assessment of the new legislation that is relevant.And also by the way I want to focus on the catastrophic effect that the EU common agricultural policy has had on developing countries.Poured the sea of ​​beef in Sahel and South Africa, tomato puree in West Africa, powdered milk in Jamaica, it is expected that all examples are well known.

How do we implement what is relatively detailed in the contracts for development aid programs?Some MPs, Mr. Ferber and Mr. Cushnahan, talked about the gap between the Sunday speeches and reality.Herr Cashman verwies darauf, daß man Taten nicht durch Worte ersetzen könne, was in gewisser Weise durchaus richtig ist.Of course you can achieve something with words, as Ms. Malmström said.She explained that she received a letter from the Chinese ambassador, an extremely gracious and highly intelligent representative and servant of his country, in which he informed her that she was wrong and the European Parliament with his attitude with regard to the question of human rights in China.I think Ms. Malmström will receive a true flood of letters from the Chinese authorities after her speech.She will then be able to fill an entire file cabinet about the supposedly real situation in China.The view of many non -governmental organizations and many people who admire Chinese civilization, but are concerned about the current events in China, have been given.It is completely right to think about what we can do.In the first speech, Mr. Salafranca mentioned two areas in which, apart from the To mention an example, in Ireland we saw the success of the leader I and leader II programs, in the sense of the jobs created thanks to the administration of these programs in the rural areas of Ireland and Europe.Leader III should be made towards the end of this year.The leading program, in essence, offers the public sector, to the private sector and volunteering groups the opportunity to put together their collective talents to create lasting and long -term jobs in small and medium -sized enterprises of rural areas.This is a classic illustration of how the concept of partnership operates and how these programs must be applied on the basis of a widest possible mandate.The European Fund for Peace and Reconciliation has achieved as many successes on the side of the creation of employment in the Irish border counties.Once again it is the active participation of public and private actors and volunteering to demonstrate how certain funds can be used at best to encourage the various local projects aimed at creating jobs in the region.During the next round of structural funds for 2000-2006 other community initiatives will operate such as Equal and Urban.These initiatives must also involve local authorities and communities in the effort to identify the optimal use of European structural funds.The rapporteur mentions the need to follow an integrated approach for the new plans and programs of the structural funds that must promote a decentralized, efficient and composite partnership, based on the skills and commitment of all sectors in regional and local authorities.This aspect is very delicate because the main economic and social difficulties in our country cannot be surmounted without a crucial integration between national, local and European funds.This report brings us back to the question of why a regional policy.To fill the regional gaps, of course.But above all, because although the European market guarantees us a priori a better functioning of the economy, it can also be a source of inequality.Jacques Delors used to say that being the myopian market, there is the political need to reduce disparities.It is that phenomenon of solidarity that is the origin of the European social model that we all defend, from which economic and social cohesion was born.Real political objective, exactly like the economy and the monetary, it is implemented in collaboration with the Member States, the local regions and community.The commission, for its part, is in charge of indicating to the Member States, thanks to the directors, the direction to be followed to obtain the desired objectives in the area of ​​programming.For this reason, I will give my support to this report while deploring, for calendar reasons, that the European Parliament has been consulted only late on orientations that should have been aid to the Member States, the Regions and the local community for the programming of objectives 1, 2 and 3. On the other hand, I hope that our assembly also takes into account the opinion of the Commission for the employment and social affairs, which contributes with a whole.of reflections on essential issues such as the fight against social exclusion, support for social economy and the implementation of a strategy for employment.

But who defines this mission?Who draws the limit from which this public service mission is committed?Our answer is clear: it is not the commission, it is not even the European council or Parliament, first phase of adaptation of Directive 97/67/EC in postal services, and I fear that a new stage of liberalization is translated by an important decrease in public service provision.On the occasion of the audition of Mr. Bolkestein, my colleague Véronique Mathieu had expressed "that any new proposal, once known, is subject to studies on the effects, so that the consequences of the programming of Mr. President, dear colleagues, it was not necessary to wait for the end of the Kosovo conflict to reach the conclusion that, after several wars in the territory of the ex-Yugoslavia, with their procession of harmful effects on the stability of the regionBalkans, it is necessary to implement a global and sustainable strategy guaranteeing peace and stability in southeast of Europe.This strategy, which was materialized by the stability pact adopted on June 10, 1999, considers the region of Southeast Europe as an entity, but it recognizes, at the same time, the diversity and the inequality of the development of the different countries that compose it.The contribution of the European Union within the framework of the stability pact, translated into the said "stabilization process and association" relates to the development of the regional conception that the EC developed in 1996 for the five countries of the region, that is to say Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, the old Yugoslav Republic of Macedia andAlbania, and whose most significant aspect is the establishment of political and economic measures intended to support the Dayton Peace Accords, which should thus contribute to the stability of the region.Consequently, the establishment of completely new bases establishing relations between the European Union and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, and the opening of this country to a prospect of full integration into the structures of the European Union through a system provided for in the stabilization and association process, constitute an important contribution for the stability of the Balkan region.

Berend Report (A5-0107/1999) We share, essentially, the evaluation and considerations that the speaker formulates regarding the sixth periodic report on the social and economic situation and the development of the regions of the European Union.Therefore, we just underline some aspects.In the first place, and as the commission says, the fact that the strong progression of GDP per inhabitant of some poorest regions between 1991 and 1996 is largely determined by the inclusion of the new German Länder in the calculations of the community average, from exactly the first of those years, which, evidently, determined a sensitive reduction in the level of GDP per inhabitant of the Union.In addition, we consider particularly important that the recovery in some regions - in which it occurred - was accompanied by a minimum increase in employment, which imposes, consequently, new development strategies, with a lot of level of concern about it.This situation that contradicts the remission of the adoption of employment promotion measures to the exclusive domain of the Member States, as is made in the report.Finally -and it is not unimportant -a reference to the proposal of the rapporteur in the sense that in the future this type of report also includes, and among other aspects, an analysis of the interregional evolution of cohesion in each of the states.The multiplicity of situations and the differentiated evolution that is given from region to region, within the same State, impose, in effect, a deeper evaluation of this issue in order to allow and guarantee corrections in regional (and other) policies with a view to guaranteeing cohesion at the internal level of each of the Member States..(FR) The Berend report offers us an interesting analysis of the situation and economic development of the European Union regions.However, the French delegation of the Union Group for the Europe of the Nations cannot unless disagree with some of the statements it contains.Thus, section 26 "emphasizes the need to consolidate the budget as a previous condition for the success of the Economic and Monetary Union and the extension of the Union."In a few times when the Member States are forced to follow a budgetary weight loss diet to meet the convergence criteria, a diet that, on the other hand, have been imposed on their own, the federalists show signs of a very surprising pecuniary gluttony.In a sign of recognition of the failure of the cohesion policy and the EMA, the insufficiency of the results obtained is included in the account of discovered and all rival eloquence to claim more credits, without anyone asking about the effectiveness of the funds used.What can be said of a budget management that consists in establishing an expense objective, instead of a maximum limit of expenses, in searching for projects to spend at all costs the approved credits, instead of granting credits for existing projects?

We must affirm the equality of sexes, the famous Gender mainstreaming, which is one of the less developed issues in the Prodi Commission program.And this means giving priority to the equality of sexes, to the adaptation of the social model and, above all, to a clear struggle against populism in a situation in which our economic and social cohesion is threatened, and that is also something that has to appear as the first priority in the work of the commission.And that it must be complemented with a clear fight against racism and intolerance to be able to affirm in practice the evolution of a union that has become a pole of attraction for the rest of the world and in an immigration zone, given its prosperity and its autumn demography.And this, I think it must be the first objective we have to pursue.In this regard, another element would also add, which is the economic government, with a unique currency -I think it is imposed -and also an issue in which the commission has to move forward.I would like -I would like my group, of course -in relation to the ambitious objectives and, above all, with something important that the commission has done, which is to adopt that extension in the negotiation and integration process, which was clearer in relation to the review of the 2000 agenda. Does the commission think that until the end there will be no review?And the issue of imposition also seems absolutely key.On the governance in general, I think a theoretical reflection can be very interesting.I call attention to one thing: it is dangerous to rethink the entire Government of the European Union from here.I would be clearly in favor of subsidiarity.If we are able to define what our area of ​​the Interior is, it seems to me that it would be very positive.In the rest, I believe that subsidiarity also applies to reflection.Not only should the commission be, it must be our states, our parliaments and our civil society who also reflect on it.Finally, Mrs. President, I would like to make a brief reference to the last objective, which seems absolutely fundamental: the stabilization of the continent and the reinforcement of Europe's role in the world.There I would say that there is an agreement and support in relation to the priority of Europe in the Southeast, with the extension and-I have already indicated-with the integration process and with the reinforcement of the Euromediterranean program and of our capacity for conflict prevention, and with an issue that is spoken very little, which is the North-South challenge.We must not forget Africa, which is the continent absolutely left not only God, but of Europe, nor our important contribution to development cooperation.And finally, an issue in which we are increasingly responsible, as the first world economic and commercial power, which is the voice of the European Union in the world, which means not only an active attitude in relation to the Round of the Millennium.It involves the reform of the United Nations and international financial institutions, in which Europe has enormous responsibility.

In my opinion, the proposal submitted by the Commission must contain elements that allow greater transparency of the working method of several organs, but there is certainly room for improvements at all times.We are ready to check the suggestions made in this context.The question that Jonas Sjöstedt and other MPs asked is of great importance.In Sweden there is the principle of the public that strengthens democracy and has a positive dialogue between citizens, decision -makers and authorities.We are very careful that the EU also takes this path, which is also supported by the Amsterdam contract.A few years ago, the Parliament accepted a report Lööw, which is very important in this context.It was warned that future development would lead to a restriction of the public principle in the Member States.Now we can see that this warning of parliament may have had a certain justification.I would like to ask the advice whether he can understand this warning with a view to the commission's work documents.I listened carefully to the statements of the incumbent Council President for transparency and the government conference.My question now is whether I can conclude from the really interesting comments by Mr. Seixas da Costa on the topics mentioned that the Portuguese presidency undertakes to examine the expansion of the agenda of the government conference and to enter.The problem of "transparency" in the working method of the institutions must not be checked only in secret or in connection with any other topics or in certain corridors - although I also know how important corridors are.This requires a special point on the agenda of the government conference, which must therefore be expanded.Mr. MP!The question of transparency is a question that is naturally connected to the organs.This government conference, at least initially, is based on the focus of the more optimal way of working of the organs, whereby in particular is invoiced that we all have, namely that the organs become more democratic, more transparent and efficient.However, all of this, while maintaining a general framework for global acceptance of all solutions that we can find in order to realize these three goals.Obviously, this question of transparency will remain on the European agenda in the long run, and apparently it will be on the agenda of this government conference.I can assure you that the Portuguese presidency will continue to confront the Member States and the representatives in the preparation group of the conference with this question.In this area, she must be able to expect the MEPs of the European Parliament, which are certainly motivated to support this proposal.Then we will check at the ministerial level how we can continue in this process.However, we have to note that we have concluded a contract of Amsterdam that was assumed in May of last year that there is a complex of measures to introduce transparency that is still implemented and the question is whether it would be premature to start a new process in the area of ​​transparency.Despite everything, I think it is a question that must always be the order of the day because there is clearly a certain awareness of the problem on the part of public opinion and because it is associated with the truly necessary responsibility of the European organs and institutions towards the citizens.

Postal services are not only a mail service, but also a social service.For some, the postman is the only person they meet in the arc of the day.We can pay homage to the postmen who, in any climatic condition, walk several kilometers on foot to guarantee their service to everyone.Dismantling the postal service, the service of proximity communication, would be a serious mistake;Furthermore, the equality of all citizens would not be protected.Pursuing profit at any cost means hindering fraternity and social cohesion.Mr. President, I voted in favor of this resolution and I wish to explain the reason.Several speakers recalled that, especially in the mountain municipalities, the only person with whom the elderly have some contact is the postman.I agree on this observation.However, I believe that the pensions of many elderly people will be reduced according to the state budget.In Italy, my country of origin, there are about 200,000 employees and cost about 50 million lire per year per capita, or 25,000 euros.The total cost is therefore equal to around 5 million euros.Moving on to the liberalization of this service, the state budget would free, that is, it would have an excess of about 10 million lire per year for each pensioner, to be allocated to one million pensioners, who would be doubled their pension.This would largely compensate for the sacrifice of not having contacts with the postman.Mr. President, I voted for the resolution on European postal services with much greater satisfaction as it once again proposes the position I have always defended, or the need for a high quality universal service, in particular in the less densely populated regions, the rural areas, and there is one also in my small country, the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg.In these regions, but also in some neighborhoods of large cities, as colleague Melt, post offices and postmen explained a role that I would call almost socio -cultural, which goes beyond the simple distribution of the mail.I know that this service is deficit.It would perhaps be less expensive to make a fax or e -mail service available to houses or villages.In the beginning I am in favor of the abolition of monopolies in the public sector, whether they are water, gas, electricity, telephone, antennas, wired nets and so on.However, liberalization, which has significantly benefited users as regards prices and quality of services, especially in the telephony sector, must stop where the service offer becomes insufficient or disappears, where companies that benefit from liberalization are not profitable.If you cannot oblige them to ensure a service that the state monopoly has guaranteed, in particular thanks to the obligation of a universal service, it is necessary to maintain the public service.I believe that we can afford to maintain a postal service, even if our P&T currently work as companies.It is clear that they have to make an effort to no longer be defined as "post snail", even if they cannot reach the speed of the e-mail.

We have a special responsibility with regard to the promotion of economic development in this region.The admission of the talks with Syria paved the way for the convening of the multilateral coordination group in Moscow at the end of this month.I will take part in this meeting and hope that we can finally push the negotiations forward again.The European Union plays an important role in peace process, this was underlined by all sides, Palestinians, Israelis, its Arab neighbors and the USA.Our role is also not limited to that of the donor.We have to be ready to act quickly to consolidate peace in this region.But we shouldn't fool ourselves either: a comprehensive peace solution in the Middle East has its price.The Commission is already concerned with the question of how the latest encouraging developments will affect the European Union.We will soon discuss this topic with the parliament and the Council in detail.However, I would like to remind the MPs that the European Union already supports the peace process financially to the process of peace.We are the largest donors in the Palestinians.We also granted Jordan, Lebanon, Syria and Egypt.With Israel, we have intensified the cooperation in several areas that are of particular interest to the country.The contribution of the community of more than EUR 600 million in the form of grants and loans that was made between 1994 and 1998 received effective support, and the reconstruction of the dilapidated infrastructure in the West Bank and in the Gaza Strip was significantly encouraged.The Member States of the European Union together provided a further EUR 860 million in this decisive phase.In this context, I welcome the important steps that the Palestinian Authority recently initiated to improve household transparency.President Arafat will meet with the Council of Ministers next week.This meeting will offer a good opportunity to talk about the need for courageous measures to improve Palestinian administration and to strengthen the rule of law.The Commission is actively involved in these efforts.The Commission also expanded its planned support for the regional cooperation projects between Israelis and Arabs.Last year we provided more than EUR 20 million for these projects.This package included other funds for citizens' initiatives and cross-border cooperation between Israelis and Arabs at non-regulation and expert level.The members are certainly aware that the European Union is the largest donor who supports the efforts to reconcile peoples in the Middle East.In the next phase of the peace process, there will be other potential areas for funding from the community.This includes supporting an agreement for the Golan heights, in which we can promote both security regulations as well as the mining clearance and the reconstruction of communities on the Golan heights.Economic development in Syria requires support so that the transition from a war economy to peacekeeping can succeed.The measures for reconstruction and renovation of the South Libanon, the only region in the Middle East, in which a military conflict still smolder, will also require considerable efforts.

Whoever threatens, in principle, the production of this factory by demanding the reimbursement of aid granted at the time does not only threaten this steelworks but also an employer of this region on which of course depend on small and medium -sized enterprises.It goes without saying that it cannot be the competition policy of the European Union.If we want competition, we must reach this association between the needs of the national economy and the requirements of companies.It is also the only chance to develop in the underdeveloped regions of economic circuits which lead to the social protection of citizens and to the strengthening of purchasing power.In addition, we must without hesitation consider more an economic policy oriented on demand rather than on the supply alone.Mr. President, since my election to the European Parliament in 1994, I have never read a report imbued with as many anti-Irish feelings and hints as the Jonckheer report we debate today.I would like to cite the report verbatim: "State aid per capita are the highest in Italy, Germany and Ireland, the latter country being clearly in the lead when adding national aid and aid of regional and social community".I believe that the rapporteur simply plays with the figures.I have difficulty understanding how he can introduce social and regional funds into this mathematical equation.I would like to remind him that the European Union approved the new guidelines for regional aid for the period after 2000, which was only a simple extension of the political objectives intended to complete the internal market within Europe.Regional disparities must be overcome if we want the internal market to be a success and prosperous.I salute the fact that a help of 40 % and that an additional aid of 15 % intended for SMEs for fixed income investments will be authorized in favor of companies set up in regions eligible for objective I in Europe, after the year 2000. I remind Mr. Jonckheer that Irish companies or foreign companies installed in Ireland must still cross two seas to reach the European market.No other Member State is disadvantaged at this point.Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues, the prohibition of agreements is the CUR itself of a functional legal order in Europe.The Commission considered that the practical implementation of the control of this ban was unsatisfactory: let's say that we approve.But opinions diverge as to the solution.Formally, the commission's proposal does not deviate from the prohibition of agreements but in the end, this proposal is a transition from the prohibition subject to authorization to the authorization subject to prohibition.We go from the principle of prohibition to the principle of abuse.In the company of other colleagues, I resolutely refuse a systemic change of this magnitude.I do not accept that a transposition problem can motivate in practice a modification of the legal order.We modify the law to be executable again: I find that it is unacceptable.
