effects, that is, that the aspect of the defense is neglected and, therefore, the possibility that accusation and defense can function effectively in such an important legal system.Through abstention in the commission we wanted to express these perplexities.Mr. President, I think it is necessary to make a reflection aloud on this issue at the headquarters of the European Parliament, in the Plenary and in the commissions, although it is evident that the debate cannot dispense with the world of culture, of legal culture and the environments in which institutional affairs are addressed.We were facing very serious episodes that in the past seemed to be a custom.Today something has changed, at least in systems, especially as far as control is concerned, but we are not yet satisfied, especially when in the competent venues you can speak even of a European prosecutor, crimes, fraud, embezzlement and revelation of secrets at European scale.I think we must protect the interests of the community and its image, as well as the relationship with taxpayers that are an indispensable and fundamental part of the life of the community.This is why it is fair to consider the problem of a protection of the interests of a general and universal nature, remembering better with justice within the scope of each of the states.

The debate between the convenience of prolonging Lomé's agreement with its quotas and its protectionism, or contrary to progressively liquidate the particular relations between the European Union and the ACP countries in the name of free change is a false debate between two ways of perpetuating the looting and impoverishment of those countries.I rebel against an innoble and inhuman organization that makes hundreds of millions of human beings be literally starving to enrich a minority.It would be enough with only one fraction of the huge wealth accumulated by the large groups so that these countries could get out of misery, but as long as we dared to blame the large capitalist groups, we will do nothing more than hide the real problems.Mr. President, I congratulate Mr. Corrie, co-chair of the ACP-EU Joint Assembly, who has had the task that is easy to prepare a report on the difficult issue of the ACP-EU Joint Assembly.In this intervention I will limit myself to expose only some points that I consider fundamental.I believe that the European Parliament must insistently ask that the Assembly be really parliamentary, urging ACP countries to send as representatives of national parliaments, to reinforce their own democratic fabric.My contribution to this debate, in the first place, will be to focus attention on globalization and the WTO, which for ACP countries represent a huge danger in their development.I consider it necessary a transition period for these countries, although, within the space of the new logic and the regionalization of aid, it is also necessary that they are supported not only with agriculture and fishing, but also that they resort to the valuation of mineral and subsoil resources, some of which are exploited with little economic benefit by these same countries.The third point refers to the effort that, through a peer working group within the Joint Assembly, the European Parliament must commit to do in order to achieve a stabilization of the Budgets of the ACP states, through a qualified selection of the points of the budgets, so that there is an economic development but above all social, and also through the control of the income policies and the fiscal policies that are in force in the ACP.We must support the peoples of these countries through the relationship with their rulers, which must be fully aware that the aids to development by the European Union are destined to the people and not to the eventual oligarchies, managers, in some of those states, of all internal and external resources.Finally, fourth point: the prevention of conflicts between ethnicities or between states must be our constant concern and, to some extent, these conflicts could be avoided or through a vigorous and authorized diplomatic offensive, or through the proposals that I have just presented.Mr. President, I make mine the positive assessment of the report that my companion Karin Junker expressed a moment and I will add that Mr. Corrie began his work as co-president of the ACP-EU Joint Assembly with an effective and impartial action that deserves all our recognition.My intervention will be limited to a specific fact that has occurred a few days ago, partly as a result of events referred to in the report we discussed here.

In politics, words can be incendiary, they can exalt the spirits or can be conciliatory.We discovered that Mr. Jörg Haider, as the architect of the word, has been a voice that defended racism and xenophobia.He is a man who has taken advantage of fear and has exploited vulnerability.There lies the importance of this debate - to record that when extremism is integrated into the mainstream, something deep is happening today in Europe.(Applause) I hurry to add that our struggle is not addressed to the Austrian people.We respect the rights of the Austrian people about their own democratic process.We defend the constitutional rights and prerogatives of the Austrian people, but here in the European Parliament we have the duty to remember our fundamental values ​​as stipulated in article 6 of the treaty - the values ​​of freedom, democracy and respect for human rights.All conscious members of this assembly believe that these values ​​are universal and indivisible regardless of race, class or creed.We must encourage and defend those rights, while we say to the people of Austria: our struggle is not against you.With regard to the initiative of the Portuguese presidency I would like to say that we support the spirit and political intention behind that initiative.It may not be an ideal initiative in terms of its structure, but we recognize, Mr. President in exercise, who is anchored in idealism, and for that reason we are inclined to support it.I share with President Prodi the preference of the community method and we must analyze article 6 and article 7 of the Treaty.Article 7 contemplates the possibility of suspension in the case of serious and persistent breaches of our fundamental values.We must find, as institutions, the way of measuring and giving meaning to this, so that it has reality and essence.Then, we can work together in the application of the community method to eradicate this cancer in our environment.I want to direct, Mrs. President, a few words to Mr. Schüssel.Mr. Schüssel is a man who has an honorable trajectory in European politics.Now it is proposed to get to the government riding on a political tiger.Mr. Schüssel, prepares to assume a very serious, personal, national and European responsibility.That responsibility, which now assumes, Mr. Schüssel, is to respect the letter and spirit of European treaties.Finally, Mrs. President, the present debate touches the heart of our democratic values ​​and institutions and brings us to memory that the price of freedom is the eternal vigilance.In this continent, especially, with the experience of hateful racism that we have suffered in the past and that such a high price has been charged, we have to insist that today's debate is not about the interference in the sovereign rights of a state.This is the stubborn insistence by the democratically chosen institution of this union that as Europeans we will not tolerate a return to the past.(Alive applause)

President, colleagues!I ask you to apologize for my delay, but today God is unfortunately still on the agenda.The Committee on Foreign Affairs, Human Rights, Common Security and Defense Policy recommends that you release the 35 million euros, and this recommendation is given because this money can really benefit the people concerned.What makes us critical is not so serious that we didn't want to help people there.But this does not mean that we forget the criticism.Of course, we would be much further in our procedure if the council administration had not forgotten to inform the European Parliament at an early stage and officially forward documents.This is the only way we could have done a really reasonable, in the matter of profound advice.I ask the administration to ensure that this can no longer happen in the future.Only because of the people concerned are we ready to refrain from drawing consequences.But we have to see that we introduce certain conditions here.One condition is that the money is given where it is applied sensibly, and not to those who may be able to use this money in order to pursue other purposes, that is, this money should really go into the responsibility of Mr. Kouchner and not into other areas.Second: Even if the Commission and the Council take a different position here because they see realistic problems, we think that the other donors also have to comply with their obligations that they have received.This is a mission that is under the jurisdiction of the United Nations, and it cannot be that the European Union alone fulfills its obligations!The other donor countries must also meet their obligations during this period in the interest of the people concerned.This means that in the future we generally have to deal with this question much more intensively, not only with this specific project, but with the entire development in Southeast Europe and the help that is given there.This in turn is an example of the fact that the European Union is ready to help the money, but that there is an inconsistency of political leadership.We have so many coordinators who are responsible for so many employers that we will soon have a coordinator for the coordinators.Perhaps it would be better if the responsible bodies of the European Union and the other institutions - from the OSCE to the United Nations - were put together in order to introduce a uniform, coordinated procedure and to check how people can really be helped there.I know that the Commission is intensively considered to achieve this, but if the European Union does the most, it should also have the management there and then bring it in a uniform way so that people can really be helped.There is no point in that we have a competition between the different international institutions and associations than that the strength is really tackled to help people on site!When I see that the encoder conference for the stability pact is being moved further and now, now to the end of March that nobody knows which projects are really behind it if you cannot see in how really being implemented and only new press conferences are given, then this does not seem to be the way we can produce peace and reconciliation of people in this area!

In a common fishing policy, the requirements of species protection and inventory management must be optimally reconciled with those of the economy and the market.For this purpose, extensive, comparable and uniform data, of which we - if they are properly recorded and evaluated - serve more general information about the fishing sector in the Union.However, we also hope that the peculiarities, the differences, the diverse fishing conditions and traditions are better recognized and emphasized and not - as happened in many ways - due to a misunderstood harmonization concept for fishing policy, restricted, restricted or even eliminated.As an example, I would like to lead the Mediterranean and in particular the fishing in Italy.After the GFP for the Mediterranean has been limited to prescriptions for marketing and operating aid for years, regulation 1626 and the measures included in it are finally launched to maintain and protect the fish stocks in order to ensure permanent use of inventory.This is a objective that can be agreed, but when implementing the biological peculiarities of the fish species of the Mediterranean were sometimes not observed.A later regulation, namely the - by no means passed in 1999 - Regulation No. 1448 left some exceptions especially for so -called "certain Mediterranean fishing".However, this exemption only applies until May 31 of this year, and the Commission must submit a proposal by then.We hope that this fishing system, which is of vital importance for the economy of extensive coastal areas and, according to the scientific data that has been recorded so far, has a certain sustainability under the aspect of biological tolerance.Thank you very much, Mr. Fischler.The pronunciation is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow at 11:00 a.m.The report (A5-0036/2000) from Mr. Hudghton follows on behalf of the Council for a guideline for a directive 93/53/EEC to determine minimum measures by the community for combating certain fish epidemics.The infectious anemia of salmon (ISA) is an infectious viral disease that was first registered in Norway in 1984, later in Canada (1986) and finally in May 1998 in Scotland and thus for the first time on the territory of the European Union.Although the virus has also been found in other species, the disease itself has so far limited itself to salmon.The virus cannot survive at a temperature of over 25ºC, and the scientists therefore agree that it is not a danger to human health.It simply cannot survive in warm -blooded creatures.The Scottish salmon breeding industry is the largest of its kind in the EU, and its locations are in the extreme outskirts in areas.It offers about 6,500 people work and generates around 800 million euros annually.It is therefore obvious that this problem for Scotland is of particular scope, but it is of the utmost importance for all parts of Europe that this disease is contained and exhausted if possible.According to the currently applicable guideline, vaccination is prohibited, instead all fish of an affected farm must be killed regardless of whether they are infected or not.

With the ratification of the Amsterdam contract, all Member States have expressed that they want to give the same priority against the combating of fraud against the financial interests of the European Union as to combat fraud at their own burdens, but the reality is that the first four member states have only ratified the agreement decided in 1995.The Commission fully agrees with the rapporteur that this situation is not acceptable.A legal act, a guideline in which the fraud, such as money laundering or bribery, is defined uniformly and its law enforcement is bindingly laid down as a goal, can continue to bring an important step further here, and I will therefore propose to the Commission to check this step very quickly.The European Office for Combating Olaf is one of the most important instruments with which the Commission fulfills its obligation to combat fraud.The Commission therefore did not accept that the two European banks ECB and EIB have denied Olaf's right to investigations in these two institutions with reference to their independent position.The Commission therefore decided to collect these two banks in its last session, and I hope that the parliament will approve of this step.The second recommendation of the present report concerns the review of Olaf's examination measures in the various European institutions to their legality.The surveillance committee for Olaf, which was also established with the establishment of Olaf, has the task of ensuring independence from Olaf, but cannot carry out the activity of internal investigative acts in the report.In it I completely agree with the surveillance committee and the rapporteur.This means that there is a gap that must be filled out and I will check the path proposed in the report in terms of further development.However, I can ask for one thing: I think it must be prevented that the debate about an expansion of the legal basis for Olaf leads to the misunderstanding that Olaf does not have enough authority now.No, it must not lead to an undermining of Olaf's authority, and I also think that this is not in the interests of the rapporteur.In this respect, I ask you to fully support Olaf's work in the current form.Thank you very much, Ms. Schreyer.The vote will take place tomorrow at 12 p.m.Votes (the parliament accepts the Commission's proposal.) Heaton-Harris (PPE-DE).(En) Mr. President, a remark on the application of the rules of procedure.I ask for an explanation of Article 133 paragraph 2 and 138 paragraph 4 of the rules of procedure.Both articles concern the vote.Isn't it the case that, with the exception of votes, is initially coordinated by a hand signal and should only be reached for the electronic voting system in case of doubt?Yes, Value Mr colleague, I had a hand signal voted because no faction had asked for a name.As you know, a name or electronic review is only intended if the MPs require this.In the present case, I can assure you that an overwhelming majority voted for the guideline that we have just voted.Mr President, I did not mean this special coordination, but votes in general.

Common resolution on Austria Mrs. President, the Europa of the Nations Group has not signed the common resolution of the PPE/De-Pse on the political situation in Austria following the formation in this country of a coalition government between the conservatives and liberalnationals of Jörg Haider.In fact, this PPE/DE-PSE resolution applauds the initiative promoted by fourteen Member States to exert a pressure on Austria through the organization of a sort of diplomatic boycott.What strikes us most is that this common intervention boasts the principles of the Treaty as if it were written somewhere that, by now, the free and democratic expression of a people can be canceled by the will of the heads of governance of neighboring countries who, in this case, have looked at each other from consulting their respective peoples.Regardless of the verbal excesses of Jörg Haider - which in fact condemn - the Austrians made a democratic choice and we must respect it.It seems clear to us that the left of the European Parliament, in contact with the Austrian left, however defeated in the elections, has designed an exquisitely political maneuver by referring to the memory of a left era, fortunately concluded.Despite the assimilation of Haider in Hitler lacking in credibility, it has partially achieved its purpose by making some deputies of the ppe-de falter.Beyond this political maneuver, what the majority of the European Parliament fears more than everything is that the questioning in Austria of a right-left cohabitation, which has corrupted its political life, soon extends to the European co-management system, which caused equally harmful consequences.To avoid this questioning this majority is willing to everything, even canceling the results of free elections, to establish a Police of thought, to establish a new form of totalitarianism.Mrs. President, on behalf of the deputies of the national front, of the Vlaams Blok and the Italian social movement, I ask this question: who pulls the ranks of the unprecedented interference in the Austrian affairs in which the European Union has taken part, in violation of international law, treaties and morale?Is hysteria spontaneously?Is it the fruit of pure stupidity or, more likely, of a precise strategy, the same everywhere in the world?Who imposes their will to the European nations, claiming to prevent them from deciding their destiny?Any hidden alliance?The Washington government?The Israeli one?Or their socialist spokespersons who, in this classroom, have the brazenness of imposing their values?So what are the values ​​of these socialists, who built their electoral fortune in the last century by deluding the disinherited with the idea of ​​greater social justice, and which today are nothing more than the party of protected officials, trade unionists and state capitalism?What are the values ​​of the Belgian Socialist Party that staggers between pedophilia and corruption scandals, passing through those of Vandam, such as the Agusta scandal?What are the values ​​of the French Socialist Party that blackmailed all the municipalities in which the majority in Urba, Sages, Graco was held?

I have also presented, on behalf of the EDD group, a resolution project in this regard.Mr. President, in recent years the oil tankers have caused repeated catastrophes worldwide without adopted appreciable or effective measures to avoid them.This time the situation is particularly serious, not ultimately because it affects a great European state, a fact that can be repeated at any time.We urgently need a directive that limits these risks.The 15 rules we have are not enough.These offer at least - without pretending to be exhaustive - three guarantees: no oil tanks or cargo ship in conditions for the drain can already scale in any port of the European Union;All parties that intervene, including the consignee of the transport, must respond for the damage caused and must subscribe sufficient insurance policies.Only in this way will it be possible to ensure that the injured can enforce their right to compensation for the damages suffered.However, we must be clear that the long -term objective must be much broader.In other words, we have to evaluate the true costs of our entire energy supply system.Mr. President, let me begin by giving thanks to the palace commissioner for his clear, adequate and also very firm response.Thanks a lot.This also means that I have a lot of respect for the communication of the meeting he sent on January 10, but also for the measures he has announced today.The Erika catastrophe demonstrates that when adjusted regulations are missing in traffic and transport at European and international level, then nature and the environment are evil.The damage inflicted, also in environmental matters, cannot be quantified in money.Hence, we now maintain this joint debate with the environmental transport and protection colleagues.On Christmas holidays, when the Dutch media were paying attention to the Erika catastrophe, I looked on the Internet to find out what was there to take action, especially after Prime Minister Jospin had said that Europe should do more.What I deduced from all that is that there is actually enough regulation, but the problem is that it is not controlled.Let me mention some issues here, which have also been pointed out by the curator.First, the "Port-State Control", 25% of the ships that must be controlled.Not only do I think that 25% must be maintained but that it is necessary to ensure that it is more controlled, that is, that 25% are increased.In addition, when a ship is no longer allowed to navigate, not only must we control the facts but there must be a legal system that establishes: it is recommended that you no longer sail or its navigation is no longer allowed.But this does not exist.President, regarding this issue I would like an action to be undertaken.As an end point, in regard to the technical requirements for ships, my colleagues also just indicated that since 1999 in the United States, oil tankers must have double helmet.

Is this the message we want to transmit?In addition, one particular point holds me to CUR: Member States must be able, when they wish, decide to set up transnational water transfers.This type of project responds to the principle of regional cohesion and solidarity that we have always defended.In this spirit, it should largely benefit from the support of the European Union, within the framework of the promotion of the Transeuropée networks and the regional policy (through structural funds).I would like to recall that our assembly adopted, two years ago, an initiative report on the technical feasibility of the Transseuropéen hydraulic networks and I would appreciate that the European Commission can soon inform the European Parliament as a result it has given to this report..(Es) We attended the transformation of a report which was first concerned with the quality of water in Europe into a trade war instrument.We all agree to say that water quality is an objective of primary importance, especially because of the opposing consequences that the development of the accelerated industrial growth model has on nature.It is obvious that the logic of private profit specific to this model has been harmful, which is why the principle of polluter pays is adequate to deal with these consequences.But beyond these principles, water must be considered as a common good that cannot be subject to market rules.Surprisingly, I imagine that with the best intentions, we transformed this ecological objective into an instrument of commercial war by making consumers support, especially in the agricultural sector, the price of installations and procedures so that water is of good quality.In fact, water becomes a commodity more subject to market laws.The neoliberal model is thus applied to water.When we do not differentiate the countries and regions where water is abundant, and does not pose any problem, regions where drought and low rainfall make it a rare good, limiting their possibilities of minimum economic and social development, we already alter the ecological principle to make it a devastating weapon.In the same vein, it is somewhat ironic to complicate the possibility of sharing this property, which for certain areas is rare, while those who live in regions where water abounds give water restriction advice to those who live in regions affected by drought.It is this lack of sensitivity and solidarity, which motivated my vote, as a deputy from one of the Mediterranean agricultural regions dry but with prospects like the Murcia region.On behalf of the Labor Party in the European Parliament, I would like to indicate that, although we have supported most of the Lienemann report, we have certain reservations.The date set in the report - 2020 - is not realistic and impossible to respect, but the date set by the Council - 2034 - is too distant.We therefore believe that conciliation will set a more realistic date.

Mr. President, Mrs. Commissioner, the proposal for the directive relating to out of use vehicles of which we deal with today curtains on the one hand to guarantee a high level of protection of the environment within the Union, but also to preserve the proper functioning of the internal market in this sector.Two words to say that, of course, historical and era vehicles must be excluded from the field of application of this directive.Even cars, and I believe that we will all agree on this point, they are part of our cultural heritage.Having said that, one of the rocks concerns article 12, i.e. the date of application of the directive.The solution proposed by Parliament, i.e. 18 months from the entry into force of the directive itself, for vehicles entered on the market for the first time, is not very realistic.The European car park has various tens of millions of cars that will have to be withdrawn although they have not been designed at all to be recycled.The common position was more practicable since it provided for the 2006 date for vehicles already in circulation.This would also allow to leave companies the time to set up funds to cope with additional expenses.Like my group, I will support in this regard the common position that in my opinion presents a balanced compromise between the constraints of companies and the indispensable progress in terms of protection of the environment.Mr. President, honorable colleagues, today the European Parliament must adopt an important decision, that is, if he intends to commit himself in favor of a protection of the environment and the consumer who opens a new way for the future or if he is willing to act as a typed to the German car industry, as they let the amendments proposed by the honorable Florenz, Lange and other colleagues suppose.The credibility of Parliament is at stake as a pioneer in the field of environmental protection.It would be extremely demeaning if the Parliament made more than a step back compared to the positions supported by the governments of the 14 Member States and by the Commission regarding the responsibility of the producers and protection of the environment.The intent pursued by the honorable Florenz and Lange is evident: destroy the directive!By proposing to restart responsibility, they aim to deprive the "polluting" principle of any content and to suffocate the innovations related to the products in the bud.By frapponing a whole series of obstacles, they aim exclusively to prevent a policy of the flows of materials and, by imposing the authorizations of the different models, want to postpone the application of the directives of at least 12 years, which is completely unacceptable.Therefore launch an appeal, addressing me in particular to the German deputies: do not allow that today such a serious political damage will be fulfilled!On the occasion of the discussion on the directive on out of use vehicles, the green-red government driving the Federal Republic has certainly not been honored.We do not continue with this trend!The complaints about the disadvantages at the level of competition are ridiculous, if it is actually a matter of jeopardizing only the German car industry!Behave by representatives of the people and do not be degraded to representatives of Volkswagen!Vote in favor of the protection of the environment and consumers, as well as innovation in the automotive and recycling industry!Mr President, this directive has been in question since 1997 and it is time to reach an agreement.By sharing the positions of the Honorable colleague Sjöstedt and the Green Representative, honorable De Roo, I will not use both minutes at my disposal, but I will focus only on two issues.

Mr. President, dear colleagues, I don't need to remember what the rapporteur said before me and my colleague Coelho.All this is indeed correct and relevant.The euro can easily be falsified.We are currently in a dangerous transition phase during which an unprecedented phenomenon arises on the criminal level, namely that a currency not yet used, not yet put into circulation, but which only acts as a scriptural currency, can nevertheless already be the object of falsification, and this while the offense of false coinage is in this specific case listed by no sanction, of the fact thatPrecisely not yet in circulation.It is therefore a very complex problem.Clearly, if we do not act quickly - I join the opinion of my colleague Cederschiöld on this point -, false euros can now be produced and their circulation cannot be the subject of any criminal sanction.I allow myself to point out by passing that it could be an attractive perspective for some.What is the European Union doing to deal with this possibility?A series of relevant things that our colleague Cederschiöld detailed us.Compared precisely to what has been described, the Parliament should be less lingering on the content of the framework decision and on the report written by Ms. Cederschiöld than on the currently applied procedures.Indeed, the way in which the European Parliament was consulted by the Council, which is by far the least democratic institution in Europe, insults the concept of democracy.We have received for consultation a text that the Council itself tinkered for a very long period, a text which also constitutes only a partial success - but I arrived there immediately.The European Parliament must now take a position, within three months, on this complex, difficult text and, in certain places, contradictory proposed by the Council.It is only thanks to the considerable investment of our colleague Cederschiöld and thanks to the fact that parliament has resigned itself not to make use of its democratic law, which allows it to apply its consultation procedures by having a sufficient period and all the texts translated into each language, that we can now give our opinion within the reduced time desired by the Council and to achieve this fact thatFor a subject as important as that of the protection against false coinage and the criminal harmonization that it requires, we can really not work at the hellish rhythm that advice imposes on us.This is why I want to say very clearly on behalf of my group that we discussed at length with our colleague Cederschiöld to find out if it was reasonable to work under these conditions.We came to the conclusion that it was not but that given the importance of the subject, we agree to accept such a procedure.The proposed framework decision constitutes an undoubted advance.Only the legal certainty desired by the Council - Ms. Cederschiöld has already alluded to it - will not be completely reached completely because, as regards the required minimum standards, the minimum criminal standard and, above all, the application of the same criminal standards in each Member State - even those in which the Euro has not yet been introduced, but in which it could theoretically be falsified -were not filled.

I can only say that these are the hard nuts that you have to cook once and for all!Mr. President, first, I want to sincerely congratulate my colleague, Mr. Van Hulten.It is nice to be able to say that it belongs to our delegation and I can be a bit proud of him, I think.In any case, congratulations on your report.Mr. President, the resignation of the Commission has caused a sense of fear of many officials of the hierarchical and bureaucratic scale.I find all the allegation about making a change towards a culture of responsibility.In the Development Commission I have been able to see very closely how thousands of projects were paralyzed;How, sometimes, up to 80 percent of the money did not be invested, sometimes creating a huge bag of money.And this, not because it is not totally necessary, not because there are no good proposals, but because the whole system stuck by itself.Lack of responsibility, too ex before, very little ex post and hence a culture based on the realization of very few truly effective investments.Spend money effectively and organize all work around this;It would be fantastic to give a signal in that direction with this report.I look forward to that the contribution we will make here, if the first draft report of the Commission becomes an official report on March 1, allows us to see real changes.Without a doubt, it will be a service, Mr. President, provided to the European public and, thanks to the results that we show, we will reconquer and recover something we have obviously lost in recent years.This is the best support we can give to European democracy.If we leave the culture of the 50s and go to the next century, we will live here a pleasant experience.Mr. President, first of all my congratulations to Michiel Van Hulten for his first report.It was a difficult steady, but in the Netherlands we have a nice saying.One learns to swim before if he throws immediately where he covers.Honor, I think that after this test can be classified for the Olympics.There are two points that, in my opinion, deserve special attention from ELDR.First, the individual responsibility of the commissioners.This must be regulated during the CIG.We prefer, however, that this important issue is not completely in the hands of the Council and, therefore, we have submitted an amendment in which we ask that an inter-institutional agreement between the Commission and the Parliament be adopted, in order to ensure a kind of Fall Back-positive and not leave our luck totally in the hands of the Council.The second point, and my colleague, Mr. Mulder, has already said it, is that the Eldr considers that the European Parliament must be investigated by independent experts.This will contribute a lot to recover, in particular, the confidence of European citizens in this institution.We cannot credibility with this renovated commission as long as we do not do an examination of consciousness and the European Parliament also puts their affairs in order.

You will find the content of this framework in the priorities of partnerships in membership, which the Commission and the Council have defined last year and which are now implemented in the corresponding planning and management of projects.Unlike this criticism, I would say that one can deplore a lack of coherence in certain areas of European policy but that, in this case, I would like to claim the fact that the Commission and the Council have developed a very clear, transparent and coherent policy.Mr. Chairman, Mr. Chairman of the Council, after the Commissioner showed us in an extremely coherent way that the president of the council of the time and his federal minister for European affairs were responsible for the lack of coherence, you might perhaps help the commissioner and ourselves to make this decision.This would help us a lot that you are responding positively to my questions about financial prospects until 2004 and on section 7 or that, at least you declared - as the Commissioner will try to achieve it with the Commission - that the Portuguese Presidency intends to compensate for the lack of consistency of the time by such a commitment.Mr. President, I think that the question asked by my friend Mr. Elmar Brok will be examined by the Council.I think that the criticism addressed to the previous presidency is not relevant.I believe that what was done by the previous presidency in the definition of financial perspectives was an excellent job, regardless of the people who were involved in this work.In any case, the question he poses is important and we will not stop, at the level of the Council, to support the proposals that the Commission will present in this direction.Mr. Chairman of the Council, I thought I understand that our colleague Bro mentioned a still previous presidency.Mr. President, Commissioner Verheugen did not answer my question, however very concrete about the financial instrument Meda.I ask him to answer it, because his answer will determine our voting behavior on various amendments.Commission.(De) dear Mr. Poos, please apologize.There was a blur, at the precise moment when you asked your question.So, with regard to Meda, Malta and Cyprus can participate in the supraregional programs, but not national, because their income is too high.Thank you very much, Mr. Commissioner Verheugen!The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Thursday.Question time (Advice) Question nº 1 of (H-0022/00): Subject: Control of oil access to community waters as following the sinking of the oil tanker Erika off the French coast, which caused a dark tide, what measures does the Council intend to adopt to control access to the community waters of oil and not compliant and not respecting the community standards?Mr. President, Ladies and Gentlemen, on January 24, the Council looked at the consequences of the sinking of the oil tanker Erika which occurred in December.

The European Commission's sixth report offers very valuable conclusions.I would like to summarize two of them briefly, the rapporteur has already taken up, a positive and a negative.The first refers to the fact that significant progress in the territorial and social cohesion has been achieved throughout the Union area and that the community funds represent an important, if not decisive factor in reducing regional inequalities.The negative is that these great efforts in the alignment of GDP and the productivity of European regions showed a greater effect than when aligning their employment levels.It is therefore necessary to bind the structural financing more to the creation of jobs.That, Mr. Commissioner, is the first commandment for the coming period.So, Mr. President, I ask my venerated colleagues for the approval of this report and, like other colleagues in front of me, I ask the Commission to take into account the conclusions from its sixth periodic report with regard to the planning of the period 2000-2006.President!Mr. Commissioner!Dear colleagues!First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the good work and the factual consideration of the proposed changes received during the treatment in the committee.The sixth periodical report is a good basis for evaluating the enforcement of regional policy goals in the Union and shows that, despite all efforts, growth only takes place unevenly.The regions of Central Europe still have a particularly fast growth, which takes place at a speed in the strong economic centers, which is above the pan -European average, while many southern European and northern regions progress considerably more slowly.Now a profound analysis on the question of why regional policy does not have the desired success in all areas.Is it due to the bureaucracy or have the differences between the regions, the large distances, very cold or hot climate, thin settlement and barren conditions have not been sufficiently taken into account?How does the Union succeed in countering the challenges of global development in such a way that the weaker -developed regions can keep up?It is also important to examine the date, the European Community's regional policy has not been able to significantly express the existing differences in per capita performance.

This is why we had expressed our keen satisfaction with regard to decisions made on this subject during the Helsinki summit in December.An far too ambitious program would currently risk delaying the enlargement process.This is not what we want and that is why we voted against the report.However, we totally agree with our colleagues to declare that the intergovernmental conference must be transparent so that citizens can realize the evolution of our work..(SV) We are happy that a limited agenda has been set for the intergovernmental conference at the Helsinki summit.Possible future Member States must also participate in the formation of the future EU and have an influence on it.The election of the 1999 European Parliament has shown very clearly that citizens do not follow reasoning on an ever more federalist EU in the Spirit of Brussels..With the opening of the next CIG, the European Union process is again topical.Once again, the debate will be monopolized by the heads of state and government.That is to say that fifteen people will discuss and decide to camera the fate of more than 350 million individuals.We understand, therefore, the disinterest of the peoples in the face of a European construction which is done behind their backs and far from their concerns.Indeed, it is enough to look at the agenda of the CIG: institutions, enlargement and autonomous defense.In reality, it is a question of strengthening executive power, developing annexions to liberalism of the countries of the East and of reviving the militarization of Europe by increasing in particular military budgets.Social Europe, used as a storage by the EU, has disappeared out of the agenda.All this only legitimizes the development, on the scale of Europe, of resistance movements anxious to impose a social charter which would harmonize from above the main demands of workers.This is why I vote against the report.I voted for the resolution which gives a favorable opinion to the summons of the CIG because it enshrines the philosophy of the Portuguese presidency, which benefits from the support of a large majority of the Parliament, the opening of the agenda of the CIG, beyond the points strictly linked to the rebalancing of power between Member States, large and small, as originally described in the summons of the Council of Helsinki.Unfortunately, in the subjects discussed in the resolutions relating to the matters of the Treaty on the European Union which will be subject to revision, nothing indicates, to date, the need to review its article 7, which deals with the suspension of a State in the event of a serious and persistent violation of the "founding" principles of the Union, set out in article 6. As we note with the current crisis with Austria,defend.The legal mechanisms provided for by the treaties are nevertheless weak, of difficult political and legal application, they do not organize the powers of institutions and they do not guarantee jurisdictional treatment to a process of the utmost importance, namely, the conviction of a Member State to a suspension.

Honor, regarding the possibility that the Presidency has in the sense of supporting actions of non -governmental organizations, very particularly in the specific case of the struggle aimed at solving the problems of homeless people, I want to tell him that such initiatives are worthy of approval and on our part there is the best disposition to consider the possibility of supporting them.We have collaborated with Portuguese non -governmental organizations and with some initiatives that those same non -governmental organizations presented in the framework of action of the Portuguese presidency and that we link with the set of concerns underlying our own program.We have no concrete initiative in that regard, but we do not rule out the hypothesis that an initiative of non -governmental organizations that are proposed to that regard is examined during our presidency: that - it is necessary to say it - in the scope of the capacity of action of the Council.But we must understand that everything that may affect the right of initiative of the Commission must obviously be done through the commission itself.Mr. President in the exercise of the Council, he has told us a lot about the future: what will the commission do, what will the presidency be in Lisbon, etc.And he has informed us of something that has scared me, Mr. President in the exercise of the Council.You have said that in Lisbon they will discuss more dynamic and more competitive development.I have begun to be afraid, Mr. President in the exercise of the Council, because there comes social exclusion, at least in part.I do not see how you will be able to answer, if you have opinions of this type.What I have asked and ask again is the following: What are the opinions of the Portuguese presidency in relation to issues such as those that, for example, have presented the networks to fight poverty and against exclusion, with the division of labor and social security, with the application of fiscal policy, especially of speculative capital, with the policy of income redistribution?I would like an answer in relation to this, if the Portuguese presidency has it in mind, and if you intend to do something.Your honor must understand that the effective capacity of an presidency in the sense of investing general or economic trends in its six months of exercise is effectively limited.I think it is perfectly clear that our capacity is also closely related to the logic of intervention, through its right of initiative, of the commission itself.I have talked about the Extraordinary European Council and the initiative that Portugal adopted to celebrate it and I have referred to the future because there are two complementary ways of seeing this issue of social exclusion: one of them is the set of immediate measures that must be adopted to face its specific effects;The second is the creation of competitiveness conditions at the international level that allow us to improve the economic fabric itself within the European Union with positive collateral effects on the problems of social exclusion.And, therefore, the Portuguese presidency has no miraculous keys to answer in six months the issues that always last.It has availability to act before the commission proposals in these spheres in everything that is community competence.It naturally has the possibility and interest of encouraging the entire set of measures that may occur, in particular by non -governmental organizations, but also in a traditional intergovernmental articulation in those spheres.

This is the program for the next five years relating to the internal security, freedom, citizens' rights and judicial cooperation sector.This document, in its brevity, is only a farce!A farce precisely because we know and appreciate the work of Commissioner Vitore and what is presented on paper is in evident contrast with reality.A document of this type is not the base for a scoreboard at all.He was welcomed and praised as a great conquest, but personally I remain convinced of the need for a scoreboard.Parliament wants to seriously examine the foundations of a program in which future developments come in this political sector.We ask for minimal rules relating to asylum procedures, in order to promptly help refugees but also to clarify towards those who are not.We want tools that allow to prevent abuses.We want a community policy for immigration to be started which obviously also takes into account the ability to integrate the Member States;It is also necessary to enhance the operating functions of Europol, for example, by adopting very concrete measures of fighting against organized crime in this area.We are dealing with these tasks with seriousness and fervor and we ask that the Commission also does the same even when it comes to simply submit a document!Lady president, I also applaud the Commission's initiative to present us with a document on its strategic objectives for the next five years with the hope, however, that it has the intention to correct, with subsequent documents, the too many general information and the nebulosity of the text submitted today to our exam.Having said that, lady president, here I am still shouting in the desert for the absence of fishing policy.It is truly surprising that in the strategic objectives for the next few years, the Commission does not enter the process of reviewing one of its common policies in view of the reform which will have to be developed in 2002. This overhaul process is undoubtedly the most important event among those that will affect the fishing sector for many years to come.However, it seems that this is not the opinion of the Commission, which was however commissioned to submit to the Council and Parliament, by 2001, the report on the functioning of the policy for common fishing in the last decade that will serve as a basis for the Council to make the appropriate decisions aimed at modifying it.In reality, the revision process has already started for many institutions, such as for example for the European Parliament which already in 1998 has developed and approved a report in which all the problems and gaps mentioned by the common policy for fishing were still indicated.Several times we asked for a minimum revision calendar without getting an answer.A period of less than two years is not so much, taking into account that, we must not forget it, fishing policy is experiencing an abnormal situation as regards the rules of the internal market and that these anomalies should be resolved within the reform process.

Mrs. President, distinguished ladies and lords deputies, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank Mr. ProCacci for the report he has prepared.But I would like to thank the commissions that have collaborated and the Parliament for the broad support they have given to the Leader+initiative.This initiative aims to give rural space new impulses to develop and rehearse new and original approaches, approaches that should later be included as models in general programs.I also celebrate that Parliament essentially supports the conception of the commission that the Leader+ program is applied in all rural regions, that higher priorities must be introduced and that, above all, it is necessary to promote active cooperation and interconnection of rural areas.In this regard I find that Parliament shares the opinion of the commission that priority must be granted to the execution of Leader+ in the form of global subsidies.To answer some concrete questions that have been raised here I can also confirm that we want to have in the Leader+ a participation and partner as possible.The different groups, whether environmental organizations or groups whose objective is employment, have the possibility of collaborating in the elaboration of the commission directives.And they are not less, but more, the resources that are made available to this period.I would also like to remember that it is not something new that we constitute an observatory.There has also been an observatory in Leader I and Leader II.This office has exclusively the objective of keeping the interconnection of the specific groups of the Leader.The financing of this observatory should not exceed 2% of the Leader resources.As regards the possibility of projects that have the training and training as content, I must say that this is precisely a point that we have now integrated into the new rural development policy, so that from our point of view it is not necessary to do this in the framework of the Leader.Now step to the content of the report.In point 14 the Parliament urges the commission to present without delay a report about the evaluation of the Leader II.I would like to indicate only that at the present time this does not make much sense because, as in the past - in concrete, until the end of 2002 - funds can be withdrawn according to Leader II.For this reason, we are of the opinion that it makes more sense to carry out this evaluation once the program concludes.Obviously, we will do it and we will send them a report in this regard.In point 18 the Parliament proposes that a compendium of examples of successful initiatives be elaborated.For this purpose I cannot help but say that it exists.It has already been prepared by the commission and I can make it available to each member of this assembly that is interested in it.In point 21 insists the parliament that we must approve the guidelines related to the Leader+ so that the programs can begin.

We find it, as always, faithful to the fundamental values, to those principles that have always guided its action.He also reminded us of his 1994 speech, he himself called provocative;In this regard, it must be said that utopias can sometimes be productive and we have been able to evaluate the path together together.You also appropriately highlighted the fundamental role of civil society, not only in relation to the candidate countries but also within each country of the European Union, to restore confidence to citizens and credibility to social solidarity, which we need so much.Finally, synthesizing the concept that has struck me the most of her speech, she wanted to explain to us that, beyond the economic aspects, the construction of Europe must first be a work of the spirit.We sincerely hope to continue this work with her.Thanks Mr. President.(The solemn session ends at 12.40) Joint assembly ACP-EU The agenda bears the discussion on the annual report A5-0032/2000, presented by the honorable Corrie on behalf of the Commission for development and cooperation, on the results of the works of the ACP-EU shareholders' meeting in 1999.I hope that the number of deputies present in the classroom is not an indication of little interest in the activities in favor of development in overseas countries.However, it is a current practice that the report on the works of the ACP-EU Joint Assembly is presented to the deputies of the European Parliament and I have the welcome task of doing it tonight.Once again I can report two highly important sessions that have taken one in Strasbourg and the other in Nassau.In many respects it was the end of an old era and the beginning of a new one.The ACP-EU equity assembly is a unique organization of its kind on the world political scene.In what other location 86 nations meet to discuss issues of common interest?The Strasbourg session was the last chaired by Lord Plumb.To pay homage to the exceptional work he did in a difficult period, the office of the Jeal's Joint Assembly has elected him honorary president, and now that he has come to the end of his career we want to give him our best wishes for the years that will follow.The two sessions were dominated by the negotiations for the renewal of the Lomé Convention: I look forward to the new agreement and that all the countries concerned will be signed as soon as possible.I remember that on the occasion of the last intermediate revision, when I was a speaker, the then commissioner Marín said that there would be no one another.Well, he was wrong and I would like to pay homage to Philip Lowe and his team who worked with such success behind the scenes to conclude a new agreement in very difficult circumstances.I was also very pleased to listen to the declaration of this morning of Commissioner Nielson, who worked tirelessly to ensure the success of the negotiations.I pay homage to him in particular for the success achieved, but also to the Now that you, Mr. Prodi, and your predecessors have deprived citizens of their right to self -determination, the quality of the work carried out in Brussels must improve significantly and that these works take place in full transparency so that citizens have at least the impression of being heard.I would just like to make a remark about what M. Dell'alba said about the dream of the founding fathers: so read the Memoirs of Jean Monnet.His dream was to create what he called a small practical secretariat.It is certainly not this small secretariat that Mr. Prodi is now president.The president, this morning, this morning, the President of the Commission, Mr. Prodi, explained the ambitious objectives of the European Union for the next five years, of the laudable objectives, in fact, to ensure a strong and effective European presence in the world: to ensure the success of the enlargement, to take up the challenge of selling electronic Europe, to introduce better principles of governance.We design that Europeans, especially the new generation, need to be given a broad view of the situation that Europe will occupy in the years to come.But, how can we succeed when the available resources are limited and when the credibility of our institutions is started?We must match this project to reality.On this point, there are three elements that I would like to exhibit.First of all, we need a flourishing European economy.We must ensure that unemployment rates continue to drop everywhere in Europe, consolidate the tendency to privatization and deregulation, encourage the introduction of information and knowledge technology of the Internet, show that electronic Europe is a favorable initiative.However, we must avoid falling back into the crossing of the regulation at the old fashion, which stifles the initiatives and the spirit of individual enterprises.We must not fear globalization, but we must make sure that we understand its political impact within the Society of Networks.Without a flourishing European economy, we will not be able to meet the challenges that await us, and more particularly the challenge of enlargement.Then, we must take care to legislate only if necessary - in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity.Do less, but better - a central point of the last commission - must also become the objective of this Commission.We will examine this point in detail when we pass the annual legislation proposals to annual programs.Mr. Bonde rightly said that there is this image of doing less but better and then, suddenly, we note that the annual program for the year 2000 has 500 proposals and recommendations, which seems to indicate a completely different direction.We must establish priorities and ensure that money is used wisely in each of these programs.Finally, we must make sure that the European Commission will be reformed adequately, true.Yes, the commission - guardian of the treaties - is supposed to be an independent body, but it must also account for European citizens through our parliament.The problem of information, to which M. Bonde has just referred, is treated as if it was a simple possibility, the commission giving the appearance of restricting the information to which, as citizens and as parliamentarians, we are entitled under the treaties.

proportions and the group of liberals, democrats and reformers is worried by a possible spelling of the competition policy, you want on the front of the examination of the mergers, you want from the point of view of surveillance on restrictive practices.The delegation of powers to the national authorities is a excellent thing, but we want to underline an assumption done by the honorable von Wogau heard in this discussion, and in particular with his colleague Jonckheer in criticizing the excess of data aggregation and in underlining the need for transparency and a socio -economic budget of aid.I also share the criticism relating to the insufficient attention dedicated to the development of article 82, especially when witnessing abuse of dominant position in a context of market concentrations.As a deputy of the Basque Country, I want to manifest full support for the measures for the application of the necessary market competition.If I say this is to dispel any doubt made by the criticisms that we have addressed to the Commission in general, and to Commissioner Monti in particular, to have opened a procedure against the incentives provided to Basque companies, considering them state aids.Our dissent is due to the fact that the Commission still shows not to understand the nature of the general system and co -responsibility of our system, by virtue of which the Basque tax provisions have the same nature, the same foundation and the same purposes of the provisions of the States of the European Union and are generally applied to all taxpayers who, based on the rules governing the relations between the State and the regions in tax matters, must undergo it.Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, it's true, we need competition!We need it to minimize unemployment, to have a high level health care, for social justice, to have high social standards;Then of course - and these are criteria for competition from national economy - we also need competition between companies: the highest quality of the products, the same conditions of access to the market for all companies, environmentally friendly products.

The union to 28 cannot be widening without dealing with the question if Europe has some principles, some common values, if it is reduced to an economic area of ​​free trade or if, on the other hand, it has a larger aspiration: wanting to be a supranational union, in ways to be defined, which also wants to trace a new path of civilization and democracy in the world.This is what you wanted and it means when asking for a European Constitution.The modification of the treaties was instead limited to a revision of some internal rules, a necessary and important revision but which does not respond to the fundamental question that precedes it: what is Europe, what are its common principles and, therefore, its objectives and limits?But politics takes revenge and, driven out of the window from a debate of a limited agenda, returns, in reality, from the door, and from the main door with the Austrian case, since in Austria a party goes to the government that seems to be recalled to intolerance, xenophobia, for forms of racism.And it is not a problem of ties with the past;It is a problem of perspectives for the future, and there is nothing more wrong than dividing, on this, between right and left.I belong to a world, that of liberal Catholics, which is not on the left but that to the values ​​of tolerance, to the European common values ​​it is attacked as much as all the others and that has nothing to do with lines that deny these values.The advice has done well to put this theme to Europe and the world and if these values ​​do not refer to a fundamental card of rights, in a European Constitution, we will build a Europe that will have no solid and lasting bases.I know, Commissioner Barnier - (The session is lifted at 00:05) Wallowing the Erika The agenda calls for the oral question (B5-0011/2000) by Mr. Varela Suanzes-Carpegna, on behalf of the Fisheries Commission, to the Commission on the shipwreck of Erika.Mr. President, the Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to greet the consideration that Mr. Fischler had to be today among us.Yesterday, our president had announced to us that he was going to be absent because of his agenda.But I believe that he thought and that he did what he is used to doing: having consideration and respect for this Parliament, as he has always been able to demonstrate, and I thank him.I’m raising the voice today in this hemicycle, on behalf of the European Parliament Fisheries Commission, in order to focus our concerns again on the sinking of the oil tanker Erika.A double political consideration leads our committee - as well as myself, as president of this commission - to raise their voice in this case.First of all to demonstrate to the Commission, the Council and the Member States that this Parliament cannot or want to forget this serious accident.And then to focus today on a concrete aspect of the serious environmental disaster caused by this accident, namely its impact on the fishing and aquiculture sectors of the affected regions.The epilogue of this accident must undoubtedly be the urgent adoption of measures to repair damage and to avoid that such a disaster will not happen again in the future.No more lamentations and reflections.We must all, Mr. President, go straight to the goal and adopt measures.First, safety in maritime transport - especially when it comes to transporting hydrocarbons and dangerous goods - requires effective controls in community waters and its ports.Questions such as the construction of ships, the double hull, its age, the control of classification companies, insurance, the creation of databases including all the necessary information, cooperation and community coordination, reinforcement of inspectors' control, responsibility for cargo cargo and owners must be addressed and in this regard, the Commission is best placed toMaterials.Transport ensured by the pavilions of complacency - which also do so wrong to fishing that we have called for "responsible fishing" must also be subject to specific surveillance and regulations.The entry into community waters of ships with complacency pavilions must be controlled in community waters that do not meet community security standards.We are waiting for the Commission to take concrete measures.With regard to the fishing and aquiculture sector - which are particularly important, developed and prestigious in the affected areas of Brittany and Vendée - the European Commission must promote the damage caused, the evaluation of the latter and the specific measures of any type that it thinks of adopting - political, economic, social, financial measures, etc.To repair the damage caused to fishermen and industries that were seriously affected overnight.How will we be able to recover the confidence of consumers with regard to products from this region?What will be the compensations for the victims?We are faced with a very serious problem that the European Union - economic, commercial, industrial, and fishing power can afford to leave without a solution.Mr. Commissioner, you have to work.We must be pioneers and avant-garde in questions of destruction of the environment, industries and professional activities.

I am against the amendments from n.7 to n.13, which were also decisively rejected by the fishing commission.Their content is largely useless or is already contained in my proposal.In particular, I focused on the need to study the extent of the disease and the interaction existing between breeding and wild salmon, to discover the origin of the disease and to extend research on virus to wild species.These amendments, presented by the green deputies of the Verts/Ale group serve to justify amendment no.18I must emphasize that the current directive prohibits the sale of infected fish and that certainly no proposal aims to modify this rule and allow for sale.The amendments from n.7 to n.13 simply do not take into account the reality represented by the contrasting data of Scotland and Norway.A Draconian arrangement has been applied to Scotland that did not achieve the objectives that had been set up.In Norway, thanks to the greater experience, the mandatory eradication of 100 percent of the fish was abandoned a few years ago and a series of measures have been adopted that have clearly improved the situation.It is in our interest to contain the disease in Scotland and prevent its propagation.Last week in Scotland a report on the contagious anemia of salmon carried out by a joint working group between government and industry was published.This exhaustive study takes into account a wide range of possible risks and suggests how to fight the disease in fields such as transmission from one place to another, the safety measures to reduce the escape of salmon, the treatment of slag and effluents, the methods of detection and diagnosis, the reproduction and rotation, the disinfection of the equipment, etc.Some of these measures will be applied immediately by the local authorities who will take advantage of the tools available to them, while others will be implemented in the conduct codes.All these measures will serve not only to combat the infectious anemia of salmon, but also to reach higher quality standards in aquaculture in general, where necessary.Ladies of colleagues, voting in favor of my proposal as approved by the Commission for Fishing, you will allow the introduction of a wider package of rules in Scotland on the control of the disease based on the reality of the Scottish situation and on the positive experiences of other countries.I congratulate the honorable Hudghton, fully support his relationship and ask the honorable deputies of this parliament to do the same.As the speaker said, fish breeding represents an important employment source for some remote areas of Rural Scotland.Now that these areas are crossing the worst recession of the last hundred years, the aquaculture industry provides an essential push to the rural economy on which many thousands of jobs depend directly and indirectly.Currently, as the speaker said, more than 85,000 tons of salmon are produced in the Scottish farms: it is an industry that fruit more than 800 million euros every year.

In turn, the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, will take initiatives to initiate and enrich this public debate.Cross -border services Mr. President, Dear Commissioner, esteemed colleagues!First of all, I have to apologize that my voice is already a little attacked today, but as an Austrian MP, there has been a lot to explain and talk today.First of all, I would like to thank the Commission very much for the initiative that she took, and for these two guidelines that we discuss here today.It closes two serious gaps in the internal market, which are of great importance for the European economy and 5 million third -state citizens in the European Union, which are here as an employee or as self -employed.The current situation, and that should be called again, is in such a way that there are judgments of the European Court of Justice in the area of ​​employees, in particular the judgment in Rush Portuguesa and van der Elst.They have made it clear that freedom of service must allow third -country citizens to use as an employee for cross -border services and to be able to do so without obtaining work permits.However, the question of visa and residence conditions was not explicitly addressed by the European Court of Justice, and the Member States could not clarify this question as a result.But also with regard to the elimination of the work permit, not all Member States have adhered to the knowledge of the court and today still maintain a large number of inadmissible barriers for cross -border services, barriers that are often impossible to overcome, especially for smaller companies.In the case of the self -employed, the situation is in such a way that the current community legal level does not provide for third -country national citizens to provide cross -border services.In any case, you need a legislative act here. Both guideline designs aim to facilitate the freedom of service from EU companies.It is not about original rights for third -country countries that are reproduced to freedom of movement.All regulations that enter and residence law questions can be seen as accessory to this freedom of service.I and with me the committee for law and internal market of the European Parliament are therefore of the opinion that the legal bases elected by the Commission are the right one and that the counter -opinion represented in the report of the legal service of the Council is inaccurate.I therefore do not see a real legal obstacle that both guidelines are treated quickly in the council.I also think that the changes proposed by the parliament should facilitate the acceptance of the guidelines in the Council to the Commission proposal.Many of our changes go back to concerns that have also been expressed in the council, and we try to reconcile these concerns with the mandate, the law and economic reason that will be applicable to us.Especially with regard to acceptance in the Council, I can only appeal to the Commission to adopt the changes adopted by the parliament as completely as possible, even if they deviate far from the original commission proposals.I am firmly convinced that on this basis we can easily find unity in the council.Now to the most important changes we propose.A major difference is that instead of a system "Service ID plus display of each individual order" we no longer provide a possibility that the prior notice to the reception state can be requested for each individual order.

In the opinion of this speaker, this image contrasts with the backward background and an annual growth rate of just 1.9% during the 199elevated during that decade that, however, could not consolidate.It should be deduced that if we do not want the same failures to be repeated, we must take this opportunity that gives us the greater economic performance to launch a new transition policy towards higher levels of sustainable growth in our economy.That is the challenge.Given this challenge, the commission fundamentally recommended that our economic policy should only prolong our position of the past, which was limited to correcting the monetary and fiscal bases of the economy, while for everything else it was trusting that the markets work the miracle without any other intervention of agents with social conscience.
