I will expose an example.The European Union rightly granted help to the Grönitz Righting of Brandenburg, despite the fact that its 5,000 jobs have now been reduced to only 700. But these are competitive, since this steel is currently the second producer of steel tools of the Federal Republic of Germany.Those who now jeopardize the production of this steeling by demanding the return of these aid, not only threaten the steel, but also an employer of that region, which also also depend, naturally, several small and medium enterprises.Of course, this cannot be the policy of competence of the European Union.If we want competition, we have to combine the political-economic demands with the requirements of the business economy.This is also the only possibility of establishing regional economic circuits in underdeveloped regions, which allow people to offer social security and improve their purchasing power.As part of this approach, we must also take into consideration the economic policy oriented to demand instead of focusing exclusively on the economic policy oriented to supply.Mr. President, since I was chosen to this Parliament in 1994, I had never seen a report with such statements and anti -surrounding connotations such as the Jonckheer report that we are debating today.I would like to quote the following: the greatest state aid per inhabitant corresponds to Italy, Germany and Ireland.If we group the national and social regional and social funds, Ireland clearly occupies the first position.I think the rapporteur is limited to playing with the figures.I find it difficult to understand how regional and social funds can include in that mathematical equation.I would like to remind the honor that the European Union has approved the new guidelines for regional aid for the period that begins in 2000. It was a simple expansion of the objectives of the policy aimed at concluding the internal market in Europe.For the internal market to result and prosper, regional disparities must be reduced.I am appropriate with the fact that as of the year 2000 it will be allowed to grant a help in the form of a 40% subsidy and a 15% supplement for fixed investments of SMEs to companies that are installed in regions of objective 1 in Europe.I have to remind Mr. Jonckheer that Irish or foreign companies based in Ireland continue to have to cross two seas to reach the continental Europe market.No other member state is in such a disadvantage situation.Mr. President, ladies, estimated and estimated colleagues, the prohibition of cartels constitutes the core of an operational competition system in Europe.The Commission considers unsatisfactory the way in which the supervision of said prohibition has been carried out in practice, which can also agree.However, opinions begin to diverge with regard to the solution.The commission's proposal does not formally depart from the prohibition of the cartels, but the result means moving from the prohibition with a reserve of authorization to the authorization with a reservation of prohibition.This is equivalent to moving from the principle of prohibition at the beginning of abuse.

The report itself contains good intentions but, as is common when we deal with these issues, it suffers from clarity of purpose and a solid base for its operation.This is the reason why my group and I are proposing three amendments and additional proposals to the text, not with the intention of eliminating everything from the proposal, but of making it more relevant to those who have to carry it out.I would like to explain here what we think.First, we are concerned about the proper use of structural funds and cohesion funds.The past experience dictates that, as elected representatives of European taxpayers, we must and have to demand probity and financial transparency in the disbursement and audit of this money.Therefore, our amendments and additional proposals are related to achieving what we know as indicators of "value in exchange for money" in the process of granting aid.Secondly, we have seen too often that huge amounts of money are spent on projects whose results are necessarily inaccurate in the initial phase of the program period.But, also too often, at the midpoint or at the end of that period there is no real way to finish the project if its effectiveness has not been demonstrated.Therefore, our additional proposals defend the provision of practical output strategies and that can be enforced so that we can not only have the required insurance against the already acquired costs that are usually loaded to the taxpayer, but also avoid the well -known syndrome to lose more money when trying to recover the already lost.Finally, we defend the introduction of a change in the balance and the method of disbursement of the funds.There must be a greater commitment of the private sector, which must present the financial reality as an element of the funds.Also, the type of financed project requires away from small -scale projects based on income, which are difficult to supervise, towards capital plans where in most cases we can all clearly appreciate the benefits.In this way the so vaunted need for transparency in the use of these funds and the temptation to unnecessarily resort to the local tax base in the areas where these projects will be developed will decrease, and the European Parliament will show that the need for that reform is seriously taken seriously.If the Chamber supports today the introduction of these changes in the report, I believe that they will place us in a subsequent phase, in which the historical objectives that the funds must meet, that is, to help in a financially sustainable way to the most needy areas of the European Union whose standard of living requires an increase, not giving them alms, but a push.I ask the camera to support these changes.Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Lordships, I would also like to congratulate the rapporteur for her report;It is arduous and conscientious work.There is no doubt that the structural policies and the cohesion policy of the European Union constitute the primary tools for the creation of the conditions that make possible the development and progressive elimination of economic and social inequalities between the regions;inequalities that, despite registered advances, remain at very high levels;Intolerately high, as regards unemployment.

We cannot help but wait for the extraordinary conference to also really meet the high expectations it has raised.Indeed, as you have already stressed, we do not need one procedure after another, one formality after another, but rather we need facts, according to which the population of the European Union can measure the utility and surplus value of the European Union's performance.For this reason, you have also ruled, rightly, employment, economic reform, growth and social cohesion and made them the main issue.It is important that all the actors of the governments and the commission pull the same rope in the direction of full employment.Then it will be possible to convince all the actors of the economic policy of the need to maintain a consistent conduct, which until now does not exist.Europe should not regret the success of the US economy or the strength of the dollar without extracting a lesson for itself.Surely the reforms of financial services, services capital and labor markets are useful and necessary.However, these reforms will not give growth the driving force that is necessary to organize at high level a lasting growth that has effects on employment.This we have had to live it many times in the 90s. In conditions of an average productivity increase of 2%, a 3.5% growth rate is necessary to achieve full employment within ten years.This has become very close.For this reason, full employment must be listed above all in the agenda.We must establish a growth objective of at least 3%.The objective of full employment cannot be achieved through economic policy only.Innovation Europe and information society must contribute to this objective.However, for now we are very far from this.We must also consider that we need another form of economic policy and economic praxis.It cannot be, simply, that shareholders or administration councils of corporations decide alone about jobs and economics, about the development of the quotation of actions.When after school the 13 -year -old schoolchildren play on the computer to modify the positions of their parents' actions, this may have more to do with a casino than with responsibility.I believe that the extraordinary summit of Lisbon will sit signs for an economic praxis responsible in the European Union.Mr. President, Mr. Prime Minister, Mr. President of the Commission, the Portuguese Presidency has presented an ambitious project for the extraordinary summit.Congratulations.I also celebrate support, which Portugal is receiving from the Commission, not ultimately through the communication that the community wants to make a society of information for all.To the Summit of Lisbon is also applicable what the Christian -democratic prime minister Jean Claude Juncker said about the summit on employment in Luxembourg in 1997: it should not be a literature summit, and thereby alluded to the numerous non -binding statements of many meetings at the summit.Through the Luxembourg procedure, the heads of government achieved concrete successes.

and in this regard, I would like to thank Professor Monti - that the new legal provisions are awarded a most widespread economic policy character and their social function is guaranteed.Mr. President, competition is the core and the strength of European internal market policy.A free open market can only exist thanks to competition, which is limited by clear, uniform rules of the game.Mr. Karl von Wogau sums up this in his report.But Europe is changing.The economies grow, soon we have 25 to 30 member states.The European Commission is overloaded with work if it continues to pursue current politics.Therefore, competition policy must be modernized.That is out of doubt.Nevertheless, the intended decentralization is worried.How will the Commission, as the guardian of the contracts, ensure that in London, Palermo, Helsinki and soon also in Budapest and Ankara by competitive matters?Legal relief must be avoided, and not the court that falls the mildest judgments may be flooded by competitive things.An indication that the Member States can look back on 40 years of experience is not enough.In the Netherlands, the competition authority is still in its infancy.The country has a very small market, which unfortunately is often defined as the relevant market.Germany faces its extremely experienced cartel office that commands a gigantic market.The confidence of the European Commission that legislation is naturally interpreted in all directions, we describe Catholics as "bold trust", and that is prohibited.

This symbolizes the need for solidarity with the countries of the South, in particular those of Africa, the Caribbean, of the Pacific, which have also questioned us in Seattle in this regard.To fully achieve its objective, the redistribution of the monetary mass released by such a tax must necessarily go in the direction of the poorest countries.In this way we make sense and moralization of commercial rules and solidarity with the southern peoples.Mrs. President, not only must we continually repeat the figure that many previous speakers have already mentioned but also must be mentioned, Mr. Commissioner, that 80% of these gigantic daily currency transactions do not have a duration of deposit of more than eight days.It cannot be that investments and the creation of jobs are less lucrative than the short -term operations of foreign exchange and actions.We cannot allow us to subtract the possibilities of political configuration or that income from a non -economic activity increases more and more quickly.Since Tobin developed his idea, in Germany it has been seen that the proportion of cash assets of 7.6% in all the income of society have almost currently doubled.It cannot be admitted that the poorest countries on Earth are the ones that are most intensely subjected to the speculative struggles of the short -term monetary oscillations.Nor do I think it is something impracticable.Why should it not be possible to reach an agreement between the G7 states, the other EU, China, Singapore and Switzerland states on the introduction of the Tobin Tax?There must be a general economic interest.Why can't it be practicable - because it is identifiable - that transactions for an immediate exchange of currency, all the so -called cash operations, currency operations and term options are subject to this tax?Why can't it be practicable to determine the amount of this tax in such a way that it does not endanger the necessary long -term economic investments but that finally makes those carried out in the short term and for speculative purposes?Undoubtedly, many difficult issues will be raised but the only big problem that I see so far is the political will and this attitude of going on responsibility from one place to another.Mr. President, we are not asking for more bureaucracy, as Mr. Karas has pointed out a few minutes before.We are looking for solutions.Of course, capital markets need transparency that is the idea.The Tobin Tax will bring some clarity to a very dark issue."The more progress is made towards the liberalization of trade, the more rules are needed," as Commissioner Lamy said during the millennium round held in Seattle.He acknowledged that the combined effort of the single market and the single currency that characterizes the process of construction of the European Union is closely linked to a huge number of new standards.Now that financing can be quickly sought through national borders without any difficulty, it will be strictly necessary to use the same approach, and the more if we consider that every day a huge amount of financial resources is used in speculative transactions.

Unfortunately, nothing will change now and will not change anything in the future.They want to drive the devil out with the Beelzebub and apply the same fateful methods and the same economic principles to areas that have so far been withdrawn their responsibility: education, wage policy, direct taxes, labor law, social protection and social assistance.The most extraordinary in all of this is the fact that this policy of social mining is largely operated by left -wing governments of various stripes - pink, red, green - that preach social justice during the election campaigns, but take general social cuts as soon as they are at the top of the state.At this point I would like to reaffirm our conviction that without national and European priority and without the protection of our markets from the brazen global competition, no social policy and no policy of full employment are possible.When it comes to jobs, social security, family or pension policy, we must first think of the Europeans.The globalization of the economy you operate is neither necessary nor fateful.This globalization is violently enforced by the only superpower that has survived the Cold War and by the multinational corporations, which develop into independent business powers that submit to the states, nations and peoples who are unable to defend themselves.They make themselves complicit in this development.They promote this process, they are working on the disintegration of our social protection systems, despite their announcements, they create uncertainty and organize social reduction.For the European social model, this globalization of the economy, especially in the form in which it takes place today, could be fatal without taking into account the social and national peculiarities of the states.Your escape to the front into extreme liberalism certainly does not enable the solution to the social problems, the problems of uncertainty and the employment problems of millions of European Europeans.Mr. President, at the summit in Lisbon we will hear many nice words again.We will be happy to listen to these words, but you will not change anything about the basic problem: that we have an economic and monetary union that is more important to combat inflation than employment.The central bank has announced that the price increase rate must never exceed 2 %.The stability pact states that the deficit in the budget law may be a maximum of 1 % in normal years.On the other hand, there is no demand that unemployment must be lower than 5 % or - even better - lower than 2 or 1 %.It is more important that the cash prize and public expenses are not allowed to increase.It is conceivable that a country wants to combat unemployment with public investments, but that is prohibited.The monetary policy is said to be preserved as a holy cow, which is more important than giving the unemployed a job.It is more important for me that the family budget is okay that Papi receives wages, not the termination.That was the attitude of the Danish government, which was formed in 1993.In 1992 there were 9.2 % unemployed - in Euroland, i.e. in the 11 countries, and also in Denmark.From 1992 to 1998 the unemployment rate in Denmark fell to 5.1 %.In Euroland it rose to 10.9 %.

I will give you an example.In the report of the 1998 Court of Auditors, an error in calculation in exchange rates concerning Italian wine will have cost 8 to 10 million pounds sterling to European taxpayers.It is clear that it is unacceptable.What about the person responsible for the calculation error?We need a system offering bonuses and promotions and these promotions must be based on merit.We admit that most of the commission officials are major workers.But we also note that certain practices are obsolete.We are impatiently awaiting the complete proposal of the Commission on the Reformation and we hope that we will be able to settle the details together, since, contrary to what Mr. they have just said, the commissioner is committed to discussing it with the Parliament by March 1.We must also recognize that those who live in glass houses should not throw stones.The European Parliament has not always been very clear, in its approach, during its history.We must also go a long way before reaching perfection.Our personnel policy is herself obsolete.Some of our work practices should be radically changed.I hope that Parliament will remain in the wake of the commission throughout this reform process.We share the proposals relating to the establishment of the budget on the basis of activities.We admit that this presupposes discipline on the part of commission officials and we also admit that, within the parliament, we are responsible for the discipline when we speak of negative priorities.Finally, I would add that the Commission must revive its relations with citizens.European taxpayers should be reassured.The fate of the Commission and the European Union as a whole is based on the delivery of this reform.This is the key question is the delivery of these proposals.Mr. President, to start I would like to send my compliments to the rapporteur, Mr. Van Hulten, for his first report.I have a particular admiration for his courage, of which he did not depart when he was buried under the amendments.I believe that the Sages' report was useful, especially for Parliament - as Morgan said - and that we did well to ask for this occasion the advice of independent experts on how to manage our administration.We have filed an amendment on this subject.I would like to insist on some of the many points of Mr. Van Hulten's report, not according to their importance but according to an arbitrary choice.I think first of all that the Commission should pay much more attention to the proper conservation of documents.The Archives of the Commission leave to desire.We found it when we had to investigate the Fléchard affair which has still not been clear.Oddly, very important documents had disappeared from the firms, even that of the president and various general directions, but it is something which, obviously, cannot happen.

Finally, I subscribe to the will of the European Commission to formulate an ambitious goal in the field of fighting poverty to drastically reduce this plague within a decade.Mr. Prime Minister, I believe it is essential to set a goal that challenges all Member States to fight against the social exclusion of all citizens from our society, not only of children but also their parents and the elderly.I wish the Presidency of the Council good luck in the realization of its ambitions.Mr. President, Mr. President in office for the Council, Mr. President, the Extraordinary European Council of Lisbon on employment, economic reforms and social cohesion will pursue, as we have seen, an ambitious, very ambitious goal, with the risk of disappointing our fellow citizens, aware of the fact that it is not enough to decree the full occupation and the eradication of poverty in Europe to make a reality.However, this summit has a not indifferent merit: that of defining, after Cardiff and Luxembourg, the political will to ensure a clearer social cohesion, in particular as regards the 57 million people who, on our territory, live in poverty: among them, single mothers, numerous families and children, to which other excluding still excluded will be added tomorrow, that is, those who will not have access to the new areas of knowledge,new social imbalances.It is therefore necessary to develop an economic and social policy clearly oriented towards the future, in order to prevent a gap, in terms of numbers, between "accidents" and "infopovers", that is, a digital fracture, as one of my colleagues has just called it.It is for this reason that, if on the one hand I think that new technologies represent a formidable integration carrier for our growth, on the other they can only be such if taught since childhood, since, by 2010, one place out of two will be provided by sectors directly connected to information technologies.In this regard, I urge to make three decisions at the Lisbon summit: firstly, a training strategy articulated along the entire span of life, with the launch of an order of works for the eradication of infantile poverty, both economic and intellectual poverty;Secondly, the establishment of the European Society, to the fullest of the European research space;Thirdly, the establishment of an open working and coordination method, based on our social and economic policies, with a concerted assessment of our national plans.Mr. President, honorable colleagues, there is an idea in the declaration of the Portuguese presidency that I like very much, and it is that the strength of our European economy is based on the skills, fantasy and creativity - in short, on the knowledge of the people who participate in the economic process in Europe.If we take this idea seriously and we really want to raise it to a political program, then the policy of social inclusion would no longer need other justifications, because social participation would in itself be the most powerful production force of our common economy.If so, Mr. Prime Minister, we have an urgent need for common objectives, solid and measurable goals - in a qualitative and quantitative sense - in terms of increasing employment rates, as proposed in the meantime, for example by the Commission.

I do not believe that there is any difference between us and the Ombudsman.There is the question of the legislative base, on which we have advised well, and I think we step on firm ground in that and I understand the concern of your honor.I want to thank the commission for something that I consider a very positive response.To be sure, I would like to confirm that there really is nothing in by (H-0829/99): Subject: Integration of the dimension of equality between men and women in the EU development aid policy in 1995 The Council of Ministers prepared the guidelines for the integration of the dimension of equality between men and women in the entire policy of the development of the EU.These guidelines require that all personnel working on development issues receive continuous training in terms of equality.However, so far only about 50 people have received such training, which still is not mandatory within the General Directorate in charge of this aid.The integration of the This is the linchpin to ensure efficiency and security.We will create a management and control system in each general directorate.The control system is currently centralized;With the reform, we go to a control system in which the decentralization of administrative controls and an efficient central audit system are connected: We will therefore have a central financial service that defines and advisable the regulations for financial management;A decentralization of the entire chain, namely the programs, obligations, contracts, expenses and the corresponding ex-Ante control systems, will take place at the level of the individual general directors, and there will be an external audit service that will control all of these operations.This means a total change in the working method of the Commission, a completely new organization that also requires an absolutely new culture.We are fully aware of the problems associated with this transition phase, and this transition phase is also the most concerned with our staff: we will therefore take the necessary safety and protective measures.Because with the reform, the Commission wants to develop into an administration that is exemplary for Europe and for the whole world.We also want to be a role model for the advanced use of information technologies.We want to give an example of a completely IT-based administration.The Commission was accused of buried under Bergen of paper;We will therefore be a paperless commission, a commission without paper, so that we can become more efficient internally and contribute to the increased use of the new technologies.This means not only a technical, but a complete organizational change.I will now leave it up to Kinnock to explain this reform in detail, but not without thanking him beforehand for the prudence, the enthusiasm and the energy he used for this work.With him, I would like to thank him to those who participated in the project, as well as the entire Commission staff, who participated in this most comprehensive discussion process, which has ever taken place in the Commission.I would like to emphasize that this is an extraordinarily new method of discussion, which in my opinion also forced us to change a radical change in our way of thinking.The white book ahead of us is also the result of your contribution: You understood that only a profoundly reformed commission can again become the world's highly valued institution that formed the starting point for the history of Europe.With the acceptance of the white book, a chapter of the past - as I hope and wishes - is finally completed.Now we are looking into the future, the challenges before the Union and all the goals of the 2000-2005 program, which we have already explained here in the past few weeks before you.In these objectives of the five -year program, the deeper political reasons for the reform lie.We - the whole Union - need a strong commission, a commission that regains its ability to act as a political actor who is recognizable as such as such.That is why we now set all priorities that we have to concentrate on.Therefore - this is another important chapter - we get rid of such activities, the implementation of which is no longer appropriate for us in accordance with the decentralization and subsidiarity principle.

At the 55th meeting of the Human Rights Commission last year, the United States decided in an already well -advanced phase to contribute a draft decision to China.This draft decision was brought down by a Chinese non -termination application.The European Union voted against this application.The position of the European Union on the attitude that the Human Rights Commission should take to China was confirmed by the Council "General Affairs" on March 21, 1999: No initiative of the European Union in relation to China and no support for a resolution of China, in the coordination of the non -interference application by the European Union.It is not certain whether the cohesion of the European Union could have been maintained, the decision would have been made to vote.The United States will bring a draft decision to China at the 56th meeting of the Human Rights Commission, and are currently putting pressure on the European Union so that it agrees to the draft.This triggered violent reactions on the side of China: Currently, the Chinese authorities in the federal states and the organs of the European Union are taking steps to prevent them from supporting the United States' initiative.This initiative is being discussed in the Union, but an early decision is not to be expected.It is in the interest of the European Union to keep all alternatives in the context of the dialogue between the European Union and China about human rights as long as possible, but in any case open until after the conference on February 25, 2000.In view of the changes that have been compiled in the composition of the Human Rights Commission, the vote on the non -arrangement application will be discontinued.Therefore, it is important that the countries of the European Union agree again this year the point of view they want to take in the event of a possible coordination on the resolution.In this context, it should be pointed out that the European Union regularly opposes the requests of China to automatically exclude the presentation of a resolution at the Geneva Human Rights Commission from the dialogue about human rights.The European Union clearly believes that the dialogue is a very valuable instrument to carry out an exchange of views and to learn about the reasons for the attitude of the other side that it must also produce concrete results on site.If this does not succeed, a resolution of the Human Rights Commission may be necessary, if necessary in the further course of the dialogue.In addition, the European Union repeatedly states that the human rights commission is the appropriate authority to bring up human rights issues and that the initiative - regardless of whether the European Union decides to support it or not - from this point of view.The next dialogue about human rights will take place on February 25 in Lisbon, and this includes seminars on legal questions and the rights of women, in which representatives from science circles and civil society should also take part.The next seminar on human rights will be carried out by the Portuguese presidency in May 2000.At the last dialogue round in October 1999, the Chinese side accepted the technical aid offered by the European Union to support the international pact of the international pact on economic, social and cultural rights and the international pact of the civil and political rights of the United Nations that the Chinese government signed.

etc. The Supergau of the Erika must be the last of this series.First of all, it is important to fully clarify the circumstances of this accident.Why shouldn't one use a parliamentary investigation are primarily recorded.Because according to expert opinion, the oil on Erika would have had to sink to the bottom and could never reach the coasts.The consequences are known.It is also important to time, the responsibility of the damage caused by the damage, the shipowner and the questioner must be determined according to the cause of the cause and the monitoring of the sea in order to prevent any degassing, enforced a serious and reliable control of the tankers, set up a well -equipped household line "natural disasters" for the member countries, introduced a special assistance of the community and the damaged departments as eligibleStructure funds are classified.In the name of the Edd faction, I brought a draft decision on this topic.President!In recent years, there have always been severe tanker disasters worldwide without any noteworthy or effective countermeasures.This time it is particularly bad, not least because it has hit a large European state, an incident that can repeat itself at any time.We urgently need a guideline to restrict these dangers.The 15 obviously are not enough.These guarantee - without entitlement to completeness - at least 3 points: No scrap tank tanker or freighter can ever start a port of the European Union more.All those involved, including the client of the transport, are liable for the consequential damage, and there are sufficient insurance from these involved.This is the only way to have a chance to get their claims for damages.However, it must be clear to us that the long -term goal must be stuck even further.This means that we need a real cost of cost for our entire energy supply system.Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank Ms. Commissioner Palacio for her factual, appropriate and binding answer.Thank you very much.At the same time, your notification dated January 10 and the action plan announced by her today absolutely necessary.The disaster with Erika proves that if, when conclusive traffic and transport regulations are missing at international and European level, nature and the environment are missing.

These are areas in mutual dependence together.Economic stability is a growth factor and can translate into a high occupation.This also guarantees the possibility of increasing well -being.But the opposite is also true: a policy articulated on social protection can contribute to a high employment and to an increase in the growth rate.In other words, social protection is a productive factor.Within the Union there are differences in terms of social protection systems.Many of these have historical explanations.Now, however, we have a series of common challenges that await us.I refer, for example, to a demographic trend in which not only the number of elderly increases, but in which the number of births also falls.The labor market is also changing: women venture into increasing number on the labor market.A further challenge is represented by technological evolution.They are all challenges that we must face in concert.The communication of the Commission advocates a more intense exchange of experiences, the creation of a high -level group and carrying out a benchmarking.In addition, the social protection report in Europe will be published annually and will be examined jointly with the employment relationship.All this is positive, but that's not enough.We propose a procedure similar to the Luxembourg process.Chiari guidelines and indicators and Member States will need to define the methodologies in national action plans.A common model is created, but subsidiarity is maintained.This form of social convergence is a process destined to continue for a long time.This is why Parliament must be involved in the works and this not with the inclusion in the group at a high level, but allowing the representatives of the Parliament to follow the works of this group and to present proposals regarding the conduct of this process.Like the employment cooperation, the Commission's proposal stands on four pillars, i.e.: to make social protection systems more oriented towards employment, make long -term long -term sustainable systems, promote social integration, guarantee high quality health care.All this is important.In our relationship we have highlighted in particular the importance of combating poverty within the Union and identifying as soon as possible indicators that allow progress in this field.For the equality between the two sexes, an ad hoc pillar has not been foreseen: Mainstreaming comes into play here.Therefore, the aspects connected to equality must be present in each of the four pillars.For us this is a firm point.We present a whole series of proposals, for example the transition to personalized social security systems, the recognition of the validity of parental leave for the purposes of social benefits, better conditions for reconciling family life and professional life, minimum old -age pensions that still allow a dignified level of life.These are proposals that are mainly for the benefit of women.Parallel to this European social convergence strategy, a concrete plan for legislative work in the social sphere is needed and proposals for framework agreements in the social dialogue is needed, with a specific calendar.

The aerial and railway routes, those of the ferries and the lines that ensure the external and internal connections of the remote areas are contracting.The contract is assigned to those who commit themselves to providing a specific service at a specific quality level with the lowest subsidies.We can call it a negative contract offer.In this way, a competitive offer of provision of services is guaranteed, based on an assignment system with public, but transparent support.Why never could not be reported in a certain region in a certain region in a certain region, following these criteria?The offer that provides for the lowest subsidy would be awarded the concession for a certain period of time.Why could the small local office of a remote country be in contract following these criteria?It would therefore be up to the local administrative, regional or national democratically responsible administrative body - perhaps under the control of the European Union - establish the criteria and financial resources to be destined for this particular social purpose.Otherwise, postal services could be left to the mercy of all the requests and limitations of the market.Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, is not a coincidence that I am the fifth Scottish deputy to intervene in the debate.This shows how important the question of postal services is for us.Scotland has a wider territory than that of some Member States and has many communities that live in remote areas, accessible only through the road network, sometimes poorly served at the level of public transport and sometimes not served at all.These communities entrust their survival to local services such as the school, the post office and the only shop.In particular, the oldest people rely only on the latter two.Often post office and shop coincide, and the supply of these two services depends on the existence of both.Scotland also has many insular communities: some can be reached by plane, but most of them depend on the connection provided by ferries.It should be considered that the current cost for the address of a letter from Edinburgh to the central Highlands is about ten times higher than that of the delivery of the same letter from one part to the other in London and is four times higher than the postal costs currently charged.This difference grows hand in hand with the distance of the remote area.Here is the problem.Ask that liberalization takes place in order to take into account these factors, allowing the maintenance of the postal service at a universal level and at affordable prices it does not mean opposing.It is for our communities of the remote and insular areas that we ask you to maintain the anchor of salvation represented by postal services.Mr. President, it is a privilege for me to replace Commissioner Bolkestein on the occasion of this in -depth debate on postal services, and I will try to respond based on the information provided by the colleague.I would like to remember that on Monday the Commissioner will be present at the meeting of the Commission for Regional Policy, Transport and Tourism.Some deputies, such as Mr Stenmarck, complain of delays in the presentation of the new proposal.

The time of resolutions has already passed.Now what is needed are actions.Unfortunately, the Council will return - I fear - to stop acting and in the future we will discuss again on another maritime and ecological disaster.Mr. President, provided there is such a disaster, it is said that it should not happen again.Actually, we can never put an end to accidents that happen in the sea, but we are concerned with learning the teachings that emerge whenever such an accident occurs and apply them to reduce risks in the future.The "Erika" accident was serious, particularly for the most directly affected Brittany population, but was devastating for the fauna and flora of much of Europe.There are those who say that it is the worst accident that has ever happened to the life of the birds of this part of Europe.The real society for the protection of birds believes that nothing less than 400,000 birds, perhaps mainly, may have died.The photographs that many of us have seen of birds soaked with oil and that official veterinarians were sacrificing were a painful and tragic time.We all want the strictest rules for ships to be, whatever the pavilion that rises.We must impose compliance with the regulations and ensure that the principle is applied that "the one who pollutes pays" so that sanctions and financial incentives are used in order to press the owners of the ships and the oil companies and ensure that the best procedures are introduced.I agree with all the words that the curator has pronounced in her observations, but the question is: how long will it take to get the measures to be addressed to address that problem as she proposes?As a politician, he must remind his officials how difficult it would be to return to this Parliament within a year, if there was a similar, equally devastating accident, in case some of the measures he has proposed today continued, simply, being beautiful words and would not have had the opportunity to put them into practice.The idea that such an accident occurs in the near future must make your head and those of its officials concentrate intensely.Mr. President, Mrs. Commissioner, I have brought a small gift: a heavy oil cake that has sent me an inhabitant of the island of Noirmoutier, who writes to me the following: "With each tide, the beach is covered with heavy oil that escapes the Erika. With each tide, volunteers, military, firefighters remove immense cakes of this black tarThis devastating accident? "Yes, this accident of Erika, like that of the Russian ship in Türkiye, is unacceptable and intolerable precisely when high technology is in all its peak.It is all the more unacceptable that it occurs twenty years after the catastrophe of Amoco Cadiz, although it had already been said and repeated several times "Never again something like that!"

We need solid objectives, established by mutual agreement, regarding the reduction of the unemployment rate to 4% in 2010, as proposed in the meantime, for example, also by the Commission.It is necessary to put an end to the logic of the Ecofin ministers who at home collect laurels for the successes achieved on the consolidation front, while the responsibilities for the huge unemployment in Europe remain wrapped in the fog.I wish you a lot of energy, the support of Parliament and I hope that there is a commitment so that this parliament, in the future, has more votes on the issues of economic policy and employment, as European citizens hope.He would thus find a further ally for his policy.Mr. President, Mr. President in office for the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, is rewarding and promising to hear in this classroom, as happened today, of this new strategic objective for the next decade which consists in transforming the European Union, in the most dynamic and more competitive economic and social space, worldwide, founding it on new technologies, innovation and knowledge, in order to be able to increase the levels of economic growth, obtaining an increase.improvement of jobs and greater social cohesion.It is clear that we must redefine the role of Europe in the world economy, creating competitive Europe, opening the way to the creation of new and better jobs, and organizing this evolution with a precise strategy of social cohesion.The central role of employment and social policy, at the dawn of this new society, is based on two factors.On the one hand, economic efficiency, since in this new technological context the quality of human resources is fundamental.From the other, social equality, because, despite the economic relaunch we are As you know, these objectives aim to reduce poverty by half by 2015, either thanks to the increase in the age of compulsory education, or thanks to the significant reduction in infantile mortality, or retreat the extreme poverty of living conditions of around a billion people, which is extraordinary but certainly requires strong participation and a strong intervention of the entire international community.This is the fourth aspect of the new development paradigm that I would like to accentuate: development policies are envisaged today, in particular in recent years, in the form of an increasingly global question which suffers from a lack of strong international leadership.The concerted actions of the United Nations system institutions contributed significantly, as well as the "Bretton Woods" system.In particular, the strong pulses given in this debate should be recorded in particular by the World Bank, in particular through its comprehensive framework document, and by the International Monetary Fund.For the first time an institution of this nature places the problem of the decline in poverty at the center of its orientations and establishes a so far unimaginable connection on the part of such an institution between the alleviation of debt and poverty.It is also in the light of this new role that international organizations fulfill in relation to the development problems that we must reflect on the role of the European Union in this context.The Portuguese presidency insists on the need for the European Union to make its important role more compatible on an international scale, as the main donor, with a director and more active role in this movement to renovate development policies, internationally, by increasing its capacity for articulation and coordination, in particular with the United Nations system and the Bretton Woods system.So that it is possible to strengthen the role of the European Union in the context of international development policies, we believe that it is necessary to fundamentally develop three types of actions.First, improve the efficiency of the development policy.As everyone knows, an overall evaluation exercise of development policies took place in 1995. It was possible to present the conclusions under the German presidency.The main conclusions emphasize the need for a more coherent policy of the European Union and a general strategic vision of the European Union in relation to development problems.They accentuate the aspects relating to the need for greater coordination and greater complementarity between organizational harmonization and simplification policies, an executive in which the Union cooperation policy runs, and the need to make the management of aid more effective, in particular by reviewing its intervention mechanisms, as well as the need to strengthen the evaluation system and to ensure more transparency in the way of applying this aid.The second aspect that must be underlined concerns the need for greater complementarity between the Union and the policies of the Member States.

briefly mention the question of coccidiostatic.It is a technical antibiotic, which is not absolutely necessary.There are replacement methods.It is possible to vaccinate the chickens.It certainly costs a little more, but is without consequences for the environment.Today, we spread the slurry containing coccidiostatic on the fields, which goes into water, that is to say in the most important component of our diet.Mr. President, the Commissioner, my dear colleagues, the report on additives in animal feed relates to a technical-economic problem to restore competitive balance between different additives in animal food and between producers of these additives.But today, after the serious crisis of dioxin which struck Belgium and other European countries last summer, we cannot be content to reflect on a simple question of competition.Indeed, in its time, even if it has gone more unnoticed by the general public, the scientific experts of the commission had discovered in citrus pulp imported from the Brazil of industrial residues of lime laden with dioxin.

Inaugurating an unfinished building in the middle of an election campaign, which could not be occupied eight months after the inauguration, has greatly ridicked the Spanish government.That the Spanish government has ridiculed me does not worry me because, in the end, it is responsible for it but that the commission was ridiculed by giving its approval, by its presence, to this inconvenient conduct, that worries me.This is why I ask you, Mr. Commissioner: does it seem normal that an unfinished building was inaugurated in the middle of the electoral campaign?Does it seem normal that the commission has given its approval, by its presence, to this inconvenient conduct of the Spanish government?It is not for me to comment on the internal political situation of one or the other Member State.I would therefore like to abstain from any comments on the situation that Mr. Berenguer has just mentioned.I must admit that the reason why an inauguration ceremony is set up in Spain escapes me.I can tell you that I hope that now, this building will come into office as quickly as possible.Let me add that I hope to be present in Alicante myself at the end of May in order to speak during a conference.I hope this building will then have come into office.I would like to tell the commissioner that it is not an electoral question.As members of the Legal Commission and the internal market, we followed the subject of the creation of this institution and, obviously, it is clear that this building was inaugurated for electoral reasons.Today - a year later - it is still unoccupied, which means that the commission spends money for a false inauguration.It should be asked to what extent this expenditure of funds for a false inauguration was justified.Again, the Commission does not deal with the considerations underlying the actions of the Member States.The commission takes care of what is officially declared and what is done.We do not intend to engage in what is called a trial of intention.We therefore take care of public and official acts and affairs and not any underlying reasons.This is why it seems difficult to me to satisfy Mr. Medina on this point and to answer his question.Again, the Commission does not wonder why something takes place more or less late, apart from the fact that the Commission attaches a price to the fact that a building such as that planned for this office is inaugurated and used as quickly as possible.In addition, the Commission does not take care either because of whether determined expenses are real or virtual.Regarding, all expenses are real.For the rest, it is the future that will tell us.Question nº 54 of (H-0117/00): Subject: monopoly of alcohol and internal market What measures does the commission intend to prevent Sweden from maintaining, as it obviously has the intention, its monopoly of state of alcohol and therefore, restrictions on the corresponding imports, so as to thus make the rules of the internal market prevail?

The fishermen's ices in Europe are faced with serious problems, and the well -being of the industry is really important to me.I therefore call on the Commission and the Council to collect the necessary information and to raise the political will for truly long -term solutions for the communities dependent on fishing and not to strive for short -term solutions.I recommend the report to the high house.The environmental committee is generally satisfied with the communication of the Commission, and we are pleased that the fishing committee has taken over our changes.In the meantime, it is widely recognized that the fishing has an impact on the sea environment, which go far beyond the mere fishing of the target type plus a little by catch and can be felt everywhere.We welcome the Commission's intention to include environmental protection in other policy areas - also in the common fishing policy - to the EU.After all, the contracts have been in the contracts since 1992 that the principle of prevention and environmental protection should be integrated into the community policies.However, as has already been determined, the adoption of a strict definition of the principle of prevention is of crucial importance, because mere lip service is all too easy and then continued "business as usual".In this context, a good example would be the UN Convention on Fish stocks from 1995. However, one aspect is missing in the message, namely monitoring and control.All reasonable measures and regulations will not lead to inventory if there is no effective system that ensures compliance with the rules.The Member States is responsible for control.A list of serious violations has recently been accepted by the Council, with which attempts are made to coordinate the punishment of similar offenses in the different countries to a certain extent.This is an important step forward, but commission and committee for fishing constantly point out that a lot of improvements are still necessary in the control programs of all Member States.I would like to congratulate the rapporteur for his excellent report.President!Fishing is an economic activity of the first rank, behind which there are very high investments and offers the entire regions of the community their basic employment under really hard conditions.But the idea that some people have from fishing is usually extremely simple and can range from pure folklore to the insult to see the fisherman as a insensitive pirate and looter.Unfortunately, I have to say that this report was apparently an opportunity for people with this kind of ideas for its connection with the environment to bring in their special nonsense.If Mr. Katiforis' report had been accepted in its original version, no member of the fishing committee could ever have put his foot in a fishing region again without having a certain risk.The relationship between fishing and sea ecosystems is obvious.But this relationship is much more comprehensive and includes many factors, such as pollution and maritime traffic.Only accusing the fisherman because of the environmental destruction is as unjust as it is wrong.Our committee prevented his own shame through a number of amendments, of which I myself brought 14, which were largely accepted by the rapporteur, for which I sincerely thank him.

However, if some of the amendments were approved, and in particular those presented by the PPE group, we believe that the report would be distorted and transformed into a contradictory document, without rigor;In this case, therefore, we will have to reconsider our support.Mr. President, honorable colleagues, among the various themes that appear on the agenda of this joint discussion I would like to insert a reflection on the theme dealt with by our colleague Berenguer, that is, the modernization of the competition policy to which the Commission's white paper alludes.I frankly believe that this modernization process has been satisfactory.Commissioner Monti is scoring good results in his own policy, like his predecessor, with the evident merit of having been able to guarantee, in parallel with the creation and development of the European internal market, the correctives necessary for a regular functioning of the market economy in the Union without those side effects that, like us economists we know, risk producing when a market expands, as happened in the European Union starting from 1993.Everything works, if we are satisfied, if the commission line has been substantially correct, then why a change?In his support, various reasons have been adduced.Mr Berenguer has traced a very careful analysis, justifying the need for the modification and related reforms with the need to improve the functioning of the competition;However, what is most hearty is to ensure that standards and criteria applicable by the various competent authorities in the Member States are actually identical everywhere.Otherwise, we would find ourselves in a paradoxical situation: it would in fact be the commission to introduce elements of unfair competition in the functioning of the European internal market.In this case, instead of progress, we would have recorded a regression in the application of competition policy within the Union.Mr. President, I would like to express my gratitude to the Commission for the improvement marked by the XXVIII Commission of the Commission on Competition Policy in the Union with respect to previous editions.I also want to highlight the work done by the speaker, honorable Radkay, who has been able to analyze in concise terms a text as vast and dense as this.And he fully supports him when he affirms the need to leave the regions - like the Basque Country, which I represent here - a margin of action by virtue of the principle of subsidiarity.However, I cannot forget the criticisms formulated, on several occasions, both by the Member States, and by the market operators who, in the face of the large margin of maneuver and discretion recognized to the Commission in relation to the evaluation of each individual case, complain about the existence of a legal uncertainty, in the absence of rules of the clear game that allow the interested parties to provide for the position of the authorities and, therefore, to regulate themselves in the presentation of theThe obtaining of subsidies in support of economic activities and employment, in the mergers between companies etc.The only guarantee has so far been represented by the attempt to seek a favorable position for the authorization already in advance, presenting individual questions that however are not evaded in less than six to eight months, an excessively long term that is added to the obstacles that already weigh on the activities generating wealth and employment.

We tend to believe that this economic growth of the Union has a solid basis, now and for the coming years, and that we must not lose sight of the fact that we are in an open, global and very competitive economy.If we want to match the leadership of the United States, or even take over, we must avoid interventionism initially proposed by Mr. Katiforis, to avoid any excessive intervention on the part of the public authorities in the construction of certain infrastructures.In addition, the Member States refused to grant more resources during discussions on the 2000 agenda, so that in the European Union level, we will have only few means in the coming years.On the other hand, we insist on the need to continue to deepen the construction of the European domestic market, which still has serious shortcomings.In certain sectors, such as those of air transport, energy or telecommunications, the costs borne by our companies are still very high if we compare unit costs to those of the United States or other countries also competitive at the international level.The report contains information specifying that the bureaucratic cost for the creation of a new company is 500 euros in the United States when it is on average 1,600 euros in the European Union.There is therefore always an excessive bureaucracy and an excessive intervention.We believe that it is by respecting the rigor agreements which are established with the programs which follow the stability pact and by deepening the creation of a market with fewer obstacles at all levels that we will reach the levels of competitiveness necessary for the European Union.Mr. President, dear colleagues, the passion that my predecessors recognized to Mr. Katiforis had, in my ears, no other objective than to call the European Parliament to meet the hope of tens of millions of unemployed, excluded and precarious in our European Union.It is this objective to which he called the European Parliament: to give hope to the peoples of Europe.There is economic recovery, of course, but it only marginally retreats unemployment in Europe.The voices of the PPE-DE and Liberals very strongly led to, even inverted, the meaning of his message.This is the reason why we have not voted the report as it was amended by them, despite our efforts, and we will not vote it in the current state.What are the minimum conditions we would vote for this report.First, the assertion that there is room for a Europe of growth, but a Europe of sustainable growth, respectful in particular of the commitments of the European Union to the conferences of Kyoto and Buenos Aires.There are enormous tasks to be performed to keep our commitments by the 2008 fateful year where we should have returned to greenhouse gas clearances at the 1990 level. Huge works are to be carried out in the field of transport, the energy saving, and even to substitute travel by internet communications.
